وما ثم شي‏ء مطلق أصلا لأنه لا يقتضيه الإمكان ولا تعطيه أيضا الحقائق فإن الإطلاق تقييد فما من أمر إلا وله موطن يقبله وموطن يدفعه ولا يقبله لا بد من ذلك كالأغذية الطبيعية للجسم الطبيعي ما من شي‏ء يتغذى به إلا وفيه مضرة ومنفعة يعرف ذلك العالم بالطبيعة من حيث ما هي مدبرة للبدن وهو المسمى طبيبا ويعرفه الطبيعي مجملا والتفصيل للطبيب فما في العالم لسان حمد مطلق ولا لسان ذم مطلق والأصل الأسماء الإلهية المتقابلة فإن الله سمي لنا نفسه بها من كونه متكلما كما نزه وشبه ووحد وشرك ونطق عباده بالصفتين ثم قال سُبْحانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ وسَلامٌ عَلَى الْمُرْسَلِينَ والْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ رَبِّ الْعالَمِينَ هذا آخر الجزء الحادي والستين‏

## (Chapter Seventy-One: Concerning the Secrets of Fasting)

O laughing one in the form of the weeping one,
You are the complained-of and the complainant through us.

Fasting (الصوم) is abstinence (إمساك) without elevation (رفعة),
And elevation without abstinence.

And they may be together with one
Who affirms Unity (توحيد) through association (إشراك).

Minds were captured from their dispositions
Without snares or traps.

Minds were captured from their dispositions
By a decisive sword of the Law (الشرع), so they submitted, though their proof did not refute it.

And they believed without comprehension (إدراك). The star of guidance (نجم الهدى) swam with them,

Between angels (أملاك) in celestial spheres (أفلاك). Were it not for you, O my soul (نفسي), I would not have been Him,

As if He, were it not for you, were not. Fast from the cosmos (الكون) and do not break your fast,

With this, the God of creation (إله الخلق) has entrusted you. And intend that fast from the perspective of what it is,

For it is naturally your nourishment. In fasting there is a meaning, if you contemplate it,

No creature would settle in your abode. "There is no like for fasting," thus said to me

Its Legislator, so reflect upon that. Because it is abandonment (ترك), so where is that which

You have done, or where is your claim? The matter has returned to its origin,

With this, my Lord has taken charge of you. And fasting, if you reflect upon its ruling,

And the root of its meaning is in your meaning. Then a messenger came from Him

Concerning your prescribed fast that has afflicted you. So fasting is for Allah, do not be ignorant,

And you are His manifestation (مجلاه), so beware! Fasting is for Allah, and you are the one who

Dies of hunger, so know that. The Merciful (الرحمن) feminized you for the sake of the one who

Appears from you when He fashioned you. Glory be to Him who fashioned you worthy of Him,

And none attained that except you. So you are like the earth, a couch for Him,

And His eye described as weeping. And the craftsmanship of Allah sees its essence

Between the two of you, so where is your manifestation? When you called upon Allah out of humility,

He, Exalted, answered you through you.

And the Most Exalted Pen (القلم الأرفع) on its Tablet
Inscribed your pure description concerning Him.

So you are the essence (عين) of the All, not His essence,
He brought you near from one aspect and kept you far from another.

Beware lest you be pleased with what you are pleased with,
For the sake of that which pleases you, beware!

Be upon your origin (أصلك) in all that
He desires; do not forget, lest He forget you.

This is the Knowledge (العلم) that came to me
From a speaker who is not a liar,

Who sent it down by the command of a Knower,
Among ascetics (زهاد) and devotees (نساك).

And praise be to Allah who distinguished me
With the knowledge of lights and adornments,

And distinguished me with a form whose
Perfection was only achieved by your sheltering.

### [Fasting is Abstinence and Elevation]

Know, may Allah support you, that fasting (الصوم) is abstinence (الإمساك) and elevation (الرفعة). It is said, "The day fasted (صام النهار)" when it rose high (إذا ارتفع). Imru’ al-Qays said:

> When the day fasted and was hot

Meaning, it rose high. Because fasting was elevated (ارتفع) above all other acts of worship (العبادات) in degree, it was named *sawm* (fasting/elevation). The Exalted One elevated it by negating likeness (المثلية) from it among the acts of worship, as we shall mention. He stripped it from His servants, despite their devotion to it, and attributed it to Himself, the Exalted. He made the reward for the one characterized by it to be in His own hand, out of His special care (أنايته), and joined it to Himself in the negation of likeness.

### [Fasting is in Reality Abandonment, Not Action]

In reality, it is abandonment (ترك) and not action (عمل). The negation of likeness (نفي المثلية) is a negative attribute (نعت سلبي), thus strengthening the suitability (المناسبة) between it and Allah. The Exalted said concerning His own Essence (حق نفسه): <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Thus, He negated that He should have a like. Therefore, the Exalted has no like, by rational (العقلية) and legal (الشرعية) demonstration. Al-Nasa’i reported from Abu Umamah, who said: I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and said, "Command me with a matter that I may take from you." He said, "Hold fast to fasting, for there is no like (لا مثل له) for it."

Thus, he negated that any act of worship legislated for His servants could be like it.

### [Fasting is in Reality Neither Worship Nor Action]

Whoever knows that it is a negative description (وصف سلبي)—since it is the abandonment (ترك) of things that break the fast (المفطرات)—knows with certainty that it has no like, for it has no entity (عين) characterized by perceptible existence (الوجود الذي يعقل). For this reason, Allah the Exalted said: *The fast is for Me* (الصوم لي).

Therefore, in reality, it is neither worship (عبادة) nor action (عمل). The application of the name 'action' (العمل) to it is metaphorical (تجوز), just as the application of the word 'Existent' (الموجود) to the intelligible Reality (الحق المعقول) is metaphorical in our view. This is because the existence (وجود) of the One whose Essence (ذاته) is His existence does not resemble the attribution of existence to us, for <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him).

(Quoting a Divine Prophetic Hadith)

Muslim reported in his *Sahih* from Abu Hurayrah, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: Allah Almighty said: "Every action of the son of Adam is for him, except fasting (الصيام), for it is Mine, and I shall reward for it. Fasting is a shield (جنة). When the day of fasting comes for one of you, let him not utter obscenities (يرفث) or raise his voice (يسخب). If someone insults him or fights him, let him say: 'I am a fasting person, I am fasting.' By the One in whose hand is the soul of Muhammad, the breath of the fasting person (خلوف فم الصائم) is sweeter to Allah on the Day of Resurrection than the scent of musk. The fasting person has two joys that he experiences: when he breaks his fast, he rejoices in his breaking of the fast, and when he meets his Lord Almighty, he rejoices in his fast."

### [The Joy of the Faster is His Attainment of the Degree of Negating Likeness]

Know that since likeness (المثلية) was negated from fasting, as established in the preceding hadith of Al-Nasa’i, and since the Real (الحق) is <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), the fasting person meets his Lord Almighty characterized by the description "There is nothing like unto Him." He sees Him by means of this description, and thus he is the Seer and the Seen. For this reason, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "He rejoices in his fast," and did not say, "He rejoices in meeting his Lord." Joy does not rejoice in itself, but rejoices in that which causes it. When the Real is the sight (بصره) of the Gnostic (العارف) during his vision (رؤيته) and witnessing (مشاهدته), he only sees himself through the Real's vision.

The joy of the fasting person is his attainment of the degree of the negation of likeness (نفي المماثلة). His joy in breaking the fast (الفطر) in this world stems from fulfilling the right of the animal soul (النفس الحيوانية), which demands nourishment for its essence. When the Gnostic sees the neediness of his animal-vegetative soul (نفسه الحيوانية النباتية) toward Him, and sees His generosity in delivering the nourishment to it—as a fulfillment of the soul's right which Allah obligated upon him—he stands in this station (مقام) with the attribute of the Real (حق). He gives with the hand of Allah, just as he sees the Real when he meets Him with the eye of Allah. For this reason, he rejoices in his breaking of the fast just as he rejoices in his fast upon meeting his Lord.

(Explanation of What This Report Contains)

Since the servant is described as possessing fasting and earned the name 'the fasting person' (الصائم) by this attribute, the Real (الحق) then negated the fast from him after affirming it for him, and attributed it to Himself, saying: "Except fasting, for it is Mine." Meaning, the attribute of Self-Sufficiency (صفة الصمدانية)—which is transcendence (التنزيه) from nourishment—belongs only to Me. Even if I describe you with it, I only describe you based on a restricted qualification (تقييد) of transcendence, not the absolute transcendence (إطلاق التنزيه) befitting My Majesty (جلالى). Then I said, "And I shall reward for it." Thus, the Real was the reward (جزاء) for the fasting person's fast when he returned to his Lord and met Him with the attribute that has no like, which is fasting. This is because one who is <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) is only seen by one who is <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>. This was explicitly stated by Abu Talib al-Makki, one of the masters of the People of Spiritual Taste (أهل الذوق): *Whoever is found in his saddlebag, he is his recompense* (مَنْ وُجِدَ فِي رَحْلِهِ فَهُوَ جَزَاؤُهُ). This is what this verse necessitates in this state.

### [The Difference Between Negating Likeness for Allah and for Fasting]

His saying, "And fasting is a shield (جنة)," means protection (الوقاية), similar to His saying, <<وَاتَّقُوا اللهَ>> (And fear Allah), meaning, take Him as a protection and also be a protection for Him. Thus, He established fasting in His place regarding protection, and He is <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>. Fasting is an act of worship that has no like (لا مثل له). However, it is not said concerning fasting, "There is nothing like unto it" (ليس كمثله شي‏ء), because a 'thing' (شيء) is an affirmative or existent matter (أمر ثبوتي أو وجودي), whereas fasting is abandonment (ترك), which is an intelligible non-existent (معقول عدمي) and a negative attribute (وصف سلبي). Therefore, it has no like (لا مثل له), but it is not that <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>. This is the difference between the attribute of the Real (الحق) in negating likeness and the description of fasting with it.

### [The Prohibition for the Faster Against Obscenity, Loudness, and Fighting]

Furthermore, the Lawgiver (الشارع) prohibited the fasting person, and prohibition (النهي) is abandonment (ترك) and a negative attribute (نعت سلبي). He said, "Let him not utter obscenities (يرفث) or raise his voice (يسخب)." He did not command him with an action, but rather prohibited him from being characterized by any action. Fasting is abandonment, so the suitability (المناسبة) between fasting and what the fasting person is prohibited from is sound. Then he was commanded to say to anyone who insults him or fights him, "I am fasting," meaning, "I am abandoning (تارك) this action that you, O fighter and insulter, have committed against me." Thus, he transcends himself from an action that his Lord commanded him to avoid. He is informing that he is abandoning, meaning he does not possess the attribute of insulting or fighting the one who insults or fights him.

### [The Breath of the Faster to Allah]

Then he said, "By the One in whose hand is the soul of Muhammad"—the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) swears—"the breath of the fasting person (خلوف فم الصائم)," which is the change in the smell of the faster's mouth that only occurs with breathing. He breathed this good word that he was commanded with, which is his saying, "I am fasting." This word, and every breath of the fasting person, is sweeter on the Day of Resurrection, <<يَوْمَ يَقُومُ النَّاسُ لِرَبِّ الْعالَمِينَ>> (The Day when mankind will stand before the Lord of the Worlds), *to Allah*. He used the comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع) characterized by all the Names. He used a Name that has no like, since no one is named by this Name except Allah, the Exalted. This is suitable for the fact that fasting has no like. And his saying, "than the scent of musk (ريح المسك)," for the scent of musk is an existent matter (أمر وجودي) perceived by the sense of smell and enjoyed by the sound, moderate temperament (السليم المزاج المعتدل). He made the breath (الخلوف) sweeter to Allah than it, because the attribution of the perception of scents to Allah does not resemble the perception of scents by the nose. This breath is foul to us, but to Him, Exalted is He, this breath is above the pleasantness of musk in scent, for it is a spirit (روح) described by that which has no like, so the scent does not resemble it. The scent of the fasting person comes from breathing, while the scent of musk does not come from breathing *from* the musk itself.

### [Ibn Arabi with Musa ibn Muhammad al-Qabbab in the Sanctuary of Mecca]

We have an incident similar to this. I was with Musa ibn Muhammad al-Qabbab at the minaret in the Sanctuary of Mecca, at the Gate of Al-Hazurah, and he used to call the *adhan* there. He had food whose smell bothered everyone who smelled it. I had heard in the Prophetic report that the angels (الملائكة) are bothered by what bothers the children of Adam, and that it is forbidden to approach the mosques with the smell of garlic, onions, or leeks. I spent the night intending to tell that man to remove that food from the mosque for the sake of the angels. Then I saw the Real (الحق) Exalted in a dream, and He said to me, "Do not speak to him about the food, for its scent with Us is not like its scent with you." When morning came, he came to us as was his custom, and I informed him of what had happened. He wept and prostrated to Allah in gratitude. Then he said to me, "O my master, despite this, adherence to the Law (الأدب مع الشرع) is more appropriate." So he removed it from the mosque, may Allah have mercy on him.

### [Foul Scents Repel Sound Temperaments]

Since foul and repulsive scents (الروائح الكريهة الخبيثة) repel sound natural temperaments (الأمزجة الطبيعية السليمة), whether human or angelic, due to the annoyance they feel from the lack of suitability (عدم المناسبة), the aspect of the Real (وجه الحق) in foul scents is not perceived except by Allah specifically, and by whomever possesses the temperament of acceptance (مزاج القبول) for it, whether animal or human, who has the temperament of that animal—but not an angel. For this reason, He said, "to Allah" (عند الله). The fasting person, being a human with a sound temperament, also dislikes the breath of fasting from himself and others. Has any creature with a sound temperament realized his Lord (تحقق بربه) at any time or in any witnessing (مشهد) such that he perceives foul scents as absolutely pleasant? We have not heard of this. My saying "absolutely" (على الإطلاق) is because some temperaments are bothered by the scent of musk and roses, especially the hot temperament (المحرور المزاج). What bothers a person is not pleasant to the owner of that temperament. Therefore, we said "absolutely," since the majority of temperaments find musk, roses, and the like pleasant. A temperament bothered by these pleasant scents is a strange temperament (مزاج غريب), meaning unusual. I do not know whether Allah has granted anyone the perception of the equality of scents such that no scent is foul to him. This is not something we have tasted ourselves, nor has it been transmitted to us that anyone perceived this. Rather, what is transmitted from the perfect ones (الكمل) among humans and from the angels is annoyance by these foul scents. Only the Real (الحق) is unique in perceiving that as pleasant. This is what is transmitted. I also do not know the state of animals other than humans in this regard, because the Real has not established me in the form of an animal other than a human, as He has established me at times in the forms of His angels. And Allah knows best.

### [The Gate of Al-Rayyan in Paradise, Through Which the Fasters Enter]

Furthermore, the Law (الشرع) described fasting, through its meaning, with a perfection (الكمال) above which there is no perfection, when the Real (الحق) singled out a special gate for it and named it with a special name that seeks perfection: it is called the Gate of Al-Rayyan. Through it the fasting people (الصائمون) enter. *Al-Rayy* (quenching thirst) is the degree of perfection in drinking, for after being quenched, the drinker accepts no further drink whatsoever. If he accepts any, he was not truly quenched, whether it be earth or other than earth from the lands of animals. Muslim reported from the hadith of Sahl ibn Sa’d that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Indeed, there is a gate in Paradise called Al-Rayyan. The fasting people will enter through it on the Day of Resurrection. No one else will enter with them. It will be said, 'Where are the fasting people?' So they will enter through it. When the last of them has entered, it will be closed, and no one else will enter through it."

This was not said concerning any prohibited or commanded act of worship except fasting. Thus, by Al-Rayyan, He made clear that they attained an attribute of perfection (صفة كمال) in action, since they were characterized by that which has no like (لا مثل له), as previously established. That which has no like is the truly Perfect (الكامل على الحقيقة). The fasting people among the Gnostics (العارفين) entered it here, and there they will enter through it, known to all creation (الخلائق أجمعين).

### [General Discussions and Issues of Fasting]

We shall mention, God willing, in this chapter the rulings (أحكام) of the prescribed fast (الصوم المشروع), its subsidiaries, its adjuncts, its types, and what is obligatory (واجبة) and recommended (مندوبة), just as we mentioned concerning its counterparts—Zakat and Prayer—in general and specific terms, according to their respective levels (طبقاتهم). Fasting has levels (مراتب) according to us. The first is the common, known fast (الصوم العام) with which Allah has commanded us, which is the apparent fast (الصوم الظاهر) in the visible world (الشاهد), fulfilling all its conditions. When we finish discussing the rulings of the issue we present concerning this, we will move on to speak in the language of the elite (الخواص) and their elect concerning the fast of the soul (صوم النفس) as it commands the limbs. This is its abstinence (إمساكها) from what is forbidden to it, issue by issue, and its elevation (ارتفاعها) above that. [We will also speak] concerning the fast of the heart (صوم القلب), which is described by its capacity for the Divine Descent (النزول الإلهي), where the Exalted said: *The heart of My servant contained Me* (وسعني قلب عبدي). We will discuss its fast, which is its abstinence from allowing anyone other than its Creator to inhabit this capacity. If anyone other than its Creator inhabits it, then it has broken its fast (أفطر) during the time when it ought to be fasting, out of preference (إيثارا) for its Lord, issue by issue. [We will also discuss] the totality of fast-breakers (المفطرات) for each type of fast, briefly and concisely, for this is a lengthy chapter. I shall include in this chapter Prophetic reports that you will encounter, God willing.

(Section on the Division of Fasting)

### [Types of Obligatory Fasting]

Know that the prescribed fast (الصوم المشروع) is partly obligatory (واجب) and partly recommended (مندوب إليه). The obligatory fast is of three types: 1. That which is obligatory by Allah’s initial imposition (إيجاب الله تعالى إياه ابتداء), which is the fast of the month of Ramadan—in which the Quran was revealed—or a number of other days (عدة من أيام أخر) for the traveler who broke his fast (or whether he broke it or not, according to us, and according to others, only if he broke it), and for the sick person. 2. That which is obligatory due to a necessitating cause (لسبب موجب), which is the fast of expiations (صيام الكفارات). 3. That which becomes obligatory from Allah due to the person obligating it upon himself, which is not disliked, and that is the fast of the vow (صوم النذر), for it extracts generosity from the miser. There is no obligatory fast other than what we have mentioned.

### [Types of Recommended Fasting]

As for the recommended fast (المندوب), some of it is restricted to a desirable time (الزمان المرغب فيه), such as fasting the White Days (الأيام البيض), Mondays, Thursdays, and similar days and months. Some of it is restricted to a state (الحال), such as fasting one day and breaking the fast one day, which is the most balanced fast (أعدل الصوم), and like fasting in the path of Allah (في سبيل الله). Some of it is not restricted by time, which is when a person fasts whenever he wishes, voluntarily (متطوعا) doing so.

(Section on the Obligatory Fast, which is the Month of Ramadan for those who Witness It)

Let us first mention Ramadan, and after that, we will discuss the rulings of its fast. Muslim reported from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "When Ramadan comes, the gates of Paradise (الجنة) are opened, the gates of the Fire (النار) are closed, and the devils (الشياطين) are chained (صفدت)." Al-Nasa’i added in his book: "And a caller calls out every night: 'O seeker of good, come forward! O seeker of evil, hold back!'" Al-Nasa’i narrated this from Arfajah, from a man among the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him).

### [The Coming of Ramadan and the Opening of the Gates of Paradise]

Since the coming of Ramadan is a cause for commencing the fast, Allah opens the gates of Paradise (الجنة). *Al-Jannah* (Paradise) means the veil/covering (الستر). Thus, fasting enters into a veiled action (عمل مستور) known only to Allah the Exalted, because it is abandonment (ترك) and not an existent action (عمل وجودي) that appears to the sight or is performed by the limbs. Therefore, it is veiled from everything other than Allah; only Allah the Exalted knows it from the fasting person—the one whom the Law calls a fasting person, not merely the hungry person.

### [The Coming of Ramadan and the Closing of the Gates of the Fires]

And Allah closes the gates of the Fire (النار). When the gates of the Fire are closed, its breath returns upon itself, so its heat is doubled upon it, and parts of it consume other parts. Likewise, the fasting person, according to the ruling of his nature (حكم طبيعته), when he fasts, closes the gates of the fire of his nature. He finds an increased heat due to the non-use of moisteners (المرطبات). He finds the pain of that internally, and his desire (شهوته) for food—by which he imagines comfort—is doubled. Thus, the fire of his desire is strengthened by closing the door to the consumption of food and drink.

### [The Coming of Ramadan and the Chaining of the Devils]

And the devils (الشياطين) are chained (صفدت). This is the attribute of distance (صفة البعد). Thus, the fasting person is near to Allah by the attribute of Self-Sufficiency (الصفة الصمدانية), for he is engaged in an act of worship that has no like. By this, he draws near to the attribute of <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>. For the one whose attribute this is, the devils are chained concerning him. It is reported in the tradition that the devil flows through the son of Adam like blood, so block its passages with hunger and thirst. Meaning, these causes assist him in what he desires from man regarding excessive behavior (التصرف في الفضول), which is what exceeds the prescribed conduct (التصرف المشروع).

### [Ramadan is One of the Names of Allah the Exalted]

Then know—may Allah grant you knowledge from His Presence (لدنه علما) and establish wisdom and ruling for you in every matter—that Ramadan is one of the Names of Allah the Exalted, and it is *Al-Samad* (The Self-Sufficient). The Prophetic report came concerning this. Ahmad ibn Adi al-Jurjani narrated from the hadith of Najih Abu Ma’shar, from Sa’id al-Maqburi, from Abu Hurayrah, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Do not say 'Ramadan,' for Ramadan is a Name among the Names of Allah the Exalted." Although Abu Ma’shar is in this chain of transmission (إسناد), the scholars of this discipline said that despite his weakness, his hadith is written down, so they considered it, may Allah be pleased with them. For this reason, Allah the Exalted said: <<شَهْرُ رَمَضانَ>> (The month of Ramadan), and did not say "Ramadan." And He said: <<فَمَنْ شَهِدَ مِنْكُمُ الشَّهْرَ>> (So whoever among you witnesses the month), and did not say "Ramadan." The hadith of Abu Ma’shar is thus strengthened by this, along with the scholars' statement that his hadith is written down despite his weakness. The hadith gained further strength from the Quranic support. Allah did not initially impose the fast that has no like except in a month that the Exalted named with one of His Names, which has no like among the months. This is because there is no name among the names of the months of the year by which Allah is named except Ramadan. Thus, it came with a specific Name (اسم خاص) that distinguishes a specific entity. This is not the case with the attribution of Rajab, concerning which the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said it is "Allah's sacred month" (شهر الله المحرم). All months are Allah's months, but here He only described it as *al-Muharram* (the sacred), which is one of the Sacred Months (الشهور الحرم).

### [The Quran Was Revealed in Ramadan]

Furthermore, Allah the Exalted revealed the Quran in this month, on the most excellent night called the Night of Decree (ليلة القدر). He revealed it therein as <<هُدىً لِلنَّاسِ وبَيِّناتٍ من الْهُدى‏ والْفُرْقانِ>> (Guidance for mankind and clear proofs of the Guidance and the Criterion). This is from the perspective of it being Ramadan. As for the perspective of it being the Night of Decree, He revealed it as a clear Book (كتابا مبينا), meaning, He made clear that it is a Book. The states of a thing being a Book, a Recitation (قرآنا), and a Criterion (فرقانا) are distinct levels (مراتب متميزة) known to those who possess Gnosis of Allah (العالمون بالله). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) prohibited saying "Ramadan" because of His saying <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). If it were said, it would be a like (مثلا) in this Name. Therefore, He added the word 'month' (الشهر) to it so that likeness (المثلية) is negated from it specifically among the months, and <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> remains upon its degree (رتبته) in every respect.

### [Allah Made Fasting Ramadan Obligatory and Recommended Standing in Prayer]

Allah has made its fast obligatory and recommended standing in prayer (قيامه). It includes both fasting and breaking the fast (فطرا) because it includes both night and day. The name Ramadan applies to it in the state of fasting and breaking the fast, so that it is distinguished from Ramadan, which is a Name of Allah the Exalted. For Allah the Exalted has the Fast (الصوم) that does not accept breaking the fast (الفطر). We have the fast that accepts breaking the fast and ends at a limit, which is the departure of the day, the approach of the night, and the setting of the sun. Thus, its application to the Real (الحق) does not resemble its application to creation (الخلق).

### [Allah's Theophany in Ramadan is Not Like His Theophany in Other Times]

He recommended standing in prayer during its night due to His Theophany (تجليه تعالى) on <<يَوْمَ يَقُومُ النَّاسُ لِرَبِّ الْعالَمِينَ>> (The Day when mankind will stand before the Lord of the Worlds). Although the Theophany (التجلي) of Allah occurs every night of the year, His Theophany in Ramadan during the time of the fasters' breaking of the fast is not like His Theophany to the one who breaks his fast without fasting. This is because the former is the existence of breaking the fast (فطر) following a prescribed abandonment (ترك مشروع) described as having no like. The latter is not called one who breaks the fast, but rather one who eats. If *al-fitr* (breaking the fast) means splitting, then this eating for the fasting person is the splitting of his intestines with food and drink after sealing them by fasting, as He said, "Block its passages with hunger and thirst." Standing in prayer (القيام) was prescribed at night because standing is the result of strength in the locus (المحل), and the cause of the locus's strength is nourishment. It was at night due to the suitability of the Unseen (الغيب), for the strength derived from nourishment is an unseen, imperceptible production of strength from food.

### [Ramadan Includes Fasting, Breaking the Fast, Standing, and Sleep]

Since Ramadan encompasses fasting, breaking the fast, standing in prayer, and not standing, it was reported in the tradition: "Let none of you say, 'I stood in prayer (قمت) all of Ramadan and fasted it all.'" The narrator said: "I do not know whether he disliked self-praise (التزكية) or said, 'There must be a sleep or a rest.'" Thus, the exception was made for standing in prayer during its night, not for fasting its day. Abu Dawud reported this hadith from Abu Bakrah, from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). Breaking the fast (الفطر) here is the departure [of the day], the approach [of the night], and the sunset, whether one eats or not.

### [The Limit of the Prescribed Day for Fasting]

The fast of the month of Ramadan is obligatory (واجب) upon every Muslim, adult, sane, healthy resident who is not traveling. It is the specific, known, famous time among the twelve months, situated between Sha’ban and Shawwal. What is specified from this time is the fast of the days, not the nights. The limit of the day of fasting is from the rising of the dawn (طلوع الفجر) until the setting of the sun (غروب الشمس). This is the limit of the prescribed day for fasting (اليوم المشروع للصوم), not the limit of the day known as *al-nahar* (daylight), which is from sunrise to sunset. Since the One who is <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> is characterized by the First and the Last, likewise the fast that has no like is described with a beginning and an end. Its beginning is the rising of the dawn (الطلوع الفجري) and its end is the setting of the sun (الغروب الشمسي). He did not make its beginning resemble its end, because He considered in its beginning what was not considered in its end, regarding what exists in its end—where the fasting person is described as breaking the fast—and in its beginning—where he is described as fasting. There is no difference between the twilight (الشفق) at sunset and sunrise, from the time of sunset until the disappearance of the twilight, or from the time of the burst [of dawn] (الانفجار) until sunrise. For this reason, the Law (الشرع) shifted to the word *al-Fajr* (dawn), because the ruling of its burst (انفجاره) for the existence of the day is the ruling of the sunset for the approach and occurrence of the night. Just as we know the approach of the day by the burst of the dawn, even if the sun has not risen, likewise we know the approach of the night by the sunset, even if the twilight has not disappeared. Look at how perfectly the Law is established in the world (العالم). The common factor between the beginning and the end of the fast is the existence of the sign indicating the approach of the time of fasting and the time of breaking the fast, which is the departure of the day, just as the dawn signifies the departure of the night. Ramadan is more general than its fast. The discussion of continuous fasting (*wisal*) will come in its proper place, and whether the one who practices it is called a fasting person or not.

### [Defining the Arabic Month]

After mentioning the definition of the day of fasting, whether in Ramadan or otherwise, let us look at the definition of the month. The minimum designation of the month is twenty-nine days, and its maximum is thirty days. This is specifically the Arabic lunar month (الشهر العربي القمري) that we are obligated to know. The witnesses of those who count also use the sign, but the people of the sign make one month twenty-nine days and another thirty. The Law (الشرع) has commanded us in this matter to rely on the sighting of the crescent (رؤية الهلال). In case of cloudiness (الغيم), we rely on the greater of the two measures [thirty days], except in Sha’ban, if the crescent of Ramadan is obscured from us. In this case, there is a difference of opinion: whether we extend Sha’ban to the greater measure (thirty days), which is the view of the majority (الجماعة), or whether we reduce it to the lesser measure (twenty-nine days), which is the doctrine of the Hanbalis and those who follow them. As for those who differ outside of these groups, the People of the Sunnah (أهل السنة) do not consider their disagreement, for they have legislated what Allah has not permitted. My view is that the astronomers (أهل التسيير) should be asked about the lunar mansion (منزلة القمر). If it is at the degree of visibility (درج الرؤية) and it is obscured from us, we act upon that. If it is not at the degree of visibility, we complete the count to thirty. As for the months that are not counted by the moon, they have specific measures. Their minimum measure is twenty-eight days, which is called February in the Roman calendar (الرومية), and their maximum measure is thirty-six days, which is called Misra in the Coptic calendar (القبطية), which is the last month of the Coptic year. We have no need for the months of the non-Arabs (الأعاجم) regarding the fast with which we are commanded.

### [The Wisdom Behind the Measure of the Arabic Month]

The completion of thirty days in this matter is the number of the lunar mansions (المنازل) and the two dwellers (النازلين) who do not fail: the Sun, which is likened to the Spirit (الروح) by which the life of the body appears to the senses, and the Moon, which is likened to the Soul (النفس) due to the existence of increase, decrease, and additive and subtractive perfection. The mansions are the measure of the distance constantly traversed by what we mentioned. Through the month, the simple numbers (بسائط الأعداد) and their compounds appeared: with the conjunction ('and') from twenty-one to twenty-nine, and without the conjunction from eleven to nineteen. The existence of oddness (الفردية) is confined to the simple numbers, which is three, and to the decade, which is thirty. Then the odd number is repeated for the perfection of the triplicity (التثليث) from which production occurs, in three places: three in the simple numbers, thirteen in the number compounded without the conjunction, and twenty-three with the conjunction. The divisions are thus confined. Since we see that the Spirit (الروح) exists, and life occurs without deficiency or excess, the Soul (النفس) may not have an existent entity (عين موجودة) that has a ruling, such as the death of a fetus in its mother's womb after the Spirit has been breathed into it, or upon its birth. For this reason, the month may consist of twenty-nine days. If you know this, you have known the wisdom behind the measure of the Arabic month. If we count it without observing the course of the crescent and intend an absolute month (شهرا مطلقا) in an oath of abstinence (*ila'*) or a vow (نذر), we act upon the lesser measure (الأقل) in that and not the greater, for by the lesser measure we have attained the limit of the month, and we are finished. We only consider the greater measure in the place where the Law has prescribed us to consider it, which is in the case of cloudiness, according to one doctrine, or when the sighting of the crescent necessitates it, due to his (peace and blessings be upon him) saying: "Fast upon its sighting, and break the fast upon its sighting."

(Section on When the Crescent Sighting is Obscured)

Scholars differed when the crescent was obscured. The majority said the count should be completed to thirty. If the obscured crescent was that of the beginning of the month, the preceding month is counted as thirty, and the first of Ramadan is the thirty-first day. If the obscured crescent was that of the end of the month—meaning Ramadan—people fast thirty days. Some say that if the obscured crescent was that of the beginning of the month, they fast the second day, which is the Day of Doubt (يوم الشك). Others say that in this matter, one refers to calculation (الحساب) based on the course of the moon and the sun. This is the doctrine of Ibn al-Shikhkhir, and it is the view I hold.

(Section on the Consideration of This)

The hadith that caused the disagreement has preceded. Muslim reported from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) mentioned Ramadan and struck his hand, saying: "The month is thus and thus," then he folded his thumb on the third time. "Fast upon its sighting, and break the fast upon its sighting. If it is obscured from you, then estimate (فاقدروا) thirty." It was also reported from the hadith of Ibn Umar that he (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "We are an unlettered nation (أمة أمية); we neither write nor calculate. The month is thus, thus, and thus," and he folded the thumb. "And the month is thus, thus, and thus," meaning a full thirty. This second hadith removes the ambiguity. As for the hadith "then estimate," those who interpreted it as restriction (التضيق) began fasting Ramadan on the Day of Doubt. Those who interpreted it as estimation (التقدير) ruled by astronomical calculation (التسيير), and this is the view I hold.

### [The Rising of the Crescent of Gnosis in the Horizon of the Gnostics' Hearts]

Know that voices are not raised except by sighting (الرؤية), and by this it is called *hilal* (crescent). Whenever the crescent of Gnosis (هلال المعرفة) rises in the horizon of the hearts of the Gnostics (قلوب العارفين) from the Divine Name Ramadan, fasting becomes obligatory. And whenever the crescent of Gnosis rises in the horizon of the hearts of the Gnostics from the Divine Name *Fāṭir al-Samāwāt wa al-Arḍ* (Originator of the Heavens and the Earth), breaking the fast (الفطر) becomes obligatory upon the spirits (الأرواح) from His saying "the Heavens," and upon the bodies (الأجسام) from His saying "and the Earth." "Rises" here means appears, for it is setting, following the sun. If it is obscured from the Gnostic and he does not see it due to the intervening veil (الحجاب الحائل) from the World of the Isthmus (عالم البرزخ)—for the cloudiness (الغيم) is an Isthmus (برزخي) between heaven and earth—the Gnostic estimates the crescent of Gnosis in his heart according to his state (حاله). This is done by looking at the crescent of his intellect (هلال عقله) through its course (تسييره) in the stations of his spiritual journey (*sulūk*), state after state, and station (*maqām*) after station. If his station grants Unveiling (الكشف), and the call has come to him from behind a veil, just as it came: <<وَمَا كَانَ لِبَشَرٍ أَنْ يُكَلِّمَهُ اللهُ إِلَّا وَحْيًا أَوْ مِنْ وَرَاءِ حِجَابٍ>> (It is not for any human being that Allah should speak to him except by inspiration, or from behind a veil). However, the veil of nature (حجاب الطبيعة) stood up for him at that time concerning one of his affairs, such as the preoccupation of the thought (شغل الخاطر) with wealth or family, even if he is *in* Allah. He acts according to the calculation of that and treats the Name of Allah, Ramadan, in a manner befitting it. Even if he does not witness it (يشهده), the state (الحال) necessitated that for him. If the state does not grant it, due to the soundness of the calculation, that Divine Name will bring you out to its time.

(Section on Considering the Time of Sighting)

They agreed that if it is sighted after the evening prayer (*al-Isha'*), the month begins on the second day. They differed if it is sighted during other times of the day, meaning the first time it is seen. Most scholars hold that the moon, when first sighted during the day, belongs to the coming day, similar to the ruling in the point of agreement. Some say that if it is sighted before the zenith (*al-zawāl*), it belongs to the preceding night, and if it is sighted after the zenith, it belongs to the coming night. This is the view I hold.

(Section on the Consideration Therein)

The ruling of the Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) in whatever state it appears: the ruling belongs to it in the present state (الحال) through Theophany (التجلي), and in the future through its effect (الأثر), until the ruling of another Name comes and removes the ruling of the first.

### [The Zenith and the Station of Equality]

As for those who consider the sighting before and after the zenith (*al-zawāl*), know that the zenith (*al-istawā’*) is called in the Path (الطريق) the Station of Equality (موقف السواء). It is the station where a master is not distinguished from a servant, nor a servant from a master. If you say in that state that he is a master, you speak truly. If you say he is a servant, you speak truly, because you have a witness of the state (شاهد حال) in every saying that testifies to the truth of what you say. This is like the saying of the Exalted to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him): <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ وَلَكِنَّ اللهَ رَمَى>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw). His throwing is true, and his not throwing is true. The Exalted says: *I was his hand with which he strikes.* If you say that the thrower is Allah, you speak truly. If you say that the thrower is Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), you speak truly. This is the Station of Equality (موقف السواء).

### [The Bakri Station and the Uthmani Station]

If you are in the station of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, you see nothing except that you see Allah before it. Thus, you are among those who saw it before the zenith, and the ruling belongs to the past. You are in the state (الحال) at the beginning of the month, and that day is its first day. If you are in the Uthmani witnessing (المشهد العثماني) or a person of intellectual proof (دليل فكر), you say, "I saw nothing except that I saw Allah after it." This is the one who saw it after the zenith, and his ruling is for the future. His time at the zenith is the time when the face of the proof (وجه الدليل) has a relation to the proof and a relation to the proven. Then the zenith (*al-zawāl*) appears, which is the shadow returning from the line of equality toward the specific inclination, for it is returning toward the evening (*al-ashiyy*), which is the seeking of the night.

(Section on Their Difference Regarding Attaining Knowledge of Sighting by Means of Sight)

Scholars differed on this. All of them said that whoever sights the crescent of the fast alone must fast, except Ibn Abi Rabah, who said he must not fast unless someone else sights it with him. They differed on whether he breaks the fast based on his sighting alone. Some said he does not break the fast, and some said he does break the fast, and this is the view I hold. Likewise, he fasts based on his sighting alone, but with the attainment of Knowledge (العلم) in both sightings. As for attaining Knowledge of the sighting through report (الخبر), some say one neither fasts nor breaks the fast except with two just witnesses (شاهدين عدلين). Some say one fasts with one witness and breaks the fast with two. Some say that if the sky is cloudy—meaning in the place of the crescent—one witness is accepted, but if it is clear, only a large multitude (الجم الغفير) or two just witnesses are accepted. Likewise, concerning the crescent of breaking the fast (هلال الفطر), some say two witnesses, and some say one.

(Section on the Consideration Therein)

Regarding what the People of Allah (أهل الله) see of the Theophany (التجلي) in the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية): Does one rely on his sighting, or does he pause until a witness from the Book (الكتاب) or the Sunnah (السنة) is established for him? Al-Junayd said: "This knowledge of ours is bound by the Book and the Sunnah." He meant that it is a result of acting upon them, and this is what we intended by the witness, which are the two just witnesses (الشاهدان العدلان). The Exalted said: <<أَفَمَنْ كَانَ عَلَى بَيِّنَةٍ مِنْ رَبِّهِ>> (Is he then who is upon a clear proof from his Lord)—this is the person of sighting (صاحب الرؤية)—<<وَيَتْلُوهُ شَاهِدٌ مِنْهُ>> (and followed by a witness from Him)—this is what we mentioned concerning acting upon the report, either the Book or the Sunnah, which is the single witness.

### [The Two Witnesses: The Book and the Sunnah]

The two witnesses are the Book and the Sunnah. We only needed to act upon them rather than relying on the transmission (النقل) that testifies for the person of this station (المقام), because that is difficult except through the breaking of habit (*kharq al-ʿāda*). This means that one knows from that realm by means of a sign of proof or a report. We have seen a group of our companions arguing for their spiritual findings (*mawājīd*) using the Quran—which they had memorized beforehand—and the Sunnah. We have narrated this from Abu Yazid al-Bistami. When this is not granted, no judgment of acceptance or rejection is made upon it. It is like the People of the Book informing us of something from their scripture: we neither confirm nor deny it, as the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded us. So we leave it suspended (*mawqūfan*).

### [This Knowledge of Ours is Bound by the Book and the Sunnah]

What I understand of Al-Junayd’s saying, due to my knowledge of the Path (الطريق), is that he intended to differentiate between what is granted to the person of spiritual retreats (*khalawāt*), struggle (*mujāhada*), and discipline (*riyāḍa*) outside the way of the Law (الشرع)—but rather according to what the souls necessitate through the intellect—and what appears to those who act upon the prescribed method through retreats and disciplines. His spiritual journey (*sulūk*) upon the prescribed Divine Path testifies for him that what appears to him is from Allah, by way of a miracle (*karāma*) granted to him. This is the meaning of Al-Junayd’s saying, "This knowledge of ours is bound by the Book and the Sunnah," or, in another narration, "supported," meaning it is the result of a prescribed Divine action, in order to differentiate it from what appears to the people of intellect (أرباب العقول), the masters of philosophical laws (النواميس الحكمية). The known reality (المعلوم) is one, but the path is different, and the person of Spiritual Taste (صاحب الذوق) differentiates between the two matters.

(Section on the Time of Abstinence)

They agreed that its end is the disappearance of the sun (غيبوبة الشمس). They differed concerning its beginning. Some say it is the second dawn (الفجر الثاني), which is the spreading light (*al-mustaṭīr*). Others say it is the red dawn (الفجر الأحمر) that appears after the white dawn, which is the view of Hudhayfah and Ibn Mas’ud. This is analogous to the red twilight (الشفق الأحمر) that occurs at the beginning of the night. The view I hold is that it is when it becomes clear to the observer, at which point eating is forbidden. This is the text of the Quran: <<حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَكُمُ الْخَيْطُ الْأَبْيَضُ مِنَ الْخَيْطِ الْأَسْوَدِ>> (Until the white thread becomes distinct to you from the black thread), meaning the whiteness of the morning and the blackness of the night.

(Section on the Consideration in This)

The disappearance of the sun is the expiration of the period of the ruling of the Divine Name Ramadan concerning the fast, for it is the one who legislated the fast. The end of the period of its ruling concerning the fast is the setting of the sun. Even though the Name Ramadan remains as it is and has not been removed from its authority, it has another ruling concerning us, which is standing in prayer (القيام). The Name *Fāṭir al-Samāwāt wa al-Arḍ* (Originator of the Heavens and the Earth) takes over the ruling in the locus that was characterized by fasting, but by the delegation of the Name Ramadan to it. It is the deputy for it, just as in fasting it is high in degrees (رفيع الدرجات) and holds the heavens and the earth from <<أَنْ تَزُولَا أَوْ أَنْ تَقَعَ عَلَى الْأَرْضِ إِلَّا بِإِذْنِهِ>> (from vanishing or falling upon the earth, except by His permission).

### [The Symbolism of the White Dawn and the Red Dawn]

The fasting person breaks his fast, and the ruling of standing in prayer remains continuous until the limit where the Divine Name Ramadan forbids eating. The Name *al-Mumsik* (The Holder/Abstainer) takes charge, and the Name *al-Fāṭir* (The Originator/Breaker of Fast) remains in authority over the sick, the traveler, the nursing mother, and the pregnant woman. That limit is the spreading white dawn (الفجر الأبيض المستطير), which is preferable to the red dawn, except according to those who say that the bubbling of the oven (*fār al-tannūr*) is the dawn. Just as relying on continuous transmission (*tawātur*) is preferable to relying on a single sound report (*khabar wāḥid ṣaḥīḥ*), and the Quran is continuously transmitted, and it is the one that says: <<حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَكُمُ الْخَيْطُ الْأَبْيَضُ مِنَ الْخَيْطِ الْأَسْوَدِ مِنَ الْفَجْرِ>> (Until the white thread becomes distinct to you from the black thread of the dawn). The origin of colors is whiteness and blackness. All other colors are Isthmuses (برازخ) between them, generated from the mixture of white and black, resulting in grayness, redness, greenness, and other colors. Whatever is closer to whiteness has a greater quantity of whiteness than blackness, and likewise at the other extreme. The Sunnah came in the hadith of Hudhayfah with redness, not whiteness, where he said, "It is the day, except that the sun has not risen." This is open to interpretation (محتمل). The whiteness mentioned in the Quran is not open to interpretation. Thus, we preferred the white over the red for two strong reasons: the Quran and the lack of ambiguity. We also consider them the ruling of Faith (الايمان), which is the white, for it is sincere to Allah (مخلص لله) and unmixed. The red is for intellectual consideration (*al-naẓar al-ijtihādī*), which is the ruling of the intellect (حكم العقل). The intellect's consideration is mixed with the senses through the Imagination (الخيال), because it takes from thought, from Imagination, from the senses, either by what the senses give it, or by what the formative faculty (القوة المصورة) gives it. It is decisive in what it gives, yet the destructive ambiguity (*al-shubha al-qādiḥa*) enters upon it. For this reason, we assigned the red twilight (الشفق الأحمر) to the consideration of the *mujtahid* (jurist), since redness is a color that arose from the mixture of white and black, which is a specific mixture.

### [The Manifest Real and the Manifesting Creation]

As for the consideration of clarity (*al-tabayyun*) in His saying, <<وَكُلُوا وَاشْرَبُوا حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَكُمُ>> (And eat and drink until it becomes clear to you): it does not become clear until the rising occurs. This is the ruling I adopt. Eating is not forbidden even if the rising occurs *in reality* (*fī nafs al-amr*), but clarity has not occurred for the observer. Likewise, the Real (الحق), even though He is *in reality* the Manifest (الظاهر) in the possible manifestations (المظاهر الإمكانية), this is not clear to everyone. Just as the Lawgiver pardoned the eater and permitted him to eat even though the rising of the dawn was realized *in reality*, but it was not clear to him, likewise, the actions of the servant who does not know that the Real is the Manifest in the possible manifestations through His Acts (أفعاله) and Names (أسمائه) are not held against him due to his ignorance of that, until the Real becomes clear to him in that matter. Then he will be upon insight (*baṣīra*) in His saying: *When I love him, I am his hearing and his sight.* Thus, the servant is the manifestation (مظهر) of the Real. It is established that Allah said through the tongue of His servant in the prayer: *Allah hears the one who praises Him.* He attributed the saying to Himself, while the tongue belongs to the servant, who is the locus of the saying, and the tongue is a spatial manifestation (مظهرا مكاني). Just as eating is forbidden to the legally responsible person (*mukallaf*) upon the clarity of the dawn, likewise it is forbidden for the person of Witnessing (صاحب الشهود) to believe that there is in Existence (الوجود) any agent (فاعلا) other than Allah, nor even anything witnessed, since the strong hadith encompassed the limbs, and there are only these two.

(Section on What the Faster Must Abstain From)

They agreed that the fasting person must abstain (الإمساك) from food (المطعوم), drink (المشروب), and sexual intercourse (الجماع). This is the extent mentioned explicitly in the Book, in His saying, the Exalted: <<فَالْآنَ بَاشِرُوهُنَّ ... وَكُلُوا وَاشْرَبُوا حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَكُمُ الْخَيْطُ الْأَبْيَضُ مِنَ الْخَيْطِ الْأَسْوَدِ مِنَ الْفَجْرِ>> (So now associate with them... and eat and drink until the white thread becomes distinct to you from the black thread of the dawn).

(Section on the Consideration in This)

As for food (المطعوم), it is the knowledge of tasting (علم الذوق) and drinking. The fasting person is upon an attribute that has no like (لا مثل لها), and whoever is characterized by that which has no like, his ruling is that he has no like. Tasting (*al-dhawq*) is the first of the beginnings of the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي). If it persists, it is drinking (*al-shurb*). Tasting is a relation (نسبة) that occurs in the taster when he tastes the tasted object. Fasting is abandonment (ترك), and abandonment does not have an existent attribute (صفة وجودية) that occurs, for abandonment is not an existent thing that occurs, because it is a negative attribute (نعت سلبي). Taste contradicts this. For this reason, the consumption of food is forbidden to the fasting person, because it removes the ruling of the fast from him.

### [Drink is a Middle Theophany]

As for drink (المشروب), it is a middle Theophany (تجل وسط). The middle is confined between two extremes for the one who is the middle for them. Confinement necessitates limitation (التحديد) in the confined entity. Fasting is a Divine attribute (صفة إلهية), and Allah does not necessitate confinement, nor is He characterized by it or by limitation, nor is He distinguished by it according to us. Thus, drink contradicts fasting. For this reason, drink is forbidden to the fasting person. Furthermore, since drink is a Theophany (تجليا), it permits the existence of the other (الغير) to whom the Theophany occurs. The 'other' in the fasting person has no entity (عين له), because the fast is for Allah, not for us. Since I am characterized by it, the Real (الحق) has placed me in His station (منزلته) with this attribute. A thing does not manifest to itself. Therefore, the fasting person does not consume drink, and it is forbidden for him.

### [The Existence of Pleasure Through Partnership]

As for sexual intercourse (الجماع), it is for the existence of pleasure (اللذة) through partnership (*al-shaf'iyya*). Each of the two spouses is a possessor of pleasure in it, so each is a like (مثل) for the other in intercourse. For this reason, it is called *jimāʿ* (intercourse/gathering), due to the gathering of the two spouses. The fasting person has no like (لا مثل له) because he is characterized by an attribute that has no like. Thus, intercourse is forbidden to the fasting person. This is the point of consensus regarding these three things that invalidate the fast, and the one characterized by them, or by one of them, is not a fasting person.

(Section on What Enters the Cavity That is Not Nourishment)

They differed concerning what enters the cavity (*al-jawf*) that is not nourishment, such as pebbles and the like; concerning what enters the cavity through a passage other than that for food and drink, such as an enema (*al-ḥuqna*); and concerning what reaches the interior of the organs but not the stomach (*al-jawf*), such as reaching the brain but not the stomach. Some say that this breaks the fast, and some say it does not.

(Section on Consideration)

The participation of the wise (الحكماء), the people of thoughts (أصحاب الأفكار), with the People of Allah (أهل الله) in what is opened to them of the science of Unveiling (علم الكشف) through retreat (*khalwa*) and discipline (*riyāḍa*): the former achieve it through intellectual consideration (*al-naẓar*), and the People of Allah achieve it through both [retreat and discipline] by way of Faith (الايمان). They meet in the result. Those among our companions who differentiated between them by Spiritual Taste (الذوق)—and that the perception of the former is different from the perception of the latter, even if they share the form—said that it does not break the fast. Those who said that the perceived reality is one, but the path is different, that is the consideration of those who said it breaks the fast.

### [What the Person of Imaginal Theophany Must Witness]

As for the consideration of the interior of the organs other than the stomach: it is that the fasting person is in a Divine Presence (حضرة إلهية), then he is established in an Imaginal Presence (حضرة مثالية), such as His saying: *Worship Allah as if you see Him.* Does the one among the servants of Allah whose Spiritual Taste (ذوقه) has transcended the ruling of anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*) and similitude (*tamthīl*) allow the saying of the Lawgiver, *Worship Allah as if you see Him*, to affect him, so that he abandons his knowledge and taste and descends to this station (منزلة) out of respect for the Law and a reality of Unveiling (كشف), thereby breaking his fast? Or does he not descend? And he says: "I am a composite of different realities. There is that which keeps me upon my current state, and there is that which the witnessing of this descent demands, which is my being imagined or possessing imagination (خيال)." He knows that the Real (الحق) has requested him to witness Him in this Presence (حضرة) from this reality, and from every reality within him. Thus, this reality that the Imaginal Theophany (التجلي المثالي) demands is specified from me, while I remain upon my reality of having no imagination or imagining. This is the consideration of those who hold that what reaches the interior of the organs outside the stomach does not break the fast.

(Section on Kissing for the Faster)

Among the scholars of the Law (الشريعة), some permitted it, some disliked it absolutely, and some disliked it for the young man but permitted it for the old man.

(Consideration of This Section)

This issue is the opposite of the issue of Moses (peace be upon him), for he sought Vision (الرؤية) after he had attained Speech (الكلام). Witnessing (المشاهدة) and Speech do not combine except in the Theophany of the Isthmus (التجلي البرزخى). This was the station (*maqām*) of Shihab al-Din Umar al-Suhrawardi, who died in Baghdad, may Allah have mercy on him. One of his companions, whose transmission I trust, narrated to me that he affirmed the combination of Vision and Speech. From this, I knew that his witnessing (مشهد) must be Isthmus-like (برزخي); otherwise, it would not occur. Kissing (*al-qubla*) is derived from turning toward (*al-iqbāl*) and acceptance (*al-qabūl*) of comprehension (*al-fahwāniyya*) from the Presence of the Tongue (حضرة اللسن), for it is the locus of Speech. Turning toward it also occurred through audible speech when one was in the Imaginal Witnessing (المشاهدة المثالية). The one who is in it may be imagined to seek turning toward comprehension. If He speaks to him, he does not witness Him. I tasted this Mosaic station (المقام الموسى) in the place where Moses (peace be upon him) tasted it, except that I tasted it in a wet spot in the sand the size of a palm, while Moses (peace be upon him) tasted it in his need, which was his seeking fire for his family. I rejoiced because it was water.

### [Consideration of Those Who Disliked Kissing for the Faster and Those Who Permitted It]

We said that if He speaks to him, he does not witness Him, because the seeking soul (النفس الطالبة) is exhausted in understanding the address (الخطاب) and thus becomes absent from Witnessing (المشاهدة). This is analogous to the one who dislikes kissing, since the fasting person is the possessor of Witnessing (صاحب المشاهدة), for fasting has no like, and Witnessing has no like. As for the one who permitted it, he said: "The Theophany is Imaginal (مثالي), so I do not care, for the Essence (الذات) is behind that Theophany, and the Theophany is only valid from the station of the one to whom the Theophany occurs." If the Theophany occurred in a station other than that of the one to whom it occurs, it would not be valid to seek anything other than what he is in, because the Witnessing of the Real (مشاهدة الحق) is Annihilation (فناء), and with Annihilation, seeking is inconceivable. Pleasure is closer than seeking speech for the witness himself, yet the witness does not experience pleasure during the state of Witnessing. Abu al-Abbas al-Sayyari, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "No rational person ever experienced pleasure in Witnessing, because the Witnessing of the Real is Annihilation (فناء), and there is no pleasure in it."

### [Consideration of Those Who Disliked Kissing for the Young Man and Permitted It for the Old Man]

As for the one who disliked it for the young man, his consideration is the beginner (المبتدي) on the Path. He permitted it for the old man, and his consideration is the end-point (المنتهى). The end-point does not seek to return from Witnessing to Speech, abandoning Witnessing and turning toward comprehension, because comprehension is only valid with a veil (الحجاب), as He said: <<وَمَا كَانَ لِبَشَرٍ أَنْ يُكَلِّمَهُ اللهُ إِلَّا وَحْيًا أَوْ مِنْ وَرَاءِ حِجَابٍ>> (It is not for any human being that Allah should speak to him except by inspiration, or from behind a veil). The end-point knows this and does not do it. As for the beginner, who is the young man, he has no experience of the stations (المقامات), for he is in the station of the spiritual journey (*sulūk*) and knows only what he has tasted. The end-point is only in Witnessing, and he hears about it from the elders, so he imagines that he will not lose Witnessing while speaking. The beginner is in an Imaginal Witnessing (مشاهدة مثالية), so it is said to him: "The matter is not as you claim. If He speaks to you, He does not witness you, and if He witnesses you, He does not speak to you." For this reason, it was not permitted for the young man but was permitted for the old man, because the old man only seeks comprehension if he is an heir of the Messenger in conveying from Allah, in which case it is permissible for him to turn toward comprehension to understand the address.

(Section on Cupping for the Faster)

Some say that it breaks the fast and abstinence from it is obligatory. Some say that it does not break the fast but is disliked for the fasting person. And some say that it is neither disliked for the fasting person nor does it break the fast.

(Section on the Consideration of This Section)

The Name Al-Muhyi (The Giver of Life) responds to the Name Ramadan in the state of its ruling over the fasting person during the month of Ramadan, or to the Name Al-Mumsik (The Withholder) who holds the heavens and the earth from vanishing <<أَنْ تَزُولا>> or holds the heaven from falling upon the earth. This is because natural life in bodies is the vapor of blood generated by the cooking of the liver, which is the body’s house of blood. It then flows through the veins like water flowing through channels to irrigate a garden for the life of the trees. If this blood overflows, it is feared that its action will be reversed in the body, so it is removed by phlebotomy or cupping (حجامة) so that only the amount necessary for life remains. For this reason, we assign the ruling to the Name Al-Muhyi or Al-Mumsik, for through life, the heavens of the spirits (أرواح) and the earth of the bodies (أجسام) subsist. By this, the ruling of Al-Muhyi becomes stronger than what it is by itself, as they are two Divine Names, brothers. When they respond to the Divine Name Ramadan in the ruling of the fasting person, or to the Divine Name by which the Real (الحق) attributed fasting to Himself outside of Ramadan, and they find in the nearest station (منزل) to this place the Divine Names Al-Darr (The Harmer) and Al-Mumit (The Giver of Death), they seek assistance from the Divine Name Al-Nafi' (The Benefiter). Thus, they become three Divine Names seeking the permanence of this subsisting entity (عين القائمة). So they moved it (the body) to seek cupping, and the fasting person did not break his fast, nor was it disliked, because by its existence, the ruling of the Divine Name Ramadan was established for it.

### The Esoteric View of Those Who Disliked Cupping for the Fasting Person

For those who said cupping is disliked but does not break the fast, the reason for the dislike, in the esoteric view (اعتبار), is that the fasting person is characterized by abandoning nourishment, because eating and drinking are forbidden to him, and nourishment is the cause of life for the fasting person, and he has been commanded to abandon it during his fast. The removal of blood by cupping in this state is only due to the fear of perishing, so it takes the place of nourishment in seeking life. Since he is forbidden nourishment, this was disliked for him. By this esoteric view, and the one preceding it, the ruling is established for those who say that it breaks the fast and that abstaining from it is obligatory.

(Section on Vomiting and Self-Induced Vomiting)

Some say that involuntary vomiting (ذرعه القيء) does not break the fast, and they are the majority. Others say it breaks the fast, namely Rabi'ah and his followers. Similarly, the consensus is that self-induced vomiting (الاستقاء) breaks the fast, except for Tawus, who said it does not break the fast.

(Section on the Esoteric View of this Chapter)

The stomach is the treasury of nourishment, from which natural life arises and the dominion (الملك) over the rational soul (النفس الناطقة) is maintained. By this, it is called a dominion, and by its existence, the benefits of bestowed (وهبية) and acquired (كسبية) knowledge are attained. The rational soul observes nature (الطبيعة), and nature, although it serves the body, knows the extent to which it is observed by the rational soul, which is within the dominion. If nature perceives that there is something in the stomach's treasury that leads to the corruption of this body, it tells the expulsive faculty (القوة الدافعة): "Expel the excess whose retention in this treasury is destructive." So the expulsive faculty takes it from the retentive faculty (الماسكة), opens the door for it, and expels it. This is involuntary vomiting.

### The Esoteric View of Involuntary and Self-Induced Vomiting

Those who considered that since it was nourishment and it exited through the same path by which it entered intentionally—and is called a fast-breaker (مفطر) because of its passage through that path when entering—then they also considered it a fast-breaker upon exiting. Those who differentiate between the ruling of entry and the ruling of exit, and do not consider the path (as they are opposites), say it does not break the fast. This applies to involuntary vomiting. If the fasting person exerts effort in expelling it, which is self-induced vomiting (الاستقاء), and he considers the existence of benefit and the repulsion of harm for the subsistence of this structure (البنية), then it takes the place of nourishment for him. Since the fasting person is forbidden to use nourishment during his fast, and his expulsion (of the vomit) was intended to achieve in the body what nourishment achieves, they said it breaks the fast. Those who differentiate between the ruling of entry and the ruling of exit said it does not break the fast.

### The Body is Never Free from the Ruling of a Divine Name

All of this, in the Divine esoteric view (الاعتبار الإلهي), constitutes the rulings of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) that the preparedness (استعداد) of this body seeks for their influence at all times. For the body is never free from the ruling of a Divine Name within it. If the locus (المحل) becomes prepared to seek a Divine Name other than the Name currently ruling it, the ruling ceases, and the Name sought by the preparedness takes charge. The analogy is when the people of a land conspire against their ruler and bring another ruler; the first one finds no helper, so his rule vanishes, and the ruling sought by the preparedness returns. The ruling is always for the preparedness, and the prepared Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي المعد) never leaves its ruling permanently; it is not deposed, nor is conspiracy against it valid from the people of the land. It does not leave him in life or death, nor in gathering or separation. It is assisted by the Divine Names Al-Hafiz (The Preserver) and Al-Qawiyy (The Strong), and their sisters. Know this.

### Hadith on Involuntary Vomiting While Fasting

It is established that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) underwent cupping while fasting. Reported by Al-Bukhari from Ibn Abbas.

And Abu Dawud reported from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever is overcome by vomiting while fasting does not have to make up the day, but whoever induces vomiting must make up the day."

All narrators of this Hadith are trustworthy.

(Section on Intention)

Some considered intention (النية) a condition for the validity of the fast, and they are the majority. Others said Ramadan does not require intention, unless the one who observes the Ramadan fast is sick or traveling and chooses to fast.

(Section on the Esoteric View Therein)

Intention (النية) is purpose (القصد). The month of Ramadan does not arrive by the ruling of the purpose of the fasting human. Those who consider that the fast is for Allah, not for the servant, affirmed intention in the fast, because the month of Ramadan only came by the Will (إرادة) of the Real (الحق) from the Divine Name Ramadan, and intention is undoubtedly Will. Those who consider that the ruling belongs to the incoming event, which is the month of Ramadan, then whether the human faster intends it or not, its ruling is fasting, so intention is not a condition for the validity of his fast. If it is not obligatory upon him, and he is given a choice despite its arrival, like the sick person and the traveler, their ruling becomes a choice between two matters, and he cannot incline toward one of the two matters except by a purpose from him, which is the intention.

(Section on Specifying the Sufficient Intention)

Some say that specifying the fast of Ramadan is necessary, and merely intending fasting generally, or intending a specific fast other than Ramadan, is insufficient. Others say that if he intends fasting generally, it suffices. Likewise, if he intends a fast other than Ramadan, it suffices and transforms into the Ramadan fast, unless he is a traveler, for the traveler, according to them, may intend a fast other than Ramadan during Ramadan. Others say that every fast intended during Ramadan transforms into the Ramadan fast, the traveler and the resident being equal in this.

(Section on the Esoteric View Therein)

Allah Almighty said: <<قُلِ ادْعُوا الله أَوِ ادْعُوا الرَّحْمنَ أَيًّا ما تَدْعُوا فَلَهُ الْأَسْماءُ الْحُسْنى‏>> (Say, "Call upon Allah or call upon the Most Merciful. Whichever you call—to Him belong the most beautiful Names). The ruling belongs to the One called upon by the Divine Names, not to the Names themselves. For even if their meanings are dispersed and distinct, they point to a specific Essence (ذات معينة) generally and in reality (في نفس الأمر), even if that Essence is unknown and cannot be grasped by definition (حد). This does not invalidate our perception and knowledge that there is an Essence to which these Names apply. Likewise, fasting is the objective, whether it is recommended (مندوبا) or obligatory (واجبا), despite the multiplicity of its obligatory divisions.

### The Divine Names Indicate One Essence and Many Attributes

Those who consider the Divine Name Ramadan differentiate between it and others, for the others belong to the Name Al-Mumsik (The Withholder), not the Name Ramadan. Although the Divine Names indicate one Essence (ذات واحدة), they are distinguished in themselves in two ways: first, by the difference in their wording, and second, by the difference in their meanings, even if they approach each other closely and resemble each other greatly. And the Names of Opposition (أسماء المقابلة) are at the extreme of distance, such as Al-Darr (The Harmer) and Al-Nafi' (The Benefiter), Al-Mu'izz (The Honorer) and Al-Mudhill (The Humiliator), Al-Muhyi (The Giver of Life) and Al-Mumit (The Giver of Death), Al-Hadi (The Guide) and Al-Mudill (The Misleader). Therefore, the ruling of the meanings they indicate must be observed. By this, the knower (العالم) is distinguished from the ignorant (الجاهل). The Real (الحق) only brought them forth as multiple in order to observe the meanings they indicate, and observing the purpose of the Real Almighty in this is more appropriate than anything else. Therefore, specification (التعيين) is necessary to achieve the benefit sought by that specific wording, distinct from other combinations of wordings, which are the Divine Words (الكلمات الإلهية).

### Rulings Follow States

Those who considered the state (حال) of the legally responsible person (المكلف)—and this is what differentiated between the traveler and the resident—have a valid point in this differentiation, because the ruling follows the states. Thus, it observes the compelled and the uncompelled, the sick and the healthy. Likewise, the Names also observe. Thus, the Name of wine (الخمر) observes when it turns into the Name of vinegar (الخل), and the Divine ruling concerning this specific substance changes with the change of Names. Just as the Names changed in some things due to the change of states, since the change in that ruling was a Divine Name that necessitated the change of the name, and thus the ruling changed.

### The Divine Names Have Arbitration, Not Ruling, Over Things

> The ruling belongs to the One called upon by the Names,
> The Names have no ruling over things.

> But they have arbitration (التحكيم) in their disposition
> Within it, like the ruling of the constellations (الأنواء).

> In the flowers and trees, in their rains
> At times, and in things like dews.

> The spirits (الأرواح) play with them in their disposition,
> Like the interplay of Acts (الأفعال) with the Names.

(Section on the Time of Intention for Fasting)

Some say that fasting is not valid except with an intention before dawn (الفجر), absolutely, for all types of fasts. Others say intention after dawn is valid for supererogatory (تطوع) fasts, but not for obligatory (فروض) ones. Others say intention after dawn is valid for fasts whose obligation is tied to a specific time, and for supererogatory fasts, but not for those obligatory upon one's liability (الواجب في الذمة).

(Section on the Esoteric View Therein)

Dawn (الفجر) is a sign of the sunrise. It is like a Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) in terms of its indication of the Named (المسمى به), but not in terms of the meaning by which it is distinguished from other Names. The one who intends fasting may intend it out of necessity or choice. And the human in his knowledge (علم) of Allah may be a person of intellectual contemplation (نظر فكري) or a person of witnessing (شهود). Whoever's knowledge of Allah comes from contemplation of a proof (دليل) must seek the proof that leads him to Gnosis (المعرفة). He is like one who intends before dawn. And the duration of his contemplation of the proof is like the duration from the rising of dawn until the rising of the sun.

### Gnosis of Allah is of Two Types: Obligatory and Non-Obligatory

Gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah is of two types: Obligatory, such as knowing His Oneness (توحيد) in His Divinity (ألوهيته). And non-obligatory Gnosis, such as knowing the attribution of Names to Him that indicate meanings. For he is not obliged to contemplate whether those meanings are additional to Him or not. Such Gnosis does not matter when he intends it, whether it is after the establishment of the proof of the Oneness of the Godhead or before it.

### Necessary Knowledge Precedes Speculative Knowledge

As for what is obligatory upon one's liability (الواجب في الذمة), it is like the Gnosis of Allah in terms of what the Law (الشرع) attributes to Him in the Book and the Sunnah. It has been determined by speculative proof (الدليل النظري) that this is His Law and this is His Speech, so faith (الايمان) occurred in it and was established in the liability. Therefore, intention (القصد) towards it is necessary without recourse to speculative proof. This is what is considered when requiring intention before dawn, because for him, it is necessary knowledge (علم ضروري), which precedes speculative knowledge (العلم النظري). For speculative knowledge is only attained if the proof is necessary, or generated from necessary knowledge, whether closely or remotely. If it is not so, it is neither a definitive proof (دليل قطعي) nor an existential demonstration (برهان وجودي).

(Section on Purity from Ritual Impurity for the Fasting Person)

The majority agree that purity from ritual impurity (جنابة) is not a condition for the validity of the fast, and that a wet dream during the day does not invalidate the fast. However, some of them held that if one intentionally causes it, his fast is invalidated. This view is reported from Al-Nakha'i, Tawus, and Urwah ibn al-Zubayr. It was also reported from Abu Hurayrah concerning both intentional and unintentional cases. He used to say that whoever wakes up ritually impure (جنبا) in Ramadan has broken his fast, and he would say, "I did not say it; Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said it, by the Lord of the Ka'bah." Some Malikis said that if a menstruating woman becomes pure before dawn but delays the ritual bath (غسل), that day is a day of breaking the fast for her.

(Section on the Esoteric View in this)

Ritual impurity (الجنابة) is estrangement (الغربة), and estrangement after menstruation (الحيض) is harm (أذى). And harm necessitates distance. I mean specific harm, like His saying: <<إِنَّ الَّذِينَ يُؤْذُونَ الله ورَسُولَهُ لَعَنَهُمُ الله>> (Indeed, those who harm Allah and His Messenger—Allah has cursed them), meaning He distanced them. The curse (اللعنة) is distance, and its cause is the occurrence of harm from them. Thus, he is far from the Name Al-Quddus (The Holy). Fasting necessitates proximity (القرب) to Allah, <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), and fasting has no like among acts of worship.
