Just as proximity and distance do not combine, fasting, ritual impurity, and harm do not combine.

### Wisdom is Giving Every Possessor of a Right His Due

Those who considered that ritual impurity is a ruling of nature (الطبيعة), and likewise menstruation, and said that fasting is a Divine attribution (نسبة إلهية) that establishes every matter in its proper place, they affirmed the validity of the fast for the ritually impure person and for the woman purified from menstruation before dawn if she delays the ritual bath and only purifies herself after dawn. This is the most appropriate in the esoteric view, due to what Wisdom (الحكمة) requires: giving every possessor of a right his due. For the Wise One (الحكيم), exalted is He, says: <<أَعْطى‏ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ خَلْقَهُ ثُمَّ هَدى‏>> (He gave everything its creation, then guided). That is, He clarified. Allah praised this statement when He recounted that Moses said it to Pharaoh, and He did not criticize Him Almighty for this statement, as He criticized those who said <<إِنَّ الله فَقِيرٌ>> (Indeed, Allah is poor) or <<إِنَّ الله ثالِثُ ثَلاثَةٍ>> (Indeed, Allah is the third of three).

(Section on the Fasting of the Traveler and the Sick Person in Ramadan)

Some say that if they fast, it is valid and suffices them. Others say it does not suffice them, and what is obligatory upon them are a number of other days. The view I hold is that if they fast, it is not sufficient for them, and what is obligatory upon them are other days. However, I differentiate between the sick person and the traveler if they perform the fast in this state during Ramadan. As for the sick person, the fast is supererogatory (نفلا) for him; it is an act of righteousness (بر) and is not obligatory upon him, even if he makes it obligatory upon himself, it remains not obligatory upon him. As for the traveler, his fast during travel, whether in Ramadan or otherwise, is not an act of righteousness. And if it is not an act of righteousness, it is like one who has done nothing—which is its lowest degree—or it is the opposite and antithesis of righteousness, which is wickedness (الفجور). I do not assert the latter, but I deny that it is an act of righteousness in that deed in that state. Allah knows best.

(The Esoteric View)

The spiritual traveler (السالك) is the one traveling through the spiritual stations (المقامات) by means of the Divine Names. Thus, the Divine Name Ramadan does not rule over him with obligatory or non-obligatory fasting. For this reason, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Fasting while traveling is not righteousness." The Name Ramadan seeks him to execute the ruling within him until the end of the month of its dominion. Travel (السفر) rules over him by transition (الانتقال), which is the lack of permanence in a single state. Thus, the ruling of the Divine Name Ramadan is nullified concerning the fasting traveler. Those who said it suffices him made his travel a means of traversing the days of the month and made the ruling within him the Name Ramadan, thus combining travel and fasting. As for the ruling of his transition, called travel, he transitions from fasting to breaking the fast, and from breaking the fast to fasting, yet the ruling of Ramadan does not leave him. For this reason, its fasting and standing (prayer) were legislated, and also the permissibility of continuous fasting (الوصال) within it, despite his transition from night to day and day to night, and the ruling of Ramadan is extended over him. For this reason, the fast of Ramadan sufficed the traveler.

### Illness is Contrary to Health, and Health is Sought Through Fasting

As for the sick person, his ruling is different from that of the traveler in the esoteric view, for scholars agreed that if the sick person fasts Ramadan during his illness, it suffices him, whereas the traveler is not considered so by them, thus weakening their reliance on the verse. The esoteric view is that illness (المرض) is contrary to health (الصحة), and what is sought through fasting is health. Opposites (الضدان) do not combine, so illness and fasting are not valid together. We considered this in the month of Ramadan, but not in others, because it is obligatory by Allah's initial imposition. The One who made it obligatory is the One who lifted it from the sick person. Thus, it is not valid for what is not obligatory from Allah to be returned as obligatory from Allah while it is not obligatory.

(Section on Whether Breaking the Fast is Better for the Traveler and the Sick Person)

Some say that fasting is better. Others say that breaking the fast is better. Others say it is a matter of choice, and neither is better than the other.

(The Esoteric View)

Those who considered that fasting has no like and that it is an Attribute (صفة) of the Real (الحق) said it is better. Those who considered it an act of worship (عبادة), which is an attribute of humility (ذلة) and need (افتقار), and thus more fitting for the servant, said that breaking the fast (الفطر) is better, especially for the spiritual traveler (السالك) and the sick person, as they need strength, and its source is usually breaking the fast, so breaking the fast is better. Those who considered that fasting is from the Divine Name Ramadan and breaking the fast is from the Divine Name Al-Fatir (The Originator), and said there is no preference among the Divine Names as they are Names of God Almighty, said that neither of the two Names is better than the other. This is the doctrine of the Verifiers (المحققين), who elevate the noble and the nobler, the lowly and the noble, which are in opposition within the world (العالم), which is an expression for everything other than Allah Almighty.

(Section on Whether Permissible Breaking of Fast for the Traveler is Limited or Unlimited Travel)

Some say he breaks the fast in the travel for which prayer is shortened, according to their differing views on this matter. Others say he breaks the fast in everything to which the name "travel" (سفر) applies, and this is the view I hold.

(The Esoteric View Therein)

The travelers to Allah (المسافرون إلى الله) are traveling toward the All-Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع), which is the desired goal. The Divine Names on the path to Him are like the stations (منازل) for travelers, and the determined lunar mansions for the moon's journey toward its intended goal. The minimum travel is the transition from one Name to another. If he finds Allah in the very first step of his journey, his ruling is according to that. He is then called a traveler, and for the maximum extent of travel, there is no end or limit according to us, due to the Prophet's (peace and blessings be upon him) supplication: "O Allah, I ask You by every Name You have named Yourself with, or taught to any of Your creation, or kept exclusively in the knowledge of the Unseen with You." This is the esoteric view of those who say one breaks the fast in whatever the name "travel" applies to.

### The Absolute Oneness or the One Has No Ruling in Number

Those who spoke of limitation (التحديد) in this, their esoteric view is according to what they limited. Those who considered the number three in this are like those who say that the Absolute Oneness (الأحدية) or the One (الواحد) has no ruling in number; rather, counting begins from two upwards. Travel here is toward the Name Allah, and there is no travel to Him except by Him. The first thing he encounters in his journey toward Him is in the singularity (الفردية), which is the number three, the first of the singular numbers. This is the limited travel. The esoteric view regarding the scholars' limitation of shortening the prayer will be taken up in the chapter on prayer in this book, and we have mentioned it in the prayer of shortening in this book.

(Section on the Illness that Permits Breaking the Fast)

Some say the illness is that which causes hardship and harm from fasting. Others say it is the dominant illness. Others say it is the minimum state to which the name "illness" applies, and this is the view I hold, which is the doctrine of Rabi'ah ibn Abi Abd al-Rahman.

(The Esoteric View)

The seeker (المريد) experiences hardship; he is engaged in struggle and effort. For this reason, <<إِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (You alone we ask for help) was legislated for us, and Allah Almighty said: <<واسْتَعِينُوا بِالصَّبْرِ والصَّلاةِ>> (And seek help through patience and prayer). So the Name Al-Qawiyy (The Strong) assists him in what he is undertaking. This is an illness that necessitates breaking the fast.

### The Human is Necessarily Not Free from Inclination

As for those who considered illness to be inclination (الميل), which is what the name "illness" applies to—and this is the doctrine of Muhammad ibn Abd al-Jabbar al-Niffari, the author of *Al-Mawaqif*, one of the Men of Allah, as I reckon him—the human is necessarily not free from inclination, for he is between the Real (الحق) and Creation (الخلق), and between the Real and the Real in terms of the Divine Names. And every side calls him to itself, so he must incline, either away from it or toward it, by it or by himself, according to his state. Especially the people of Allah's Path, for their permissible actions (مباح) are in a state of recommendation or obligation, so they have no purely permissible action at all. No one among the people of Allah has the pans of his scale in equilibrium, and the human is the tongue of the scale, so he must incline toward the side of the caller of the Real (داعي الحق). This is the esoteric view of those who say one breaks the fast in whatever the name "illness" applies to. And that Allah is with the sick person, according to established Divine reports. Do you not see him resorting to Him and frequently mentioning Him, regardless of his religion or sect? He necessarily inclines toward Him. This becomes clearly apparent to you in his seeking salvation from his condition, for the human, by nature, rushes, when afflicted by harm, to seek the one who removes it from him, and that is none other than Allah. Allah Almighty said: <<وإِذا مَسَّكُمُ الضُّرُّ في الْبَحْرِ ضَلَّ من تَدْعُونَ إِلَّا إِيَّاهُ>> (And when affliction touches you at sea, lost are those you invoke except Him). Even if he is ignorant of the path to Him, he is not ignorant of necessity (الاضطرار), for it is his state by direct experience (ذوقا). We only observe the purpose (القصد), which is the objective.

### Actions Attributed to the Servant

As for those who considered the dominant illness (المرض الغالب), it is what is attributed to the servant from actions (الأفعال), for it is an inclination away from the Real (الحق) in actions, since they belong to Him. The conformer and the opposer incline with them toward the servant, whether the inclination is by power, creation, or acquisition. This is a sensory legal inclination, which is their saying: "Our Lord, we have believed in what You revealed," thus attributing faith to themselves as an origination. And Allah's saying to them, "Believe in Allah," confirms the validity of what they attributed of actions to themselves by this attribution. This is the legal aspect. This is equivalent to illness, and it is the dominant inclination because it is between the Real and Creation.

(Section on When the Fasting Person Breaks the Fast and When He Abstains)

Some say he breaks the fast on the day he sets out traveling. Others say he does not break the fast on that day. Scholars recommended that whoever knows he will enter the city that day should enter it fasting. If he enters it having broken the fast, they did not impose expiation upon him.

(The Esoteric View)

When the spiritual traveler (السالك) departs in his journey (سلوك) from the ruling of one Divine Name toward the ruling of another Divine Name that called him to it, so that the ruling of another Name—neither the one he departed from nor the one he is reaching—may convey him, he is under the ruling of that Name by which he travels, and it is with him wherever he is. Allah Almighty said: <<وهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). If that Name necessitated fasting for him, he was under the ruling of the attribute of fasting. If it necessitated breaking the fast, he was under the ruling of the attribute of breaking the fast. If he knows that he will arrive on that very day (يومه الذي هو نفسه) under the ruling of the Name that called him and upon which he intends to descend, he is under the ruling of the attribute of that Name, whether breaking the fast or fasting. I do not specify a state for him, because states differ, and there is no blame upon him in whatever that state may be. Success is from Allah.

(Section on the Traveler Entering His Destination City After Part of the Day Has Passed)

Scholars differed concerning one in this situation. Some said he continues upon his state of breaking the fast. Others said he must abstain from eating. Likewise, a menstruating woman who becomes pure must abstain from eating.

(Section on the Esoteric View in this Chapter)

The traveler had an objective in his journey and reached it. Does his joy in what he reached veil him from thanking the One who conveyed him to it? If it veils him, the ruling changes upon him, and he observes the ruling of abstinence (الإمساك). If it does not veil him, upon arrival he occupies himself with observing the One who conveyed him, so he does not depart from His ruling and continues upon the attribute he was upon in his journey, worshipping that Name with the worship of gratitude (عبادة شكر), not the worship of obligation (عبادة تكليف).

### Forbidden Truthfulness and Forbidden Lying

Likewise, the menstruating woman (الحائض) is the lying of the soul (كذب النفس) that is granted truthfulness (الصدق), so she purifies herself from the lying that is her menstruation. Does she continue upon the attribute of breaking the fast by means of permissible lying (الكذب المشروع)—such as reconciling disputes, lying in war, and a man lying to his wife—or does she necessitate what is truthfulness (صدق) in praiseworthy, obligatory, and recommended matters? For forbidden truthfulness, such as backbiting (الغيبة) and slander (النميمة), is like forbidden lying; both incur sin and veiling (الحجاب) equally. An example is one who speaks of what transpired with his wife in bed, reporting truthfully, yet it is one of the major sins. Likewise, what we mentioned regarding backbiting and slander. End of Volume Fifty-Six.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Section on Whether a Person Fasting Part of Ramadan May Initiate Travel and Then Not Fast)

Scholars differed concerning one in this situation. Some say it is permissible for him, and they are the majority. Others say it is not permissible for him to break the fast. This view is reported from Suwayd ibn Ghafalah and others.

(The Esoteric View)

Since it is held by us and by all the People of Allah (أهل الله) that every Divine Name (اسم إلهي) encompasses all the Names, and for this reason, every Divine Name is described by all the Divine Names, because it encompasses all their meanings. If the matter is as we mentioned, then whichever Divine Name rules you by its dominion, a meaning of another Divine Name may appear to you in that ruling, whose ruling in that Name is clearer and more manifest than the Name you are under at that time, so you initiate a spiritual journey (سلوك) toward it.

### Whoever is Under the Disposition of States is Under the Ruling of the Name Whose Dominion is Decreed Upon Him

Some among us say he remains upon the Theophany (تجلى) of the Name in which that meaning appeared to him. Others say he transitions to the Name whose meaning appeared to him in the encompassing Name, for it is clearer and more complete. The man is given a choice if he is strong in the disposition of states (تصريف الأحوال). But if he is under the disposition of states, he is subject to the state of the Name whose dominion is decreed upon him.

(Section on the Unconscious Person and the Insane Person)

The jurists agreed on the obligation (of making up the fast) upon the unconscious person (المغمى عليه) and differed concerning the insane person (المجنون). Some imposed the make-up fast (قضاء) upon him, and others did not impose it, and this is the view I hold. Likewise, in my view, concerning the unconscious person. They also differed on whether unconsciousness and madness invalidate the fast. Some said it invalidates it. Others said it does not invalidate it. Some differentiated between whether he became unconscious before dawn or after dawn. Some said that if he became unconscious after most of the day had passed, it suffices him, but if he became unconscious at the beginning of the day, he must make it up.

(The Esoteric View)

Unconsciousness (الإغماء) is a state of annihilation (فناء), and madness (الجنون) is a state of bewilderment (وله). Neither of those possessing these attributes is legally responsible (مكلف), so there is no making up (قضاء) upon him. Furthermore, making up is fundamentally inconceivable in the Path (الطريق) according to us, for every time has a specific incoming spiritual experience (وارد). There is no time in which the ruling of a past time exists. What has passed of time has passed with its state, and what we are in, we are under its dominion. What has not yet come has no ruling over us.

### The Time of the State Has No Knowledge of What Has Passed or What Is to Come

If they say that the ruling of the current time (زمان الحال) may be the making up (قضاء) of what was due in the first time, we say to him: Then he is performing (مؤد) it now, since this is the time for the performance of what you called making up. If you mean this, it is accepted in the Path. You called him one who makes up, but the time of the state has no knowledge of what has passed or what is to come, for it exists between two ends of non-existence (عدم). It has no knowledge of the past, nor of what it brought, nor of what its possessor missed from it.

### The Resemblance of the State to the Past is in Form, Not in Reality

What the time of the state brings may resemble what the time of the past brought, in form but not in reality. Just as the 'Asr prayer in the existential time of the state resembles the Dhuhr prayer that was in the past time in all its conditions, as if it were the same. Yet it is known that the ruling of 'Asr is not the ruling of Dhuhr. Even if we saw a person maintaining his prayers at their times, and it happened that he forgot Dhuhr or slept through it until the time of 'Asr entered, and we saw him praying four units at that time, we would assume he is praying 'Asr due to the great resemblance between them, yet this is not that.

(Section on the Manner of Making Up for One Who Broke the Fast in Ramadan)

Some scholars imposed continuous fasting (التتابع) in making up, just as in performance (الأداء). Others did not impose it. Among these, some gave a choice, and others recommended it. The majority agree on not imposing continuity.

(The Esoteric View)

When the time for an obligation (الواجب) expanded by time enters, the first Name seeks performance (الأداء) from the legally responsible person (المكلف). If the legally responsible person does not act and delays the action until the end of the time, the other Name receives him. The legally responsible person is then making up (قاضيا) that action relative to the first Name. If he had performed it at the beginning of the time, he would have been performing it without intrusion or doubt, and he would have been performing it relative to the other Name. Thus, when the fasting traveler or sick person breaks the fast, what is obligatory upon him is a number of other days outside of Ramadan. This is an obligation expanded in time, from the second day of Shawwal until the end of his life, or until Sha'ban of that year. The first Name receives him on the second day of Shawwal. If he fasts it, he is performing (مؤديا) without doubt or intrusion. If he delays it beyond that time, he is performing from one perspective and making up from another. By continuous fasting (التتابع) in the beginning of its time, he is performing without doubt, but if he does not fast continuously, he is making up.

### The Entire Cosmos is in the Grip of the Divine Names

Those who considered the shortness of hope and ignorance of the appointed time (الأجل) made it obligatory. Those who considered the expansion of time gave a choice. Those who considered caution recommended it. Every one of these states has a Divine Name whose ruling is not transgressed within it, for the Cosmos (الكون) is in the grip of the Divine Names, which dispose of it in two ways: according to their realities (حقائقها) and according to the preparedness (استعدادات) of the existents (الأكوان) for them. Both matters are necessary for one who has two eyes. For the essential attributes (الأوصاف النفسية) of the Names and non-Names do not change. Understand this and verify it, and you will be happy, God willing.

(Section on One Who Delays Making Up Ramadan Until the Next Ramadan Arrives)

Scholars differed concerning one in this situation. One group said he must make up the fast (قضاء) and offer expiation (كفارة). Another group said he must make up the fast but has no expiation upon him, and this is the view I hold.

(The Esoteric View)

The spiritual stations (المقامات) that have many different aspects—the spiritual traveler (السالك) may be heedless of their ruling in one of their related aspects, such as scrupulousness (الورع). For it has a ruling in many aspects, including food, drink, clothing, taking, looking, listening, striving, touching, and smelling. Umar ibn al-Khattab was brought musk from the spoils before its distribution to be presented to him, and he held his nose so that he would not benefit from its scent before the Muslims received their share, out of scrupulousness. He was asked about this, and he said, "One only benefits from this by its scent." Likewise, scrupulousness applies to lineage and Names. If the spiritual traveler misses one of the aspects related to such a station and moves on to other stations, while a remnant of the ruling of the station he left remains upon him, when its application becomes necessary for him at another time due to a state that demands it, such as food or otherwise, he remembers what he missed of it before. Some among us said he must offer expiation, and his expiation is repentance (التوبة) for his negligence and seeking forgiveness. Others said there is no expiation upon him, for he did not intend or aim to violate the sanctity; rather, he was excused by an interpretation of the matter or by heedlessness (غفلة).

### The Human is Held Accountable for Heedlessness in the Sufi Path

The human on this Path is held accountable for heedlessness according to some, which is why those who imposed expiation did so. Those who believe he is not held accountable for heedlessness did not impose expiation.

### The Sufi Forgives and Even Does Good to Those Who Harm Him

Making up (القضاء) is agreed upon by all. Its form is that if someone takes something from him that is forbidden for the taker to take—whether reputation, property, or physical effect like a wound—he has the right to forgive the one who took it from him. He forgives and does good, and does not hold accountable for every offense committed by others against him, which excessive scrupulousness (الورع المتعدي) dictates should not be done. This is the form of making up. Then he exhausts all aspects related to that station (المقام) with his effort, so that he leaves nothing of it. Reflect upon this matter, for it is one of the most beneficial matters on the Path of Allah.

(Section on One Who Dies Owing Fasts)

Some say his guardian (وليه) fasts on his behalf. Others say no one fasts on behalf of another. The followers of this latter view differed: some said his guardian feeds the poor on his behalf, and others said there is neither fasting nor feeding unless he makes a bequest (يوصى به). Some said he fasts, and if he cannot, he feeds the poor. Some differentiated between a vow (نذر) and an obligatory fast, saying his guardian fasts on his behalf for a vow, but not for an obligatory fast.

(The Esoteric View)

The disciple (المريد) under spiritual training (التربية) may have been qualified by the Shaykh and designated for a specific invocation (ذكر مخصوص) to attain a specific state (حالة مخصوصة) and a particular station (مقام خاص), but he dies before achieving it. Some among us hold that since the Shaykh was his guardian (وليه), and death intervened between him and that station—which, had he attained it, he would have achieved the Divine rank deserved by the Lord of that station—the Shaykh begins the action that leads to that station on behalf of the deceased disciple. When he completes it, he brings forth that deceased person, like one who brings forth his likeness in his imagination (خيال) in the form he was upon, and clothes that represented form with that matter, and asks Allah to maintain that upon him. Thus, the soul (نفس) of that deceased person attains that station in its most complete form, as a favor and grace from Allah. <<والله ذُو الْفَضْلِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (And Allah is the Possessor of Great Bounty).

### Ibn Arabi and His Shaykh Abu Ya'qub al-Kumi

This is the doctrine of our Shaykh, Abu Ya'qub Yusuf ibn Yakhlaf al-Kumi. None of my Shaykhs trained me in spiritual discipline (رياضة) except him. I benefited from him in discipline, and he benefited from me in his spiritual ecstasies (مواجيده). He was a student and a master to me, and I was the same to him. People used to wonder at this, and none of them knew the reason. This was in the year 586 AH, for my spiritual opening (فتحي) had preceded my discipline, which is a dangerous station. So Allah bestowed upon me the attainment of discipline at the hands of this Shaykh. May Allah reward him on my behalf with all good.

### No One Performs an Action on Behalf of Another, But Seeks It for Him Through Spiritual Aspiration and Supplication

Some of the People of Allah (أهل الله) say that no one performs an action on behalf of another, but rather seeks it for him through his spiritual aspiration (همته) and supplication. The majority hold this view, and the former (the Shaykh performing the action) is rare. This is the esoteric view of those who say no one fasts on behalf of another. And the esoteric view of those who say his guardian (وليه) fasts on his behalf. And those who said there is neither fasting nor feeding unless he makes a bequest (يوصى به)—this means the disciple says to the Shaykh upon death: "Include me in your spiritual aspiration and grant me a share of your action, so that Allah may grant me what was in my hope." If the disciple does this, it is bad manners (سوء أدب) toward the Shaykh, as he is employing him for his own benefit, and it implies an accusation that the Shaykh might forget the disciple's right.

### The Shaykh Does Not Forget the People of His Time, Let Alone His Disciple Specifically Dedicated to His Service

The basis for this is that a man asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to ask his Lord for his companionship in Paradise. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him: "Help me against your own soul by increasing prostrations." By this action, he drew his attention to his own soul and his bad manners toward him. The Path requires that the Shaykh does not forget the people of his time, let alone his disciple specifically dedicated to his service. For it is part of the spiritual chivalry (فتوة) of the people of this Path and their knowledge of souls that when the Day of Resurrection comes and their high standing (جاه) with Allah becomes manifest, those who harmed them in this world will fear them. The first people they intercede for on the Day of Resurrection are those who harmed them, before accountability begins. This is the explicit statement of Abu Yazid al-Bistami, and it is our doctrine.

### Ibn Arabi and His Intercession on the Day of Resurrection for Those His Sight Reached

As for those who did good to them, the essence of their good deed suffices them, for by their good deed, they are intercessors for themselves with Allah through the good they presented concerning this saint (ولي). <<وهَلْ جَزاءُ الْإِحْسانِ إِلَّا الْإِحْسانُ>> (Is the reward for good anything but good?). And whoever pardons and reconciles, his reward is upon Allah, and that is for those who pardon people. Moreover, the saint does not forget those who know the Shaykh, even if the Shaykh does not know them. He asks Allah Almighty to forgive and pardon whoever heard mention of him and cursed or blamed him, or praised him with good. I tasted this within myself, and my Lord granted it to me, praise be to Allah. He promised me intercession on the Day of Resurrection for everyone my sight reached, whether I know them or not, and He specified this vision for me until I witnessed it by true direct experience (ذوقا صحيحا), in which I have no doubt.

### Ibn Arabi with His Shaykh Abu Ishaq ibn Tarif in Algeciras

This is also the doctrine of our Shaykh, Abu Ishaq ibn Tarif, one of the greatest I met. I heard this Shaykh one day while I was with him at his residence in Algeciras (الجزيرة الخضراء) in the year 589 AH. He said to me: "O my brother, by Allah, I see no one among the people who knows me except that they are saints (أولياء) to the last one." I asked him, "How can you say that, O Abu Ishaq?" He replied: "The people who have seen me or heard of me either speak well of me or speak the opposite. Whoever speaks well of me and praises me has only described me with his own attribute. Had he not been worthy and a locus for that attribute, he would not have described me with it. So, this person is one of Allah's saints (أولياء الله تعالى) in my view. And whoever speaks ill of me is a saint in my view, whom Allah has informed of my state, for he possesses spiritual insight (فراسة) and Unveiling (كشف), looking with the Light of Allah. So he is a saint in my view. Thus, O my brother, I see only saints of Allah." He only said this to me because of a conversation that took place between us concerning a man from Ceuta who spoke ill of the Shaykh, contrary to how he was received. This shows the extent of his good belief. He was one of the Shaykhs whose breaths were counted against them, and who were punished for their moments of heedlessness (غفلات). He died while undergoing the punishment for a moment of heedlessness, which we mentioned in *Al-Durrah al-Fakhirah* when I mentioned him there.

### The Esoteric View of Those Who Differentiate Between a Vow and an Obligatory Fast

The vow (النذر) was made obligatory by Allah through the servant's imposition (إيجابه), while the obligatory fast, which is Ramadan, was made obligatory by Allah initially, without the servant's imposition. Since the servant had an active role (تعمل) in the obligation of the vow by imposing it, his guardian (وليه) fasts on his behalf, because it stems from the obligation of a servant, so a servant like him deputizes for him until his liability (ذمته) is cleared. As for the initially obligatory fast, the servant had no active role in it. The One who imposed it upon him is the One who caused him to die. If he had left it, he would have fasted it, so the blood money (الدية) would be upon the killer. Allah Almighty said concerning one who departs <<مُهاجِراً إِلَى الله (وَ رَسُولِهِ) ثُمَّ يُدْرِكْهُ الْمَوْتُ فَقَدْ وَقَعَ أَجْرُهُ عَلَى الله>> (as an emigrant to Allah and His Messenger, and then death overtakes him—his reward has already become incumbent upon Allah). The one who differentiated was a jurist of the soul (فقيه النفس), sound in contemplation, and knowledgeable of the Realities (الحقائق). This is his ruling in the esoteric view.

(Section on What is Due from the Nursing and Pregnant Woman if They Break the Fast)

Some say they feed the poor (يطعمان) and have no make-up fast (قضاء) upon them, and this is the view I hold, for it is the text of the Quran, and the verse, in my view, is specific (مخصصة) and not abrogated (منسوخة) concerning the pregnant woman, the nursing woman, the old man, and the old woman. Others say they only make up the fast and have no feeding upon them. Others say they make up the fast and feed the poor. Others say the pregnant woman makes up the fast but does not feed, and the nursing woman makes up the fast and feeds the poor. The feeding is a *mudd* (measure) for each day, or they scoop it up with two hands, and feed as Anas used to do.

(The Esoteric View)

The pregnant woman (الحامل) is one dominated by the state (الحال), and the nursing woman (المرضع) is one striving for the right of another. A right among the rights of Allah is determined upon them. Those who held that debt (الدين) precedes bequest (الوصية) prioritized the right of the other over the right of Allah due to pressing need, for that is the ruling of the time. Those who prioritized the right of Allah over the right of the other, and saw the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him): "Indeed, the right of Allah is more deserving of being fulfilled," and saw that Allah prioritized bequest over debt in the Quranic verse on inheritance, prioritized the right of Allah, and this is the view I incline toward. The right of the creditors (الغرماء) is preferred by me if what remains of the deceased's wealth is insufficient for them, and the ruler pays it on his behalf from the *sadaqat* (charities) in the public treasury, for they are among the eight categories (of recipients). The creditor has a matter to which he can return regarding his debt, but the bequest does not have that, so its prioritization is undoubtedly obligatory according to the just person.

### The Possessor of the State is Not Subject to a Right of Allah

As for the nursing woman, although she is concerned with the right of another, the right of the other is among the rights of Allah, since Allah legislated its fulfillment. The possessor of the state (صاحب الحال) is not subject to a right of Allah because he is not legally responsible (غير مكلف) at the time of the state. The nursing woman is like one striving for the right of another, so she is in the right of Allah, for she is engaged in a matter legislated for her. We have now entrusted you, after this clarification and detail, to your own contemplation regarding who among those we mentioned should make up the fast (قضاء) and feed the poor (إطعام), or one of the two.

(Section on the Old Man and Old Woman)

Scholars agreed that if they cannot fast, they may break the fast. They differed on whether they must feed the poor if they break the fast. Some said they must feed. Others said they do not feed, and this is the view I hold, although they recommended feeding the poor for them. The view I hold is that feeding the poor (الإطعام) was only legislated when one has the capacity to fast. As for one who cannot bear it, the legal responsibility (التكليف) for it has been lifted from him. There is no feeding legislated in the Law for one whose attribute is the lack of capacity for it. For Allah has not burdened <<نَفْساً إِلَّا وُسْعَها>> (a soul beyond its capacity), and He did not burden it with feeding. If He had burdened it despite the lack of capacity, we would not have deviated from it and would have affirmed it.

(The Esoteric View)

Whoever's witnessing (مشهده) is that he has no capacity, like us, or says that created capacity (القدرة الحادثة) has no effect of origination in the object of capacity, and whose witnessing is that fasting is for Allah, then the ruling of fasting and feeding is negated for him. Allah says: <<وهُوَ يُطْعِمُ ولا يُطْعَمُ>> (And He feeds, but is not fed). And confirming His intimate friend (Khalil), He said: <<الَّذِي (هُوَ) يُطْعِمُنِي>> (Who feeds me), and He confirmed it and did not reject it. Feeding is only a compensation (عوض) for an obligation one has the capacity for. Since there is no obligation, there is no compensation, and thus no feeding. The constant invocation (هجير) of the possessor of this station is <<لا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللَّهِ>> (There is no power except with Allah). He has no entry into <<إِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (You alone we ask for help), nor into the *nūn* of *naf‘al* (we do) or the *alif* of *af‘al* (I do). But he has, from these four augmentative letters, the letter *tā’* dotted from above, indicating the second-person pronoun (You), and sometimes the *yā’* dotted from below, *yaf‘al* (He does), indicating the pronoun of Divine Identity (الهوية). Know this, and success is from Allah.

(Section on One Who Intentionally Engages in Intercourse During Ramadan)

They agreed that he must make up the fast (قضاء) and offer expiation (كفارة). It was also said that only the make-up fast is obligatory upon him, because the expiation in this case was not definitive, due to circumstantial evidence, since the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded him to fast when he could not free a slave or feed the poor, and this was necessary since he was healthy. Had he been sick, he would have told him to fast when he regained health. Some said only expiation is obligatory upon him, and no make-up fast. The view I hold is that there is no make-up fast upon him, and it is recommended for him to offer expiation if he is able to do so. Allah knows best His ruling in this.

(The Esoteric View)

The two capacities (القدرتان) combine to bring about a possible from a possible, in what is attributed of that action to the servant, according to everyone whose intellect does not reach the Gnosis (معرفة) of that. This is either by freeing a slave (عتق رقبة) from slavery absolutely or conditionally. If he frees him from slavery absolutely, it means that he establishes himself in the state where the Real (الحق) is his very eye in his faculties and limbs, by which he is distinguished from other species by form and definition. When he is in this state and this is his description, he is a master (سيدا), and his servitude (عبودية) vanishes absolutely, because servitude is gone here, since a thing cannot be the servant of itself; he is He. Abu Yazid, realizing this station, said, pointing and reciting: <<إِنَّنِي أَنَا الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا أَنَا فَاعْبُدْنِي>> (Indeed, I am Allah. There is no god except Me, so worship Me). This is what Allah revealed to Moses, and it is a discourse that encompasses all creation.

### The Restricted Servant

If the servant is restricted (مقيدا), it means he frees himself from the slavery of the Cosmos (رق الكون), thus becoming free from others, a servant of Allah. For our servitude to Allah is impossible to lift or free from, because it is an essential attribute (صفة ذاتية) for Him. Freedom from it is impossible in this state, but not in the first state. He drew attention to this by His saying: <<قُلِ اللَّهُمَّ مَالِكَ الْمُلْكِ>> (Say, "O Allah, Possessor of the Dominion"), naming Him *Malik* (King) so that the Name *Al-Malik* (The Owner) is valid for Him, and He did not say *Malik al-'Alam* (Owner of the World). He also said, and this is from the perspective of allusion (إشارة) and verification (تحقيق): <<قُلْ أَعُوذُ بِرَبِّ النَّاسِ * مَلِكِ النَّاسِ>> (Say, "I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind, the Sovereign of mankind"). From the perspective of verification, when He named them *al-Nās* (mankind) and did not name them with a name that implies they are the Real (الحق), He attributed Himself to them by the Name *Al-Malik* (Sovereign). From the perspective of allusion, *al-Nās* is the active participle of *nisyān* (forgetting), defined by the definite article, because he forgot that the Real (الحق) is his hearing, his sight, and all his faculties, while he is entirely Light (نورا).

### Allah is Light in His Essence and Luminous in His Servant

This is the station that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) asked his Lord to establish him in forever, saying: "And make me Light." For Allah is one of His Names, Al-Nur (The Light); rather, He is The Light, according to the established Hadith: "Light, I see Him." Some narrators corrupted it, saying: "Luminous (نوراني), I see Him." A wondrous meaning arose from this corruption: when He makes His servant Light, the Real (الحق) is seen in him and from him. At that point, he is luminous (نوراني) and nothing else. So He is Light (نور) in His Essence (ذات) and luminous (نوراني) in His servant. Understand what we have said.

### The Thingness of Establishment and the Taking of the Covenant

When the forgetful person (الناسي) did not remember this state, being heedless of it in himself, the Real (الحق) addressed him, reminding him of it in the Quran, whose recitation He made an act of worship for him, <<لِيَدَّبَّرُوا آياتِهِ ولِيَتَذَكَّرَ أُولُوا الْأَلْبابِ>> (that they might reflect upon its verses and that those of understanding might remember) what they had forgotten. This indicates that they possessed prior knowledge concerning the thingness of establishment (شيئية الثبوت) and the taking of the covenant (أخذ العهد).

### Feeding in Expiation and Assuming the Character of the Divine Name Al-Muhyi

As for feeding (الإطعام) in expiation (الكفارة), food is a cause for preserving life for its consumer. Thus, in feeding, he assumes the character (متخلق) of the Name Al-Muhyi (The Giver of Life), because by his action (intercourse), he killed an act of worship that had no like, which he was upon. Thus, he was described by Al-Mumit (The Giver of Death) in that action because he did it intentionally. So he was commanded to feed, so that the opposing Name, which is Al-Muhyi, might manifest. Understand this.

### Fasting Two Months and the Soul's Journey Through the Divine Stations

As for fasting two months in expiation, the month, among the Muhammadans (المحمديين), is an expression for the completion of the moon's journey through the determined stations (منازل), and that is the journey of the soul (النفس) through the Divine Levels (المنازل الإلهية). The first month, he travels through them by himself, to establish the Lordship (ربوبية) of his Creator over him in his own view. The other month, he travels through them by his Lord, for He is his foot with which he walks, based on the principle that the Real (الحق) is all his faculties and limbs. He traversed these stations by his faculties, and the Real is the very eye of his faculties, so he traversed them by his Lord, not by himself.

(The Fasting Person Came Upon)

As for the statement of this doer to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) when he commanded him to fast as expiation (كفارة)—meaning, 'Be characterized by the Attribute of the Real (صفة الحق),' for the fast belongs to Him—he said, "The fast has overcome me." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) laughed, and his laughter was a sign of the lightness of the matter, and because he knew that the Real (الحق) had made him speak, even though the speaker did not intend that, and the Bedouin was ignorant of it. It is as if the Prophet said to him, in his command to expiate by fasting, "Be the Real (كن حقا)." So, he was moved to say, "The Real has overcome me," for when I was the Real, the obligation (التكليف) was removed from me, since the Real is not obligated. Why then do you keep me as the Real? Bring me down to servitude (العبودية) and impose upon me the expiation (الكفارة), which is concealment (الستر)—meaning, "Do not mention that you disobeyed Me through Me."

### [The poorest between its two lava fields is poorer than me]

For this reason, he said to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), "Will you give it to someone poorer than me? The poorest between its two lava fields is poorer than me." He attributed the perfection of poverty (كمال الفقر) to himself because he returned to servitude (العبودية) from his lordship (سيادته), thus magnifying his abasement and poverty. Maintaining poverty (استصحاب الفقر) does not cause pain in the poor person like the pain of one who was rich and then became poor; his pain is more intense and his regret is greater. His situation is like that of one who was captured after being free, feeling the pain of enslavement because it came after freedom.

> He who was a king and returned to being a king,
> Has attained ruin and died by violence.

The original, established, inherited slave (العبد الأصلي المؤثل القن) does not feel that pain. For this reason, he said, "The poorest between its two lava fields is poorer than me." Allah made him utter this without him realizing it, so that it would be consistent with what Allah also made him utter in his statement, "The fast has overcome me."

### [Allah's Wisdom in Manifesting Realities through the Tongues of His Servants]

Observe Allah's wisdom in manifesting these Realities (الحقائق) through His servants without them being aware; He is the Speaker in reality, not they. This is the ruling concerning expiation (الكفارة) for one whose action is of this nature. Praise be to Allah, all the opinions we mentioned regarding this issue are included in this interpretation if you reflect upon it. There is no need for lengthy discussion, as it would be repetitive, although mentioning them might contain additional benefits beyond what we have stated due to the difference in relationships (النسب). However, this suffices for the consideration (اعتبار) of this issue.

(Section concerning one who ate or drank intentionally)

Some scholars said that he must make up the fast (القضاء) and pay the expiation (الكفارة) required for intercourse. Others said there is no expiation upon him. What I hold is that neither making up the fast nor expiation is required of him, for he shall never make it up. Rather, he should increase his voluntary fasting (صوم التطوع) so that his obligatory duty (فريضة) may be completed by his voluntary acts. For us, obligatory duties (الفرائض) restricted to specific times, if their time passes due to the intentional action of the obligated person, they are never to be made up absolutely. He should increase the voluntary acts that correspond to them, except for the Hajj, which, although tied to a time, is only required once in a lifetime—unless one holds the view of continuous ability (الاستطاعة). But whenever he performs Hajj, he is fulfilling the duty, though he is sinful for delaying it while able.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

Eating and drinking nourished him, so eating and drinking gave him life in this instance, because his life is derived (مستفادة), just as his existence (وجوده) is derived, in order to distinguish the contingent being whose existence is necessary through another (الممكن الواجب بالغير) from the Necessary Being by Himself (الواجب بنفسه). The fast is for Allah, not for the servant, so there is neither making up nor expiation upon him.

### [Consideration of those who required making up the fast and those who required expiation]

He who required expiation (الكفارة) obligated him to conceal his station (مقامه), and his ruling concerning it is the same as that of the one who engaged in intercourse, in terms of the consideration (الاعتبار). He who required making up the fast (القضاء) says that the only reason he was obligated to make it up is that he is 'other' (غيرا), just as he was in the original imposition of the duty (أصل التكليف), and just as it is in the fast of Ramadan. Thus, he makes it up by returning it to the One for whom the fast is intended. For the fast of the servant, which is for Allah, is like someone who borrowed something from another; his repayment of that debt is merely returning it to its rightful owner, despite the benefit he derived from it. The servant only fasts by borrowing that, because Self-Sufficiency (الصمدانية) does not belong to him, and the fast is Self-Sufficiency. Thus, it belongs to Allah, not to him. Know this.

(Section concerning one who engaged in intercourse forgetful of his fast)

It was said that neither making up the fast nor expiation is required of him, and this is what I hold. It was also said that he must make up the fast but without expiation. And it was said that he must make up the fast and pay the expiation.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

This falls under the category of Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية). When the servant characterized himself with that which belongs to Allah—even though it is legislated, namely the fast—Allah made him forget that he was fasting, placing him in a station and state that invalidated his fast. This was a warning to him that this Reality (الحقيقة) is characterized only by Allah, out of Divine Jealousy that He should be challenged regarding what belongs to Him through any form of partnership. Since the servant had no intention in this, nor did he violate the sanctity of the obligated duty, both making up the fast and expiation are dropped from him. You already know the meaning of intercourse in the case of one who engaged in it intentionally.

### [Consideration of the opinion: Making up the fast without expiation]

He who required making up the fast without expiation said that the servant witnesses Self-Sufficiency (الصمدية) as belonging to Him (Allah), not to himself, even while it subsists in him. Thus, he is characterized by it, yet not characterized by it, similar to His saying: <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ>> (And you threw not when you threw), where He negated and affirmed simultaneously.

### [Consideration of the opinion requiring both making up the fast and expiation]

He who required both making up the fast and expiation said that forgetfulness (النسيان) is abandonment (الترك), and fasting is abandonment. The abandonment of abandonment is the existence of the opposite of abandonment, just as the non-existence of non-existence is existence. One whose state is this has not maintained the abandonment which is the fast, and thus has not complied with the obligation. Therefore, there is no difference between him and the intentional doer, and both making up the fast and expiation are required of him. The consideration (الاعتبار) for this has already been presented. Furthermore, the Hadith does not state whether that Bedouin was mindful of his fast when he had intercourse with his wife or forgetful, nor did the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) inquire whether he was mindful or forgetful. They both shared the intention for intercourse, so the forgetful person is obligated just as the mindful person is obligated to fast—especially in the consideration, for the Path (الطريق) necessitates accountability for forgetfulness, because it is the path of Presence (الحضور), and forgetfulness is alien to it.

(Section concerning whether the expiation is sequential, as in the case of *Zihar*, or optional)

For he said to him, "Emancipate," then he said to him, "Fast," then he said to him, "Feed." It is not known whether the Prophet (peace be upon him) intended sequence (الترتيب) or not. It was said that it is sequential: first, emancipation (العتق); if he cannot find a slave, then fasting (الصوم); if he cannot fast, then feeding (الإطعام). It was also said that it is optional (التخيير). Among them are those who preferred feeding over emancipation and fasting. It is conceivable here to prefer some of these categories over others according to the state of the obligated person (المكلف) or the intent of the Lawgiver (مقصود الشارع).

### [The purpose of legal penalties is only deterrence, according to some]

[This view holds] that the intent is severity, and that expiation (الكفارة) is a punishment. If the person involved in the incident was rich or a king, he would be addressed with fasting, as it is harder for him and more deterrent. For the purpose of legal penalties (الحدود) and punishments is only deterrence (الزجر). If he was of moderate financial means and would be harmed by spending more than by fasting, he would be commanded to emancipate or feed. If fasting was harder for him, he would be commanded to fast.

### [What should be prioritized is the removal of hardship]

And whoever holds that what should be prioritized in this matter is the removal of hardship (رفع الحرج), [cites] His saying, the Exalted: <<وَمَا جَعَلَ عَلَيْكُمْ فِي الدِّينِ مِنْ حَرَجٍ>> (And He has not laid upon you in religion any hardship). Thus, the obligated person is charged with the expiation that is easiest for him. This is the view I hold in issuing legal rulings (الفتيا), even if I would not act upon it for myself if it occurred to me, unless I were unable. For Allah does not charge a soul except with what it can bear: <<لَا يُكَلِّفُ اللَّهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا وُسْعَهَا>>. And concerning what He has given it: <<سَيَجْعَلُ اللَّهُ بَعْدَ عُسْرٍ يُسْرًا>> (Allah will bring about ease after hardship). And He did so, for He said: <<فَإِنَّ مَعَ الْعُسْرِ يُسْرًا>> (Indeed, with hardship [is] ease), then <<إِنَّ مَعَ الْعُسْرِ يُسْرًا>> (Indeed, with hardship [is] ease). He brought one hardship (عسر) and two eases (يسر) accompanying it. Therefore, the Real (الحق) does not observe ease in religion and the removal of hardship while the jurist issues a ruling contrary to that.

### [The idea that legal penalties were instituted for deterrence has no textual basis from Allah or His Messenger]

The idea that legal penalties (الحدود) were instituted for deterrence (الزجر) has no textual basis (نص) from Allah or His Messenger. Rather, it is a conclusion derived from intellectual speculation (النظر الفكري), which may be correct or incorrect. Especially since we see light penalties (خفيف الحد) for the most harmful crimes in the world. If deterrence were intended, the punishment would be more severe for them. Furthermore, some major sins (الكبائر) have no prescribed penalty (حد). Moreover, the Law (الشرع) concerning some penalties for major sins is such that they are not carried out except upon the demand of the created being (المخلوق), and if that demand is dropped, the penalty is dropped. The harm caused by dropping the penalty is more apparent in such cases, like when the guardian of the murdered person (ولي المقتول) pardons the killer, and the ruler (الإمام) is not permitted to execute him. Such instances of leniency and dropping the penalty weaken the argument of those who say that legal penalties were instituted for deterrence.

### [The reason for instituting, dropping, lightening, and intensifying legal penalties]

If we were to begin discussing the reason for instituting legal penalties (الحدود), dropping them in some places, lightening them in others, and intensifying them in yet others, we would reveal great secrets (أسرار عظيمة), because they vary according to the different states (الأحوال) in which they were legislated. Discussion of this is lengthy and involves complexities, such as the thief and the murderer. Destroying a soul is more severe than destroying property. Yet, if the guardian of the murdered person pardons, the killer is not executed. But if the owner of the stolen property pardons, or if the stolen item itself is found with the thief and returned to its owner, the thief's hand must still be cut off in all cases, and the ruler (الحاكم) is not permitted to abandon that. From this, you know that the right of Allah (حق الله) in things is greater than the right of the created being (حق المخلوق) in them, contrary to what the jurists (الفقهاء) believe.

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The right of Allah is more deserving of being fulfilled."

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

Sequence (الترتيب) in expiation (الكفارة) is preferable to option (التخيير), for wisdom (الحكمة) necessitates sequence, and Allah is All-Wise (حكيم). However, option is preferable to sequence in some matters, as wisdom necessitated it. The servant in sequence is a servant of necessity (عبد اضطرار), like the servitude of obligatory duties (عبودة الفرائض). The servant in option is a servant of choice (عبد اختيار), like the servitude of supererogatory acts (عبودة النوافل), though it contains a trace of the servitude of necessity. Between the worship of supererogatory acts and the worship of obligatory duties, there is a vast difference in the elevation of rank (علو المرتبة) regarding Divine Proximity (التقريب الإلهي). For Allah made proximity in obligatory duties greater than proximity in supererogatory acts, and that is more beloved to Him. For this reason, He placed obligatory duties within supererogatory acts and commanded us not to invalidate our deeds, even if the deed is supererogatory, in observance of the servitude of necessity (عبودية الاضطرار) over the servitude of choice (عبودية الاختيار), because the manifestation of the sovereignty of Lordship (سلطان الربوبية) is clearer in the former, and its indication of it is greater.

(Section concerning expiation upon the woman if she willingly complied with her husband's desire for intercourse)

Some say expiation is upon her, and some say no expiation is upon her, and this is what I hold. For the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), in the Hadith of the Bedouin, did not mention the woman, nor did he address her or ask about her. It is not proper for us to legislate what Allah has not permitted.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

The soul (النفس) is inherently receptive to both wickedness (الفجور) and piety (التقوى). By its very essence, it is subject to the ruling of another, and thus cannot separate itself from being controlled. Therefore, there is no punishment upon it. Desire (الهوى) and Intellect (العقل) are the two controllers of the soul: the Intellect calls it to salvation, and Desire calls it to the Fire. Whoever holds that the soul has no ruling regarding what it is called to says there is no expiation upon her. And whoever holds that she has the choice (التخيير) in acceptance, and that the ruling of neither controller manifests except through her acceptance—since she had the power to refuse what she was called to, or to accept—then when she gave preference, she is rewarded if it was good, and punished if it was evil. Thus, it was said that expiation is upon her.

(Section concerning the repetition of expiation due to the repetition of breaking the fast)

It was said that if someone had intercourse, then paid expiation, and then had intercourse again on the same day, another expiation is required of him. It was also said that if someone had intercourse repeatedly on the same day, only one expiation is required. They also differed concerning one who had intercourse on one day of Ramadan and did not pay expiation until he had intercourse on a second day. Some said that an expiation is required for each day. Others said that only one expiation is required, provided he had not yet paid expiation for the first intercourse. What I hold is that only one expiation is required, because it was legislated only in consideration of Ramadan during the state of fasting, not in consideration of the fast itself. If he broke a make-up fast (صوم القضاء), he would not pay expiation. If this expiation were like the expiation for *Zihar* (a form of divorce), another expiation would not be required if he had already paid expiation for the first intercourse. Since they required it after the occurrence, we hold that it is binding upon him if he engages in intercourse after having paid expiation for a previous intercourse, whether that previous one was multiple or single.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

A single spirit (الروح الواحد) governs multiple bodies if it has the power to do so. This occurs in this world for the saint (الولي) through the breaking of custom (خرق العادة), and in the Hereafter, the nature of human existence (نشأة الإنسان) grants this. Qadib al-Ban was among those who possessed this power, as was Dhu al-Nun al-Misri.

### [The single spirit governs all other limbs of the body]

Just as the single spirit (الروح الواحد) governs all other limbs of the body—hand, foot, hearing, sight, and so forth—and just as the soul (النفس) is held accountable for the actions of the limbs (الجوارح) that occur from them, similarly, regarding the many bodies governed by a single spirit, whatever action occurs from them, that single spirit is questioned about it. Even if the exact action occurring from one body is the same as that occurring from the other body, the accountability required for the action of one body is required for the action of the other, even if it is similar.

### [What is required of the single spirit due to the repetition of the act through the multiplicity of bodies]

The schools of thought (المذاهب) were divided based on this limit regarding what is required of the single spirit due to the repetition of the act through the multiplicity of bodies, which is analogous to the multiplicity of time concerning the one who engages in intercourse during Ramadan. Know this.

(Section concerning whether feeding is required of him if he becomes wealthy, having been poor at the time the obligation became due)

Some say nothing is required of him, and this is what I hold. Others say he must pay expiation when he becomes wealthy.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

The one whose actions are stripped away (المسلوب الأفعال) through witnessing (مشاهدة) and unveiling (كشف) is poor (معسر) and possesses nothing, so nothing is required of him. If he is veiled from this witnessing (الشهود) and affirms this through the path of Knowledge (العلم) after witnessing—like one who imagines a sensible thing after having perceived it through the senses—then the legal rulings (الأحكام الشرعية) are undoubtedly binding upon him. The ruling is not precluded in his case by the existence of Knowledge, but it is precluded by the existence of Witnessing (المشاهدة), for he witnesses the Real (الحق) moving him and stilling him. Likewise, if his station (مقامه) is higher than this, which is that the Real becomes his hearing and his sight through unveiling (الكشف) and witnessing (الشهود): some of us say his ruling is the same as that of the possessor of Knowledge, for Allah has made it obligatory upon Himself, though He does not thereby fall under the definition of the obligated. And some of us attach him to the witnessing of the Acts (الأفعال) originating from the Exalted, as we presented earlier, so the ruling is not binding upon him, just as it was not binding there. Thus, sometimes the name of the Real (الحق) is applied to this servant, and sometimes the name of the servant (العبد) is applied, depending on the variation of these states (الأحوال). In each of these levels (المراتب), the ruling is binding upon him from one perspective and negated from another.

(Section concerning one who performed an action during his fast about which there is disagreement, such as cupping [الحجامة], intentional vomiting [الاستقاء], swallowing a pebble, or the traveler who breaks his fast on the first day he departs, according to those who hold he is not permitted to break the fast)

All those who required breaking the fast (الفطر) for these actions and their like differed: some said he must make up the fast (القضاء), and some said he must make up the fast and pay expiation (الكفارة). This applies to every disputed matter. What I hold regarding what we mentioned is that intentional vomiting (الاستقاء) requires making up the fast, based on the report. The consideration (اعتبار) for the actions we mentioned has already been presented. As for one who breaks the fast on a day when breaking the fast is permissible for her—such as a woman who breaks her fast before menstruating and then menstruates on that day, or the sick person and the traveler who break their fast before falling ill or before traveling, and then fall ill or travel on that day—our school of thought holds that making up the fast is required, but no expiation. We only required making up the fast because she menstruated, or he fell ill, or he traveled. However, his ruling regarding sin (الإثم) is the same as that of one who broke the fast intentionally, such that if she had not menstruated, or he had not fallen ill or traveled, he would never make up that day, but should increase voluntary fasting. Nevertheless, their affair is up to Allah, because they broke the fast on a day when breaking the fast was permissible for them in the sight of Allah. As for the outward ruling (الظاهر), it is what we stated.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

In this action, there is a trace of the unveiling (الكشف) belonging to the souls (النفوس) and an insight into the Unseen (الغيب) without the person realizing it. The reason is that the soul is from the World of the Unseen (عالم الغيب), even though the physical constitution (النشأة الجسمية) is its mother, and the Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي) is its father. Thus, it has insight from behind a thin veil, such that if the doer of this action were to enter the path of the People of Allah (أهل الله), unveiling (الكشف) would hasten to him due to his readiness and qualification for it. Such a thing is not called accidental (اتفاقيا), for accidental matters are not valid according to us. Indeed, the entire affair belongs to Allah, and Allah does not bring anything into existence by accident. Rather, He brings it into existence based on sound Knowledge (علم صحيح), Will (إرادة), unseen Decree (قضاء غيبي), and Destiny (قدر). Therefore, whatever exists must necessarily be in His Knowledge.

### [The attachment of the legal ruling to the one who possesses unveiling and insight into the Unseen]

What remains is whether sin (إثم) is attached to the one through whom such a Divine Act (الفعل الإلهي) manifests. According to us, sin is attached to him, even if he obtained sound Knowledge (العلم الصحيح) that he was on a day when breaking the fast was permissible for him, yet he had not yet engaged in the cause (السبب). For breaking the fast was only legislated for him upon engaging in the state by which he is named menstruating, sick, or traveling, according to the outward language (اللسان الظاهر). This is the doctrine of the Verifiers (المحققين) among the People of Allah (أهل الله), and it is our doctrine in such an issue. The ruling concerning the doer is up to Allah: if He wills, He pardons, and if He wills, He holds accountable, out of grace and justice. This is unless his state is that of one who has been informed, through witnessing (مشاهدة) and unveiling (كشف), of the crimes that will occur from him, and whose insight into what is decreed (المقدر) includes the knowledge that he will not be held accountable for it by Allah. If he does not have this insight, he should not rush, nor should he act deliberately in that matter unless he knows Allah's Knowledge concerning it. If he knows that he will inevitably be held accountable, then he knows that Allah has observed the ruling of the outward (حكم الظاهر) in general, and he should prepare himself for Allah's decree (قضاء الله) that is executed upon him. This, according to us, does not happen at all, even though it is rationally possible.

### [Allah's dialogue with Iblis]

It was said to Iblis, "Why did you refuse to prostrate?" He replied, "O Lord, had You willed me to prostrate, I would have prostrated." He said to him, "When did you know that I did not will you to prostrate? Was it after the refusal and disobedience occurred, or before that?" He replied, "O Lord, I knew after the refusal occurred." He said, "By that, I hold you accountable."

### [The servants of Allah whom He informs of the acts of disobedience decreed upon them]

Know that among the servants of Allah are those whom Allah informs of the acts of disobedience (المعاصي) decreed upon them. They hasten to commit them out of intense shame (حياء) before Allah, so that they may quickly repent, leaving the sin behind them, and find rest from the darkness of witnessing it. When they repent, they see it transformed into a good deed (حسنة) according to its measure. Such an occurrence does not diminish their station (منزلته) with Allah, for the commission of such acts by such people was not a violation of Divine Sanctity (الحرمة الإلهية), but rather the execution of the Decree (القضاء) and Destiny (القدر) upon them. This relates to His saying: <<لِّيَغْفِرَ لَكَ اللَّهُ مَا تَقَدَّمَ مِن ذَنبِكَ وَمَا تَأَخَّرَ>> (That Allah may forgive you your sin that preceded and that which will follow). Thus, forgiveness preceded the occurrence of the sin. This verse may have an interpretation concerning the infallible (المعصوم): that he is veiled from sins, so sins seek him but cannot reach him, and thus no sin occurs from him at all, for he is veiled from it. Or, he is veiled from punishment, so it does not reach him, for punishment is directed toward the loci of sins. Allah veils whomever He wills among His servants, through His forgiveness, from the infliction of punishment and accountability. The first interpretation is more perfect: forgiveness preceded the occurrence of the sin, whether it was an act or an omission, so nothing occurs from him except a good deed (حسنة), which he witnesses, and its goodness.

### [The servants of Allah who only perform what is permissible for them]

And among the servants of Allah are those who, in reality (في نفس الأمر), only perform what has been made permissible for them to perform, specifically regarding that individual. This is the closest view among the People of Allah (أهل الله). For it is established in the Law (الشرع) that Allah says to a servant, due to a specific state (حالة خاصة), "Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you." This is the permissible (المباح). And whoever performs a permissible act is not held accountable by Allah for it, even if, generally and outwardly, it is an act of disobedience (معصية). Thus, in the Law, it is not an act of disobedience concerning that specific person. The acts of disobedience of the People of the House (أهل البيت) in the sight of Allah are of this category.

The Prophet (peace be upon him) said concerning the People of Badr: "And what makes you know? Perhaps Allah looked upon the People of Badr and said, 'Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you.'"

And in the established Hadith, a servant committed a sin and said, "O Lord, forgive me." Allah says, "My servant committed a sin and knew that he has a Lord who forgives sin and holds accountable for sin." Then he returned and sinned again, until, on the third or fourth time, He said, "Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you."

Thus, He made permissible for him everything that He had previously restricted, so that he only performs what is permissible for him to do. No word of sin (لسان ذنب) is applied to him in the sight of Allah, even though our ignorance of who possesses this attribute and this ruling in the sight of Allah prevents us from knowing him. This does not diminish his station (منزلته) with Allah.

### [The rulings of the Law are based on states]

One whose state (حالته) is this has only performed what was permissible for him to do or omit. For the ruling (الحكم) is based on states (الأحوال). The state of the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), despite the variation in their states, is not the state of one whose state is veiled from him. Whoever equates the two has transgressed in his judgment. Do you not see that carrion (الميتة) is never forbidden to the one in necessity (المضطر) whenever necessity exists, and carrion is never permissible for the one who is not in necessity? This is the outward ruling of the Law (ظاهر الشرع). Thus, the rulings of the Divine Laws (أحكام الشرائع) are based on states. As for those whose state we are ignorant of, we must maintain a good opinion of them as long as we find a way to do so.

(Section concerning one who intentionally broke a make-up fast of Ramadan)

Most scholars hold that no expiation is required of him, and this is the view I adopt, but he must make up the fast. Some said he must make up two days. The proponent of this view has a subtle, hidden justification that led him to this opinion: that he was given the choice (مخير) to make up the fast on that day, and he chose to make it up, then he changed his mind and broke the fast. Had it been a supererogatory fast (متنفلا), we would have required him to make up that day merely by starting it. This is the first day. The other day is the day of Ramadan that was due upon him. Thus, the proponent of this view was not deficient in his consideration. Qatadah said that both making up the fast and expiation are required of him.

(The Consideration - الاعتبار)

Whoever's witnessing (مشهده) is the Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) *Ramadan* during the state of making up the fast (القضاء), his ruling is the same as the ruling for performance (*Ada'*). The ruling for performance concerning one who intentionally broke the fast in Ramadan has already been discussed, and the disagreement concerning it depends on what is present with him, and the consideration (اعتباره) proceeds according to that method.

### [He whose witnessing is other than the Divine Name specific to his month]

And he whose witnessing (مشهده) is not the Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) specific to the month in which he performed the make-up fast—neither the month of Ramadan nor the Name *Ramadan*—but rather his witnessing is the Name that rules over him with abstinence (الإمساك), then he does not pay expiation. However, for those whose doctrine is that expiation is required in the month of Ramadan, the saying of the Exalted, <<فَعِدَّةٌ مِّنْ أَيَّامٍ أُخَرَ>> (Then [make up] a number of other days), is sufficient. For He called them "other" (أخر), so they are not the days of Ramadan. Rather, they are days of fasting in the indefinite sense (على النكرة)—any day he wishes. A day is not called a day except by its completion, so if it is not completed in his case, it is not a day of his fast.

### [The Divine Names corresponding to the lunar months]

The Names corresponding to the lunar months (الشهور القمرية) are: *Ramadan* for the month of Ramadan; *Al-Rafi'* (The Exalter) for Shawwal; *Al-Rahman* (The Most Merciful) for Dhu al-Qa'dah; *Al-Murid* (The Willing One) for Dhu al-Hijjah; *Al-Muharram* (The Forbidden) for Muharram; *Al-Mukhalli* (The Relinquisher) for Safar; *Al-Muhyi* (The Giver of Life) for Rabi' al-Awwal; *Al-Mu'id* (The Restorer) for Rabi' al-Akhir; *Al-Mumsik* (The Withholder) for Jumada al-Ula; *Al-Rabb* (The Lord), meaning The Constant (الثابت), for Jumada al-Akhirah; *Al-Azim* (The Magnificent) for Rajab; *Al-Fasil* (The Separator) and *Al-Hakim* (The Judge) for Sha'ban; and what is contained in the meaning of each of these Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية).

(Section concerning recommended fasting)

I shall mention what is encouraged by state (بالحال), such as fasting during *Jihad* (struggle), and what is encouraged by time (بالزمان), such as fasting on Mondays, Thursdays, Arafah, Ashura, the [first] ten days, Sha'ban, and their like. And what is specified in itself without being restricted to a particular day of the week, such as Ashura and Arafah. Because they are specified by month, we attach them to time (الزمان). Because they are unknown in terms of the days of the week, we do not restrict them by time. Some are specified within the months, like the month of Sha'ban. Some are unrestricted in days but restricted by months, like the White Days (الأيام البيض) and fasting three days of every month. Some are absolute, like fasting any day one wishes. Some are restricted by timing, like the fast of David: fasting one day and breaking the fast one day, and what follows this pattern. As for fasting the Day of Arafah while in Arafah, there is disagreement concerning it, but outside of Arafah, it is encouraged. In any case, it expiates the sins of the year preceding it and the year following it. As for fasting the six days of Shawwal, it is encouraged. There is disagreement concerning its timing within Shawwal and its continuity. There is also an anomalous disagreement: that the first day is performed in Shawwal and the remaining days are performed throughout the rest of the year.

(Section concerning fasting in the Way of Allah)

### [The fast of the servants]

Muslim recorded in his *Sahih* from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "No servant (عبد) fasts a day in the Way of Allah (في سبيل الله) except that Allah distances his face from the Fire by that day for seventy autumns (خريفا)."

He mentioned the fast of the servants (العبيد), not the fast of the free. Servants are few in state (بالحال) but all of humanity in belief (بالاعتقاد). Fasting is a Divine resemblance (تشبيه إلهي), and for this reason, He negated it from the servant by His saying, the Exalted: "The fast is for Me." The servants have nothing of the fast except hunger. Thus, the transcendence (التنزيه) in the fast belongs to Allah, and the hunger belongs to the servant.

### [When the servant is established in the station of Divine resemblance]

When the servant is established in the resemblance to the Divine (التشبيه بالإله)—expressed as being characterized by the Names (التخلق بالأسماء) in the attribute of subjugation (القهر) and dominance over the contender, who is the enemy—for this reason, He placed it in *Jihad* (struggle), meaning the fast. For the Way (السبيل) here, outwardly, is *Jihad*. We know this by contextual indicators (قرائن الأحوال), not by the absolute meaning of the word. If we take it according to the absolute meaning of the word, not according to custom—which is the perspective of the People of Allah (أهل الله) regarding the Names (الأسماء), observing what Allah restricted and what He left absolute—then the discourse occurs according to how it came. It came with the indefinite form (التنكير) for "the Way" (السبيل), and then defined it by attributing it to Allah, the Exalted.

### [Allah is the Comprehensive Name for all the Realities of the Names]

And Allah is the Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع) for all the Realities of the Names (حقائق الأسماء). All of them have a specific righteousness (بر مخصوص) and a way (سبيل) to them. So, whatever righteousness the servant is engaged in, he is in the way of righteousness, which is the Way of Allah (سبيل الله). For this reason, He brought the Comprehensive Name, making it general, just as the indefinite form (النكرة) makes things general, meaning it does not specify. Likewise, He made "a day" indefinite and did not define it, so as to expand the means of proximity to Allah for all His servants. Then He made "seventy autumns" indefinite, bringing the specification (التمييز), and specification is only indefinite. He did not specify a time, so we do not know whether seventy autumns refers to the time of the days of the Arabs, or the days of the Ascending Stairways (ذي المعارج), or the days of one of the lunar mansions (منزلة), or the days of one of the retreating, sweeping stars (الجواري الخنس والكنس), or the days of the Great Movement (الحركة الكبرى), or the known days we possess. Thus, the matter was left ambiguous, matching the indefiniteness found in the context of the Hadith.

### [The path of verification in contemplating the speech of Allah and those who translate for Him]

Likewise, His saying "his face" (وجهه) is ambiguous. Does it mean his face which is his Essence (ذاته), or his face known by custom? Similarly, His saying "from the Fire" (من النار) with the definite article: Did He mean the known Fire, or the Abode (الدار) that contains the Fire? For one may perform a deed that merits entering that Abode, yet the Fire does not touch him.
