In reality (الحقيقة), there is none among us who shall not approach it, for it is the path to Paradise, even if the meaning were only that the Bridge (الصراط) is over it in the Hereafter, and in this world, it is surrounded by hardships (المكاره). I have placed you upon the path of verification (مدرجة التحقيق) in contemplating the speech of Allah and the speech of those who translate for Allah, whether a sent Messenger or an inspired Saint (ولي محدث).

(Section concerning the choice given to the pregnant and nursing woman regarding the fast of Ramadan, even if they are able to fast, between fasting and breaking the fast)

It resembles the obligatory (المفروض) from one perspective, which is that if she chooses it and accepts the option (التخيير), its ruling concerning her is the ruling of the permissible (المباح) act where one is given the choice to perform or omit it. Thus, it resembles the supererogatory (التطوع). And performing the recommended act is better than omitting it. For this reason, He said concerning it: <<وَأَن تَصُومُوا خَيْرٌ لَّكُمْ>> (And that you fast is better for you).

Muslim recorded from Salamah ibn al-Akwa' that he said: "We used to be in Ramadan during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). Whoever wished fasted, and whoever wished broke the fast and paid a ransom (افتداء) by feeding a poor person, until this verse was revealed: <<فَمَن شَهِدَ مِنكُمُ الشَّهْرَ فَلْيَصُمْهُ>> (So whoever among you witnesses the month, let him fast it)." Some considered this an abrogation (نسخ), and some considered it a specification (تخصيص), which is our doctrine. Thus, the ruling of the verse remained for the pregnant and nursing woman if they feared for their child. Allah called it a supererogatory act (تطوعا) and said: <<فَمَن تَطَوَّعَ خَيْرًا فَهُوَ خَيْرٌ لَّهُ>> (And whoever volunteers good, it is better for him). He made "good" indefinite (خيرا), which includes feeding and fasting. Al-Bukhari mentioned from Ibn Abbas concerning the saying of the Exalted: <<وَعَلَى الَّذِينَ يُطِيقُونَهُ فِدْيَةٌ طَعَامُ مِسْكِينٍ>> (And upon those who are able to fast [but with difficulty] is a ransom: feeding a poor person). Ibn Abbas said: "It is not abrogated. It is for the elderly man and the elderly woman." Abu Dawud reported from Ibn Abbas that it was affirmed for the pregnant and nursing woman. Al-Daraqutni reported from Ibn Abbas concerning this that one feeds a poor person half a *sa'* of wheat for every day.

### [When the Real gives the servant a choice, He has perplexed him]

Know that when the Real (الحق) gives the servant a choice (خير), He has perplexed him (حيره). For the servant's reality (حقيقته) is servitude (العبودية), and he only acts by the ruling of necessity (الاضطرار) and compulsion (الجبر). Choice (التخيير) is an attribute of the Master, not an attribute of the servant. The Master has placed His servant in choice as a test and trial, to see whether he will remain with his servitude or choose and thus act in things like his Master, even though, in essence, he is compelled in his choice, since it is by the command of his Master. Thus, he should not depart from his servitude nor resemble his Lord in what Allah has obligated him to choose. Among the servants are those who are bewildered and do not know what to prefer. And among the servants are those who say, "My Lord says: <<مَا كَانَ لَهُمُ الْخِيَرَةُ>> (The choice is not for them), negating it. So I stand with the negation, and I will not depart from my servitude for the blink of an eye." And among them are those who say, "My Lord says: <<مَا كَانَ لَهُمُ الْخِيَرَةُ>> from their own selves, but I have permitted them to act by choice; I chose that for them and specified its loci." Among its loci is what came in this verse regarding the choice between fasting and breaking the fast, and some expiations.

### [The reward in optional expiations is multiplied]

When He alerted His servants that fasting is better for them if they choose it, He thereby clarified the path of preference (الأفضلية) so that they might prefer fasting over breaking the fast. This was part of His gentleness (رفقه), the Glorified, toward them, as He removed their bewilderment in the choice by this degree of preference. Nevertheless, the trial (الابتلاء) remains associated with it, because the Exalted did not obligate them to perform what He preferred for them, but rather kept the door of choice open. For this reason, one does not sin by breaking the fast. Whoever fasts it has fulfilled an obligation, for the performance of one of the two was imposed upon him, though not specifically designated. When the obligated person, who is the servant, designates it, the obligatory duty becomes specified in it. Since it is optional in its origin, it resembles a supererogatory fast (صوم التطوع). Thus, the servant in this state, if he fasts it, receives the reward of the obligatory duty (أجر الفرض), the reward of the supererogatory act (أجر التطوع), and the reward of hardship (أجر المشقة). His reward is greater or more abundant than that of one who performs an obligatory duty that is not optional. Likewise, the reward in optional expiations (الكفارات المخير فيها) is the reward of obligation and the reward of supererogation. This is part of Allah's generosity in imposing duties (التكليف). [End of the Fifty-Seventh Part]

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Section concerning forming the intention [تبييت] for fasting, both obligatory and recommended)

### [Fasters differ in reward according to the timing of the intention]

Al-Nasa'i recorded from Hafsah, the Mother of the Believers (may Allah be pleased with her), that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever does not form the intention (يبيت) for fasting from the night, there is no fast for him." The fast is recorded for him from the moment he forms the intention, whether it is at the beginning of the night, the middle, or the end. Thus, fasters differ in reward according to the timing of the intention (التبييت). This is supported by continuous fasting (*Wisal*). Just as the fast is recorded for him when he connects his day with the first part of his night, it is recorded for him when he connects the last part of his night with his day. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever fasts continuously (*muwasil*), let him continue until the pre-dawn meal (*Suhur*)." The discussion of *Wisal* and *Suhur* will follow in this chapter.

### [The Real, in verification, is Unseen in witnessing and witnessing in the Unseen]

Indeed, this Hadith—I mean, "Whoever fasts continuously"—indicates encouragement for the pre-dawn meal (*Suhur*). Thus, the night, during continuous fasting (*Wisal*), is also a place for fasting and a place for breaking the fast. Fasting during the night is optional, like supererogatory fasting during the day. The fast is for Allah in both times, for it follows the faster. At whatever time the name "faster" is applied to you, the fast is for Allah. It is more appropriate during the night because it has a greater relationship to the Unseen (الغيب). The Real (الحق), the Glorified, is Unseen (غيب) to us in that He promised us His vision, yet He is witnessed (مشهود) by us through His Acts (أفعاله) and traces (آثاره). The Real, in verification (التحقيق), is Unseen in witnessing (غيب في شهود) and witnessing in the Unseen (شهود في غيب). Likewise, the fast is Unseen in witnessing, because it is abandonment (ترك), and abandonment is not visible. But since it is intended (منويا), it is witnessed. If one forms the intention at any time during the night, he should not eat after the intention so that the intention is valid along with the commencement [of the fast]. Everything he fasts during the night is considered a supererogatory fast (صوم التطوع) until the dawn breaks. At that point, the ruling belongs to the obligatory fast (صوم الفرض), thus combining the supererogatory and the obligatory, and he receives the reward for both.

### [In fasting, the servant draws near to his Master through His Attribute]

Since the fast is for Allah, and the servant desires to draw near to Allah, the Exalted, by entering into it and being characterized by it, it is preferable that he form the intention (يبيته) from the beginning of the first third [of the night] until the end of the first or middle third. For Allah manifests (يتجلى) at that time in His descent to the lowest heaven. The servant then draws near to Him through His Attribute (بصفته), which is the fast. For the fast is only for Allah, unless the servant is characterized by it. If the servant is not characterized by it, there is no fast that is for Allah. In this station (الموطن), the fast is like hospitality (القرى) for the descent of the Real (الحق) to him and upon him.

### [The reward from Allah for the faster is without intermediary]

Since fasting is of this status, as we mentioned, Allah took charge of its reward with His I-ness (بأنانيته), not assigning it to anyone else. Just as the fast from the servant was for Allah without an intermediary (واسطة), the reward from Allah for the faster is without an intermediary. When someone meets his Master with what the Master deserves, the Master's turning toward the one who performs this act is the most complete turning, because the Master manifested in this station (الموطن) with the manifestation of one who benefits, so He met him Himself and did not entrust His generosity (كرامته) to another. <<فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ غَنِيٌّ عَنِ الْعَالَمِينَ>> (Indeed, Allah is free from need of the worlds).

(Section concerning the time for the faster to break the fast)

### [At sunset, the faster is governed by the Name Al-Fatir]

Muslim recorded from Abdullah ibn Abi Awfa that he said: "We were with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) on a journey during the month of Ramadan. When the sun set, he said, 'O so-and-so, dismount and prepare *sawiq* (a drink) for us.' He said, 'O Messenger of Allah, daylight is still upon you.' He said, 'Dismount and prepare *sawiq* for us.' So he dismounted and prepared the *sawiq* and brought it to him, and the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) drank. Then he said: 'When the sun sets from here and the night comes from here, the faster has broken his fast.'" Whether he ate or did not eat, the Law (الشرع) informed that he has broken his fast, meaning that that time is not for fasting, and that at sunset, the Name Al-Fatir (The Breaker/Originator) governs him.

### [The coming of night is the manifestation of the sovereignty of the Unseen, not the manifestation of what is in the Unseen]

The coming of night is the manifestation of the sovereignty of the Unseen (سلطان الغيب), not the manifestation of what is in the Unseen. It came to conceal what the sun of Reality (شمس الحقيقة) had unveiled, out of jealousy (غيرة) due to the lack of respect shown by those who received the unveiling (المكاشفين) for the sacred rites (شعائر الله) and sanctities they witnessed. For the sight perceived what, if considered in any part of it, would not fulfill the Divine veneration (التعظيم الإلهي) due to it. When respect diminished from them, the night concealed it out of jealousy, and it entered into the Unseen of the night.

### [The sciences of lights and the sciences of secrets]

However, when a human enters the Unseen (الغيب) and is characterized by it, he perceives the sciences of lights (علوم الأنوار) within it, but not the sciences of secrets (علوم الأسرار). The sciences of lights are all knowledge related to the benefits of all existents (الأكوان), just as when night comes, the lights of the stars appear, and Allah made them so that we may be guided by them <<فِي ظُلُمَاتِ الْبَرِّ وَالْبَحْرِ>> (in the darknesses of the land and the sea). These are the science of spiritual excellence (*Ihsan*) and the science of life. The sciences of secrets are hidden from the sight of observers; they are the Unseen of the Unseen (غيب الغيب). Thus, the Unseen, according to this, contains what can be perceived and what cannot be perceived.

### [It is preferable for the faster to hasten breaking the fast at sunset]

Since the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "The faster has broken his fast," it is preferable for the faster to hasten breaking the fast (تعجيل الفطر) at sunset, after the Maghrib prayer. This is more appropriate because Allah made Maghrib the odd number (*witr*) of the day's prayers, and it should be performed with the attribute that was present during the day, which is abstinence from food and drink. It is recommended for him, once he has finished the obligatory prayer (الفريضة), to begin breaking the fast, even if only with a sip of water or a date, before the supererogatory prayer (النافلة). For the one who does this remains in goodness.

Muslim recorded from Sahl ibn Sa'd that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "People will remain in goodness as long as they hasten the breaking of the fast."

He called eating or drinking "breaking the fast" (*fitr*), even though he said that the faster had broken his fast by the coming of night and the setting of the sun. Thus, by eating, he combined two breakings of the fast: breaking the fast by action (بالفعل) and breaking the fast by ruling (بالحكم).

### [The Muhammadan Station and the Josephian Station]

Whoever holds to the implied meaning (بالمفهوم) sees that if he does not break the fast by eating, the goodness that would have come to him by eating quickly is removed. If he delays, he does not attain that goodness granted by hastening, and he is deprived and loses in his transaction. Furthermore, he misses the joy (الفرحة) that the faster experiences when breaking the fast—meaning, he misses tasting its sweetness. This joy is the pleasure of moving from compulsion (الجبر) to choice (الاختيار), from restriction (الحجر) to illumination (السراج), and from narrowness (الضيق) to spaciousness (السعة). This is the Muhammadan Station (المقام المحمدي). Remaining in restriction is the Josephian Station (مقام يوسفي). The messenger came to Joseph from the *Aziz* (the ruler) with the command to leave the prison, but Joseph said: <<ارْجِعْ إِلَى رَبِّكَ فَاسْأَلْهُ مَا بَالُ النِّسْوَةِ>> (Return to your master and ask him what was the case of the women). He did not leave and chose to remain in prison until the messenger returned to him with the answer, even though it corresponded to his entry into the prison. He entered it out of love, and that state accompanied him, which is his saying: <<رَبِّ السِّجْنُ أَحَبُّ إِلَيَّ مِمَّا يَدْعُونَنِي إِلَيْهِ>> (My Lord, prison is more beloved to me than that to which they invite me). This was a love of attribution (محبة إضافة), not a true love (محبة حقيقة). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "May Allah have mercy on my brother Joseph. If it were me, I would have answered the caller." He means, "I would have hastened to leave the prison," because his station (peace and blessings be upon him) grants spaciousness (السعة). For Allah sent him as a mercy (رحمة), and one who is a mercy cannot tolerate narrowness (الضيق). For this reason, we said that the pleasure of the faster's joy upon breaking the fast is a Muhammadan Station, not a Josephian one.

### [Prayer is the right of Allah, and breaking the fast is the right of the soul]

We only said to hasten the prayer, so one breaks the fast after Maghrib and before the supererogatory prayer, because this was the action of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). We prioritized it over breaking the fast because prayer, even though it is for the servant, is the right of Allah (حق الله), while breaking the fast is the right of your soul (حق نفسك). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to the person whose mother died while she owed fasts and who wanted to make them up for her: "Do you not see that if she owed a debt, would you pay it off?" He said, "Yes." He said: "Then the right of Allah (حق الله) is more deserving of being fulfilled."

Thus, he prioritized the right of Allah and made it more deserving of fulfillment than the right of the created being. Muslim mentioned from Abu Atiyyah that he said: "Masruq and I entered upon Aisha and said, 'O Mother of the Believers, two men from the Companions of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him): one hastens breaking the fast and hastens the prayer, and the other delays breaking the fast and delays the prayer.' She asked, 'Which one hastens breaking the fast and hastens the prayer?' We said, 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud.' She said, 'That is how the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to do.'"

### [The Messenger of Allah is the excellent example]

Since Allah made him (peace and blessings be upon him) an example to be followed, the Exalted said: <<لَقَدْ كَانَ لَكُمْ فِي رَسُولِ اللَّهِ أُسْوَةٌ حَسَنَةٌ>> (There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern). He used to break his fast by moistening his intestines with some fresh dates (*rutab*) or dry dates (*tamr*) or sips of water before praying Maghrib. After the prayer, he would eat what was decreed for him.

Abu Dawud said in his *Sunan* from Anas ibn Malik that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to break his fast with fresh dates (*rutab*) before praying. If there were no fresh dates, then with dry dates (*tamr*). If there were no dry dates, he would take sips of water.

He prioritized the fresh date (*rutab*) because it is newer in covenant with its Lord than the dry date (*tamr*), just as the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did in the open ground: he went out himself and uncovered his garment until the rain touched him. When asked about this action, he (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "It is newly arrived from its Lord."

(Section concerning fasting the secret of the month)

Know that this is the fast of a day for which a command came from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him).

We narrated it through the chain of Abu Dawud from Abdullah ibn al-Ala' from Mughirah ibn Qurrah, who said: Mu'awiyah addressed the people on the day of Mashhal, which is at the gate of Homs, and said: "O people, we saw the crescent moon on such and such a day, and I am going ahead with the fast. Whoever wishes to do so, let him do it." Malik ibn Hubayrah al-Sabali stood up and said: "O Mu'awiyah, is this something you heard from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), or is it your own opinion?" He replied: "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: 'Fast the month.'"

### [Fasting the secret of the month and the station of the hidden, innocent saints]

Know that the secret (*sirr*) is the opposite of fame (*shuhra*). The month (*shahr*) is named *shahr* because of its fame, distinction, and the attention Muslims and astronomers give it. Thus, fasting is encouraged both in the state of secrecy (السر) and declaration (الإعلان). Know that the secret of the month (سر الشهر) is the time when the moon is in the grasp of the sun, under its rays. Similarly, when the servant is established in a station of proximity (مشهد من مشاهد القرب) where the eyes of the existents (الأكوان) seek him but cannot perceive him. This is the station of the hidden, innocent saints (الأخفياء الأبرياء) who are not distinguished among the common people in this abode, realizing the Attribute of their Master, who did not make a way for His vision in this abode due to the claims of existence (دعاوى الكون) in the Divine Level (المرتبة الإلهية). So they said, "We should not appear except with the appearance of our Master," and that is in the Hereafter, when He says: <<لِمَنِ الْمُلْكُ الْيَوْمَ>> (Whose is the sovereignty this Day?), and no one dares to claim it. It is there that this class manifests, showing that Allah has hidden ones (أخفياء) among His servants, treasures whom He has enveloped in His protection. Since they resembled their Master in this attribute of concealment and non-manifestation, the fast of the secret of the month became binding upon them. For fasting is an attribute of Self-Sufficiency (صفة صمدانية). Thus, they characterized themselves with the Attribute of the Real (صفة الحق) in this proximity, just as they characterized themselves with it in the declaration of the obligatory fast, like the month of Ramadan, which manifested there with its Name *Ramadan*, and the month was named by it as a veil (حجاب) from the Exalted.

### [The fast of secrecy and the fast of declaration]

The common people say, "I fasted Ramadan," while the Gnostic (العارف) says, "The month of Ramadan," declaring it. For Allah said to them: <<فَمَن شَهِدَ مِنكُمُ الشَّهْرَ فَلْيَصُمْهُ>> (So whoever among you witnesses the month, let him fast it). This is the declaration and fame of Ramadan. Except for the traveler, for the traveler travels to witness it, so he is not in a state of witnessing during his journey. The sick person is inclined away from the Real (الحق), because psychological sickness is the soul's inclination toward existence (الكون), so he did not witness the month. Menstruation is the soul's lie (كذب النفس), and for that reason, it is a harm in the locus that contradicts the purity (الطهارة) which necessitates proximity, which is truthfulness (الصدق).

It is reported in the sound Hadith that when a servant tells a lie, the angel distances himself from him by thirty miles due to the stench of what he brought.

Thus, the number thirty was brought, which is the full count of the lunar month that was concealed in the sun's rays. Therefore, the menstruating woman is far from witnessing the month for the reason we mentioned.

### [The Divine manifestation in the form of the perfection of gifts through the Divine Robe of Honor]

The Real (الحق), the Glorified, only brings His servant near to grant him gifts and bestowments. Then He reveals him to the people little by little, so that the splendor of the light of what He gave him does not overwhelm them, due to the weakness of the eyes of their inner sight (عيون بصائرهم)—a mercy to the common people. He continues to manifest to them little by little, revealing to them only so much of the Knowledge of Allah (العلم بالله) that He granted him during that state of secrecy (السرار) as He knows will not distract them, until the eyes of their inner sight become accustomed. Then He manifests to them in the form of the perfection of gifts through the Divine Robe of Honor (الخلعة الإلهية), which is His saying: <<مَن يُطِعِ الرَّسُولَ فَقَدْ أَطَاعَ اللَّهَ>> (Whoever obeys the Messenger has obeyed Allah). That is equivalent to the moon on the night of the full moon (*Badr*). This is the measure that the servant attained on the night of secrecy (ليلة السرار) in the Presence of the Unseen (حضرة الغيب) from his inner aspect. For the light of the full moon was present during the concealment (السرار) from the sun on the side facing the sun during conjunction, while the outward side had no light. On the night of the full moon (*Ibdar*), the matter is reversed, and the manifestation occurs through the Name *Al-Zahir* (The Manifest).

### [The action of the Real with His common servants]

Likewise is the action of the Real (الحق) with His common servants. He veiled Himself from them with the utmost veil, like the moon's concealment (السرار), so they did not perceive Him. He said: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), as a mercy to them. Thus, they found nothing in their minds or in the levels of their states (طبقات أحوالهم) that would distract them. So He came secretly in the mercy of the veil of this verse. This is the ultimate descent of the Real to His servants in the station of mercy toward them. Then He gradually led them on with verses like: <<وَهُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (And He is the Hearing, the Seeing), and <<قُلْ هُوَ اللَّهُ أَحَدٌ * اللَّهُ الصَّمَدُ>> (Say: He is Allah, [who is] One, Allah, the Self-Sufficient [الصمد]), and His saying: <<أَلَمْ يَعْلَم بِأَنَّ اللَّهَ يَرَى>> (Does he not know that Allah sees?), until the lights of their inner sight (أنوار بصائرهم) were strengthened by Gnosis (المعرفة بالله) and they became gradually familiar with Him. This continued until He manifested to them in the perfect, transcendent Gnosis (المعرفة التامة النزيهة) in which, had He manifested to them at the beginning, they would have perished instantly. Then He, the Mighty Speaker, said: <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). They accepted this and were not repelled by it, and they forgot the state of <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>. Their remaining in that station was due to the cutting off of despair, thereby removing correspondence (المناسبة) from all aspects.

Do you not see that the loneliness of the family of the deceased is cut off from their dead one because they do not hope to meet him in this world, so their grief does not remain? But the family of the absent one is not like that, for they have not despaired of meeting him, and his letters and news reach them intermittently until the time of meeting upon his arrival. Glory be to the All-Wise, the All-Aware: <<يُدَبِّرُ الْأَمْرَ يُفَصِّلُ الْآيَاتِ>> (He arranges [all] affairs, detailing the signs), so that perhaps we may understand from Him. It is for this reason that the fast of the secret of the month (صيام سر الشهر) occurred. The month is a struck example (مثلا مضر), and woe to him who does not understand from Allah.

### [Fasting the secret of the month and the station of gathering one's aspiration upon Allah]

In the fast of the secret of the month (صيام سر الشهر) is the station of gathering one's aspiration upon Allah (جمعية الهمة على الله) so that one sees none but Allah. This relates to his (peace and blessings be upon him) saying: "I have a time when none but my Lord encompasses me." This is because he is in a specific theophany (تجل خاص), and for this reason, he attributed it to Him, saying "my Lord" (*Rabbi*), and not *Allah* or *Al-Rabb*. What supports our view that the fast of the secret of the month intends this gathering of aspiration is his encouragement and urging to fast the secret days (*surar*) of Sha'ban, and that whoever misses them should make them up. For Sha'ban is related to dispersion (التفريق). For this reason, it was said that this month was only named *Sha'ban* because the Arab tribes dispersed in it. Likewise, Allah, the Exalted, said: <<وَجَعَلْنَاكُمْ شُعُوبًا وَقَبَائِلَ>> (And We made you into peoples [شعوب] and tribes [قبائل]). The *shu'ub* (peoples) among the non-Arabs are like the *qaba'il* (tribes) among the Arabs—meaning, He dispersed you into peoples and distinguished one tribe from another. Death (*maniyyah*) is also called *shu'ub* because it separates the deceased from his family.

### [Fasting the secret days of Sha'ban is more emphasized than fasting the secret days of other months]

Thus, fasting the secret days (*surar*) of Sha'ban is more emphasized (آكد) than fasting the secret days of other months, due to the dispersion (التفريق) inherent in it.

Muslim recorded from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) asked a man: "Have you fasted any of the secret days (*surar*) of this month?" He said, "No." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Then when you break the fast of Ramadan, fast two days in its place." In another narration also by Muslim from Ibn Umar: "Have you fasted any of the secret days of Sha'ban?"

### [Knowing the station of the moon and the sun in striking the example]

In this chapter are Divine knowledges (علوم إلهية) and secrets, known by whoever realizes what we have drawn attention to. The most fortunate people in this regard are the people of contemplation (أهل الاعتبار) who observe the movements of the sun and the moon to preserve the times of worship. For the knowledge of the station of the moon and the sun, when used as a parable, is one of the greatest proofs of the Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي) specific to the Universe (الكون), the Lordly Aid (الإمداد الرباني), and the preservation of the subsistence of the essences of created things (أعيان الكائنات). <<إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَذِكْرَى لِمَنْ كَانَ لَهُ قَلْبٌ أَوْ أَلْقَى السَّمْعَ وَهُوَ شَهِيدٌ>> (Indeed, in that is a reminder for whoever has a heart or lends an ear while he is a witness [to the truth]), meaning, present in what the informant conveys to him, so he visualizes it before his eyes as if he is witnessing it (يشاهده). For it is a truthful report brought by a truthful, trustworthy one.

> Brought by a truthful, trustworthy one, *** informing of all that shall be,
> In every universe, in every aspect, *** concerning all that is difficult and all that is easy,
> Of what hearts see as an unveiling (كشفا) of meaning, *** and what eyes cannot perceive.

It was brought by the Lord of the Abode, Who informs him of everything beautiful deposited therein. The Exalted said: <<وَكُلَّ شَيْءٍ فَصَّلْنَاهُ تَفْصِيلًا>> (And We have detailed everything in [precise] detail). That is <<لِتَعْلَمُوا أَنَّ اللَّهَ عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ وَأَنَّ اللَّهَ قَدْ أَحَاطَ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عِلْمًا>> (so that you may know that Allah is over all things competent and that Allah has encompassed all things in [His] Knowledge).

(Section on the wisdom of the fast of the people of every land based on their sighting [of the moon])

Muslim narrated in his *Sahih* from Kurayb that Umm al-Fadl bint al-Harith sent him to Mu'awiya in Syria. He said: I arrived in Syria and fulfilled her need. Ramadan began while I was in Syria, and I saw the crescent moon on Thursday night. Then I arrived in Medina at the end of the month. Abdullah ibn Abbas questioned me, and then mentioned the crescent moon, asking, "When did you see the crescent?" I replied, "We saw it on Thursday night." He asked, "Did you see it yourself?" I said, "Yes, and the people saw it and fasted, and Mu'awiya fasted." He said, "But we saw it on Friday night, so we will continue fasting until we complete thirty days or we see it." I asked, "Are you not satisfied with the sighting and fasting of Mu'awiya?" He replied, "No, this is how the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded us."

[Indeed, Allah has not obligated anyone based on the state of another]

Your body and your powers are your land (بلدك), your region (إقليمك), and your world (عالمك). They are your flock (رعيتك), and you are addressed (مخاطب) to manage them according to the measure that the Real (الحق) has defined for you in His Law (شرعه). You are the shepherd (الراعي) responsible for them, not anyone else. For Allah has not obligated anyone except according to his own state (حاله) and capacity (وسعه); He has not obligated anyone based on the state of another. Thus, <<كُلُّ نَفْسٍ بِمَا كَسَبَتْ رَهِينَةٌ>> (Every soul, for what it has earned, will be retained), and <<وَكُلُّ نَفْسٍ تُجَادِلُ عَنْ نَفْسِهَا>> (And every soul will argue on its own behalf), and <<وَكُلَّ إِنْسَانٍ أَلْزَمْنَاهُ طَائِرَهُ فِي عُنُقِهِ>> (And [for] every person We have attached his fate to his neck).

[When the crescent of Gnosis (المعرفة) rises in the heart from the Divine Name 'Ramadan']

When the crescent of Gnosis (هلال المعرفة) rises in your heart from the Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) 'Ramadan,' that rising calls you to be characterized by what belongs to Him, which is the Fast (الصوم). So, He commanded you to restrain all your outward limbs and to restrain your inward powers. He commanded you to perform the night vigil (قيام ليلة) and encouraged you in it, which is the preservation of His Unseen (غيبه). He appointed for you a breaking of the fast (فطرا) at the beginning of the night and commanded you to hasten it, and a meal (غذاء) at the end of the night, and commanded you to delay it until the delay places it in the position of one who said, "It is daytime, except that the sun has not risen." This is due to the wisdom of realizing the other Name (الاسم الآخر) during the night of Ramadan, just as you were in its day, for you are between the two extremes of permissibility (تحليل) and prohibition (تحريم).

[The Real (الحق) addressed you only from you and by you]

The Real (الحق) addressed you only from you, and addressed you only by you. This is the case with every obligated person (مكلف) in the World (العالم), whether angel, jinn, or human—indeed, every creature. The ruling descends upon that creature according to its state (حال ذلك المخلوق) by means of the attribute of Speech (صفة الكلام), whether that speech includes letters of the alphabet or not. It is the very essence of Divine Speech (الكلام الإلهي) in the World. Indeed, Allah said through the tongue of His servant, "Allah hears whoever praises Him." And the Glorified One inspired me concerning this with the following verses, which I shall mention, God willing:

> The Real (الحق) called me from My Heaven, *** without a letter of the alphabet,
> Then He called me from the earth of My Being, *** with every letter of the alphabet,
> And He said to me: "All of it is My Speech, *** so do not turn aside to anything other than Me.
> And do not see that there is anything other than Me, *** for that is the utmost distance."

[Every soul is required by the Real (الحق) in its own self]

When I knew that every land has its own sighting [of the moon], and that the ruling of one land does not depend on another, I knew that the matter is serious, and that every soul is required by the Real (الحق) in its own self: <<لَا تَجْزِي نَفْسٌ عَنْ نَفْسٍ شَيْئًا>> (No soul will pay for another soul at all). And that the turning of the human being in worship (العبادة)—from one aspect by his own essence (بذاته) and from another aspect by his Lord (بربه)—allows no room or entry for anyone else. This was shown to me in a vision (واقعة), and I awoke from my sleep moving my lips with these verses, which I had never heard before this, neither from myself nor from anyone else. They are:

> The Real (الحق) said to me in my sleep, *** though that was not from My Speech,
> "At times I call you among My servants, *** at times I converse with you in My Station (مقاني).
> And you, in both states, are with Me, *** under the protection of preservation and covenant.
> From prayer to purification (زكاة), *** and from purification to fasting (صيام),
> And from the forbidden (حرام) to the permissible (حلال), *** and from the permissible to the forbidden.
> And you, in this and that, are from Me, *** like the enclosure of the tents."

[Every limb in the human being is addressed concerning a fast specific to it]

If the human being knew from which station (مقام) the Exalted Real (الحق تعالى) called him to fast in His saying, <<يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا>> (O you who have believed), and that he is the addressee (المخاطب) in his own self alone with this comprehensiveness (الجمعية)—for He said, "Every morning, charity is due upon every joint (سلامي) of yours"—He made the obligation general within the single human being. If this applies to his veins, then where are you concerning his limbs: his hearing, his sight, his tongue, his hand, his stomach, his leg, his private parts, and his heart, which are the chiefs of his outward being? Indeed, every limb (جارحة) is addressed concerning a fast specific to it, which is its restraint from what has been restricted to it and prevented from its use, by His saying: <<كُتِبَ عَلَيْكُمُ الصِّيَامُ>> (Fasting has been prescribed for you).

[Fasting (الصيام) is the restraint from everything whose performance or abandonment is forbidden]

Know that Allah called you, by virtue of your being a believer, from the station of comprehensive wisdom (مقام الحكمة الجامعة), so that by detailing what He addresses you with, you may stand upon the knowledge of what He intended from you in this worship. So He said: <<كُتِبَ عَلَيْكُمُ الصِّيَامُ>> (Fasting has been prescribed for you)—meaning, the restraint (الإمساك) from everything whose performance or abandonment has been forbidden to you—<<كَمَا كُتِبَ عَلَى الَّذِينَ مِنْ قَبْلِكُمْ>> (as it was prescribed for those before you). This means fasting (الصوم) in terms of its essential nature as a fast. Even if it also means the fast of Ramadan specifically, as some have held, those before us among the People of the Book (أهل الكتاب) increased it until they reached fifty days, which is something they altered.

[The Fast (الصوم) has no likeness, so it belongs to the One Who has no likeness]

His saying <<كَمَا كُتِبَ>> (as it was prescribed) means, imposed <<عَلَى الَّذِينَ مِنْ قَبْلِكُمْ>> (upon those before you), who are your predecessors (سلف) in this ruling, and you are their successors (خلف). <<لَعَلَّكُمْ تَتَّقُونَ>> (so that you may become righteous/pious), meaning, that you may take the Fast as a shield (وقاية). For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed us that "Fasting is a shield (جنة)." A shield (الجنة) is a protection (الوقاية). They only take it as a protection if they make it an act of worship (عبادة). Thus, the Fast belongs to the Real (الحق) from the aspect of the transcendence (التنزيه) contained within it, and from the aspect of its being an act of worship, it is a shield and protection (جنة ووقاية) for the servant against claiming what belongs to Allah and not to him. For the Fast (الصوم) has no likeness, so it belongs to the One Who has no likeness. Therefore, the Fast is for Allah, not for you.

[The month is either twenty-nine days or thirty]

Then He said: <<أَيَّامًا مَعْدُودَاتٍ>> (A number of days). The operative verb governing 'days' is undoubtedly the first 'prescribed' (كتب). For we do not know whether what was prescribed upon those before us was a single day, which is Ashura, or whether it was [a number of] days. What was prescribed upon us is only a month, and the month is either twenty-nine days or thirty days, depending on our sighting of the crescent moon. The days [mentioned in the verse] are from three to ten, no more. Thus, the wording of the Quran corresponds to what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, informed us regarding the number of days in the month. He said, "The month is thus," and he gestured with his hand (meaning ten days), then he said, "And thus" (meaning ten days), and "And thus," folding his thumb on the third time (meaning nine days). On another occasion, he did not fold his thumb, also intending ten days. This is because the Exalted said <<أَيَّامًا مَعْدُودَاتٍ>> (A number of days). The Lawgiver counted the days of the month in tens so that the mention of 'days' would be valid and conform to the Speech of Allah. For if He had said "thirty days," it would have been like what He said concerning the oath of abstention (الإيلاء) regarding Aisha: "The month may be twenty-nine days." But He did not say "thus and thus" as He did concerning the number of the month of Ramadan. Thus, we know that He intended conformity with the Exalted Real (الحق تعالى) in what He mentioned in His Book.

[But whoever among you is ill or on a journey]

Then He said: <<فَمَنْ كَانَ مِنْكُمْ مَرِيضًا أَوْ عَلَى سَفَرٍ فَعِدَّةٌ مِنْ أَيَّامٍ أُخَرَ>> (But whoever among you is ill or on a journey, then [he is to fast] an equal number of other days). He mentioned 'days' again and referred to the addressees with His saying <<مِنْكُمْ>> (among you), who are those who have believed. *Ill* (مَرِيضًا) means being in the confinement of the Real (حبس الحق). *Or on a journey* (أَوْ عَلَى سَفَرٍ) refers to the people of spiritual traversing (أهل السلوك) on the path to Allah through the stations (المقامات) and states (الأحوال). The journey (السفر) is derived from *isfar* (ظهور - manifestation/disclosure), because a journey is only called a journey because it discloses (يسفر) the character of men within it. Thus, the station and the state are disclosed to them in this traversing, [showing] that the action is not theirs, even though they are engaged in it, but rather Allah is the One acting through them, as the Exalted said: <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ وَلَكِنَّ اللَّهَ رَمَى>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but it was Allah Who threw). <<فَعِدَّةٌ مِنْ أَيَّامٍ أُخَرَ>> (then [he is to fast] an equal number of other days) means during the time of veiling (الحجاب), for they are 'other days' until the obligation (التكليف) finds a place that accepts it as mandatory. We have previously discussed similar matters in this chapter, so let it be reviewed there.

[Whoever is able to fast is given a choice between fasting and the ransom of feeding]

Then He said: <<وَعَلَى الَّذِينَ يُطِيقُونَهُ فِدْيَةٌ طَعَامُ مِسْكِينٍ فَمَنْ تَطَوَّعَ خَيْرًا فَهُوَ خَيْرٌ لَهُ وَأَنْ تَصُومُوا خَيْرٌ لَكُمْ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ تَعْلَمُونَ>> (And upon those who are able to fast [but with difficulty] is a ransom [فِدْيَةٌ]—the feeding of a poor person. But whoever volunteers excess good, it is better for him. And that you fast is better for you, if you should know). He says that whoever is able to fast (يطيق الصوم) has been given a choice between fasting and feeding. Thus, He moved from a specific obligation (وجوب معين) to an unspecified obligation (وجوب غير معين) for the obligated person, even though it is restricted. Allah already knows what the obligated person will do, so He attached it to voluntary action (التطوع). Since neither of the two is specifically obligatory, whatever he chooses is a voluntary act (تطوعا) on his part, as he has the option to choose the other instead. Then Allah favored the Fast (الصوم), which belongs to Him, so that the servant might perform it, since the attribute of the Fast, in terms of its being an act of worship, has no likeness. If you say, "But feeding (الإطعام) is also His attribute, for He is the Feeder," we reply: If He had mentioned feeding without the ransom (الفدية), it would be so. But when He coupled feeding with the ransom (الفداء) and attributed it to it, the obligated person was required to fast, and Allah is not required to do anything according to true conventional etiquette (الأدب الوضعي الحقيقي) except what He has obligated upon Himself. Whoever falls under the ruling of obligation (الوجوب) is confined under His authority. Thus, the ransom (الفداء) was specified, and it was the feeding. Allah therefore favored the Fast (الصوم) there, making it better for him, for it is His attribute. Do you not see Him saying: <<وَفَدَيْنَاهُ بِذِبْحٍ عَظِيمٍ>> (And We ransomed him with a great sacrifice) from the captivity of destruction? <<إِنْ كُنْتُمْ تَعْلَمُونَ>> (If you should know). The particle *an* (أن) here may mean *ma* (ما), meaning, "You would not have known that fasting is better than feeding had I not informed you." Its meaning may also be: "If you know the superior choice in what I have given you the option for, then I have informed you," meaning the level (مرتبة) of the Fast and the level of the Feeding.

[The month of Ramadan in which the Quran was revealed]

Then He said: <<شَهْرُ رَمَضَانَ>> (The month of Ramadan). He says, the month of this Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي), which is Ramadan, thus attributing it to the Exalted Allah by His Name Ramadan, which is a strange, rare Name. <<الَّذِي أُنْزِلَ فِيهِ الْقُرْآنُ>> (in which the Quran was revealed). He says, the Quran descended with the specific obligation of its fast, unlike other months. <<هُدًى>> (as guidance), meaning clarification, <<لِلنَّاسِ>> (for mankind). The Quran (القرآن) means the collection/gathering (الجمع). Therefore, He gathered you and Him together in the attribute of Self-Sufficiency (الصفة الصمدانية), which is the Fast. Whatever transcendence (تنزيه) is in it belongs to Allah, for He said, "The Fast is for Me." And from the aspect of its being worship, it is guidance (هُدًى) for you—meaning clarification for mankind according to their levels (طبقاتهم) and the understanding (الفهم) they have been granted concerning it, for every person has a share (شربا) in this worship—and <<وَبَيِّنَاتٍ>> (and clear proofs). Thus, every person has a specific clear proof (بينة) according to what he understood from the Speech of Allah concerning that guidance (الْهُدَى), which is the Divine clarification, and <<وَالْفُرْقَانِ>> (and the criterion). For He first gathered you with Him in the Fast through the Quran, then He separated you to distinguish you from Him through the Criterion (الفرقان). So you are you, and He is He, in the ruling we mentioned concerning your use of what belongs to Him, which is the Fast. It belongs to Him from the perspective of transcendence, and it is for you an act of worship that has no likeness.

[So whoever sights the month, let him fast it]

<<فَمَنْ شَهِدَ مِنْكُمُ الشَّهْرَ فَلْيَصُمْهُ>> (So whoever sights the month, let him fast it). He says, let him restrain himself during this fame (الشهرة)—meaning, let him transcend himself through humility (الذلة) and need (الافتقار) until his joy is great at the time of breaking the fast. <<وَمَنْ كَانَ مَرِيضًا>> (And whoever is ill)—meaning inclined, for illness (المرض) is inclination (الميل), or confined, for the ill person is in the confinement of the Real (حبس الحق)—<<أَوْ عَلَى سَفَرٍ>> (or on a journey)—meaning spiritual traversing (سلوك) in the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) through direct experience (ذوق), or traveling away from Him toward the created realms (الأكوان)—<<فَعِدَّةٌ مِنْ أَيَّامٍ أُخَرَ>> (then [he is to fast] an equal number of other days)... <<أَيَّامٍ مَعْدُودَاتٍ>> (a number of days) that are neither increased nor decreased. <<يُرِيدُ اللَّهُ بِكُمُ الْيُسْرَ>> (Allah intends for you ease) in what He addresses you with, showing gentleness in the obligation, <<وَلَا يُرِيدُ بِكُمُ الْعُسْرَ>> (and does not intend for you hardship), which is what is difficult for you. He confirmed this statement with His saying: <<وَمَا جَعَلَ عَلَيْكُمْ فِي الدِّينِ مِنْ حَرَجٍ>> (And He has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty). Here, He defined the ease (اليسر) with the definite article, referring to the unspecified ease mentioned in *Surat Alam Nashrah* (The Expansion), meaning, "That ease is what I intended for you," which is His saying: <<فَإِنَّ مَعَ الْعُسْرِ يُسْرًا>> (For indeed, with hardship [there is] ease). In the hardship of illness, there is the ease of breaking the fast. Then, <<إِنَّ مَعَ الْعُسْرِ>> (indeed, with hardship)—the hardship of travel—<<يُسْرًا>> (there is ease)—the ease of breaking the fast also. <<فَإِذَا فَرَغْتَ>> (So when you have finished) from the illness or the journey, <<فَانْصَبْ>> (then stand up) yourself for worship, which is the Fast. He says, "Make it up (اقضه)." And <<وَإِلَى رَبِّكَ فَارْغَبْ>> (and to your Lord direct [your] desire) for aid. Our Shaykh Abu Madyan, may Allah have mercy on him, used to say concerning this verse: <<فَإِذَا فَرَغْتَ>> (So when you have finished) from the created realms (الأكوان), <<فَانْصَبْ>> (then stand up) your heart for the witnessing (مشاهدة) of the All-Merciful, and <<وَإِلَى رَبِّكَ فَارْغَبْ>> (and to your Lord direct [your] desire) for permanence. When you enter into an act of worship, do not think of leaving it, and say, <<يَا لَيْتَهَا كَانَتِ الْقَاضِيَةَ>> (Oh, would that it had been the decisive end!).

[And that you may complete the number and that you may glorify Allah for that [to] which He has guided you]

<<وَلِتُكْمِلُوا الْعِدَّةَ>> (And that you may complete the number) by sighting the crescent moon or by completing thirty days. <<وَلِتُكَبِّرُوا اللَّهَ>> (And that you may glorify Allah)—that you witness His Grandeur (الكبرياء) for Him, reserving it for Him alone, and not disputing it with Him, for it belongs only to Him, the Glorified. Thus, you glorify Him above the attribute of ease (اليسر) and hardship (العسر), for He said concerning the Resurrection, <<وَهُوَ أَهْوَنُ عَلَيْهِ>> (And it is easier for Him). He knows best what He says. Beware of your own interpretation (تأويلك) and applying it to yourself, so glorify Him above this. <<عَلَى مَا هَدَاكُمْ>> (for that [to] which He has guided you)—meaning, for having granted you success (وفقكم) in such a thing and clarified for you what you deserve and what the Exalted deserves. <<وَلَعَلَّكُمْ تَشْكُرُونَ>> (and perhaps you will be grateful). He made that a blessing (نعمة) for which gratitude (الشكر) is obligatory upon us, because we accept increase (الزيادة), and gratitude is a Divine attribute (صفة إلهية): <<فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ شَاكِرٌ عَلِيمٌ>> (Indeed, Allah is Appreciative [Shakir], All-Knowing). By this attribute, He sought increase from us, because He is Appreciative, for He said: <<لَئِنْ شَكَرْتُمْ لَأَزِيدَنَّكُمْ>> (If you are grateful, I will surely increase you). Thus, He alerted us to what the gratitude entails so that we may increase in action.

[And when My servants ask you concerning Me]

<<وَإِذَا سَأَلَكَ عِبَادِي عَنِّي>> (And when My servants ask you concerning Me), because you are the gatekeeper (حاجب الباب), <<فَإِنِّي قَرِيبٌ>> (then indeed, I am near) through what we share with them: gratitude (الشكر) and the Fast (الصوم), which is for Me. We commanded them to fast and informed them that it is for Us, not for them. So whoever clothes himself with it (تلبس به) has clothed himself with what is specific to Us, and thus becomes one of the people of distinction (أهل الاختصاص), like the People of the Quran (أهل القرآن), who are the people of Allah and His chosen ones. <<أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ>> (I answer the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me) with insight (على بصيرة). He says, just as We made you call people <<إِلَى اللَّهِ عَلَى بَصِيرَةٍ>> (to Allah upon insight), We made the supplicant who calls upon Us possess insight regarding Our response to him, unless he says, "He did not respond to me." <<فَلْيَسْتَجِيبُوا لِي>> (So let them respond to Me)—meaning, to what I have called them to, which is My obedience and My worship—for <<وَمَا خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ وَالْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). I called them to this through the tongues of My messengers and in My revealed Books with which I sent My messengers to them. He emphasized this with the letter *sin* [in *fastajibū* - let them respond] because He knew of our reluctance and distance from responding to Him—meaning, for My sake. You do not know this, hoping to attain what is with Me, so that you become servants of blessing (عبيد نعمة) and not My servants (عبيدي), though they are My servants willingly or unwillingly, and they cannot escape that.

[The Reality of Faith (الإيمان)]

<<وَلْيُؤْمِنُوا بِي>> (And let them believe in Me)—let them affirm My response to them when they call upon Me. And let their faith be in Me, not in themselves. For whoever believes in himself, not in Allah, his faith does not encompass what is due to Him. But if he believes in Me, and gives the matter its due right, giving every possessor of a right his right, this is the one who affirms all reports. As for whoever believes in himself, he believes in what his own proof (دليله) grants him. And what I commanded him to believe in has contradictory proofs (متناقض الدلالة), wavering between anthropomorphism (تشبيه) and transcendence (تنزيه). So, the one who believes in himself believes in some and disbelieves in others through interpretation (تأويلا), not rejection. Whoever interprets, his faith is in his intellect, not in Me. And whoever claims in himself that he knows Me better than I know Myself has not known Me nor believed in Me. He is a servant who denies Me in what I attribute to Myself, using fine expression. When asked, he says, "I intended transcendence." This is one of the tricks of the souls (حيل النفوس) due to the pride (العزة) within them, the desire for independence (الاستقلال), and the abandonment of adherence (الخروج عن الاتباع). <<لَعَلَّهُمْ يَرْشُدُونَ>> (that they may be rightly guided). Meaning, that they may follow the path of right guidance (الرشد), as the successful ones (الموفقون) do, who, when they see the path of right guidance, take it as their way, and it leads them to eternal bliss (السعادة الأبدية). Thus, the response of the Real (الحق) to them when they called upon Him, and the end of their path, was what their souls rejoiced in: the permissibility (تحليل) of what had been forbidden to them during their fast, from the beginning of the day until its end.

[Permitted for you is the night of the fast]

So He said: <<أُحِلَّ لَكُمْ لَيْلَةَ الصِّيَامِ>> (Permitted for you is the night of the fast)—meaning, the night to which your fast ended, not the night in which you wake up fasting. It is an attribute that accompanies you until the night of Eid al-Fitr. If the attribution of 'the night of the fast' were to the future, the night of Eid al-Fitr would not be included, for you do not wake up fasting on the day of Eid. If you were to fast on it, you would be disobedient. This does not apply to the first night of Ramadan, for eating and similar things were permissible before that, and the ruling remained continuous. Therefore, we attribute it to the past fast. <<الرَّفَثُ>> (Sexual intimacy)—meaning intercourse—<<إِلَى نِسَائِكُمْ>> (with your women). He used the word *women* (النساء) and did not say *spouses* (الأزواج) or anything else, for this Name contains the meaning of delay (التأخير) found in women. They had been delayed from this ruling, which is intercourse, during the time of fasting until the night. When the night came, the ruling of delay was removed by the declaration of permissibility (الإحلال). It is as if He says, "to what you were delayed from, and they were delayed from, among your spouses and those whom your right hands possess who are lawful for intercourse." <<هُنَّ لِبَاسٌ لَكُمْ وَأَنْتُمْ لِبَاسٌ لَهُنَّ>> (They are clothing for you, and you are clothing for them). Meaning, the suitability (المناسبة) between you is sound. It is not like your clothing yourselves with Us in your fast, where you were characterized by an attribute that belongs to Me, which is the Fast. For you are not clothing for Me in My saying, "My servant's heart encompasses Me," nor am I clothing for you in My saying, <<بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ مُحِيطٌ>> (encompassing all things), for clothing encompasses the one clothed and covers him.

[Allah knew that you were deceiving yourselves]

<<عَلِمَ اللَّهُ أَنَّكُمْ كُنْتُمْ تَخْتَانُونَ أَنْفُسَكُمْ>> (Allah knew that you were deceiving yourselves) [derived] from the betrayal (الخيانة) of My testimony against you when you accepted the Trust (الأمانة) when I offered it to you, and I said concerning its bearer: <<إِنَّهُ كَانَ ظَلُومًا جَهُولًا>> (Indeed, he was unjust [to himself] and ignorant). Unjust (ظلوما) to himself by obligating it with what he did not know Allah's knowledge concerning it when he bore it; ignorant (جهولا) of its measure and the blame attached to it, since the one who was entrusted betrayed it. Since the ignorant one (الجهول) is <<أَعْمَى وَأَضَلُّ سَبِيلًا>> (blind and further astray in path), not knowing where to place his foot or seeing where to place his foot, He said: <<عَلِمَ اللَّهُ أَنَّكُمْ كُنْتُمْ تَخْتَانُونَ أَنْفُسَكُمْ>> (Allah knew that you were deceiving yourselves) when He restricted you in what He restricted. <<فَتَابَ عَلَيْكُمْ>> (So He accepted your repentance)—meaning, He returned to you—<<وَعَفَا عَنْكُمْ>> (and pardoned you)—meaning, by the small amount He permitted you of the time of permissibility (الإحلال), which is the night. He only made it small because the restriction remains in place concerning intimacy for the one performing spiritual retreat (*i'tikaf*) in the mosques, without dispute, and with dispute outside the mosque, and for the one who continues fasting without breaking it (*muwasil*). <<فَالْآنَ بَاشِرُوهُنَّ>> (So now, have relations with them)—which is the time of breaking the fast in Ramadan—<<وَابْتَغُوا مَا كَتَبَ اللَّهُ لَكُمْ>> (and seek what Allah has ordained for you). Seek what Allah has prescribed for your sake so that you may know it and act upon it, concerning everything mentioned in this verse. <<وَكُلُوا وَاشْرَبُوا>> (And eat and drink)—a command to give your soul its due right of eating and drinking—<<حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَكُمُ الْخَيْطُ الْأَبْيَضُ>> (until the white thread becomes clear to you)—the approach of the day—<<مِنَ الْخَيْطِ الْأَسْوَدِ>> (from the black thread)—the retreat of the night—<<مِنَ الْفَجْرِ>> (of the dawn)—the bursting forth of light in the horizon.

[Then complete the fast until the night]

<<ثُمَّ أَتِمُّوا الصِّيَامَ إِلَى اللَّيْلِ وَلَا تُبَاشِرُوهُنَّ وَأَنْتُمْ عَاكِفُونَ فِي الْمَسَاجِدِ>> (Then complete the fast until the night. And do not have relations with them as long as you are staying in the mosques for worship). Thus, He maintained the restriction on intimacy for the one in this state, and likewise concerning eating and drinking for the one who intends continuous fasting (*wisal*). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever continues fasting should continue until the pre-dawn meal (*sahar*)." This refers to the mixing of light and darkness, meaning the time when the tail of the wolf (*dhanab al-sarhan*) appears, between the two dawns (the elongated and the spreading). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, continued fasting with his companions for two days, and they saw the crescent moon. Those are the limits of Allah (حدود الله) which He commanded you to stand at, so do not approach them, lest you look upon what lies beyond them. Herein lies an obscure knowledge (علم غامض) known only to those who have been granted a taste (ذوقا) by Divine Providence (عناية إلهية), such as Al-Khidr and others. For perhaps <<تَزِلَّ قَدَمٌ بَعْدَ ثُبُوتِهَا وَتَذُوقُوا السُّوءَ>> (a foot may slip after it was firm, and you may taste evil). <<كَذَلِكَ يُبَيِّنُ اللَّهُ آيَاتِهِ>> (Thus does Allah make clear His verses)—meaning His signs (دلائله)—to mankind as a hint (إشارة), so that they may remember by them. <<لَعَلَّهُمْ يَتَّقُونَ>> (that they may become righteous/pious)—that they may take those signs as a protection (وقاية) against blind imitation (التقليد) and ignorance. For the blind imitator is not upon a clear proof (بينة) from his Lord, nor is he a possessor of a sign (دلالة). He used the word of hope (لعلهم) because not everyone who is granted the sign and reaches the signified (المدلول) and attains the knowledge is granted success (وفق) in applying what he knows, if it is among the knowledges whose goal is action.

(Section on the Pre-dawn Meal [Suhur])

[Hadiths concerning the Pre-dawn Meal (Suhur)]

Muslim narrated from Anas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Take the pre-dawn meal (تسحروا), for indeed, there is blessing (بركة) in the pre-dawn meal." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded the pre-dawn meal and encouraged it with what he mentioned.

*Second Hadith for Muslim:* Muslim also narrated from Amr ibn al-As that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The distinction between our fast and the fast of the People of the Book is the eating of the pre-dawn meal (أكلة السحور)."

*Third Hadith for Al-Nasa'i:* Al-Nasa'i narrated from Al-Irbad ibn Sariya that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, calling to the pre-dawn meal in the month of Ramadan, saying: "Come to the blessed breakfast (الغذاء المبارك)."

*Fourth Hadith for Al-Nasa'i:* Al-Nasa'i also narrated from Abdullah ibn al-Harith, from a man among the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: I entered upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was taking the pre-dawn meal, and he said: "It is a blessing (بركة) that Allah has given you, so do not neglect it."

*Fifth Hadith for Muslim and Al-Bukhari:* Muslim narrated from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had two callers to prayer: Bilal and Ibn Umm Maktum the blind. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Bilal calls the prayer at night, so eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls the prayer." He said: There was only the time it took for one to descend and the other to ascend. Al-Bukhari added: "For he does not call the prayer until the dawn rises," meaning Ibn Umm Maktum. Al-Bukhari narrated this from the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him.

*Sixth Hadith for Abu Dawud:* Abu Dawud narrated from Abu Hurayrah that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If one of you hears the call to prayer while the vessel is in his hand, he should not put it down until he satisfies his need from it."

*Seventh Hadith for Al-Nasa'i:* Al-Nasa'i narrated from Asim from Dharr, who said: We asked Hudhayfa, "At what time did you take the pre-dawn meal with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him?" He replied: "It was daytime, except that the sun had not risen."

*Eighth Hadith for Muslim:* Muslim narrated from Anas, who said: We took the pre-dawn meal with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, then we stood up for prayer. I asked, "How much time was between them?" He said: "The time it takes to recite fifty verses."

*Ninth Hadith for Muslim:* Muslim narrated from Samura ibn Jundub that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not let the call to prayer of Bilal deceive you concerning your pre-dawn meal, nor the elongated whiteness of the horizon like this, until it spreads out like this." Hammad demonstrated it with his hand, meaning horizontally.

[This Knowledge of ours is bound by the Book and the Sunnah]

These are the hadiths concerning the pre-dawn meal that I have mentioned so that whoever hears my words about the pre-dawn meal may refer to them, and know that we have not departed in our method of contemplation (الاعتبار) from what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, indicated, both in word and deed. For the master of this group (الطائفة), Abu al-Qasim al-Junayd, says: "This Knowledge of ours is bound by the Book and the Sunnah." He, may Allah be pleased with him, says: Even though we took our knowledge directly from Allah, not from books nor from the mouths of men, Allah the Exalted has not taught us any knowledge by which we contradict what the Prophets, peace be upon them, brought from Allah concerning the reports I mentioned, nor what Allah revealed in His Book. Rather, it is with us as Allah informed concerning His servant Al-Khidr, that He granted him mercy from Himself and taught him knowledge from His own presence (من لدنه علما). This is the knowledge of Divine Gift (علم الوهب الإلهي) produced by piety (التقوى) and action based on the Book and the Sunnah. If the People of the Book had acted upon what was revealed to them and <<أَقَامُوا التَّوْرَاةَ وَالْإِنْجِيلَ>> (established the Torah and the Gospel)... <<لَأَكَلُوا مِنْ فَوْقِهِمْ>> (they would have eaten from above them)—an allusion to this station, meaning the knowledge of Divine Gift—<<وَمِنْ تَحْتِ أَرْجُلِهِمْ>> (and from beneath their feet)—an allusion to the knowledge of acquisition (علم الكسب), which is the knowledge attained by the people of piety (أهل التقوى) from this Community. For it is acquired knowledge (علم كسب) since it is the result of action, which is piety.

[The Pre-dawn Meal (Suhur) is derived from *Sahar*, which is the mixing of light and darkness]

Know that the pre-dawn meal (السحور) is derived from *Sahar* (السحر), which is the mixing of light and darkness. This refers to the time of the pre-dawn meal. It has an aspect toward the day and an aspect toward the night. In the aspect that faces the day, He called it *ghidha* (breakfast/sustenance), thus favoring the ruling of the day over the ruling of the night, just as He did with the breaking of the fast (*fitr*), where He commanded hastening it, thus also favoring the day over the night due to the presence of the sun's traces. For the eating occurs before the traces and indication of the day disappear, even though the day has retreated. This is because the reality of the day is from the rising of the first edge of the sun until the setting of the last edge of the sun. With its setting, the disk of the sun disappears. The traces of the day are present from the beginning of the night, from its setting until the disappearance of the whiteness, and its traces are present at the end of the night from the rising of the first dawn until the rising of the sun. However, the rising of the first dawn does not legally prevent eating, while there is a difference of opinion concerning the second dawn. The point of consensus is the redness [of the horizon]. What precedes that is not *Sahar*; it is only night. And what follows it is only day.

[Ambiguity (Shubha) has an aspect toward the Real (الحق) and an aspect toward falsehood (الباطل)]

Likewise is the attribute of ambiguity (الشبهة): it has an aspect toward the Real (الحق) and an aspect toward falsehood (الباطل) in intellectual matters. Similarly, the ambiguous (*mutashabih*) has an aspect toward permissibility (الحل) and an aspect toward prohibition (الحرمة). This is why the first dawn is called the false dawn (*al-fajr al-kadhdhab*). It is not truly false, but the falsehood is attributed to it because the one taking the pre-dawn meal might imagine that eating is forbidden at that point, which is not the case. Its cause is the striking of the sun—meaning, the projection of its rays onto the sea—whereupon the light begins to elongate. When it rises, that light reflected from the sea goes to the horizon, and darkness returns, and the emergence of the sun toward us approaches. Its light then appears in the horizon like a bird opening its wings. This is why it is called spreading (*mustatir*). It continues to increase until the sun rises. Similarly, with the Real and falsehood: <<فَأَمَّا الزَّبَدُ فَيَذْهَبُ جُفَاءً وَأَمَّا مَا يَنْفَعُ النَّاسَ فَيَمْكُثُ>> (As for the foam, it vanishes as [worthless] scum; but as for that which benefits the people, it remains)—meaning, it is firm—which is the true dawn (*al-fajr al-sadiq*). What is between the two is the *Sahar*. Just as what is between the two aspects that appear in ambiguity (الشبهة) is the sound knowledge (العلم الصحيح) by which it becomes clear that it is an ambiguity, and by your knowledge of it, the Real is distinguished from falsehood. Similarly, the false dawn is distinguished by its sinking back toward the earth and the apparent darkness at that time, indicating that the first dawn does not prevent the one who intends to fast from eating. This is why the Arabs called it the tail of the wolf (*dhanab al-sarhan*), because among predators, none is more malicious or deceitful than it. It feigns weakness to be underestimated and neglected, so it can achieve its goal of preying. Since its tail resembles a dog's tail, one who does not know it imagines it to be a dog and feels safe from it. Thus, it resembles the hypocrite.

[The eating of the Pre-dawn Meal is a blessing from Allah]

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded the eating of the pre-dawn meal at that time and said, "It is a blessing (بركة) that Allah has given you," thus confirming His command by prohibiting us from neglecting it. Just as He explicitly commanded it, He explicitly prohibited its abandonment, emphasizing its necessity. It resembles the Witr prayer, for it is a prayer commanded as a means of drawing near (القربة المأمور بها); thus, it is an emphasized Sunnah, and according to some scholars of the Law (الشريعة), it is obligatory. The eating of the pre-dawn meal is even more emphasized than the Witr in the category of prayer, due to the explicit prohibition against neglecting it. It is equivalent to investigating ambiguity (الشبهة) until the Real (الحق) is known from falsehood by means of it. This is the blessing (البركة) found in the eating of the pre-dawn meal. For blessing means increase (الزيادة), and it is increased over all other meals by the inclusion of the command for it and the prohibition against neglecting it. This ruling does not apply to other meals.

[The distinction between the status of the People of the Book and our status in Fasting]

Furthermore, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made it a distinction (فصلا) between the status of the People of the Book and our status. This means either that the Real (الحق) distinguished us with it over the rest of the communities of the People of the Book, or that He commanded us to maintain it so that we might be distinguished from the People of the Book, since it was revealed to them just as it was revealed to us, but they neglected its right, as they did with many things. Both aspects are permissible. This distinction encompasses hastening the breaking of the fast (تعجيل الفطر) and delaying the pre-dawn meal (تأخير السحور). If we consider the People of the Book to be those who uphold their Book, we know that Allah distinguished us with the favor of hastening the breaking of the fast and delaying the pre-dawn meal over them, and that He did not reveal that to them, so they were deprived of its favor. If we consider the People of the Book to be those to whom a Book from Allah was revealed, whether they acted upon it or not, it is confirmed for us that Allah emphasized this so that we might be distinguished from the People of the Book, since they were commanded with it but lost it by neglecting the action. Whoever views the pre-dawn meal (*uklat al-suhur* - with a *damma* on the hamza) is satisfied with a single morsel to establish the difference between himself and the People of the Book, which is the minimum amount. Whoever pronounces the hamza with a *fatha* (*aklat al-suhur*) intends the sustenance/breakfast (الغذاء).

[Come to the blessed breakfast]

Furthermore, among the confirmations of its importance is the Prophet's, peace and blessings be upon him, maintenance of it and its delay, and his calling to it. Thus, he established it as a Sunnah both verbally and practically. He said: "Come to the blessed breakfast (الغذاء المبارك)," just as he said, "Hasten to the prayer." Moreover, due to his emphasis on it and his preference for eating over abandoning it, even with the realization of the preventative factor—the true dawn—[he ruled that] if you hear the call to prayer, provided that the caller in that land is one who knows that he only calls when the rising occurs by which the prayer is valid, like Ibn Umm Maktum during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, then when the one taking the pre-dawn meal hears that, abandonment becomes obligatory upon him. Yet, he was told that if he hears it while the vessel is in his hand and he is drinking, he should not cut off the stream of water, despite this realization, until he satisfies his need from it. As Hudhayfa said, "It is daytime, except that the sun has not risen." Thus, the ruling was made according to the state of the time, which is existence (الوجود). And repulsion (الدفع) was easier than removal (الرفع), because the repelled is non-existent, while what you seek to remove is existent and actively ruling—which is that you are eating or drinking. So the ruling belongs to it until it removes itself.

[The ruling belongs to the Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) that governs the servant at that time]

Similarly, when the Name ruling the servant at a given time is sought by another Name that has no ruling over him, the servant's priority is not to separate himself from this Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) until it no longer has a ruling over him that demands his attention. When he is finished with its ruling, he then receives with proper etiquette that other Divine Name that also seeks him. This is the case in this world and the Hereafter.

[The confrontation between the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) when the servant commits a transgression]

For example, a person upon whom the Name The Acceptor of Repentance (*al-Tawwab*) rules, concerning an action where the Divine Names confronted each other at the time of the sin. The Avenger (*al-Muntaqim*) said, "I have a greater claim over him." And The Merciful (*al-Rahim*) and The Forgiving (*al-Ghaffar*) said, "We have a greater claim over him." Thus, the Names confronted each other concerning the state of the disobedient one: which Divine Name (اسم إلهي) would rule over him and in him? They found The Acceptor of Repentance (*al-Tawwab*). So the Name The Merciful gained strength over The Avenger and said, "This is My deputy in the locus, for had I not shown him mercy, he would not have repented." Thus, The Avenger was repelled from seeking him, and The Merciful took possession of him. The Acceptor of Repentance then returned him to his Lord, moving from obedience to obedience, after having returned him from disobedience or disbelief to obedience. This penitent one (*al-ta'ib*) is never isolated, because repentance may not be from a sin, but rather a return to Allah in every state, in every act of obedience. If the Name The Abandoner (*al-Khadhil*) is found in the locus—which is its ruling over the servant when he commits a violation—then the confrontation between the opposing Names becomes greater and more intense, for this action calls for both of them. The Abandoner was in constant attendance between him and these Names, without either of them realizing what the other was doing. The Merciful says, "The Abandoner called me, so he helps me against The Avenger." The Avenger says, "He called me, so he helped me against The Merciful." But when they approach, they see no help from him for either of them.

[And The Judge—The Just (الحكم- العدل)—came with the decisive speech]

If the abandonment (الخذلان) was disbelief (*kufr*), the Name The Just Judge (*al-Hakam al-'Adl*) comes to arbitrate between the two opposing Names: The Merciful and His brethren, and The Avenger and His brethren. He says, "Allah commanded me to judge between you," which is His saying: <<فَأَصْلِحُوا بَيْنَهُمَا بِالْعَدْلِ وَأَقْسِطُوا>> (So make reconciliation between them justly and be fair). He says to the two factions of Names, "Watch this servant until his last breath. If he leaves this body while still in his disbelief, then let The Avenger take possession of him, and you, O Merciful, and your group, withdraw from him." The Merciful says, "Mercy preceded wrath, so I am the predecessor, and I will not withdraw." The Just Judge says to Him, "Precedence is only considered at the end of the term (المدى), and the term has not yet ended. Leave The Avenger until he has exacted from him the measure of the time of violation and abandonment. That is the end of the term. When it ends, you may renew your claim." Allah then judges according to what He wills. If He sends me as a judge, I judge according to what my knowledge grants me. If He appoints The Favored One (*al-Mufaddil*) or The Avenger, he also judges according to what he is permitted. They separate based on this limit. If the abandonment in this locus did not result in disbelief but resulted in disobedience, and this confrontation occurred between the Names, The Just Judge comes and speaks to each of the two factions and hears their claims, and that each one claims the right for himself. He asks them for proof (*bayyina*). The Avenger says, "What proof is clearer than the occurrence of the act? Do you not see him drunk, if he drinks wine, or a thief, or a murderer, or whatever act of transgression it may be?" The Judge says, "These actions, even if they occurred, are a place of ambiguity (*shubha*). The Judge does not rule except with proof. For the occurrence of drinking wine does not necessarily mean he committed a forbidden act. Perhaps he choked on a morsel. Perhaps he is ill, and he only used what is permissible for him to use. Perhaps this murderer killed the killer of his father, or someone whom this killer was the guardian of, and he transgressed against him in the same way he was transgressed against. I do not know this except by evidence." So his appearance is that of an abandoned one, but with this ambiguity. His opponent says, "He concedes to me that this person transgressed the limit of Allah by drinking wine, or killing, or whatever acts of disobedience occurred in that state." The Merciful says, "Yes, he spoke the truth, except that I have a strong authority in the locus that strengthens me, and he is with me against The Avenger." The Judge asks Him, "Who is he?" He says, "The Name The Giver of Security (*al-Mu'min*) has descended to him in the abode of faith, which is his heart, so he has security." He said, "Call him." So he came and said, "Are you a transient traveler in this locus, or is it your locus and your dominion?" He says, "It is my locus and my dominion, and the perpetrator of this action, the disobedient one, has not opposed me in my dominion. May Allah reward him well on my behalf. He employs me in every state according to what my reality grants, and I am in need of him." He says to The Avenger, "Withdraw from him until we consult the Name The Willer (*al-Murid*), who is the closest gatekeeper to Allah, for He has the Will (المشيئة) concerning this servant and this ruling." The matter remains suspended until the end of the term (المدى), which is the appointed time (*al-ajal al-musamma*), which is death. If he dies upon the violation, The Willer takes possession of him. If he repents at the time of death, The Avenger withdraws from him entirely, and The Merciful and His companions take possession of him. Thus, the end of the term for the disobedient one is until the time of death, and for the disbeliever, it is as we established. End of Part Fifty-Eight.

(Section on the ruling of fasting the Day of Doubt)

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful. Al-Tirmidhi narrated from Ammar ibn Yasir, who said: "Whoever fasts the day about which there is doubt has disobeyed Abu al-Qasim [the Prophet]." He said: This is a sound, authentic hadith. The majority of scholars prohibit fasting the Day of Doubt on the basis that it is part of Ramadan. They differed concerning the deliberate fasting of it as a voluntary act (*tatawwu'*). Some disliked it, and some permitted it. As for the hadith of Ammar, in my view, it is not a definitive text (نص) nor a matter attributed directly to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Rather, it is possible that it stems from Ammar's own consideration, and it is possible that it is a report from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Some said that if he fasted it believing it was part of Ramadan, and then confirmation came that it was indeed Ramadan, it suffices him.

(Contemplation/Reflection)

Since doubt (الشك) wavers between two matters without preference, it resembles the state of the servant when the Real (الحق) is his hearing and his sight. If the observer looks at the Real being his hearing, he says, "It is the Real." If he looks at the attribution of hearing to the servant by the pronoun *his* (هاء) in His saying "his hearing," he says, "It is the servant." There is no state that favors one observer over the other, so both fall away. When they fall away, they remain by the ruling of the origin (الأصل). The origin is the existence of a servant and a Lord. This is the theoretical and legal origin from one aspect.

[The Origin of Origins (أصل الأصول), Gnostic (الكشفى) and Legal: The existence of a Lord in the very essence of a servant]
