As for the Origin of Origins (أصل الأصول) observed prior to this origin—indeed, the one from which this origin is a branch—it is the existence of a Lord in the very essence of a servant (وجود رب في عين عبد). This is the Gnostic (الكشفي) and legal Origin of Origins from one aspect. So act according to what is strengthened within you concerning that, and whatever your spiritual path (*mashrab*) is, stand by it until the aspect of the Real (وجه الحق) in the matter becomes clear to you. Then you will be among the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) and Existence (الوجود).

(Section on the ruling of breaking a voluntary fast)

Some have narrated consensus that whoever enters into a voluntary fast (*siyam tatawwu'*) and breaks it due to an excuse is not required to make it up (qada'). They differed if he intentionally breaks it without an excuse. Some say he must make it up, and others say he is not required to make it up.

(Contemplation/Reflection)

If he enters into an action through the servitude of choice (عبودية الاختيار), he has obligated himself to servitude (العبودية). If he returns to his origin in that obligation, his ruling is the ruling of the servitude of necessity (عبودية الاضطرار), and he is required in the voluntary act what is required in the obligatory one. Whoever observes that the Real (الحق) made this servant choosing (مختارا) says: "The ruling of the Real is not lifted from me in this action," for that leads to disputing the Real, since he places choice in the position of necessity. So He treats him with the treatment of choice: if he wills, he makes it up, also by choice; and if he wills, he does not make it up. There is length in the contemplation of this matter, but this much suffices in this Book, for the obligation (التكليف) establishes the essence of the servant, whether he is compelled or choosing.

(Section on the volunteer who breaks his fast forgetfully)

Scholars differed concerning this. One group said he must make it up (عليه القضاء), and another group said he is not required to make it up. I hold the view of abandoning the making up, due to the reported hadith concerning it.

(Contemplation/Reflection)

The forgetful one (*al-nasi*) is the one who abandons what he chose after having chosen it. If it was due to a whim of the soul (هوى نفس), then he must make it up. If it was due to being preoccupied with a station (مقام), a state (حال), or a Divine Name (اسم إلهي), then he is not required to make it up. Making it up (*al-qada'*) here means the ruling imposed upon him according to what he volunteered.

(Section on the fast of the Day of Ashura)

They differed as to which day of Muharram it is. Some said the tenth, which is the correct view, and which I hold. Others said the ninth.

(Contemplation/Reflection)

Here is the ruling of the Name The First (*al-Awwal*) and The Last (*al-Akhir*). Whoever is established in the station of His Unique Essence (أحدية ذاته) fasts the tenth, for it is the first of the units of the decade. Whoever is established in the station of the Divine Name The Last (الاسم الآخر الإلهي) fasts the ninth day, for it is the last of the simple numbers. Since the fast—meaning the fast of Ashura—was encouraged, and its obligation preceded the obligation of Ramadan (with disagreement concerning its mandatory nature), it was valid for it to hold the station of obligation (الوجوب), and its ruling was that of the obligatory. Whoever fasts it attains the proximity of the obligatory and the proximity of the recommended, so its performer has two witnessing-places (مشهدان) and two theophanies (تجليان), known by whoever tastes them, by virtue of his having fasted the Day of Ashura.

(Section on the virtue of the fast of the Day of Ashura)

[Fasting the Day of Ashura is an expiation for the year preceding it]

Muslim mentioned from Abu Qatada that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning the fast of the Day of Ashura: "I hope from Allah that it will expiate the sins of the year preceding it." Thus, the power of the action of that day stands in the place of the powers of all the days of the year, if every day were treated according to what is appropriate for it in the worship of fasting. So, by its power, it carries away from the one who fasts it all that he committed in the year preceding it. He is not held accountable for anything he committed therein, whether in Ramadan or other virtuous days and nights, even though Ramadan is superior to it, as are the Day of Arafah, the Night of Decree (*Laylat al-Qadr*), and the Day of Friday.

[The Imam who leads in prayer one who is superior to him]

Its example is like the Imam who leads in prayer one who is superior to him, such as Ibn Awf when he led the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him—whose superiority is definitively established—in prayer. The Imam carries the forgetfulness of the follower, despite the follower being superior. Therefore, it is not far-fetched that the fast of the Day of Ashura carries away the transgressions of the sinner during all the days of the year. If you were to witness the matter or were among the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), you would know the correctness of what we have said.

[The expression of hope (al-tarajji) is more appropriate for the creature, as a matter of etiquette with Allah]

What the Lawgiver and the Gnostic intend when saying, "I hope from Allah" (احتسب على الله), is not merely good opinion of Allah, but rather an expression of etiquette (لفظة أدب) used with Allah, even though he knows from Allah that Allah will expiate them. Allah says: <<عَسَى اللَّهُ أَنْ يَتُوبَ عَلَيْهِمْ>> (Perhaps Allah will accept their repentance), and He, the Glorified, knows what He executes concerning His servants. Yet, He used the expression of hope (الترجي). The creature is more deserving of this attribute, for it is truly his, had Allah not informed him. But when Allah informs him, he remains upon the origin (الأصل) as a matter of etiquette with the Exalted Allah. Do you not see that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, despite his certainty that he would die—for Allah says to him: <<إِنَّكَ مَيِّتٌ وَإِنَّهُمْ مَيِّتُونَ>> (Indeed, you are to die, and indeed, they are to die)—how did he make an exception when he came to Al-Baqi' and stood by the graves and greeted them, saying: "And we, if Allah wills, will join you"? He made an exception concerning a matter that is certain. Whether the exception is concerning death or faith, both are certain for him. That is Divine etiquette, for Allah said to him: <<وَلَا تَقُولَنَّ لِشَيْءٍ إِنِّي فَاعِلٌ ذَلِكَ غَدًا إِلَّا أَنْ يَشَاءَ اللَّهُ>> (And never say of anything, "Indeed, I will do that tomorrow," except [by adding], "If Allah wills"). Since he used the active participle (*lahiqun* - joining) in his saying "will join you," he made an exception, complying with the command of the Exalted Allah.

(Section on whoever fasts it without intending the fast overnight)

Al-Bukhari mentioned from Salama ibn al-Akwa' that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded a man from Aslam to announce among the people: "Whoever has eaten, let him complete the rest of his day, and whoever has not eaten, let him fast, for today is the Day of Ashura." Thus, He made its ruling the same as the ruling of one who did not intend the fast overnight for the Day of Doubt at the beginning of Ramadan, and then ate, and then it was confirmed that it was Ramadan, so he was commanded to restrain himself and make it up (القضاء). This is an authentic hadith. He said, "let him complete the rest of his day," and did not call him a faster, which strengthens the hadith concerning making it up (القضاء) that Abu Dawud mentioned from Abd al-Rahman ibn Salama, from his uncle, that Aslam came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said, "Did you fast your day thus?" They said, "No." He said, "Then complete the rest of your day and make it up," meaning the Day of Ashura. Even though this hadith was not included among the authentic ones.

[In the Day of Ashura is a secret by which Allah raises its virtue upon His servants]

He observed the sanctity of the day due to the secret (السر) Allah placed in it, which raises its virtue upon His servants. Here, the virtue of restraining oneself from food and drink, even without fasting, became apparent. This is the hunger (الجوع) that the Sufis refer to in their discourse. Concerning this, I say:

> I go hungry, but I do not fast, for my soul *** disputes with me over the reward of fasting.
> If its wages were annihilated, we would say *** that fasting and standing [in prayer] are obligatory.
> For the servant is the servant of Allah, unless *** he is in himself a target for a shooter.

[We were commanded to oppose the People of the Book in what Allah did not permit]

When He commanded making it up (قضائه), He confirmed its resemblance to Ramadan, not to a specific vow (*nadhr*) whose day has passed, for that is not made up, even if its performer restrains himself for the rest of the day if he did not intend it overnight. Since we were commanded to fast it and encouraged to do so, and we had been commanded to oppose the People of the Book—Jews and Christians—in what they legislated for themselves without Allah's permission, and which they altered and changed, and since we could not distinguish what they legislated for themselves from what their Prophet legislated for them, we were commanded to oppose them, except in what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, confirmed for us as having been their law, and which we knew with certainty, such as the stoning of the married adulterer and the performance of prayer for one who remembers it after forgetting it. When certainty was established for us concerning it, we acted upon it.

[We are more deserving of Moses than you]

For the Exalted Allah says concerning the Prophets: <<أُولَئِكَ الَّذِينَ هَدَى اللَّهُ فَبِهُدَاهُمُ اقْتَدِهْ>> (Those are the ones whom Allah has guided; so follow their guidance). And He said: <<شَرَعَ لَكُمْ مِنَ الدِّينِ مَا وَصَّى بِهِ نُوحًا>> (He has ordained for you of religion what He enjoined upon Noah...). And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "We are more deserving of Moses than you." He used "We" (نحن) to refer to himself and his community. Thus, we are more deserving of Moses than the Jews, because they did not believe in everything Moses brought. Had they believed in everything Moses brought, they would have believed in Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Book. We were commanded to believe in him and in what was revealed to him. Then the Real (الحق) informed us of this, and His report is true. Therefore, it is impossible for a believer in the community of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, to believe in some and disbelieve in others. This is Divine Providence (عناية إلهية), as He informed us of our infallibility (*'isma*) from that, which is good tidings for us. The Exalted said: <<آمَنَ الرَّسُولُ بِمَا أُنْزِلَ إِلَيْهِ مِنْ رَبِّهِ وَالْمُؤْمِنُونَ كُلٌّ آمَنَ بِاللَّهِ وَمَلَائِكَتِهِ وَكُتُبِهِ وَرُسُلِهِ لَا نُفَرِّقُ بَيْنَ أَحَدٍ مِنْ رُسُلِهِ>> (The Messenger has believed in what was revealed to him from his Lord, and [so have] the believers. All of them have believed in Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers, [saying], "We make no distinction between any of His messengers").

[Indeed, Allah protected us from opposing the Prophets and relieved us of some of their laws]

Among what Moses brought was the fast of the Day of Ashura. So we believed in it and fasted it by the command of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, as an obligation, according to one view among us, just as Moses fasted it as an obligation. Then Allah obligated Ramadan upon us and gave us the choice concerning the fast of Ashura. So we fast it by way of preference (الأولوية), thereby combining the reward of the obligatory and the supererogatory (النفل), a degree added to the believers among the people of Moses, peace be upon him. Since the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded us to oppose the Jews, he commanded us to fast a day before Ashura, which is the ninth, and a day after it, which is the eleventh. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said to us: "Fast the Day of Ashura, and oppose the Jews in it: fast a day before it and a day after it."

He did not say, "Contradict Moses," for Allah has protected us from contradicting the Prophets. Rather, Allah has abrogated some of their laws (شرائعهم) for us, just as He has abrogated some of what He legislated for us. We believe in every abrogating (ناسخ) and abrogated (منسوخ) verse in every law (شرع). However, belief does not necessitate the existence of the action unless that action is specifically commanded. It is to this extent that we differ from the Jews.

### [The Day of Ashura is the Tenth of Muharram]

For this reason, our scholars mistakenly assumed that Ashura is only the ninth of Muharram. We have narrated traditions (روينا) that support our assertion that it is the tenth day. This is based on the tradition (حديث) we narrated from Abi Ahmad ibn Adi al-Jurjani, who narrated it from Ibn Hayyi, from Dawud ibn Ali, from his father, from his grandfather, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "If I remain until the next year, I shall fast the day before it and the day after it."

The second tradition is that which Muslim narrated from the tradition of Al-Hakam ibn al-A'raj, who said: I came to Ibn Abbas while he was reclining on his cloak at Zamzam. I said to him, "Inform me about the fast of the Day of Ashura." He replied, "When you see the crescent (هلال) of Muharram, O man, count eight days, and fast on the morning of the ninth." I asked, "Was this how Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to fast it?" He said, "Yes."

(Meaning, had he lived until the following year.) What we have stated is supported by what Muslim also narrated from Ibn Abbas, who said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, fasted the Day of Ashura and commanded its fasting, they said, "O Messenger of Allah, it is a day that the Jews and Christians venerate." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said, "If we are alive next year, God willing, we shall fast the ninth day." Ibn Abbas said, "The next year did not come before the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, passed away."

Thus, he did not fast the ninth day *as* Ashura, even if he had lived to fast it. He fasted the Day of Ashura, which is definitively the tenth of Muharram. Therefore, it is not appropriate to say that the ninth is Ashura, given the existence of these reports.

### [The Wisdom in Fasting a Day Before Ashura and a Day After It]

We have already mentioned the wisdom (حكمة) of the ninth and tenth days in relation to the First Name (الاسم الأول) and the Last Name (الاسم الآخر) in this chapter. Similarly, I speak concerning the fasting of the day after Ashura, so that the correspondence (التناسب) we alluded to may be understood. We say that it is also annexed to the First Name, just as Ashura is in the tenth day. The tenth is the beginning of the decade (العقد), and the eleventh is the beginning of the composition of numbers (تركيب الأعداد)—the composition of simple numbers with the decade. Observe the wisdom of the Lawgiver (الشارع) in commanding the fast of a day before it and a day after it, connected to it, so that the Jews would not say that our fast is intended to imitate them. Such imitation is disliked in obligatory duties (الفرائض), unless a person is already engaged in a practice they perform, in which case they do not care, unless a prohibition occurs. We have been forbidden from intentionally preceding Ramadan by a day or two, unless it falls within a fast we habitually observe. Furthermore, it is part of the wisdom that we were forbidden from fasting the Day of Eid al-Fitr, so that we do not connect the fast of Ramadan with another fast, thereby distinguishing the right of the obligatory (الفرض) from the supererogatory (النفل), unlike the consideration of the Day of Jumu'ah (Friday), the discussion of which will come later in this chapter, God willing.

(Section on the Virtue of Fasting the Day of Arafah)

### [Fasting the Day of Arafah is an Expiation for the Year Before It and the Year After It]

It is reported in the authentic tradition (الحديث الثابت) from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, concerning the fast of the Day of Arafah: "I anticipate that Allah will expiate (يكفر) the sins of the year preceding it and the year following it." This was narrated by Muslim from the tradition of Abu Qatadah.

Whoever fasts this day has taken a generous share of what Allah granted His Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in His saying: <<لِيَغْفِرَ لَكَ الله ما تَقَدَّمَ من ذَنْبِكَ وما تَأَخَّرَ>> (That Allah may forgive you your sin that preceded and that which will follow). Thus, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, throughout his entire life, was under the ruling (الحكم) of one who fasts the Day of Arafah.

### [Gnosis and Knowledge]

He specified it with the name Arafah (عرفه) due to the nobility (شرف) of the word *al-Ma'rifah* (Gnosis), which is Knowledge (*al-Ilm*). This is because *al-Ma'rifah* in the language with which our Prophet, peace be upon him, was sent, takes only one object; thus, it possesses the quality of Oneness (الأحدية). It is a noble Name (اسم شريف) by which Allah named Knowledge. Therefore, *al-Ma'rifah* is Knowledge of Oneness (علم بالأحدية). Knowledge (*al-Ilm*) may relate to Oneness or to other things, unlike the term *al-Ma'rifah*. Thus, the two terms are distinguished by what they were designated for. Knowledge (*al-Ilm*) may sometimes substitute for Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*) in language through usage, as mentioned by the grammarians (النحاة), who cited as evidence His saying: <<لا تَعْلَمُونَهُمُ الله يَعْلَمُهُمْ>> (You do not know them; Allah knows them). The interpretation is: "You do not recognize them." They counted *al-Ilm* (Knowledge) as taking a single object due to substitution. Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*) has no ruling except in relation to Oneness. They (the grammarians) were heedless of what we know: that Knowledge (*al-Ilm*) also seeks Oneness (الأحدية). For this reason, it is valid for *al-Ma'rifah* to be one of His Names (أسماء), because the Act (العمل) is the origin, for it is an Attribute (صفة) of the Real (الحق). Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*) is not His Attribute, nor does He have a Name derived from it according to our Law (الشرع), even though Gnosis and Knowledge share a single definition. However, Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*) is one of the names of Knowledge (*al-Ilm*), as we said, and the Gnostic (*al-Arif*) is one of the names of the Knower (*al-Alim*) among us, specifically in relation to Oneness.

### [Knowledge is Designated for Oneness, Just Like Gnosis]

As for our statement that Knowledge (*al-Ilm*) is designated for Oneness (الأحدية), just like Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*), and for this reason we call Knowledge Gnosis: when we say, "I knew Zayd to be standing," our objective was neither Zayd himself nor the standing itself. Rather, our objective was the relationship (نسبة) of Zayd's standing, and that is a single objective, for it is one specific relationship. We know Zayd alone through Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*), and the standing alone through Gnosis. Thus, we say, "I had Gnosis of Zayd," and "I had Gnosis of the standing." This point escaped the grammarians, who imagined that the connection of Knowledge to the relationship of standing to Zayd is identical to its connection to Zayd and the standing themselves. This is an error. For if Zayd was not known to him, and the standing was also not known to him beforehand, it would not be valid to relate what he does not know to what he does not know, because he would not know whether that relationship is sound or not. This type of knowledge is called *al-Tasawwur* (Conception) by the masters of the Balance of Meanings (ميزان المعاني)—which is the Gnosis of particulars (المفردات)—and *al-Tasdiq* (Assent)—which is the Gnosis of composites (المركبات). *Al-Tasdiq* is the relationship of one particular to another by way of informing about one through the other. This is known to the grammarians as the subject and the predicate (المبتدأ والخبر), and to others as the subject and the attribute (الموضوع والمحمول).

### [Oneness is the Noblest Attribute of the One]

We now return to our topic and say: We know the nobility (شرف) of the Day of Arafah from its name, due to its designation and its connection to Oneness (الأحدية). Indeed, Allah is One God (إله واحد), and Oneness is the noblest Attribute (صفة) of the One among all Attributes. It permeates (سارية) every existent thing. Were it not permeating every existent thing, it would not be valid for us to know the Oneness of the Real (الحق), glory be to Him. No one knows Him except through himself, and there is no proof of His Oneness except His Oneness itself.

"Whoever knows himself knows his Lord."

Thus he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said. And Abu al-Atahiyya said:

> وفي كل شي‏ء له آية *** تدل على أنه واحد
> And in everything there is a sign for Him, *** Indicating that He is One.

The sign (الآية) is the Oneness (أحدية) of everything, which distinguishes it from others of its kind. Oneness permeates everything—pre-eternal (قديم), originated (حادث), non-existent (معدوم), and existent (موجود). Not everyone perceives its permeation due to its extreme clarity and manifestation, just like Life (الحياة) according to the masters of Unveiling (الكشف) and Faith (الايمان). Life permeates everything, whether its life is manifest, like the animal, or hidden, like the plant and the inanimate. Allah is Living (حي) without dispute. There is nothing other than Allah that does not glorify Allah with His praise, and nothing glorifies Him except that which knows Him. A prerequisite for the Knower (*al-Alim*) is that he must be living; therefore, everything must be living.

### [The Preference for Fasting the Day of Arafah Outside of Arafah]

Since Oneness (الأحدية) belongs to Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*), and Oneness belongs to Allah, exalted is He, in His Essence (ذاته), we preferred fasting the Day of Arafah over breaking the fast (فطره) when outside Arafah. If we are *in* Arafah, we know that the fast is for Allah, not for us, so we prefer breaking the fast over fasting, due to the witnessing (شهود) of Arafah—so understand this. Fasting is truly for Allah, and Oneness is truly for Him. Thus, a correspondence (المناسبة) occurred between fasting and the Day of Arafah, for each is unique. The effect of fasting Arafah extends to what comes after it, which is not the case for any other fast for everyone, and it affects what precedes it, because it is temporal (زماني) and thus restricted by precedence and subsequence. The point is that its effect is general, like the Attribute of the Real (صفة الحق) in bringing the possibilities (الممكنات) into existence generally, not restricted to one possibility over another. Although the command belongs to Allah, before and after (من قبل ومن بعد), it came as an indeclinable noun (مبنيا) without annexation (غير مضاف), due to His Exaltedness not being restricted by before and after. This quality belonging to the Day of Arafah is not shared by other times; thus, it is distinguished from its genus. Although there are other acts that are stronger in effect, they are not temporal—that is, they do not belong to the time itself. The utmost effect of Ashura is that it expiates the year preceding it, so its connection is to the past. Arafah's connection is to the past and the non-past. Ashura is an elevator (رافع), while Arafah is an elevator and a preventer (دافع). Thus, it combines elevation and prevention, which corresponds to the Real (الحق), for the Real relates to the existent through preservation (حفظا) and to the non-existent through creation (إيجادا). The correspondence between the Day of Arafah and the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) is thus abundant. Therefore, fasting it is preferred when outside Arafah, even though it retains this ruling *in* Arafah. However, breaking the fast in Arafah is superior to fasting it, for the reason we mentioned, and also according to the apparent ruling (الحكم الظاهر) of following and emulation (الاتباع والاقتداء). Concerning following, He said: <<فَاتَّبِعُونِي يُحْبِبْكُمُ الله>> (So follow Me, [and] Allah will love you). Concerning emulation, He said: <<لَقَدْ كانَ لَكُمْ في رَسُولِ الله أُسْوَةٌ حَسَنَةٌ>> (There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern). And he broke the fast on this day in Arafah.

### [The Difference Among Scholars of Formalism Regarding Fasting the Day of Arafah in Arafah]

The Scholars of Formalism (علماء الرسوم) differed only regarding fasting it *in* Arafah, not elsewhere, due to the likelihood of hardship (المشقة) and weakness for supplication (الدعاء), which is generally the required act for the pilgrim on this day, for the best supplication is the supplication of the Day of Arafah. This is like the traveler breaking the fast during Ramadan. Some scholars chose for the pilgrim to break the fast and for the non-pilgrim to fast, combining the two traditions. We previously presented the authentic narrated report regarding its fasting at the beginning of the chapter. We mention that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not fast it in Arafah out of mercy (رحمة) for the people who would experience hardship in fasting it—this is what the Scholars of Formalism assumed. But the matter is as we stated: he was capable of fasting it himself, yet he forbade his community from fasting it in Arafah. Similar instances occurred in the Law (الشرع), such as the marriage of donation (نكاح الهبة), which was exclusive to him but unanimously forbidden for the community, and like continuous fasting (*al-Wisal*), which, even if permissible, is disliked. Muslim narrated from Umm al-Fadl that people disputed in her presence on the Day of Arafah regarding the fasting of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Some said he was fasting, and others said he was not. So, she sent him a cup of milk while he was standing on his camel, and he drank it. Allah the Exalted said: <<وما أَرْسَلْناكَ إِلَّا رَحْمَةً لِلْعالَمِينَ>> (And We have not sent you except as a mercy to the worlds). The mercy here, according to us, is that he informed them that breaking the fast on the Day of Arafah *in* Arafah is the Sunnah (practice). According to the Scholars of Formalism, it was seeking ease (الرفق). Our proof lies in his saying: "Take your rites (مناسككم) from me." Among these rites is the absence of fasting in that place on that day. The command to adopt it is not suspended when it comes free of anything that would prevent its adoption.

### [The Tradition Prohibiting Fasting the Day of Arafah in Arafah]

As for the tradition prohibiting fasting the Day of Arafah in Arafah, its chain of narration (إسناده) includes Mahdi ibn Harb al-Hijri, who is not well-known.

Al-Nasa'i narrated it from his tradition, from Abu Hurayrah, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade fasting the Day of Arafah in Arafah.

Al-Tirmidhi's tradition from Uqbah ibn Amir states that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The Day of Arafah, the Day of Sacrifice (يوم النحر), and the Days of Tashriq (أيام التشريق) are our festival (*Eid*), the people of Islam, and they are days of eating and drinking."

Abu Isa said: The tradition of Uqbah is *hasan sahih* (good and authentic). It is as if this statement points to what we have said, and it points to the station of Gnosis (*al-Ma'rifah*) and the Gnostic (*al-Arif*). The station of Gnosis does not permit fasting, since the Gnostic knows for Whom the fast is. Thus, his day of *Eid* (festival) is the day he attains this station. Festival days are days of joy. He intended to spread joy, outwardly and inwardly: in the rational soul (النفس الناطقة) by abandoning the fast, and in the animal soul (النفس الحيوانية) by eating and drinking. Thus, he combined the two joys. He did not explicitly mention the prohibition of fasting in this tradition, but he coupled it with the forbidden fast, which is the Day of Sacrifice, and the disliked fast, which is the fast of the Days of Tashriq. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, preferred eating and drinking outwardly on that day and did not address the prohibition of fasting it. We were forbidden from fasting the Day of Eid al-Adha by a different report, which I shall mention, God willing. Furthermore, his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in this report, "the people of Islam," and not "the people of Faith (الايمان)," indicates the consideration of the outward (الظاهر) here. For this reason, we said that he considered the animal soul, whose joy on its festival day is in eating and drinking. Know this.

(Section on Fasting the Six Days of Shawwal)

### [The Tradition of Fasting the Six Days of Shawwal]

The difference of opinion regarding their timing has already been mentioned. I have a reservation (نظر) concerning this report because the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not affirm the letter *ta marbuta* (الهاء) in the number—meaning in the word *sitta* (six)—when he said, "and follows it with *sittan* (six) of Shawwal." He was an Arab, and days (*ayyam*) are masculine, and fasting only occurs during the day (*yawm*), which is the daylight (*nahar*). Therefore, the *ta marbuta* must be affirmed in the number. This is the reason why the text (*matn*) of the tradition is considered objectionable (*munkar*) despite the authenticity of its chain of narration (*tariq al-khabar*). Thus, it is preferred in my view that he considered continuous fasting (*al-Wisal*) in this matter, connecting the fast of the day with the fast of the night, since the night precedes the day because the day is stripped away from it. Alternatively, it could be a rare dialect (لغة شاذة) spoken by the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in a gathering where someone spoke that dialect.

### [Continuous Fasting in the Six Days of Shawwal]

Despite this, whoever is able to perform continuous fasting (*al-Wisal*) during these six days is more worthy, acting upon the apparent meaning of the report's wording. Continuous fasting was not forbidden by way of prohibition (*tahrim*). Rather, he observed compassion and mercy (الشفقة والرحمة) for the common people (ظاهر الناس) so that they would not impose difficulty and hardship upon themselves. Had it been forbidden, he would not have performed continuous fasting with them. It is reported that he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed, this religion is firm, so penetrate it gently."

And he said: "Whoever strives against this religion will be overcome by it."

Muslim narrated from Anas ibn Malik that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, performed continuous fasting at the end of Ramadan, and some Muslims followed suit. When this reached him, he said: "If the month were extended for us, we would perform continuous fasting such that the extremists would abandon their extremism."

Whoever is unable to perform continuous fasting for all of them should fast continuously until the pre-dawn meal (*al-Suhur*) each day, so that the night enters the fast every night. The limit for breaking the fast (فطرها) would then be the pre-dawn meal, just as sunset is the limit for the day for those who do not fast continuously.

In the *Sahih* collection, he, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever among you wishes to fast continuously, let him fast continuously until the pre-dawn meal." Al-Bukhari narrated this from Abu Sa'id.

### [The Lawgiver Forbade Continuous Fasting Out of Mercy for the Community]

What supports our statement that he intended mercy for the people in this matter is what Muslim also narrated from Aisha, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade them from continuous fasting out of mercy for them. They said, "But you fast continuously!" He replied, "I am not like you. I spend the night being fed and given drink by my Lord."

Thus, he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was unveiled (كوشف) to the state of that group he addressed—that they did not possess this state. He did not mean that this was exclusive to him apart from his community. Indeed, we have found this as a spiritual experience (*dhawq*) within ourselves during our continuous fasting. We spent the night in a state of continuous fasting, and our Lord fed us and gave us drink during our night of *wisal*. We awoke strong, desiring no food, and the scent of the food we ate—which our Lord fed us—was smelled emanating from us. People were astonished by its pleasant fragrance and asked us, "Where did you get this scent from the food you ate? We have never smelled anything like it." I informed some of them of the state, and I remained silent regarding others. If this were exclusive to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, we would not have attained it. Thus, continuous fasting and breaking the fast are both valid for us, combining the two rewards and the two joys.

### [The Wisdom of Continuous Fasting]

The wisdom (حكمة) of continuous fasting (*al-Wisal*) is that the Real (الحق) said that fasting is for Him, and He commanded us with what belongs to Him, making it an unparalleled act of worship. If one separates the two days by breaking the fast, he has not performed *wisal*. If he does not break the fast, *wisal* is realized. This alludes to connecting the servant's fast with the Fast attributed to the Real, to show the servant that he possesses a form of Transcendence (تنزيه) through fasting, just as the Real possesses Transcendence through the Fast. This is a beautiful intimation for the Gnostics (*al-Arifin*). This is also the case in reality, for the servant has a specific transcendence, especially when his action is the transcendence of the Real. His action returns to him, which is transcendence. The Transcendence of the Real is not due to the transcendence of the one who declares Him transcendent; rather, He, exalted is He, is Transcendent in Essence (منزه الذات) by Himself—we did not make Him transcendent. Therefore, our transcendence returns to us when others are deprived of it. Thus, whoever is able to perform continuous fasting during these six days is more entitled and worthy.

### [Omission of the Ta Marbuta in the Masculine Number]

If anyone finds a narration from the Arabs in the language where the *ta marbuta* (الهاء) is omitted in a masculine number, the tradition should be interpreted according to that dialect. We have narrated that when Allah revealed to His Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: <<ومَكَرُوا مَكْراً كُبَّاراً>> (And they planned a great plot), those present did not recognize this grammatical error (اللحن) nor did they know its meaning. While they were in this state, a Bedouin arrived, approaching as a stranger. He entered upon the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, greeted him, and said, "O Muhammad, I am a man from the *kubbar* (great ones) of my people," pronouncing the *kaf* with a *damma* and the *ba* with a *shadda*. The attendees then realized that this word had been revealed in the dialect of that Arab and his companions, and they understood its meaning.

Thus, it is not unlikely that the omission of the *ta marbuta* is permissible in a masculine number in the dialect of some Bedouins. Even if that were the case, it would not invalidate the Realities (الحقائق) unveiled to us. The All-Knowing Lawgiver (الشارع العالم) would then intend both meanings simultaneously in this word: for those whose dialect it is, and for those whose dialect it is not.

### [The Two Considerations for Fasting the Six Days of Shawwal]

He made them six and not more or less, and He clarified that this constitutes fasting the entire year (*sawm al-dahr*), based on Allah the Exalted's saying: <<من جاءَ بِالْحَسَنَةِ فَلَهُ عَشْرُ أَمْثالِها>> (Whoever comes with a good deed will have ten times its like). Most scholars of Allah (علماء بالله) hold this view. This interpretation has a specific limit: that the number of days in Ramadan must be thirty. If it is less, the reward falls below this degree. According to us, these six days compensate for the deficiency in fasting the entire year caused by breaking the fast on the days when fasting is forbidden—which are six days: the Day of Eid al-Fitr, the Day of Sacrifice, the three Days of Tashriq, and the sixteenth day of Sha'ban. These six days compensate for the deficiency caused by the days when fasting is forbidden. The other consideration, which is relied upon regarding the fasting of these days being exactly six, is that Allah the Exalted <<خَلَقَ السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضَ وما بَيْنَهُما في سِتَّةِ أَيَّامٍ>> (created the heavens and the earth and what is between them in six days). We were the intended purpose of that creation, so He manifested what He manifested of creation during those six days for our sake, as reported in the tradition.

Thus, He, glory be to Him, was for us during those days. He made the fast of these six days for us in correspondence to those six days, so that we might be characterized therein by what belongs to Him, which is Fasting, just as He characterized Himself by what belongs to us, which is Creation.

### [Ahmad al-Sabti ibn Harun al-Rashid]

For this reason, Ahmad al-Sabti, the son of the Commander of the Faithful Harun al-Rashid, used to fast six days of every week and dedicate himself to worship during them. When Saturday came, he would work a trade (احترف) to earn what he would eat for the rest of the week. Because of this, he was named Al-Sabti (The Saturday Man). I met him during the circumambulation (*Tawaf*) on a Friday after the prayer, while I was performing *Tawaf*. I did not recognize him, but I sensed something unusual about him and his manner of *Tawaf*. I did not see him jostle or be jostled; he would pass through two men without separating them. I said, "This is undoubtedly a spirit that has materialized." I held him and greeted him. He returned the greeting, and I walked alongside him. A conversation and discussion took place between us, during which I asked him why he dedicated Saturday to working a trade. He replied, "Because Allah, glory be to Him, began our creation on Sunday, and the completion of it ended on Friday. I dedicated those days to the worship of Allah the Exalted, not engaging in anything that contained a share for my lower self (نفسي). When Saturday came, I isolated myself for the share of my lower self, working a trade to seek sustenance for those days, doing this every week. For He, glory be to Him, looked upon what He created on Saturday, reclined, placed one hand over the other, and said, 'I am the King,' due to the manifestation of Sovereignty (الملك). For this reason, the day was named *al-Sabt* (Saturday), and *al-Sabt* means rest. This is why He, the Exalted, informed us that no weariness (لغوب) touched Him in what He created—and weariness is exhaustion. So, it is rest, but not from exhaustion, as it is in our case." I was astonished by his insight and intention. I asked him who the Axis of the Time (*Qutb al-Zaman*) was in his era. He replied, "I am." Then he bade me farewell and departed. When I came to the place where I sit for people, one of my companions, a neighbor named Nabil ibn Khazr ibn Khazrun al-Sabti, from the people of Ceuta (*Sabtah*), said to me, "I saw a strange man whom we do not know in Mecca speaking and conversing with you during the *Tawaf*. Who was he, and where did he come from?" I recounted his story, and those present were astonished by it.

### [The Knowledge of Wisdom in Things and the People of Allah]

This is the correct consideration for the six days. The Lawgiver (الشارع) omitted the *ta marbuta* (الهاء), if the narration is authentic, due to the consideration of the nights (الليالي), because they are the signs of the Unseen (*al-Ghayb*), unlike the day. The Unseen is that which the Real (الحق) has kept exclusively for Himself, for He <<فَلا يُظْهِرُ عَلى‏ غَيْبِهِ أَحَداً إِلَّا من ارْتَضى‏ من رَسُولٍ>> (does not disclose His Unseen to anyone, except to a messenger whom He has approved). Similarly, the knowledge of Wisdom (*Ilm al-Hikmah*) in things is not truly knowledge except for the People of Allah (*Ahl Allah*). As for the people of speculation and analogy (أهل الفكر والقياس), they encounter wisdom merely by chance (بحكم الاتفاق), so it is not considered knowledge by them. But the People of Knowledge of Allah (*Ahl al-Ilm bi-Allah*) know that this is the intended meaning of that command, and thus it becomes knowledge for them by that consideration, and they pursue it intentionally, not by chance. When some people see the generosity of the People of Allah in such matters, they speak of it as a possibility, but they do not assert it definitively, based on their own souls and their rank in knowledge. This is Allah the Exalted's saying concerning those whose state is such: <<ذلِكَ مَبْلَغُهُمْ من الْعِلْمِ>> (That is the extent of their knowledge). Know this, and Allah is the Granter of success to what is correct.

(Section on the First Days of the Month, which are the First Three Days)

### [Every Month is a Guest Arriving to the Human from the Side of the Merciful]

Muslim narrated from Mu'adhah that she asked Aisha, "Did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, fast three days of every month?" She replied, "Yes." I asked her, "Which days of the month did he fast?" She said, "He did not care which days of the month he fasted."

Know that every month that comes to a person is merely a guest (*dha'if*) arriving from the side of the Real (الحق). It is therefore incumbent upon the person to fulfill its right, which is called hospitality (*dhiyafah*), and the right of the guest is three days. For this reason, the Lawgiver legislated in the recommended law (الشرع المندوب إليه) three days of every month. He encouraged us to fast them at the beginning, so we said we should fast them during the three *Ghurar* (first bright days) of the month, because the Law came commanding the hastening of food for the guest. He said: "Haste is from Satan, except in three things," and he mentioned feeding the guest among them. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to fast three days from the beginning (*ghurrah*) of every month. Al-Nasa'i narrated this from Ibn Mas'ud. Fasting is an Attribute (صفة) of the Real, and He singled it out from all actions for Himself. It is an action specific to this phenomenal existence (*nash'ah*); it does not belong to an angel. Thus, no close-stationed angel (ملك مقرب) witnesses Him, glory be to Him, in the station of my fast, nor does He, glory be to Him, ever manifest Himself to him in the station of my fast, for it is among the specific characteristics of this phenomenal existence. This hospitality was three days for every month because it comes from the Real and returns to Him, glory be to Him, praising Him for receiving it, or possessing its wealth, according to how the servant receives it. The best way to receive it is with what is a Divine Attribute, which is Fasting.

### [The Wisdom in Fasting the First Days of Every Month]

Allah the Exalted possesses three hundred dispositions (*khuluq*), as reported from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Three out of three hundred is one-tenth of one-tenth. One-tenth of three hundred is thirty, which is the month, and one-tenth of thirty is three. Thus, it is one-tenth of one-tenth. This relates to His saying: <<من جاءَ بِالْحَسَنَةِ فَلَهُ عَشْرُ أَمْثالِها>> (Whoever comes with a good deed will have ten times its like). The Real accepts those three days as thirty, and then rewards him for the thirty with three hundred dispositions, because He said "ten times its like." It is as if he fasted the entire month, and thus he is rewarded with the three hundred, since the thirty were accepted as an action, not a reward, for they are the like of the good deed (*al-hasanah*), and the good deed is an action. The two likes are those that share the attributes of the soul (النفس). Observe the subtlety and beauty of the Lawgiver's wisdom in encouraging us to fast three days of every month and how He did not alert the general populace to the exact nature of the reward. For the attainment of the reward, when it comes suddenly, without knowing its cause or anticipating it, is sweeter to the common soul. Fasting is a Divine disposition (خلق إلهي), so its reward is of the same genus: the three hundred Divine dispositions with which the one who fasts these three days is characterized, just as he was characterized by Fasting, which is a Divine description. The common person (*al-Ammi*) who did not fast with this understanding will have his reward derived from the fact that he did not eat or drink, and it will be said to him: "Eat, O one who did not eat, and drink, O one who did not drink." Allah the Exalted said: <<كُلُوا واشْرَبُوا هَنِيئاً بِما أَسْلَفْتُمْ في الْأَيَّامِ الْخالِيَةِ>> (Eat and drink in satisfaction for what you put forth in the days past)—meaning the days of fasting during the time of obligation (*taklif*). The People of Allah (*Ahl Allah*) who fast these three days, or any fast performed with the awareness we mentioned—that he is characterized by a Divine description—will have their reward derived from this description, according to His saying: <<من وُجِدَ في رَحْلِهِ فَهُوَ جَزاؤُهُ‏>> (Whoever is found in his saddlebag, that is his recompense).

### [The Human is the Most Complete in Phenomenal Existence, and the Angel is the Most Complete in Station]

Since this Attribute (Fasting) is not an action for the angel, the angel does not attend the Presence (حضرة) of this Theophany (التجلي) with the one who fasts. Thus, the angel does not know this manifestation by intrinsic spiritual experience (*dhawq dhati*). The human, if he is among the People of Complete Knowledge of Allah, witnesses Him, exalted is He, in everything the angel witnesses, regardless of the angel's station. Despite this, it does not indicate that the human is greater in the sight of Allah than the angel. The human is the most complete in phenomenal existence (*akmal nash'ah*), and the angel is the most complete in station (*akmal manzilah*). This is what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, told me in a visionary experience (*waqi'ah*) where I saw him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and asked him. However, the human is more comprehensive in spiritual experience (*ajma' bi-dhawq*) than the angel due to his comprehensiveness (جمعيته). Some people err in this station because the spiritual being (*al-Ruhani*) can take any form it wishes, not realizing that applying kohl to the eyes is not the same as being the kohl itself. The Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل)—not the animal human—is the most complete phenomenal existence for the Realities (الحقائق) upon which the Realities of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) and the Realities of the World (العالم) were established. He is the one whom Allah created upon His Form (الصورة). By his comprehensiveness, he is entirely the Real (حق كله). The Real is his locus of manifestation (*majla*), since he possesses perfection. Thus, he sees Him with every eye and witnesses Him in every form. This does not imply that he is superior in the sight of Allah, for this is due to his comprehensiveness. It cannot be said that a thing is superior to itself. Superiority (*fadilah*) occurs between two distinct entities, and there is no distinction here, for the angel is a part of the human, and the part belongs to the whole. The whole possesses something from the part that the part does not possess from the whole. Two likes do not possess superiority over each other in that aspect in which they are alike; if they possess superiority, then they are not alike.

### [The One Held in the Abode]

We have a poem concerning this, from a wondrous visionary experience (*waqi'ah*), in which I was called, "The One Held in the Abode (ممسوك الدار)":

> مسكتك في داري لإظهار صورتي *** فسبحانكم مجلى وسبحان سبحانا
> I held you in My Abode to manifest My Form, *** So glory be to you, the locus of manifestation, and glory be to the Glorified.

> فما أبصرت عيناك مثلي كاملا *** ولا أبصرت عيني كمثلك إنسانا
> Your eyes have never seen a Perfect One like Me, *** Nor have My eyes seen a human like you.

> فلم يبق في الإمكان أكمل منكمو *** نصبت على هذا من الشرع برهانا
> There remains nothing more perfect than you in possibility, *** I have established a proof for this from the Law.

> فأي كمال كان لم يك غيركم *** على كل وجه كان ذلك ما كانا
> Whatever perfection existed was none other than you, *** In every aspect, that is what was.

> طهرت إلى خلقي بصورة آدم *** وقررت هذا في الشرائع إيمانا
> I manifested Myself to My creation in the Form of Adam, *** And I established this in the Laws as Faith.

> وسميته لما تجلى بصورتي *** إلى ناظري حقا وإن كان إنسانا
> And I named him, when he manifested in My Form, *** To My observer, the Real, even though he was human.

> فقل فيه ما تهواه إن شئت أنه *** ليقبله عينا وإن كان أكوانا
> So say about him whatever you desire, if you wish, that he *** Accepts it as the Essence, even if it is the cosmoses.

> فلو كان في الإمكان أكمل منكمو *** لكان وجود النقص في إذا كانا
> If there were anything more perfect than you in possibility, *** Then deficiency would exist in Me if that were the case.

> لأنك مخصوص بصورة حضرتي *** وأكمل منها ما يكون فقد بأنا
> Because you are specified by the Form of My Presence, *** And what is more perfect than it has already been made manifest.

> فماثل وجودي فالتقابل حاصل *** فزن ذاتكم إني وضعتك ميزانا
> So resemble My Existence, for correspondence is achieved, *** Weigh your Essence, for I have set you as the Balance.

> تجد علم ما قد قلت فيك مسطرا *** ولا أحدا أوجدته منك ريانا
> You will find the knowledge of what I have said about you inscribed, *** And no one whom I brought into existence is more quenched than you.

> ظهرت لنا مجلى فعاينت صورتي *** وعاينت فيك الكون رمزا وتبيانا
> You appeared to Us as a locus of manifestation, so you witnessed My Form, *** And you witnessed the Cosmos in yourself, as a symbol and an explanation.

> وساررتكم لما رأيت سراركم *** وأعلنت قولي إذ تجليت إحسانا
> I confided in you when I saw your secrets, *** And I declared My saying when I manifested as Benevolence (الإحسان).

> وما أنت ذاتي لا ولا أنا ذاتكم *** فإن كنت لي عينا فلا تبده الآنا
> You are not My Essence, nor am I your Essence, *** But if you are My Essence, do not reveal it now.

> فأخسرنا من كان يعلن سره *** وأربحنا من كان يخفيه كتمانا
> The one who declares his secret loses, *** And the one who conceals it gains.

> فمن كان ذا كتم لسري وغيرة *** سيلقي غدا روحا لدي وريحانا
> Whoever possesses concealment of My secret and protective jealousy, *** Will find spirit and sweet basil with Me tomorrow.

> إذا كنت لي عينا أكون لكم يدا *** وأظهركم بالحال سرا وإعلانا
> If you are My Essence, I shall be your Hand, *** And I shall manifest you through the spiritual state, secretly and openly.

> وصيرت قلبي للتجلي منصة *** ومهدته حبا لخيلك ميدانا
> I made your heart a platform for Theophany, *** And paved it with love as a field for your cavalry.

> وأملأته من كل شهم غشمشم *** لدعواك فرسانا تجول وركبانا
> And I filled it with every noble, fierce warrior, *** For your call, horsemen and riders who roam.

> وجئتك بالأسماء يقدم جمعها *** من أسمائه الحسنى خبيرا ومحسانا
> I came to you with the Names, their assembly led *** By two of His Beautiful Names: The All-Aware and The Benevolent.

> وأنزلتها تبغي الفناء بفنائكم *** وأرسلتها عينا معينا وطوفانا
> And I sent them down seeking Annihilation (الفناء) through your annihilation, *** And I sent them as a flowing spring and a flood.

> وهبتك يا عبدي من أسماء ذاتكم *** ملابس أعياد ضروبا وألوانا
> And I granted you, O My servant, from the Names of your Essence, *** Garments of festivals, of various kinds and colors.

> فإن كنت لي بي كنت أنت ولا تقل *** أنا أنت بل كن في الخليقة رحمانا
> If you are for Me, by Me you shall be you, and do not say, *** "I am You," but rather, be The Merciful (رحمانا) among creation.

### [Fasting the First Days of the Month and the Zakat of the Tenth]

Therefore, realize, may Allah support you, what we alluded to regarding the fasting of the three days of every month. For us, they are according to the limit we mentioned. For the common people (*al-Ammah*), these three days are accepted as the *Zakat* (purifying alms) of that month, and in the total year, they are the *Zakat* of that year, amounting to thirty-six days. This is like the tenth (*al-ushr*) in the *Zakat* of grains. The common people are concerned with the soul that seeks nourishment, which is the Vegetative Soul (النفس النباتية), not the Animal Soul (النفس الحيوانية). The animal does not seek nourishment by virtue of being alive, but rather by virtue of being vegetative. So, do not confuse the Realities (الحقائق). For this reason, they were permitted, since they abstained during the time of fasting, from consuming what causes them to grow, which is nourishment. Allah the Exalted showed mercy to them through the pre-dawn meal (*al-Suhur*) as a substitute for eating during the day. The fasting person loses nothing of his nourishment if he takes the *Suhur*. Allah encouraged the consumption of the *Suhur* and named it nourishment so that the Vegetative Soul would have no claim to seek a right from Allah. If the servant abandons the *Suhur*, the seeking of its right becomes incumbent upon him from the soul, and from Allah, Who commanded him to deliver its right to it, for the obligated person (*al-mukallaf*) is commanded to render to every possessor of a right his due.

### [The Fast of the Common People and the Fast of the Elite]

Just as we distinguished ourselves from the People of the Book regarding the pre-dawn meal, and our consideration in our *Suhur* is different from what the common people consider, our fast differs from theirs in this respect. We share with them what the Vegetative Soul seeks from us and from them, but they do not share with us what is specific to the Rational Soul (النفس الناطقة), which is the intellect, concerning delivering the Real (الحق) to its rightful recipient. Indeed, your soul has a right over you, and it is the most severe of the rights of the contingent entities (الأكوان) after the right of Allah over you, because your adversary is between your two sides. There is no right belonging to any contingent entity over anyone except that Allah has a right in that contingent entity. So, guard your soul. When tomorrow comes, in the station of Recompense and Theophany (التجلي), the difference between the groups and the degrees of superiority will become manifest. How great is the difference between a soul that is resurrected with Divine characteristics (نعوت إلهية) and a soul deprived of that, whose value on the Day of Resurrection is spent on what it spent its value on in the world: rushing headlong into what this natural phenomenal existence seeks, namely, expansion beyond necessity. There is no difference between such a person and the rest of the animals; this is the animal human.

### [The Human Remains Anxious and Greedy in the Present and Future]

Often, when an animal is satisfied, it has no ambition for the future. The human is not like that; he remains anxious (مهموما) and greedy (منهوما) in the present and the future. He gathers but is never satisfied, because he <<خُلِقَ هَلُوعاً إِذا مَسَّهُ الشَّرُّ جَزُوعاً وإِذا مَسَّهُ الْخَيْرُ مَنُوعاً إِلَّا الْمُصَلِّينَ الَّذِينَ هُمْ عَلى‏ صَلاتِهِمْ دائِمُونَ>> (was created anxious. When evil touches him, impatient, and when good touches him, withholding, except the observers of prayer, those who are constant in their prayer). They are those who lag behind this characteristic upon which they were naturally disposed, for the one who prays (*al-musalli*) is the one who comes late after the one who preceded him in the racecourse. This is the meaning of His saying, <<إِلَّا الْمُصَلِّينَ>> (except the observers of prayer), here in consideration. It may also be an interpretation of the verse, which is permissible, but interpreting it as an allusion (إشارة) is more protective. The souls of the common people who are in this state are veiled in this world and the Hereafter, so that pain may be lifted from them, just as it was lifted here. The People of Allah (*Ahl Allah*) are likewise; just as they are created in this world, so shall they be tomorrow on the Day of Resurrection.

### [The Gathering of Bodies and the Spiritual and Sensory Gardens]

Were it not for the gathering of bodies (حشر الأجسام) in the Hereafter, the regret of missing out (*hasrat al-fawt*) would arise in the souls of the ascetics (*al-Zuhhad*) and the Gnostics (*al-Arifin*) in the Hereafter, and they would be tormented if the Gardens were restricted to the Spiritual Gardens (الجنات المعنوية) and not the Sensory Gardens (الحسية). Thus, Allah created in the Hereafter a Sensory Garden and a Spiritual Garden. In the Sensory Garden, He permitted them whatever their souls desire and removed from them the pain of needs. Their desires are like the Will (الإرادة) of the Real: when it relates to the desired object, it comes into being. The people of bliss (*Ahl al-Sa'adah*) do not eat to repel the pain of hunger, nor do they drink to repel the pain of thirst. Since they occupied themselves with Allah here, according to what He obligated them, conducting affairs by the balance (الميزان) He set for them, fearing that they might give short measure or lose the balance, He, glory be to Him, made their occupation in the Hereafter the Sensory Garden for their natural bodies, as a corresponding reward (*jaza'an wifaqan*). Allah the Exalted said: <<إِنَّ أَصْحابَ الْجَنَّةِ الْيَوْمَ في شُغُلٍ فاكِهُونَ هُمْ وأَزْواجُهُمْ في ظِلالٍ عَلَى الْأَرائِكِ مُتَّكِؤُنَ‏>> (Indeed, the companions of Paradise, that Day, will be busy in enjoyment. They and their spouses will be in shade, reclining on couches).

### [And the Harvest of the Two Gardens is Near for the Gnostics]

The Gnostics (*al-Arifun*) and others are equal in this sensory form. But the Gnostics triumph by what they exceed others in: the Gardens of Meanings (جنات المعاني). Thus, <<جَنَى الْجَنَّتَيْنِ للعارفين دانٍ>> (The harvest of the two gardens is near for the Gnostics). <<فَبِأَيِّ آلاءِ رَبِّكُما تُكَذِّبانِ>> (Then which of the favors of your Lord will you deny?) We deny none of Your favors, O our Lord. This occupation (الشغل) prevents the common people and the Scholars of Formalism (علماء الرسوم) in this world and the Hereafter. The People of Allah (*Ahl Allah*) are with them in this occupation insofar as their Vegetative and Animal Souls are concerned, yet they are with Allah from that other aspect. Just as their need for nourishment did not veil them from Allah in this world, despite the strength of His authority in this world to repel the pains of hunger, thirst, and the sensation of various painful things, similarly, the sensible bliss of the Gardens will not veil them from Allah in the Hereafter, in being characterized by His Names that are appropriate for the Final Abode. For that Abode has Divine Names that no one knows at all today. The Divine Names are only manifested by their stations. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, will say, "I praise Him with praises that I do not know now," for the station determines the Names, since it is derived from their effects. However, this bliss we mention, which contains no regret, will only be in Paradise, not on the Day of Resurrection (*al-Qiyamah*). For the Day of Resurrection is the Day of Mutual Loss (يوم التغابن) for everyone. The fortunate one says, "Woe is me, I wish I had done more," and the wretched one says, <<يا حَسْرَتى‏ عَلى‏ ما فَرَّطْتُ>> (Oh, my regret over what I neglected). For this reason, it is called the Day of Regret (*Yawm al-Hasrah*), because it manifests such things, derived from *hasartu al-thawb* (I uncovered the garment), meaning I removed it, and what was beneath it appeared.

(Section on Those Who Made the Three Days of Every Month the Fast of the Three White Days)

### [The White Days, or the Appearance of the Sun to Our Eyes in the Moon]

Al-Nasa'i narrated from the tradition of Jabir ibn Abdullah that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Fasting three days of every month is like fasting the entire year. The White Days (الأيام البيض) are the thirteenth, fourteenth, and fifteenth."

This is the manifestation of the Real (حق) in creation (خلق), which is the appearance of the sun—not its essence—in the moon during its full nights, which are the White Nights (الليالي البيض). Their days are called the White Days because the night, from beginning to end, remains illuminated during them. He made their nights into days to remove the darkness of the night, with the rising of the sun being perfected through the mediation of the moon. Thus, He made them a witnessing (شهادة), whereas they were Unseen (غيب) in which everything was concealed. Now, everything that was hidden by the darkness of the night becomes manifest in them. Although the day is the offspring of the night, it is one of its enemies, for it constantly drives it away. Allah the Exalted said: <<إِنَّ من أَزْواجِكُمْ وأَوْلادِكُمْ عَدُوًّا لَكُمْ فَاحْذَرُوهُمْ‏>> (Indeed, among your wives and your children is an enemy to you, so beware of them).

> يا حذرى من حذرى *** لو كان يغني حذرى
> O my caution against my caution, *** If only my caution could avail me.

The day is a disobedient child (ولد عاق) that constantly chases away its father and drives him out, night and day, to the extent it is able.

### [The Appearance of the Sun in the Mirror of the Moon is the Manifestation of the Real in Creation]

The appearance of the sun in the mirror of the moon is the manifestation of the Real (حق) in creation (خلق), because Light (*al-Nur*) is one of the Names of Allah the Exalted. He manifested through His Name, Light, in the appearance of the moon. Allah the Exalted said: <<وجَعَلَ الْقَمَرَ فِيهِنَّ نُوراً>> (And made the moon within them a light). Thus, the moon is a locus of manifestation (*majla*) for the light of the sun. And He <<وجَعَلَ الشَّمْسَ سِراجاً>> (made the sun a lamp). The true Light is He, glory be to Him, for He is the Provider of luminosity to every illuminator. A lamp (*siraj*) is a light extended by oil, which grants it the persistence of illumination. For this reason, He made the sun a lamp.

### [The Prophet is an Illuminating Lamp in Calling His Servants to Allah]

Likewise, He made His Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, an illuminating lamp (*sirajan muniran*) because He sustains him with the light of Divine Revelation (*al-Wahy al-Ilahi*) in his calling His servants to Allah. A condition for one who claims to respond to this call is implied by the preposition *ila* (to) in His saying "to Allah," which is a particle of destination, signifying the end of the objective. The particle *ila* implies that the one being called must exert effort from himself toward Allah. If he walks in darkness, he will not see the places of destruction on the path, and a pit he falls into, a well he tumbles into, or a tree or wall that strikes his face will intervene between him and reaching Allah, to Whom he was called, diverting him from his objective. Or he will lose the path leading to Him due to lack of distinction between the roads. All of these are like misleading ambiguities (الشبه المضلة) in a person's view when he seeks proximity to Allah through knowledge derived from his intellect, and he is in need of a light by which he can unveil what obstructs him from his objective and prevents him from reaching Him when called. Thus, the Real made His Law (*Shar'*) an illuminating lamp by which the called person discerns the path leading to the One Who called him. Allah the Exalted said: <<يا أَيُّهَا النَّبِيُّ إِنَّا أَرْسَلْناكَ شاهِداً ومُبَشِّراً ونَذِيراً وداعِياً إِلَى الله بِإِذْنِهِ>> (O Prophet, indeed We have sent you as a witness and a bringer of good tidings and a warner, and one who invites to Allah, by His permission)—meaning by His command, not from your own self, intellect, or speculation—<<وسِراجاً مُنِيراً>> (and as an illuminating lamp)—meaning that by it, what prevents the called person from reaching Him is made manifest, so he avoids it with insight, just as he said: <<أَدْعُوا إِلَى الله عَلى‏ بَصِيرَةٍ أَنَا ومن اتَّبَعَنِي>> (I invite to Allah upon insight—I and those who follow me). Thus, He granted us a share of the description with which the Real described him, the attribute of the illuminating lamp, which is a light sustained by Divine sustenance, not intellectual sustenance.

### [The Lawgiver Commanded the Transcendence of Time as Al-Dahr]

Furthermore, since *Al-Dahr* (Time/Eternity) is one of the Names of the Real, glory be to Him, as reported in the *Sahih* collection: "Do not curse Time (*Al-Dahr*), for Allah is Time (*Al-Dahr*)," He commanded the transcendence (تنزيه) of time insofar as the time of the cosmos (دهر الكون) is named *Al-Dahr*, a Name of Allah the Exalted. Thus, the word *Al-Dahr* became one of the ambiguous terms (الألفاظ المشتركة). Similarly, we declare the transcendence of the letters—meaning the letters of the alphabet—insofar as the Word of Allah the Exalted was written with them, and we venerated them. He said: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلامَ الله>> (So grant him protection until he hears the Word of Allah). And He forbade us from traveling with the *Mushaf* (Quranic text) to the land of the enemy. Yet, the listener hears nothing but sounds and letters. When He made it His Word, He obligated us to declare its transcendence, sanctify it, and venerate it.

### [Fasting the White Days is Fasting Al-Dahr]

The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, informed us that fasting the White Days (الأيام البيض) is fasting *Al-Dahr* (صيام الدهر), by way of allusion (الإشارة), [meaning] what your fast is. Thus, he attributed the fast to *Al-Dahr*, which relates to His saying, the Exalted: "Fasting is for Me."

When He made it the fast of *Al-Dahr*, and you are the one fasting during these days, *Al-Dahr* was like the sun in its manifestation in the moon, and the moon was like the fasting human. The light of the moon was like the fast attributed to the human, since he is the locus and the manifestation (*majla*) of *Al-Dahr*, exalted is He. Thus, it is the fast of the Real (حق) in the form of creation (خلق), just as He said through the tongue of His servant: "Allah hears the one who praises Him." The Speaker is Allah, and the hearing relates to the servant's utterance. Thus, it is a Divine utterance in creation; it is the saying of Allah in this state, not the saying of the servant. In reality, the hearing relates only to the Word of Allah upon the tongue of the servant, who is the channel for the articulated letters.

### [Fasting the First Days and Fasting the White Days]

It is therefore appropriate for one whose soul is sound to fast the first days (*al-Ghurar*) of every month with the intention of the consideration we mentioned to you, and to fast the White Days (الأيام البيض) with this other consideration, which is the fast of deputyship (النيابة) on behalf of the Real. You will receive the reward of the Real, not the reward appropriate for you. Everything belongs to Him, so there is nothing that can stand in His place to be a reward for Him. Likewise, this fasting person, with this Presence (الحضور), is engaged in an unparalleled worship through Divine deputyship and as a locus of manifestation (*majla*) for a Divine Name called *Al-Dahr*. Everything belongs to Him, just as *Al-Dahr* is the container for everything. Therefore, the reward for this fasting person is none other than the One who repented from him, since he is His locus of manifestation. For this reason, He said, "And I reward it," meaning that We are his reward, because he is fasting with the right of witnessing (شهودي), and what belongs to the Real, not the servant, is witnessed for him.

### [The Strange Knowledge and the Satanic Vision]

I have informed you how to fast the White Days and what you should bring into your soul when you intend to begin them. This is the attribute of the servant's perfection in receiving from Allah, just as the moon during these days is characterized by perfection in receiving light from the sun, which is from the Manifest Name (الاسم الظاهر) for creation. The moon also has another perfection in its other face, derived from the Hidden Name (الاسم الباطن) on the night of concealment (*laylat al-sirar*). On that night, it is a locus of manifestation without sustenance returning to creation; rather, in its concealment, what is specific to it, purely from its Essence, belongs to it. This is what we alluded to regarding the fast of the concealed days (*surar al-shahr*), which is commanded by the Law and has been discussed previously. Direct your attention to what We have opened up to the eye of your understanding, as a favor from Allah to you, without you realizing it. Do not let the Satanic vision (الرؤيا الشيطانية) that was seen concerning Abu Hamid al-Ghazali veil you from this Strange Knowledge (العلم الغريب) that we have explained to you. The Scholars of Formalism (علماء الرسوم) narrated it, heedless of Allah the Exalted's command to His Prophet in His saying: <<وقُلْ رَبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْماً>> (And say, "My Lord, increase me in knowledge"). He did not say "action," or "spiritual state," or anything other than Knowledge. Do you think He commanded him to seek veiling from Allah, distance from Him, and an attribute deficient in the degree of perfection? Do you think in His saying, "He struck with His hand"—meaning the Real struck him—"and I knew through that strike the knowledge of the first and the last," that He mentioned nothing of action or spiritual state? The people of formalism narrated from a person they named that he saw Abu Hamid al-Ghazali in a dream and asked him about his state. He replied, "Were it not for this Strange Knowledge, we would be in great goodness." The Scholars of Formalism interpreted this as referring to Abu Hamid's knowledge of this spiritual path. Iblis intended by this interpretation, which he beautified for them, that they should turn away from this Knowledge and thus be deprived of these degrees. This is assuming Iblis had no hand in the vision and that the vision was angelic. If the vision was from Allah, and the seer was not in the sensory realm, and the seen person was dead, then he is with the Real, not in the sensory realm.

### [The Knowledge of the Secrets of Worship and the Hereafter, and the Knowledge of Rulings and Worldly Matters]

The knowledge that Abu Hamid and others like him encouraged regarding the secrets of worship and other matters is not strange to that station where a person is after death; rather, that is his Presence (حضرة) and his place. Therefore, the only Strange Knowledge (العلم الغريب) remaining in that station is the knowledge he was occupied with in the world, such as the knowledge of divorce, marriage, transactions, agriculture, and the sciences of legal rulings (علوم الأحكام) that pertain to the world and have absolutely no connection to the Hereafter, because he separates from them upon death. These are the sciences strange to the station of the Hereafter, such as engineering, astronomy, and similar sciences that have no benefit except in the worldly abode. Even if he receives reward for them based on his intention (قصده) and purpose (نيته), the goodness that returns to him is his intention and purpose, not the knowledge itself, for knowledge follows its object of knowledge (*ma'lum*), and the ruling of this object of knowledge was in the world, not the Hereafter. It is as if he was saying to him in his vision: "If we had occupied the time of our occupation with the knowledge appropriate for this station, which this place demands, instead of this Strange Knowledge (العلم الغريب) that is strange to this station, we would be in great goodness." Thus, we missed out on the goodness of this station in proportion to our occupation with the knowledge whose connection was to the worldly abode. This is the interpretation of the seer's vision, not what they mentioned. Had they used their intellects, they would have noticed his saying, "the Strange Knowledge." If his knowledge concerned the secrets of worship and what relates to the Hereafter, it would not be strange, because that is its station, and strangeness (*ghurbah*) only occurs when one leaves one's homeland. Thus, what we have mentioned is established. Beware of being veiled from seeking these Divine and eschatological sciences. Take from the sciences of the Law (*Shari'ah*) only what is necessary, specifically what is individually obligatory upon you to seek. And say constantly, in this world and the Hereafter: <<وقُلْ رَبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْماً>> (And say, "My Lord, increase me in knowledge").

(Section on Fasting Monday and Thursday)

### [The Two Days of the Week When Deeds are Presented]

Al-Nasa'i narrated from Usamah ibn Zayd, who said: I said, "O Messenger of Allah, you fast until you almost never break the fast, and you break the fast until you almost never fast, except for two days. If they fall within your fast, you fast them, and if not, you fast them anyway." He asked, "Which two days?" I replied, "Monday and Thursday." He said, "Those are two days when deeds are presented to the Lord of the Worlds, and I love for my deeds to be presented while I am fasting."

### [The Five Numerical Days of the Week]

Know that the names of the five days came with numerical names: the first is Sunday (*al-Ahad*), and the last is Thursday (*al-Khamis*). The sixth day was specified by the name *al-Arubah* (Friday's ancient name) and in Islam by the name *al-Jumu'ah* (Friday), and the seventh by the name *al-Sabt* (Saturday). They were named by their state, not by a numerical name, just as He swore by the five retreating stars (*al-Khunnas al-Jawari*), which have approach and retreat. He did not include the sun and the moon in this oath, even though they are moving bodies (*al-Jawari*), but they are not retreating (*al-Khunnas*). Likewise, Friday and Saturday, although they are days, their names were not made from the numerical names.

### [Monday is for Adam, and Thursday is for Moses]

Let us mention here what is specific to Monday and Thursday, just as we will mention what is specific to the fasting of Friday, Saturday, and Sunday in their respective places within this chapter.

Monday belongs to Adam (peace be upon him), and Thursday belongs to Moses (peace be upon him). Thus, Muhammad (peace be upon him) shared with Adam the comprehensive nature (الجمعية) regarding the Names (الأسماء) and the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم). Just as Adam was taught all the Names, so too was Muhammad (peace be upon him) granted the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم), and the Names are part of the words. Therefore, he associated himself with Monday, which is specific to Adam, due to this shared characteristic.

As for Moses, he shared with Muhammad (peace be upon him and all the prophets) the quality of gentleness (الرفق), which is what Mercy (الرحمة) demands. The Prophet (peace be upon him) was sent by Allah as <<a mercy to the worlds>> (رَحْمَةً لِلْعالَمِينَ).

During the Night Journey (الإسراء), when the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) met with Moses and the other prophets (peace be upon them), none of the prophets commanded him or drew his attention to gentleness towards his community except Moses (peace be upon him), when Allah obligated fifty prayers upon us that night. When the Messenger returned to them, none of the prophets asked him what Allah had obligated upon his community except Moses (peace be upon him). He showed concern for us, unlike the rest of the prophets (peace be upon them). When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) told him, "Fifty prayers," Moses (peace be upon him) said to him, "Go back to your Lord concerning that."

[The rest of] the Hadith states: "I continued to go back and forth between my Lord, the Blessed and Exalted, and Moses (peace be upon him), until He obligated five [prayers] in practice, and made their reward the reward of fifty." Thus, the burden (التكليف) was reduced, but the reward remained as it was originally.

### [Muhammad’s Comprehensive Nature with Adam in Knowledge and with Moses in Mercy and Gentleness]

Since he shared with Moses the attribute of gentleness towards us, he associated himself with Thursday, which belongs to Moses (peace be upon him). By fasting on Monday, he remembered Adam concerning the Knowledge (العلم) he possessed, and by fasting on Thursday, he remembered Moses concerning the Mercy (الرحمة) with which he was sent to the worlds.

Both of them are in a state where they neither eat nor drink, for they have departed from the life of this world and are not in the realm of physical generation (النش‏ء الجسمي) that requires sustenance. Rather, they are in an Isthmus (برزخ) between the two states of generation, where there is no physical sustenance. Therefore, when the aforementioned shared characteristics occurred between him and them, he desired to associate himself with these two days—the days when he meets them—by abstaining from food and drink, in agreement with them. This was so that he (peace be upon him) could devote himself to attaining that which led him to meet them on these two days. He made this abstinence a fast (صوم), rather than merely considering it a reduction of food, so that his abstinence would be a prescribed act. Thus, he associated himself with an Attribute (صفة) belonging to The Real (الحق), which is Fasting (الصوم). He fasted them so that his deed might be presented to the Lord of the Worlds (رب العالمين) on those two days, while he was associated with the Attribute of The Real, since the Fast belongs to Him.

### [The Corruption of the Sign is only the Onset of Doubt upon it in Rational Consideration]

Since fasting, in relation to servants, is susceptible to corruption because it is receptive to it, and also receptive to rectification (الصلاح), the presentation [of the deed] was made to the Lord of the Worlds (رب العالمين) and not to any other Name. The Lord (الرب) is the Rectifier, so He rectifies whatever corruption may have entered this fast without the person realizing it. This ruling relates specifically to the Sign (العلامة), which is the indication of Allah, the Exalted. That is why He said [the presentation is] to the Lord of the Worlds, concerning the Sign. The corruption of the Sign is only due to the onset of doubt (الشبهة) upon it in rational consideration (النظر العقلي). There is no greater doubt than attributing the Fast to Allah, exclusively of all other deeds, while simultaneously describing the servant as performing it.
