When the presentation occurs, which is the Theophany (التجلي) and Unveiling (الكشف), showing what belongs to Allah of the Fast and what belongs to the servant of it, the doubt that the intellect accepts is removed by the Divine Unveiling (الكشف الإلهي). This is the meaning of the Rectifier of the Sign.

### [The Knowledge of the Names and the Knowledge of the Twelve Springs]

If you consider it in relation to the Sustainer (مربي) of the worlds—that is, their Provider—the sustenance of the fasting person in this presentation is the Knowledge (العلوم) that The Real (الحق) grants during this fast, specific to these two days. This includes the Knowledge of the Names (علم الأسماء) and the Knowledge of the Twelve Springs (علم الاثنتي عشرة عينا), the knowledge of which entails the knowledge of everything other than Allah. This is the Knowledge of Life (علم الحياة) by which everything lives. It is the Knowledge generated between the plant and the inanimate realms (النبات والجماد) of generated things, by the attribute of Compulsion (القهر).

The twelve springs only appeared when the staff struck the rock, and twelve springs burst forth from it by that striking. This signifies the sciences of Witnessing (علوم المشاهدة) resulting from spiritual struggle (مجاهدة) caused by the striking, and the sciences of Taste (علوم ذوق), because water is among the things that are tasted and whose flavor varies in the tasting. Through this, one knows the relationship of Life, and how that which is called inanimate (جماد) is characterized by it, to the extent that the Truthful One informed us that it glorifies Allah’s praise, because The Real attributed this to the rock by His saying, "from it." Whoever lacks Unveiling (كشف) or faith does not affirm life for the inanimate, let alone glorification. We seek refuge in Allah from abandonment (الخذلان).

Through this Unveiling (كشف), the relationship of Life to the plant realm is also known, because the striking was done with the staff, which is from the plant realm, and by striking with it, what appeared, appeared. Whoever lacks Unveiling does not know that the plant is alive, except for those who restrict life to growth.

Thus, on Thursday, if one fasts for the sake of the spiritual support (الإمداد روحانية) of Moses (peace be upon him) on that day, one attains the Knowledge of the Twelve Springs (علم الاثنتي عشرة عينا) through Unveiling (الكشف) and Witnessing (المشاهدة). This is the knowledge related to the welfare of the world. <<Every group of people knew their drinking place>> (قَدْ عَلِمَ كُلُّ أُناسٍ مَشْرَبَهُمْ) from those springs. Whoever knows them knows the ruling of the twelve constellations (بروج), knows the limit of the Names of Numbers, which is twelve, and knows the human being in his capacity as a friend of Allah (ولي لله).

> Look at a tree that judges a stone,
> And look at the striker from behind veils.

Moses (peace be upon him) was the veil (الحجاب) and the covering (الستر) for him, just as Muhammad (peace be upon him) was the veil for the Bedouin concerning the Word of Allah.

### [Seeking Protection through the Fasting of Monday and Thursday]

By fasting on Monday, one unites Creation (خلق) and The Real (حق) upon the carpet of Witnessing (مشاهدة) and Presence (حضور) for the attainment of the Knowledge of the Divine Names (علم الأسماء الإلهية). By fasting on Thursday, one combines the preservation of the self and the preservation of the four directions from which misleading doubts (الشبه المضلة) enter upon him. These are the paths of Satan, derived from [Allah’s] saying: <<Then I will come upon them from between their hands>> (ثُمَّ لَآتِيَنَّهُمْ من بَيْنِ أَيْدِيهِمْ) concerning a matter, <<and incite them>> (واسْتَفْزِزْ), <<and from behind them>> (ومن خَلْفِهِمْ) concerning a matter, <<and assault them>> (وَأَجْلِبْ عَلَيْهِمْ), <<and from their right>> (وَعَنْ أَيْمانِهِمْ) concerning a matter, <<and share with them>> (وَشَارِكْهُمْ), <<and from their left>> (وَعَنْ شَمائِلِهِمْ) concerning a matter, <<and promise them>> (وَعِدْهُمْ). He [Satan] is precisely in the center, for it is by him that these four directions are distinguished.

The total in this Presence (حضرة) was five. One seeks protection (اعتصم) by fasting on Thursday because the number five is one of its characteristics, and Moses is its companion. Moses is rough and stern (فظ غليظ), and Satan flees from him due to his sternness. The person fasting on Thursday seeks protection through this Presence (حضور) we mentioned, both from the Satan who lies in wait for him in these directions, and from the self’s acceptance of what this Satan might bring upon him, which is the fifth element assisting Satan in his aims. Thus, Moses acts as the gatekeeper (حاجب) of these doors, and the fasting person remains therein, rested and safe. He is the master of the Fast on that day.

This was not said concerning Adam regarding the fast of Monday. We considered it a union of The Real (حق) and Creation (خلق) so that no defect (خلل) might unexpectedly occur in his fast. For Adam, the master of that day, accepted the slip (الإزلال) from Iblis without realizing it. And whoever cannot defend himself is even less able to defend others. Therefore, Monday is carried upon [the concept of] The Real and Creation due to the shared attribute of Fasting, and Adam is not considered in this specific context.

### [The Relationship of the Five Retreating Stars to Thursday]

The Five Retreating Stars (الخمسة الخنس) are related to Thursday, which belongs to Moses, because they possess the ability to advance and retreat (الكر والفر) due to their approach and withdrawal in motion. Thus, they possess authority and power over others because of the strength of the five that unites them. The number five, among the numbers, preserves itself and preserves twenty. There is no other number that possesses this rank or this power except this five. Whoever preserves himself and others is more strongly analogous to what intellects seek in emulating one who possesses this attribute. The Exalted said: <<And the preservation of both [the heavens and the earth] does not weary Him>> (ولا يَؤُدُهُ حِفْظُهُما). And He said: <<And your Lord is Guardian over all things>> (ورَبُّكَ عَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ حَفِيظٌ). And Allah speaks The Truth (الحق), and He guides to the Way. End of the Fifty-Ninth Section.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

(Section on the Chapter of Fasting on Friday)

Scholars have differed regarding fasting on Friday. Some say it is disliked, and others say it is disliked unless one fasts the day before it or the day after it.

Muslim reported from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "None of you should fast on Friday unless he fasts the day before it or the day after it."

Al-Bukhari reported from Juwayriyyah bint al-Harith that the Prophet (peace be upon him) entered upon her on a Friday while she was fasting. He asked, "Did you fast yesterday?" She said, "No." He asked, "Do you intend to fast tomorrow?" She said, "No." He said, "Then break your fast."

### [Friday: The Day Adam was Created, and the Perfection and Goal of Creation Appeared]

Know that Friday is the last of the days of Creation (الخلق). On it, the one whom Allah created upon His Form (على الصورة)—Adam—was created. In it appeared the perfection of the completion of Creation and its goal. Through it appeared the most perfect of creatures, which is the human being (الإنسان), and he is the last of the generated things (المولدات). By him, Allah preserved the Name 'The Last' (الآخر) upon the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية), and Allah preserved him by the Name 'The Last.' He is the one looked upon by the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية).

Since Allah gathered the creation of the human being on this day, combining the two Forms upon which He originated him—the Form of The Real (صورة الحق) and the Form of the World (صورة العالم)—Allah named it, in the language of the Sacred Law, the Day of Gathering (يوم الجمعة). When Allah adorned him with the adornment of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), beautified him with them, and established him as a vicegerent (خليفة) in them by means of them, he appeared in the most beautiful Divine adornment in perfection. Allah, the Exalted, distinguished him by making him vaster than His Mercy (رحمته), for His Mercy does not encompass Him (Exalted is He) nor does it return to Him. Rather, the locus where Mercy has its effect is the created beings (المخلوقون). The Real (الحق), Exalted is He, made the heart vast. Therefore, it is vaster than Allah’s Mercy. This is one of the most astonishing things: that he is created from Allah’s Mercy yet is vaster than it. And whoever is the manifestation (مجلى) of the perfection of The Real, there is no adornment higher than the adornment of Allah. Thus, Allah gave it a name upon the tongues of the Arabs in the Age of Ignorance (الجاهلية), which is the word *al-`Arubah* (العروبة), meaning it is the day of beauty and adornment.

### [Friday is Distinguished by the Hour that Belongs to No Other Day]

The Real (الحق) manifested in His perfection in the most perfect of creation, which is Adam. Thus, there was no day more perfect than Friday, for in it appeared the wisdom of Divine Power (حكمة الاقتدار) by creating the human being upon His Form. No perfection remained for the Divine Power to create, since there is nothing more perfect than the Form of The Real.

Since it was the most perfect of days, and the most perfect of existents was created in it, Allah distinguished it with the Hour (الساعة) that belongs to no other day—and all time is nothing but these days. This Hour was not granted to any time except Friday. It is one part out of twenty-four parts of the day, and it is in the middle of it, which is referred to as the daytime. Thus, it is in the exterior of the day and the interior of the human being, because the exterior of the human being corresponds to the interior of the day, and the interior of the human being corresponds to the exterior of the day.

Do you not see that during Ramadan, one is commanded to stand in prayer at night (القيام بالليل)? Standing is the ruling of the human exterior, for the exterior is the part that rests through sleep, and Allah made the day a rest (سباتا) for him. The night is the locus of the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) and the Lordly Descent (النزول الرباني). Receiving this Descent through cosmic standing (القيام الكوني) is obligatory on the Path, as a matter of Divine etiquette. This Descent at night takes the place of the Hour that occurs during Friday daytime. However, the Descent occurs every night, while the Hour is specific to Friday, for it is the Hour of Perfection (ساعة الكمال). Perfection can only be one in every genus, provided that genus has the readiness for perfection, like the readiness of the human being, and nothing preceding him [in creation] possesses this readiness except the human being.

### [The Human Being is Perfected by His Lord, and Friday is Perfected by the Human Being]

The human being (الإنسان) is perfect through his Lord because of the Form (الصورة), and Friday is perfect through the human being because he was created in it. He was only created in the aforementioned Hour within it, for it is the most noble of its hours. The ruling in this Hour belongs to the Spirit (الروح) in the Sixth Heaven, which is the Heaven of Justice and Moderation (العدل والاعتدال) of the Attributes (صفات) and the perfection of the Interior (كمال الباطن). The sovereign of this day is the Spirit in the Third Heaven. He has complete autonomy (الاستبداد التام) on his day during the first and eighth hours of it. He rules by himself through Theophany (تجليا), and during the rest of its hours, his rule is carried out by his deputies.

Knowledge (العلم) is the most perfect of Attributes (الصفات), so the most perfect was specified for the most perfect. Fasting (الصوم) has no equal among acts of worship, so it resembles the One Who has no equal (من لا مثل له) in the negation of likeness. The One Who has no equal is characterized by two opposing Attributes from a single perspective: <<He is the First and the Last>> (هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ). He is also what is between them when He is the One described, just as He is between the Manifest (الظاهر) and the Hidden (الباطن). These two Attributes are one in meaning. The division only occurs in the ruling that manifests from them. The name 'The Manifest' is applied because the ruling manifests from it, and the name 'The Hidden' because its cause is concealed. Thus, they are two relations (نسبتان) belonging to Him. Since it is necessary to affirm this relational Attribute (الصفة النسبية)—whose ruling is intelligible, though the ruling of the One described is not—it was necessary to affirm it. Every ruling that has a beginning (أولية) and an end (آخرية) in the subject of the ruling is 'The First' and 'The Last' in terms of meaning, and its beginning and end are two extremities in that which is indivisible.

When the matter is as we have established, whoever wishes to fast on Friday should fast a day before it or a day after it, and should not single it out for fasting, due to the doubts (الشبه) we mentioned regarding fasting on that day and standing in prayer on its night. For there is no day like it; it is the best day on which the sun has risen. How wise is the science of the Sacred Law (علم الشرع) in ruling that it should not be singled out for fasting, nor its night for standing in prayer, in veneration of its rank above all other days.

It is the day concerning which the nations differed, and Allah guided us to the Truth (الحق) concerning which they differed, by His permission. Allah did not clarify it for anyone except Muhammad (peace be upon him) due to his suitability for perfection, for he is the most perfect of the Prophets. We are the most perfect of nations. The Truth was not clarified for the other nations and their prophets concerning it, because they were not prepared for it, being below the degree of perfection—their prophets being below Muhammad (peace be upon him), and their nations being below us in our perfection. Praise be to Allah Who chose us. By the grace of Allah, we are Friday, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) is the very essence (عين) of the Hour within it, by which Friday is favored over all other days, just as we are favored over all other nations by Muhammad (peace be upon him).

Fasting (الصوم) belongs to Allah from the perspective of Transcendence (التنزيه), and fasting is an act of worship (عبادة) for the human being. The point of commonality is the Fast. Thus, the fast of Friday, in what belongs to it, is for Allah, and the fast of the day added to it is what belongs to the servant of it. For, by the servant’s fasting, it is valid for the Fast to be for Allah, and by fasting the day added to Friday, the fast of Friday becomes valid. And Allah is <<All-Knowing, All-Wise>> (عَلِيمٌ حَكِيمٌ).

(Section on the Chapter of Fasting on Saturday)

Abu Dawud reported from Abdullah ibn Bishr, from his brother, that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Do not fast on Saturday except for what has been obligated upon you. If one of you finds nothing but a grape stalk or the bark of a tree, let him chew it." Abu Dawud said: "This is abrogated." Abu Isa said concerning this Hadith: "It is a sound (حسن) Hadith." Al-Nasa’i reported from Umm Salamah that she said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to fast on Saturday and Sunday more than any other days, and he would say, 'They are the feast days (`id) of the polytheists, and I love to oppose them.'"

### [Saturday is the Day of Eternity]

Scholars have differed regarding fasting on Saturday. Some say it should be fasted, and others say it should not be fasted. Know that Saturday, in our view, is the Day of Eternity (يوم الأبد), whose day has no end. Its night is in Hell, which is black and dark, and its day is for the people of the Gardens (Jannah), so Paradise is bright and shining. Hunger is continuous and permanent for the people of the Fire, and the opposite is true for the people of the Gardens, who eat out of desire, not to repel the pain of hunger or thirst.

Whoever’s Witnessing (مشهده) is Contraction (القبض) and Fear (الخوف), which are characteristics of Hell, says one should fast it, because fasting is a shield (جنة) by which one guards against this matter that has preoccupied him. It is reported in the book *Al-Targhib* by Ibn Zanjawayh, from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), that whoever fasts one day seeking the Face of Allah, Allah distances him from the Fire by seventy autumns (خريفا).

### [Wisdom is Granted on Saturday]

Whoever’s Witnessing (مشهده) is Expansion (البسط), Hope (الرجاء), and Paradise, and knows that Saturday (السبت) was only named *Sabt* due to the meaning of rest (الراحة) within it, even if that rest is not from fatigue. It is the day between the beginning of Creation, which occurred on Sunday, and the end of Creation, which occurred on Friday. These are the six days in which Allah created Creation. On Saturday, He said, having placed one leg over the other, "I am the King, and I rule the world." He decreed its provisions (أقواتها) in the earth, <<and revealed in every heaven its command>> (وَأَوْحَى فِي كُلِّ سَمَاءٍ أَمْرَهَا), established the balances, referred creatures to one another, made some the Giver (المفيض) and others the Receiver (القابل), perfected their readiness in the most complete manner, and acted as He informed, that <<He gave everything its creation>> (أَعْطَى كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ). He described Himself as having finished (الفراغ). Whoever has this Witnessing says that Wisdom (الحكمة) dictates breaking the fast on this day, so fasting it is restricted. This is due to the fatigue involved, which contradicts rest, for fasting is hardship, as it is contrary to the natural disposition of the human being to seek nourishment.

### [The Fasting that is Opposition to a Contrary]

As for the one who fasts it in observance of opposing the polytheists (المشركين), his Witnessing (مشهده) is that the polytheist’s witnessing is the partner (الشريك) he has set up. When this partner, in their claim, took charge of their affairs by what they entrusted to him, he made that day a feast (`id) of joy in his authority, and he fed them and gave them drink on it. I do not mean the partner they worshipped and relied upon, but rather the image of the partner established in their souls (نفوسهم), not the partner itself. It is this image that gave them joy on this day and made it a feast for them.

As for those who made him a partner to Allah, that designated partner either accepts this absurdity or does not. If he accepts, he is like them, such as Pharaoh and others. If he does not accept and flees to Allah from what they attributed to him, he is blessed in himself, and wretchedness befalls those who set him up. Whoever fasts it with this Witnessing (شهود), his fast is an opposition to a contrary (مقابلة ضد), due to the distance in suitability between the polytheist and the monotheist. Thus, he desired to characterize himself, in his ruling concerning that day, with the attribute of opposition through fasting, which opposes their breaking of the fast. That is why he (peace be upon him) used to fast it.

(Section on the Chapter of Fasting on Sunday)

### [The Difference in Intention of the Gnostics Regarding Fasting on Sunday]

Whoever considers what we mentioned of this Witnessing (شهود)—that it is a feast day (`id) for the Christians—fasts it in opposition to them. Whoever considers it the first day Allah attended to the creation of creatures in their Fixed Entities (أعيانهم) fasts it in gratitude to Allah, the Exalted, opposing it with an act of worship that has no equal. Thus, the intention of the Gnostics (العارفين) in their fasting differs. Among the Gnostics are those who fast it specifically because it is *al-Ahad* (The One). *Al-Ahad* is an Attribute of Transcendence (تنزيه) for The Real (الحق), and Fasting (الصوم) is an attribute of Transcendence and a rank whose sanctuary is protected. This is because fasting involves restricting the fasting person from the portion of the self (الحظ النفسي) related to breaking the fast, enjoying intercourse, and transcending blameworthy things. The fasting person is restricted from backbiting, obscene speech, acting ignorantly, or being characterized by anything legally blameworthy in that state. Thus, a suitability occurred between it [the fast] and *al-Ahad* in the attribute of Transcendence, so he fasted it for that reason. Everyone has a known portion (شرب معلوم), so he dealt with it using the most noble of Attributes.

### [The Natural Soul, the Spirit Governing the Body, and the Secret of Fasting on Sunday]

For this reason, fasting naturally results in heat and dryness due to the lack of nourishment, which is contrary to what nature demands. Nature demands heat for the sake of life, not its effect, and demands moisture, which is the effect of coldness. The fasting person opposes nature with its contrary; he opposes it with the origin and its effect, for he is commanded to oppose the soul (النفس). The soul (النفس) is pure nature, inherently contending with the Divine, because the existence of the entire world of bodies depends on it. Were it not for the soul, the world of bodies would not manifest an entity (عين). Therefore, it became arrogant and haughty. So, it was said to the Spirit (الروح) governing this elemental body, which is commanded to maintain moderation (الاعتدال) in this body and look after its welfare: "If you see the natural soul (النفس الطبيعية) in this state of arrogance and pride, prevent it from food, drink, and sexual enjoyment, with the intention of opposing it and the intention of transcending what nature imagines—that you are dependent upon it in that." And so that nature may know that it is ruled, and thus submit under servitude (العبودة) and need (الافتقار) when seeking nourishment from this governor of the structure. Such governance is called Fasting (صوما). However, preventing it from all that merely for the rectification of the temperament (صلاح المزاج) is not called fasting. That action of the Spirit is merely part of the governance of nature, so such a thing is called a diet (حمية), not a fast. If the Spirit intends by this diet, and by assisting nature in what it commanded, the rectification of the temperament of this body for the sake of worshipping Allah, and so that he may perform all the acts of worship Allah commanded him in his movements and stillness—which only manifest through a sound temperament—he will be rewarded for that diet, even if it is not a fast. Thus, I have clarified for you some of the secrets of fasting on Sunday.

(Section on the Chapter that the Imaginative Theophany of Ramadan and others, when it occurs, is for its specific time)

Muslim reported in his *Sahih* from Abu al-Bakhtari, who said: We met Ibn Abbas and said, "We saw the crescent moon." Some people said, "It is three nights old," and others said, "It is two nights old." He asked, "Which night did you see it?" We replied, "Such and such a night." He said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Allah extended it for the sighting, so it belongs to the night you saw it.'"

### [The Ruling Belongs to the Time, and the Sufi is the Child of His Time]

The Masters among the People of Allah (أهل الله) said: The ruling belongs to the Time (الوقت), and the human being, or the Sufi, is the child of his time (ابن وقته); neither the past nor the future rules over him. However, the ordinary human being does not know that he is the child of his time, even though the ruling of the time is upon him. The Sufi knows that he is subject to the ruling of his time, as this is the reality of the matter (في نفس الأمر). For this reason, we say the Sufi is the child of his time, due to his awareness of this and his knowledge that the ruling imposed upon him contains the trace of Prophethood (أثر النبوة). Not every human being knows this, even though it is the reality of the matter. Whenever this ruling becomes manifest to a person, and he is characterized by the knowledge that he is the child of his time, that is the meaning of his (peace be upon him) saying: "It belongs to the night you saw it."

We know with certainty that when the crescent moon is in the glare [of the sun], it is manifesting (متجل) to us, but we do not see it. Just as we know with certainty that the stars in the sky are manifesting to us during the day, but we do not see them due to the weakness of visual perception. Thus, we do not attribute [the ruling] to it [the unseen manifestation]. When we see it, that is the time in which we see it, so that we may know it. Then, the ruling dictated by that Theophany (التجلي) is imposed upon us. If it is Ramadan, it affects us with the intention of fasting. If it is the crescent of breaking the fast (هلال فطر), it affects us with the intention of breaking the fast. If it is merely the crescent of any month, it affects us with the knowledge of the cessation of the ruling of the month that has passed and the ruling of the month whose crescent this is. The states of people differ, and the times are distinguished by it, due to the expiration of terms (الآجال) in everything: sales, debts, leases, and the rites of Hajj. Allah, the Exalted, says: <<They ask you about the new moons. Say: They are fixed times (مَواقِيتُ) for the people and for the Hajj>> (يَسْئَلُونَكَ عَنِ الْأَهِلَّةِ قُلْ هِيَ مَواقِيتُ لِلنَّاسِ والْحَجِّ), as we have established.

(Section on the Chapter of Testimony in Sighting it)

### [For the Crescent of Breaking the Fast, Two Outer Witnesses; For the Fast, One Outer and One Inner Witness]

If we do not see it, and one or two men inform us of it, do we then fall under the ruling of the Time, and does the testimony take the place of the sighting? I say: The ruling of this crescent, in its appearance, must either manifest with a ruling that agrees with the self’s purpose (الغرض النفسي) or contradicts it. If it contradicts, we accept the testimony of one person concerning it. The other witness is what we have been commanded: the opposition of the self (مخالفة النفس). Since the self naturally does not desire this ruling, we should act upon it regarding the crescent of the Fast (هلال الصوم). Since breaking the fast (الفطر) involves the self’s purpose, we seek another outer witness to testify for us, so that our breaking the fast is an act of worship (عبادة) and not merely for the self’s purpose. We might even stipulate uprightness (العدالة) in both [witnesses], even though this breaking of the fast, which is the Eid al-Fitr, is an act of worship and fasting on it is forbidden. In it—meaning in the sighting of the crescent of breaking the fast—we are receiving an act of worship, due to the obligation of breaking the fast and the prohibition of fasting, just as in the crescent of Ramadan we are receiving an act of worship, due to the obligation of fasting and the prohibition of breaking the fast. There is no difference. Despite this, two witnesses are required for the crescent of breaking the fast, following the general principle. Were it not for the report concerning the crescent of the Fast, we would treat it like the crescent of breaking the fast, even though the matter involves probability. But we rely on what has manifested. Thus, for the crescent of breaking the fast, two outer witnesses are needed, and for the crescent of the Fast, one outer and one inner witness. The inner witness is the command to oppose the self (مخالفة النفس). The Exalted says: <<and restrained the soul from [its] desire>> (وَنَهَى النَّفْسَ عَنِ الْهَوَى). The soul has no natural desire (هوى طبيعي) in fasting. Thus, we only fast with two witnesses, and we only break the fast with two witnesses, because each of these two acts of worship is an existential ruling (حكم وجودي), and every conclusion requires two premises, which, in these acts of worship, are the two witnesses.

### [The Reports Concerning the Sighting of the Crescents of Fasting and Breaking the Fast]

Let us mention the reports concerning this, so that the reader of this book may benefit from our source and not need another book, so I say:

A Hadith reported in the *Sunan* of Abu Dawud: Abu Dawud reported from Rib`i ibn Khirash, from a man among the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him), who said: People differed concerning the last day of Ramadan. Then two Bedouins came and testified before the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) that they had sighted the crescent yesterday evening. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) commanded the people to break their fast and to go out to their prayer ground the next morning.

Another Hadith also from the *Sunan* of Abu Dawud: Abu Dawud also reported from Ibn Umar, who said: People sighted the crescent, and I informed the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) that I had seen it. So he fasted and commanded the people to fast.

A third Hadith from Abu Dawud also: Abu Dawud also reported from Al-Husayn ibn al-Harith that the Amir of Mecca gave a sermon and then said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entrusted us to perform the rites based on the sighting. If we do not see it, and two upright witnesses testify, we perform the rites based on their testimony. Then he said: "Among you is one who has more knowledge of Allah and His Messenger than I," and he pointed with his hand toward a man. Al-Husayn said: I asked an old man next to me, "Who is the one he pointed to?" He said, "That is Abdullah ibn Umar." The Amir of Mecca was Al-Harith ibn Hatib al-Jumahi.

A fourth Hadith from Al-Daraqutni: Al-Daraqutni mentioned, from the Hadith of Ibn Umar and Ibn Abbas, that they said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) accepted the testimony of a single man for the sighting of the Ramadan crescent, and they said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did not accept testimony for breaking the fast except from two men. This Hadith is weak.

(Section on the Chapter that the Fasting Person Spends Most of His Day Seeing Himself, Not His Lord)

### [Whoever Observes Allah in His Deed, His Reward is He, and None Other]

Since Fasting (الصوم) is a ruling that Allah attributed to Himself, and stripped the fasting person of it, despite commanding him to fast, it is incumbent upon the fasting person to look toward his Lord throughout the duration of his fast, so that his being a fasting person is valid, and he does not become heedless of Him. For The Real (الحق) does not attribute it to Himself unless it is valid as a fast, and it is only valid through the servant’s fasting in the manner prescribed by Allah for him to perform. If he does not fast it according to what was prescribed for him, then he is not fasting. And if he is not fasting, there is no fast for Allah to attribute to Himself. The fasting person may think he is fasting, yet he may have performed an action during his fast that necessitates his departure from the state of fasting, such as backbiting (الغيبة) and similar acts. In this case, he has broken his fast—that is, he is not fasting—even if he has not eaten. If that action requires expiation (كفارة) and he performs it, then he is fasting. The fasting person should guard this, for it involves preferring The Real (الحق) over his own self, and He rewards him according to the One preferred, which is Allah, the Exalted. Whoever observes his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, Allah observes him. His reward can only be He Himself. <<Whoever is found in his saddlebag, he is his recompense>> (مَنْ وُجِدَ فِي رَحْلِهِ فَهُوَ جَزَاؤُهُ). And He was found in his saddlebag, for The Real (الحق) is necessarily in the heart of His believing servant who is present with Him. The Fast was found with Allah, for it belongs to Him. When the fast of the fasting person was valid, He sought his saddlebag, and it was said to him, "Allah took it." Thus, Allah was his reward. He said: "The Fast is for Me, and I shall reward for it."

### [The Hadith of Khirash ibn Abdullah concerning the Corruption of the Fast]

A Hadith reported concerning the corruption of the fast: Abu Ahmad ibn Adi al-Jurjani mentioned, from the Hadith of Khirash ibn Abdullah, from Anas, from the Prophet (peace be upon him), who said: "Whoever gazes upon the creation of a woman until the size of her bones becomes clear to him from behind her clothes while he is fasting, has broken his fast." This Khirash is unknown, because he used to narrate from a scroll he possessed, and this Hadith is from it. The one who narrates from him is weak, as mentioned by our Shaykh Abu Muhammad Abd al-Haqq.

(Section on the Ruling of Fasting on the Sixteenth of Sha’ban)

### [The Six Days on which Fasting is Forbidden]

Fasting on it is forbidden according to us. It is one of the six days on which fasting is forbidden: this day, the day of Eid al-Fitr, the day of Eid al-Adha, and the three Days of Tashriq.

Al-Tirmidhi reported from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "When half of Sha’ban remains, do not fast." Abu Isa said: "This is a sound and authentic (حسن صحيح) Hadith."

### [The Consideration in the Prohibition of Fasting on the Sixteenth of Sha’ban]

Since the night of the middle of Sha’ban is the night when the Angel of Death is written down for those whose souls he will seize in that year, he draws a black line over the name of the wretched (الشقي) and a white line over the name of the blessed (السعيد). By this, the Angel of Death knows the blessed from the wretched. Thus, death is witnessed for this person, because it is the time of becoming aware of the appointed terms (الآجال) and bringing them to mind for the believer who does not have this awareness. When the night of the sixteenth follows it, the person who has this Witnessing (الشهود) or who brings it to mind cannot detach himself from observing death. He is thus counted, by his state, among the children of the Hereafter. With death, the burden (التكليف) of obligation ceases. He is not in a state where he can intend the fast overnight, due to his witnessing the state of the Attribute (الصفة) that cuts off deeds. He remains intoxicated by the effect of this Witnessing. Whoever remains in this state until the entry of Ramadan is prevented from fasting the middle [of Sha’ban]. Whoever does not remain in it is prevented from fasting the sixteenth specifically, because he did not intend the fast overnight, and the night of the sixteenth is not the night of the abrogation of appointed terms, which is the night of the middle [of Sha’ban].

### [The Hadith Prohibiting Fasting on the Sixteenth of Sha’ban]

Some scholars of the Exoteric (أهل الظاهر) specifically designated the sixteenth as the locus for the prohibition of fasting, based on what I shall mention. He (may Allah have mercy on him) cited an authentic Hadith:

A group narrated to us: Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Khalaf ibn Saf al-Lakhmi, Abu al-Qasim Abd al-Rahman ibn Ghalib al-Qumari, Abu al-Walid Jabir ibn Abi Ayyub al-Hadrami, and Abu al-Abbas Ibn Miqdam—all of these said: Abu al-Hasan Shurayh ibn Muhammad ibn Shurayh al-Ra`ini al-Muqri narrated to us, who said: Abu Muhammad Ali ibn Ahmad narrated to us, who said: Abdullah ibn al-Rabi` narrated to us, who said: Umar ibn Abd al-Malik narrated to us, who said: Muhammad ibn Bakr narrated to us, who said: Abu Dawud narrated to us, who said: Qutaybah ibn Said narrated to us, who said: Abd al-Aziz ibn Muhammad al-Darawardi said: Abbad ibn Kathir came to Medina and went to the mosque of Al-Ala ibn Abd al-Rahman. He took his hand and made him stand, saying: "O Allah, this man narrates from his father that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'When Sha’ban is halfway through, do not fast.'" Al-Ala said: "O Allah, my father narrated to me from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said that."

Abu Muhammad ibn Hazm said: Sufyan narrated it thus from Al-Ala. Al-Ala is trustworthy; Shu`bah, Sufyan al-Thawri, Malik, Ibn Uyaynah, Mas`ar ibn Kidam, and Abu al-Uways all narrated from him, and all of them use his Hadith as evidence. The criticism of Ibn Ma`in does not harm him. It is not permissible to assume that Abu Hurayrah contradicted what he narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him), and assumption is the most lying of speech. Whoever claims consensus here has lied.

### [The Dislike of Fasting After the Middle of Sha’ban]

Abu Muhammad said: Some people disliked fasting after the middle of Sha’ban entirely, but the authentic and certain implication of the wording of this report is the prohibition of fasting after the middle of Sha’ban. Fasting cannot be less than a day. It is not permissible to interpret the prohibition as applying to the rest of the month, as that is not clear. Sha’ban is either thirty or twenty-nine days. If it is thirty, its middle is at the completion of fifteen days. If it is twenty-nine, its middle is at the half of the fifteenth day. The prohibition is only against fasting *after* the middle. From this, the prohibition of fasting the sixteenth is established without doubt. End of the words of Abu Muhammad in the book *Al-Muhalla*, from which I copied it. This is my narration from the group we mentioned at the beginning of the chain of Al-Ala’s Hadith and others, from Abu al-Hasan Shurayh ibn Muhammad ibn Shurayh from him. He is the one who held that fasting the sixteenth is impermissible, and our discussion is based on his view.

(Section on the Chapter of Fasting the Days of Tashriq)

Scholars (may Allah be pleased with them) have differed regarding fasting the Days of Tashriq. Some say it is permissible to fast them, some say it is permissible for the pilgrim performing *tamattu`* (المتمتع) to fast them, some say it is disliked, and some say fasting is absolutely forbidden on them. The Days of Tashriq are the three days following the Day of Sacrifice (يوم النحر). They are days of eating, drinking, and remembrance of Allah, the Exalted. Muslim mentioned in his book, from Nubayshah al-Hudhali, that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said that. This is the characteristic of the people of Paradise. Wherever this characteristic is found, every deed ceases in the state of its ruling, except for worship (`ibadah), for it is a reality (حقيقة) that does not depart from the human being in this world.

### [The Consideration of Fasting and the Consideration of Breaking the Fast on the Days of Tashriq]

Fasting (الصوم) is abstinence and worship. Whoever considers the worship aspect permits fasting on them. Whoever considers what the Sacred Law (الشرع) preferred—that they are days of eating, drinking, and remembrance of Allah, the Exalted, and did not say nights of eating and drinking—[knows] this is a Divine report, because he (peace be upon him) <<does not speak from [his own] desire. It is not but a revelation revealed>> (إِنْ هُوَ إِلَّا وَحْيٌ يُوحَى). It is a Divine notification in the form of a report, and a report is not subject to abrogation (النسخ). Thus, it made breaking the fast on them an obligatory act of worship. Whoever fasts on them has preferred his own view over the report of Allah, the Exalted, concerning what should be done on them. Whoever contends with Allah concerning something He declared to be His has exposed himself to ruin, for the Fast is His, and the breaking of the fast is yours. The *mujtahid* (independent jurist) only permitted fasting them for those who could not find the sacrificial animal (*al-hady*), as reported by Al-Bukhari from Aisha and Ibn Umar.

### [The Remembrance of Fathers and the Remembrance of Allah on the Days of Tashriq]

Then He made remembrance of Allah (ذكر لله) for you on them, which is His saying, the Exalted: <<And when you have completed your rites, remember Allah as you remember your fathers or with a stronger remembrance>> (فَإِذا قَضَيْتُمْ مَناسِكَكُمْ فَاذْكُرُوا الله كَذِكْرِكُمْ آباءَكُمْ أَوْ أَشَدَّ ذِكْراً). He commanded you to remember Allah on them, for the Arabs used to mention their lineages and merits during these days of the season, due to the gathering of the Arab tribes, seeking pride and reputation (الفخر والسمعة). This is the meaning of His saying, <<as you remember your fathers>>: that is, occupy yourselves with praising Allah for what He is, by way of pride, since you are His servants, and the servant’s pride is in his Master, for he is attributed to Him, and greater than that, he is from Him. As he (peace be upon him) said: "The client of a people is one of them," and "The People of the Quran are the People of Allah and His chosen ones." The servant has no pride in his father; rather, his pride is in his Master. If the servant takes pride in his father, he only takes pride in him insofar as his father was close to his Master, being a servant like him, complying with His command, and abiding by His limits and ordinances, for he too is a servant of Allah. For this reason, He said, <<as you remember your fathers>>. He did not forbid them from remembering their fathers, but He preferred their remembrance of Allah over their remembrance of their fathers by His saying, <<or with a stronger remembrance>>. He is the One Who advises His servants with His saying: <<Be grateful to Me and to your parents>> (أَنِ اشْكُرْ لِي وَلِوالِدَيْكَ). That is, let your preference for the remembrance of Allah and pride in Him, as He is your Master and you are His servants, be greater than what your fathers were upon. And the remembrance of Allah is greater.

### [The Remembrance of Allah in Every Act of Worship is the Greatest of the Actions of Worship]

In any act of worship the servant performs that includes the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله), the remembrance of Allah is the greatest part of the actions and sayings of that worship. The Exalted said: <<Indeed, prayer prohibits immorality and wrongdoing, but the remembrance of Allah is greater>> (إِنَّ الصَّلاةَ تَنْهى‏ عَنِ الْفَحْشاءِ والْمُنْكَرِ ولَذِكْرُ الله أَكْبَرُ). Meaning, the remembrance within it is greater than all its actions, for when you remember Allah in it, He is your companion (جليس) in those acts of worship, as He informed that He is the companion of whoever remembers Him. If He is your companion, you are either one who possesses Divine insight (بصر إلهي) and witnesses Him (تشهده), or one who lacks Divine insight and witnesses Him through the path of faith (الايمان) that He sees you. In this state, you are like the blind person who knows that Zayd is his companion, and even though he does not see him, it is as if he sees him. The one who sees Him witnesses Him as the Mover (محركا) in all his actions. The one who does not see Him senses that there is a Mover in his actions through the sense of faith, not the sense of visual Witnessing (الشهود البصري), which is the meaning of the saying, "as if you see Him." Through remembrance, he knows that He is his companion. <<Does he not know that Allah sees?>> (أَلَمْ يَعْلَمْ بِأَنَّ اللَّهَ يَرَى). The companion of The Real (الحق) must necessarily be in solitude with Him. It is impossible for another companion to remain in the mind of this servant when The Real accompanies him, because it is a companionship of the Unseen (غيب). It was said to one of them, "Remember me in your solitude with Allah." He replied, "If I remember you, I am not in solitude with Allah."

### [Allah Does Not Speak to His Creation Except from Behind a Veil]

Just as Allah does not speak to His creation except from behind a veil (حجاب), and the veil is the very essence of the speech, similarly, you do not speak to Him, nor remember yourself or anyone else in His presence, except from behind a veil. This is necessary. For Witnessing (المشاهدة) leads to astonishment and muteness. The one who remembers, even if The Real is his companion, must necessarily be blind, and his blindness is his remembrance. The Real is the companion of the Unseen (جليس غيب) for every rememberer. Whoever is overcome by the witnessing of Imagination (الخيال) concerning his Lord—from the saying "as if you see Him," which is a mental presence in the imagination—such a person combines Witnessing and speech. For the companion in that state is like you, not the One <<There is nothing like unto Him>> (لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ). This was the state of Al-Shihab, the nephew of Al-Najib (may Allah have mercy on him), according to what a trustworthy source conveyed to me, regarding his saying that the human being combines Witnessing and speech. How far is this spiritual taste (*dhawq*) from the taste of the Verifier Abu al-Abbas al-Sayyari, one of the men mentioned in Al-Qushayri’s *Risala*, when he said: "No rational person has ever found pleasure in Witnessing, because the Witnessing of The Real is Annihilation (فناء), and there is no pleasure in it." How far is this taste from the taste of Al-Shihab? Understand this, for it is a point of error for the greatest Verifiers among the People of Allah (أهل الله), let alone those below them.

### [Those Who Are Above What They Say and Those Who Are Below What They Say]

We have been informed about those we have seen among the People of Allah (أهل الله) who are attributed to Allah, who say this—meaning, something like the saying of Al-Shihab. If he possesses complete Knowledge (علم تام), he says it according to the limit we have drawn. If he is below that, he only says it as one who has no knowledge of the Realities (الحقائق) says it. If he had said it in my presence, I would have discussed it with him until I knew by which tongue he spoke it, and then I would attribute him specifically to what he said. Know that if he said that according to the course of verification (التحقيق), we would know that he is above what he says. And among them are those who are below what they say. Those who are below what they say are two groups: one group is at the extreme limit of Knowledge of Allah (العلم بالله) that is within the capacity of human beings to know of Allah; and the other group is at the extreme limit of distance and veiling (الحجاب) from Allah. These are the ones who <<know the outward appearance of the worldly life>> (يَعْلَمُونَ ظَاهِرًا مِنَ الْحَيَاةِ الدُّنْيَا). They are those who see nothing beyond the knowledge of conventions (علم الرسوم). They resemble the high-ranking group in that they are below what they say, just as they share with them the name of Knowledge, but are separated from them by the One Who is enriched by the Known—that is, by the object to which their knowledge relates. All of this is the realization of the people of the Days of Tashriq. If they eat on them, it is because they are days of eating, drinking, and remembrance. If they fast on them, it is because they are days of the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله), and remembrance preoccupies them from eating and drinking. Thus, their abstinence from eating is an abstinence of state, not an abstinence of worship.

(Section on the Chapter of Fasting on the Day of Breaking the Fast and the Day of Sacrifice)

Fasting on these two days is forbidden by the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah and the Hadith of Abu Said. As for the authentic Hadith of Abu Said, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: "Fasting is not valid on two days: the Day of Breaking the Fast (يوم الفطر) from Ramadan, and the Day of Sacrifice (يوم النحر)." Those who permit fasting the Days of Tashriq use this as evidence, because the implication of the address requires that fasting is valid on days other than these two; otherwise, specifying them would be futile. As for the authentic Hadith of Abu Hurayrah, also in Muslim, it is that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade fasting on two days: the Day of Sacrifice (يوم الأضحى) and the Day of Breaking the Fast (يوم الفطر). The Day of Breaking the Fast is the day people break their fast, and the Day of Sacrifice is the day they sacrifice. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) interpreted it thus, as Al-Tirmidhi mentioned from Aisha, from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and he said concerning it: "A sound and authentic Hadith."

### [The Reason for the Prohibition of Fasting on the Days of Breaking the Fast and Sacrifice]

The reason for the prohibition of fasting on these two days is that through the breaking of the fast and the sacrifice, the distinction (التمييز) between him and his Lord is validated for him, so he knows what belongs to him and what belongs to Him. Therefore, it is forbidden for him to associate himself with fasting on these two days, which are proofs of the Knowledge (العلم) of the difference and the distinction. With that [knowledge], he cannot associate himself with fasting, for the Fast is for Allah, since it is a transcendent (منزهة) attribute of Self-Sufficiency (صفة صمدانية)—the attribute of the One Whose description is free from food and drink. If he were to associate himself with fasting while witnessing the face of this proof, he would not be truthful in informing himself that he is in this station. Thus, his breaking the fast on these two days is an act of worship (عبادة) and a prescribed obligation (تكليفا مشروعا), so that he may combine the two states. Unveiling (الكشف) granted him the worship aspect of it, as we mentioned, and the legal obligation (التكليف الشرعي) granted him the reward for it, since he acted according to its ruling when the Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade fasting them. For this reason, we said concerning the sighting of the crescent of breaking the fast (هلال الفطر) that it is receiving an act of worship, just as some scholars explained concerning the crescent of the Fast. He was heedless of the prohibition of fasting on the crescent of breaking the fast, so he required two witnesses for its sighting.

(Section on the Chapter of One Who is Invited to Food While Fasting)

Some say that one must accept the invitation by consensus. They differed on whether he should break his fast or remain fasting. Some say he should inform the host that he is fasting and supplicate for him; this is the view of Abu Hurayrah. Some say he should not eat, but should perform the prescribed non-obligatory prayer and supplicate for the host; this is the view of Anas. Some say he is given the choice between breaking the fast and completing the fast, but if he breaks it, he must make it up; this is the view of Talhah ibn Yahya and others. Some say he may break the fast if he wishes, with no make-up required; this is the view of Sharik and Mujahid. Some say he may break the fast if he wishes, provided it is before midday; this is the view of Ja’far ibn al-Zubayr. Some say he has the choice regarding making up the fast if he breaks it; this is the view of Umm Hani and Simak ibn Harb.

### [Those Who Are in the Station of Spiritual Wayfaring]

Know—may Allah grant you the success of the Gnostics (العارفين)—that whoever initiates a fast voluntarily, without The Real (الحق) specifying that day for him to wake up fasting, has made a covenant (عقد عقدة) with Allah, seeking nearness (القربة) to Him, the Exalted, through this specific act of worship that he has associated himself with and initiated. Allah says to him: <<And do not invalidate your deeds>> (وَلَا تُبْطِلُوا أَعْمَالَكُمْ). If he is in the Station of Spiritual Wayfaring (مقام السلوك), he should not accustom himself to breaking the covenant with Allah, the Exalted, for Allah says: <<And fulfill My covenant [with you], I will fulfill your covenant [with Me]>> (وَأَوْفُوا بِعَهْدِي أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ), especially concerning what you have obligated upon yourself and contracted with your Lord, which is His saying: "No, unless it is a voluntary fast."

### [Those for Whom Vicegerency Over Their Souls is Validated]

If he is one of the great People of Knowledge of Allah (أهل العلم بالله الأكابر) who have mastered their souls and for whom Vicegerency (الخلافة) over their souls is validated, they see no speaker, commander, or inviter in Existence (الوجود) except Allah, speaking through the tongues of His servants. As the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Allah said through the tongue of His servant: 'Allah hears the one who praises Him.'" They view all the speech of the entire world, in state and in word, with this characteristic. The validity of the Station of Witnessing (مقام الشهود) dictates this ruling upon them, for they do not deny what they know. Just as the veiled person says, "So-and-so spoke," the possessor of this station says, "The Real (الحق) spoke through the tongue of this servant such-and-such," whatever the matter may be.

### [The Perfect One Always Has the Choice in Willing]

Furthermore, the speaker is either in this station, seeing that he speaks by The Real (الحق) and not by his own self, or he is not in this station. The invited person should look at the state of the inviter. If he invites him by his Lord, he accepts his invitation, says "I am fasting," does not eat, supplicates for the people of the house, and prays with them. If he wishes, he may eat, if he knows that his eating will please the inviter. He is given the choice (مخير) due to his perfection (كماله) and his realization of the Attribute (الصفة). For the Perfect One (الكامل) always has the choice in Willing (المشيئة), whether he wills or not, as long as he has not resolved (عزم). If he resolves, his resolution is like [Allah’s] saying: <<The word will not be changed with Me>> (مَا يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ), and like His saying: "And he must meet Me," and similar statements.

If this inviter invites him by his own self, he only invites his like, for he only invites one for whom eating and drinking is valid. Were it not for this Witnessing (شهوده), he would not have invited him. Therefore, this listener should not eat, and must complete his fast, for the right of Allah is more deserving of fulfillment. The right of Allah has become incumbent upon him by his associating himself with this fast.

### [The Right of the Self and the Right of the Other]

If his eating soul (نفسه الآكلة) says to him, "He did not invite you; the invitation was for me, not for you, and my acceptance of his invitation is the very essence of my eating," he replies to it: "That would only be yours if you had not initially entered into this act of worship with The Real (الحق) without Him obligating it upon you. Since you associated yourself with it, its completion became incumbent upon you, for that is your right which you obligated upon yourself, and your right upon yourself takes precedence over the right of others upon you. The Real (الحق) has informed you of this through the tongue of your Prophet." He said: "The best of charities is what you give in charity to your own self." And concerning the one who kills himself, he said: "Paradise is forbidden for him." And concerning the one who kills another, if he dies and no retribution is taken from him, He said: "If He wills, He forgives him, and if He wills, He punishes him."

If you break the fast, you neglect the right of your soul (نفسك) and fulfill the right of another. Yet, in the right of your soul is the right of Allah (حق الله). So, you prevent it from breaking the fast and occupy it with prayer (الصلاة) instead. He means that the person is engaged in intimate conversation (مناجيا) with Allah the Exalted, Who is the noblest and most perfect Caller. Allah has called him to prayer in this state, for He said to him through the tongue of His Prophet (PBUH): <<وَإِنْ كَانَ صَائِمًا فَلْيُصَلِّ>> (And if he is fasting, let him pray). Thus, He commanded him to pray in this state.

(Chapter on Perpetual Fasting)

It is only valid for the Perpetual (الدهر), not for anything other than the Perpetual. Perpetual fasting (صيام الدهر) for a human being means fasting the entire year completely. This is not valid for him because of the days of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha, as breaking the fast (الفطر) on those days is obligatory by consensus. Therefore, it is not valid. For *al-Dahr* (The Perpetual) is a Name of Allah, and the fast belongs to Him. What belongs to Allah is not yours. Something is only yours if He has not restricted it from you. If He restricts it—and it is fundamentally not yours—He has informed you that it cannot be achieved. If you attempt it, you are working in a place that is not a workplace and hoping for something that is not a source of hope.

(Chapter on the Fasting of David, Mary, and Jesus, Peace be upon them)

### The Fasting that is the Greatest Spiritual Struggle against the Soul

The best and most balanced form of fasting is fasting one day for your own right and fasting one day for the right of your Lord, with one day of breaking the fast (فطر) in between. This is the greatest spiritual struggle (مجاهدة) against the soul (النفس) and the most equitable in judgment. In such a fast, the state of prayer (الصلاة) is attained, like the state of illumination (الضوء) derived from the light (نور) of the sun. For prayer is light (*nur*), and patience (الصبر)—which is fasting—is illumination (*diya’*). Prayer is an act of worship divided between the Lord and the servant. Likewise, the fast of David (PBUH) was fasting one day and breaking the fast one day, thereby combining what belongs to you and what belongs to your Lord.

### He whose Soul Overcomes Him, his Divinity Overcomes Him

When some realized that the right of Allah (حق الله) is more deserving, they did not see equality between what belongs to Allah and what belongs to the servant. So, they fasted two days and broke the fast one day. This was the fast of Mary (PBUH). She saw that men held a degree (درجة) above her, so she said, "Perhaps I should make this second day of fasting in exchange for that degree." And so it was, for the Prophet (PBUH) testified to her perfection (الكمال), just as he testified to the perfection of men. Since she saw that the testimony of two women equals the testimony of one man, she said, "My fasting of two days is equivalent to the one day of fasting of a man." Thus, she attained the station of men (مقام الرجال) and equaled David in the merit of fasting. In this way, he whose soul (نفسه) overcomes him, his Divinity (ألوهيته) overcomes him. Therefore, he should treat his soul as Mary treated herself in this situation, until she is joined with her intellect (عقلها). This is a beautiful allusion (إشارة) for those who understand it.

### Jesus son of Mary, who was Manifest in the World by the Name *al-Dahr* and the Name *al-Qayyum*

If her perfection (الكمال) was achieved by joining the men, then the most perfect state for her is joining her Lord, like Jesus son of Mary, her son. He used to fast perpetually (يصوم الدهر) without breaking the fast and stand in prayer all night without sleeping. He was manifest in the world (العالم) by the Name *al-Dahr* (The Perpetual) in his day and by the Name *al-Qayyum* (The Self-Subsisting) in his night, He <<الَّذِي لَا تَأْخُذُهُ سِنَةٌ وَلَا نَوْمٌ>> (Whom neither slumber overtakes nor sleep). Thus, Divinity (الألوهية) was claimed for him, and it was said: <<إِنَّ اللهَ هُوَ الْمَسِيحُ ابْنُ مَرْيَمَ>> (Indeed, Allah is the Messiah, son of Mary). This was not said about any prophet before him. The most that was said about Uzayr was that he was the son of God; it was not said that he was God. Look at the effect this Attribute (الصفة) had, from behind the veil of the Unseen (حجاب الغيب), upon the hearts of those veiled among the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), such that they said: <<إِنَّ اللهَ هُوَ الْمَسِيحُ ابْنُ مَرْيَمَ>> (Indeed, Allah is the Messiah, son of Mary). He attributed disbelief (الكفر) to them in this matter as a justification for them, for they did not commit *shirk* (polytheism); rather, they said, "He is Allah." The polytheist (*mushrik*) is one who sets up another god alongside Allah. This person is a disbeliever (*kafir*), not a polytheist (*mushrik*). Thus, the Exalted said: <<لَقَدْ كَفَرَ الَّذِينَ قَالُوا إِنَّ اللَّهَ هُوَ الْمَسِيحُ ابْنُ مَرْيَمَ>> (They have certainly disbelieved who say that Allah is the Messiah, son of Mary). He described them with veiling (الستر) because they took the humanity (ناسوت) of Jesus as a locus of manifestation (مجلى). Jesus drew attention to this station (مقام) in what Allah the Exalted informed, confirming them in what they said. The Messiah said: <<يَا بَنِي إِسْرَائِيلَ اعْبُدُوا اللَّهَ رَبِّي وَرَبَّكُمْ>> (O Children of Israel, worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord). They replied, "We shall do so," and they worshipped Allah *in him*. Then he said to them: <<إِنَّهُ مَن يُشْرِكْ بِاللَّهِ فَقَدْ حَرَّمَ اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ الْجَنَّةَ>> (Indeed, he who associates partners with Allah—then Allah has forbidden him Paradise). That is, Allah has forbidden him His protective covering (كنفه) which veils him. And Allah has described them with veiling (الستر) when He described them with disbelief (الكفر). This is a verse whose apparent meaning yields the same result as the reality of the matter, and interpretation (*ta’wil*) regarding it leads to blame. If you grasp what we have mentioned, you will fall into a tremendous ocean from which no one who drowns in it ever escapes, for it is the Ocean of Eternity (بحر الأبد). How wise is the Speech of Allah for one who looks into it, gains insight, and possesses clear vision (بصيرة) from Allah concerning it!

(Chapter on the Voluntary Fasting of a Woman when her Husband is Present)

Muslim reported on the authority of Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: <<لَا تَصُومُ الْمَرْأَةُ وَبَعْلُهَا شَاهِدٌ إِلَّا بِإِذْنِهِ>> (A woman should not fast while her husband is present except with his permission).

The *hadith* refers to voluntary fasting, given the consensus on the obligation of the Ramadan fast. For this reason, Abu Dawud added the phrase "other than Ramadan" to this *hadith*.

### The Woman is the Believing Soul and her Husband is her Faith in the Law

Know that the woman (المرأة) is the believing soul (النفس المؤمنة), and her controlling husband (بعلها المتحكم فيها) is her faith in the Divine Law (إيمانها بالشرع), not the Divine Law itself. Then, the Lawgiver (الشارع) legislates for her faith whatever He wills to legislate. Thus, she does not enter into an action nor commence a deed except with his permission—that is, by his ruling (حكمه). Few of Allah’s servants do this, observing the ruling of the Divine Law in all their actions when commencing the deed. If they were to do so, it would be better for them. For this reason, much good and great knowledge (علم كبير) escape them.

(Chapter on the Fasting of the Traveler)

### It is not Righteousness to Fast while Traveling

It is established in the two *Sahih* collections (Muslim and Bukhari) on the authority of Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: <<لَيْسَ مِنَ الْبِرِّ أَنْ تَصُومُوا فِي السَّفَرِ>> (It is not righteousness to fast while traveling).

The word *min* (من) in this *hadith* is from the narration of Bukhari, for the *hadith* of Muslim reads "It is not righteousness" without *min*. Travel (*safar*) is named *safar* because it unveils (*yusfir*) the character of men, due to the hardship and effort it entails even for people of wealth and ease, so what about the weak? Thus, whoever has his deed unveiled to him by its Doer (عامله) stands apart from his fast and leaves it to the Doer, so he does not claim it, even though he is fasting. This is the fast that is untainted by hypocrisy (*riya’*) in his view. For it is not righteousness, or rather, it is not righteousness for a person to claim as his own something he knows does not belong to him, even if he is realized (متحققا) in his Lord. This is an allusion (إشارة), so pause here, for the discussion in this chapter has been lengthy.

(Chapter on the Number of Days of Obligatory Fasting)

The number of days of obligatory fasting is two hundred and twenty-six days. Vows (*al-nadhr*) are not fixed, so we limit them; their maximum is one year minus six days, or three days, for those who prohibit fasting on the days of *Tashriq*, or two days, which is the point of consensus: the day of Eid al-Adha and the day of Eid al-Fitr. The minimum vow for fasting is one day. If you consider the minimum, you would say two hundred and twenty-seven days. What is outside this number is not obligatory, including the sixty days for one who had intercourse during Ramadan, sixty for *zihar* (injurious divorce formula), and sixty for accidental killing (قتل الخطاء). Thirty days are for Ramadan. Three days are for the ransom (*fida’*) during Hajj, three for breaking an oath (*yamin*), ten for *tamattu’* (Hajj type), and at least one day for a vow (*nadhr*). Among these are obligations that are optional (*mukhayyar*), extended (*muwassa’*), or fixed by a restricted time (*mu’ayyan bi-zaman mudayyaq*).

### The Suitability between Fasting and these Acts that Made it Obligatory

Know that if there were no suitability (مناسبة) between fasting and these acts that made it obligatory, or the acts for which it serves as compensation, it would not be valid for it to take their place. This applies to every fast that serves as an expiation (*kaffara*), which is what we call the optional obligation (الواجب المخير). Some of it permits what was forbidden to him, some of it removes the right of Allah (حق الله) upon him, and some of it removes the right of Allah and the right of others upon him. It was said to me: "Since you have known these days and their obligation, we have entrusted you to your own soul (نفسك) in extracting these suitabilities. You are not alone; rather, everyone who knows them, to the point of knowing them, is restricted from making them known, regardless of the means by which he learned them." This prevented me from clarifying these suitabilities. Adherence to the Divine Commands (الأوامر الإلهية) and the Lordly Allusions (الإشارات الربانية) is obligatory upon the people of this Path (الطريق).

(Chapter on the Tooth-Stick (*Siwak*) for the Faster)

### The *Siwak* is a Purifier for the Mouth and a Pleasure for the Lord

It is established in the *Hasan* category (of Hadith) on the authority of Amir ibn Rabi’ah that he said: "I saw the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) using the *siwak* while fasting countless times."

Some say it is permissible absolutely throughout the day, and this is my view. Others say it is disliked after noon. Whoever observes the ruling concerning the breath odor (*khuluf*) dislikes it, but he is deficient in his perspective on the matter, for it is established from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) that: <<السِّوَاكُ مَطْهَرَةٌ لِلْفَمِ مَرْضَاةٌ لِلرَّبِّ>> (The *siwak* is a purifier for the mouth and a pleasure for the Lord).

It is pure and purifying, pleasing the Lord and cleaning the teeth from tartar (*qalah*) and the yellowness that appears on them.

Al-Bazzar narrated that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to his Companions: <<مَا لَكُمْ تَدْخُلُونَ عَلَيَّ قَلِحًا اسْتَاكُوا>> (Why do I see you entering upon me with tartar? Use the *siwak*!). He mentioned what pertains to the sense of sight, but he did not address the sense of smell. The *siwak* does not remove the breath odor (*khuluf*), for it is a change in the stomach manifested by breathing. The person who holds this view and the one who says "the camel became a she-camel" are the same.

### The Breath Odor of the Faster is Sweeter to Allah than the Scent of Musk

If the breath odor (*khuluf*) of the faster is sweeter to Allah on the Day of Resurrection than the scent of musk, then on the Day of Resurrection, its odor will change to the scent of musk, so there will be no *khuluf* there. Nothing transmitted from the Prophet (PBUH) concerning the faster prohibits the use of the *siwak* during fasting, nor is it disliked. Rather, it is something recommended and encouraged absolutely, without restriction by time or state. It is closer to being obligatory than merely recommended, due to the emphasis placed upon it by the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). This report served to comfort the heart of the faster when an odor appeared from his mouth that might offend his companion if the companion was not a believer. As for the one adorned with faith, far be it from him to be offended, for it is part of faith to know the station of the faster's breath odor with Allah. He finds pleasing, for a spiritual purpose (الغرض النفسي), what the sound observer finds repulsive. What then is the state of the believer when he perceives what pleases the Lord, rejoicing and eagerly speaking of it? In our view, by direct experience (*dhawq*), a sign of his faith is that he perceives that breath odor here as being like the scent of musk. When such a report is transmitted, honoring this odor above other odors due to Allah's attention to it, the heart of the faster is comforted, and he desires to increase his fasting. He knows that the angels and the Men of Allah (رجال الله) are not offended by sitting with him due to his breath odor. For the angels are offended by what the children of Adam are offended by—this is reported concerning the odors of garlic and the like—but not by the breath odor of the faster. The faster who uses the *siwak* holds a higher station than one who does not use the *siwak* at any time, for he is engaged in an additional deed that pleases Allah, which is using the *siwak*.

### The Breath Odor does not belong to the Human, but is a Necessity of Nature

Know that the breath odor (*khuluf*) does not belong to the human being; rather, it is a necessity of nature (الطبيعة) due to the putrefaction that occurs from the remnants of food remaining in the stomach, which has not been veiled by new, pleasant-smelling food. The breath (النفس) exits from the heart, passes over the stomach, and emerges carrying whatever it passes over, whether pleasant or foul, physically. This is similar to how the angel perceives it spiritually (معنى) when the servant tells a lie: the angel distances himself thirty miles due to the stench of what the lie brought forth. The People of Scents (أهل الروائح) perceive that stench from the liar through olfactory perception. If a judge is among the people of this station (مقام) and possesses this state (حال), and false testimony is given before him in a judgment, it is incumbent upon him not to execute the ruling in favor of the one testified for. If he rules in his favor, he is sinful before Allah. This is a matter of great benefit for the People of Direct Experience (أهل الأذواق). Although a judge may not rule based on his personal knowledge, he is fundamentally not permitted to contradict his knowledge. This applies to matters of wealth. As for matters concerning persons (الأبشار), he is not obliged to execute the ruling against the defendant for another reason which I do not need to explain. Since fasting is the cause of the breath odor, and fasting is for Allah, it is obligatory upon the believer to tolerate what he perceives of the faster's breath odor. Allah the Exalted took care of the one who perceives this by commanding the faster to hasten the breaking of the fast (تعجيل الفطر) and delay the pre-dawn meal (تأخير السحور) to remove the odor for the sake of his companions, and He naturally granted him joy (فرحة) upon breaking his fast.

(Another Consideration in Correspondence)

He commanded the hastening of the breaking of the fast and the delaying of the pre-dawn meal so that the intimate conversation (مناجاة) during these two prayers might be with a pleasant scent, since the time of fasting has ended. The breath odor after the time of fasting has ended is not the breath odor of the faster, for the faster's breath odor occurs only during his state of fasting. Furthermore, Allah says in this report conveyed by the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) that the pleasantness of the faster's breath odor with Allah is only on the Day of Resurrection, if it happens that the faster does not remove it. If he removes it with a *siwak* or something else that does not break the fast, it is purer and more pleasant, and he moves from pleasantness to pleasantness, and he pleases Allah. For the breath odor has no effect on the fast.

### The Beauty of Everything is in what is Suitable and Required for It

It has been reported that Allah is the most deserving of those for whom one adorns oneself. And part of adornment (*tajammul*) is using what makes scents pleasant and removes any foulness from them. For <<إِنَّ اللهَ جَمِيلٌ يُحِبُّ الْجَمَالَ>> (Indeed, Allah is Beautiful and loves beauty). The beauty of everything lies in what is suitable and required for it, which is enjoyed by the perceiver through that specific sense perception—hearing, sight, smell, taste, and touch—by means of what is heard, seen, smelled, tasted, and touched. Furthermore, it has been reported that a prayer with a *siwak* is better than seventy prayers without a *siwak*. By way of allusion (إشارة), your prayer with your Lord is better than your prayer with your soul (نفسك). He alluded to the straight path (*al-sawiyy*). The seventy is an allusion based on the typical lifespan of a human being, for the septenaries are often considered by the Divine Law (الشرع) in simple and composite things. As for the method of interpreting this *hadith*, it is that it combines two purifications: *wudu’* (ablution) and the *siwak*. The intention behind *wudu’* here is rinsing the mouth (*madmada*), which is one of the obligatory acts of *wudu’* according to our Sunnah. The mouth is the locus of intimate conversation (مناجاة), for prayer is conversation with Allah by day, intimate night talk (*musamara*) by night, and private dedication (مساررة) and public conveyance (تبليغ jahar) for the standing, the sitting, and the reclining on the side. If you belong to the world of allusion (عالم الإشارة) and pray with a *siwak*, then pray with it only to the One whose Name is *al-Subbuh* (The Glorified) and *al-Quddus* (The Holy), for *al-Quddus* grants the use of the *siwak*.

### Allusion, Realization, and the Combination of the Outer and the Inner

We only differentiated in expression between allusion (الإشارة) and realization (التحقيق) so that those who lack gnosis (معرفة) of what the People of Allah (أهل الله) take might not imagine that they discard the outward aspects (*al-zawahir*), thereby attributing them to the Esotericists (*al-Batiniyya*). Far be it from them! Rather, they are those who affirm both extremes. Our Shaykh, Abu Madyan, used to criticize both extremes when taken individually and say that the one who combines both extremes is the Perfect One (الكامل) in the Sunnah and in Gnosis (المعرفة). The ambiguity occurred in the pronunciation of *bi-siwak* (with a *siwak*). The *kaf* (ك) in *al-siwak* (السواك) is inherent to the word itself, whereas in the exception (the *hadith*), it is an added possessive pronoun and not inherent. However, whoever considers it from the perspective of realization (التحقيق) views the addition of the addressee (the possessive *kaf*) as a single matter, treating it as inherent in the addition, like a single word. He considers the composition within it like the composition of letters in a word. The existence of such an addressive addition is not valid without the *kaf* of addition, just as the name *al-siwak* is not valid without the *kaf*. Look at how subtle the perspective of the People of Allah (أهل الله) is! If this were based on mere thought, they would surpass others by it. How then is it for the one who <<وَمَا يَنطِقُ عَنِ الْهَوَىٰ * إِنْ هُوَ إِلَّا وَحْيٌ يُوحَىٰ * عَلَّمَهُ شَدِيدُ الْقُوَىٰ>> (does not speak from [his own] inclination. It is not but a revelation revealed, taught to him by one intense in strength)? <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ هُوَ الرَّزَّاقُ>> (Indeed, Allah is the Provider), and knowledge (العلم) is the provision (*rizq*) of the spirits (الأرواح), <<ذُو الْقُوَّةِ الْمَتِينُ>> (Owner of Strength, the Firm).

(Chapter on One Who Feeds a Faster)

### Breaking the Fast is Part of the Completion of the Fast

The report transmitted by Al-Tirmidhi on the authority of Zayd ibn Khalid al-Juhani states that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: <<مَنْ فَطَّرَ صَائِمًا كَانَ لَهُ مِثْلُ أَجْرِهِ غَيْرَ أَنَّهُ لَا يَنْقُصُ مِنْ أَجْرِ الصَّائِمِ شَيْءٌ>> (Whoever feeds a fasting person to break his fast will have a reward like his, without anything being diminished from the reward of the fasting person).

He said concerning it, "A sound *hadith*." Thus, the faster has a reward for breaking his fast, just as he had a reward for his fasting. Therefore, the one who feeds him has the reward for the breaking of the fast, not the reward for the fasting itself. Understand this. We learn from this report that breaking the fast (الفطر) is part of the completion (تمام) of the fast, and that whoever assists a person in a deed shares with him in the good that results from that deed—a sharing that does not necessitate any diminution, but rather is complete for each of the two partners, as came in the *hadith* about "whoever establishes a good practice..." Thus, He made the breaking of the fast part of the completion of the fast, and that it is a part of it.

### Whoever is Adorned with a Part of a Thing whose Parts are Suitable, attains its Goodness

Whoever is adorned with a part of a thing whose parts are suitable (المتناسب الأجزاء) attains the goodness of that thing, even if he does not attain or is not characterized by the whole matter as its possessor is. This is like one who is characterized by a part of the parts of Prophethood (النبوة): he has the reward and merit of the one for whom Prophethood is established, without being adorned with all of it, so he is not a prophet. For this reason, it is reported that people will come on the Day of Resurrection who are not prophets, whom the prophets will envy (*yaghbituhum*), because the prophets attained this merit through the burdens and hardships (*mashaqq*) inherent in Prophethood, while these people were characterized by a part of it, or more than a part, and were adorned with it. Perhaps this part was one that involved no hardship, yet they attained the merit of one who was adorned with the whole. This is like the poor person compared to the wealthy or knowledgeable person regarding the good deeds he wishes to perform. If he sees the wealthy or knowledgeable person doing what the poor person cannot do, they are equal in reward, having shared only in the intention (*niyya*). The person of intention is further distinguished by the dropping of the reckoning and questioning about what he spent and how he earned it.

### Those whom the Prophets Envy, though they are not Prophets

These are the ones whom the prophets envy in that station (مقام), but this occurs on the Day of Resurrection, in the Standing (الموقف), not in Paradise. This is referred to in His saying: <<لَا يَحْزُنُهُمُ الْفَزَعُ الْأَكْبَرُ>> (The greatest terror will not grieve them). For the Messengers fear for their communities, not for themselves, and the believers fear for themselves due to the transgressions they committed. But these people have neither followers to fear for, nor have they committed transgressions that necessitate fear for themselves. Thus, <<لَا يَحْزُنُهُمُ الْفَزَعُ الْأَكْبَرُ>> (The greatest terror will not grieve them). Likewise, every prophet is given the reward of the community to whom he was sent, whether they believed in him or disbelieved, because the intention (*niyya*) of every prophet is that he wished they had believed.
