Thus, all are equal in the reward of wishing, but each is distinguished from the other in the Standing (الموقف) by the number of followers. A prophet comes with the largest group, and fewer, and fewer, until a prophet comes with only two men, or one man, and a prophet comes with no one at all. Yet, all are equal in the reward of conveyance (التبليغ) and in the wish.

### Whoever Feeds a Faster has been Characterized by a Divine Attribute

Whoever feeds a faster has been characterized by a Divine Attribute (صفة إلهية), which is His Name *al-Fatir* (The Originator/Breaker of the Fast). For Allah breaks the fast of the faster with the setting of the sun, whether he ate or did not eat, drank or did not drink; he is legally breaking the fast (*muftir*). The setting of the sun removes him from the state of being adorned with the fast. And this person breaks his fast by what he was fed. When he attained this degree (درجة), he was characterized by what belongs to Allah, just as the faster was adorned in his fast with what belongs to Allah, namely, the transcendence (*tanzih*) from food, drink, companionship, and every description that invalidates the fast.

(Chapter on the Fasting of the Guest)

When Al-Tirmidhi transmitted on the authority of Aisha that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: <<مَنْ نَزَلَ عَلَى قَوْمٍ فَلَا يَصُومَنَّ تَطَوُّعًا إِلَّا بِإِذْنِهِمْ>> (Whoever stays with a people should not fast voluntarily except with their permission),

We learned that the Sufis (الصوفية) are the guests of Allah, for they have traveled away from the portions of their souls (حظوظ أنفسهم) and all created things (الأكوان), preferring the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي), and they have settled with Him. Thus, they do no deed except with the permission of the One with Whom they have settled, Who is Allah. They neither act, nor rest, nor move except by a Divine Command (أمر إلهي). Whoever does not possess this attribute is still on the path, traversing the stages of his soul (مناهل نفسه) until he reaches his Lord. Only then is it valid for him to be a guest. If he remains with Him and does not return, he is worthy of being among the People of the Quran—who are those gathered with the Exalted—for they are the People of Allah and His chosen ones.

Our Shaykh, Abu Madyan, in the Maghrib, had abandoned earning a living and sat with Allah, relying on whatever Allah opened up for him. He followed a remarkable method with Allah in that sitting, for he never rejected anything brought to him, just like Imam Abd al-Qadir al-Jili, except that Abd al-Qadir was outwardly more active due to the honor granted to him. He was asked, "O Abu Madyan, why do you not earn a living, or why do you not affirm the necessity of earning a living?" He replied, "I do affirm it." He was asked, "Then why do you not earn a living?" He said, "When a guest stays with a people and intends to reside, what is the fixed time for the obligation of hospitality upon them, according to you?" They said, "Three days." He asked, "And after the three days?" They replied, "He should earn a living and not remain with them until he burdens them." The Shaykh said, "Allah is Greater! Be fair to us. We are the guests of our Lord, the Blessed and Exalted. We have settled with Him in His Presence (حضرة) with the intention of residing with Him forever. Thus, the hospitality is fixed, for the Exalted never indicated a noble character trait for His servant unless He Himself was more worthy of being characterized by it." They said, "Yes." He said, "And the days of our Lord are as He said: <<وَإِنَّ يَوْمًا عِندَ رَبِّكَ كَأَلْفِ سَنَةٍ مِّمَّا تَعُدُّونَ>> (Indeed, a day with your Lord is like a thousand years of those which you count). So, His hospitality is according to His days. If we remain with Him for three thousand years and they pass, and we still do not earn a living, then your objection would be directed at us. But we shall die and the world will end, and we will still have a surplus of His hospitality remaining with the Exalted." The objector approved of this from him. Look into this spiritual breath (النفس) if you are one of them.

(Chapter on Covering the Seven Days with Fasting)

When it was reported in the *hadith* transmitted by Al-Tirmidhi on the authority of Aisha that she said: "The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to fast Saturday, Sunday, and Monday in one month, and Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday in another month,"

### The Righteous Servant Adorns Himself for His Lord Every Day

We learned that he (PBUH) intended to be adorned with the worship of fasting on every day of the week, either as a favor from him upon that day—for the days boast over one another because of the acts of worship performed by the discerning servant that bring him closer to Allah, since the day is the vessel for the act. Thus, the righteous servant (العبد الصالح) desires to dedicate to every day of the week, the month, and the year all the righteous deeds (*af’al al-birr*) he is capable of, so that every day praises him, and he adorns himself with it before Allah, and the day testifies for him. If he is unable to gather all good deeds in a single day, he performs what he can. When that day returns in the following week, he performs what he missed in the first week, until he fulfills all the good deeds he is capable of in that day, and similarly for the days of the month and the year.

### The Days of the Months and the Hours of the Day in the Stations of the Furthest Sphere

Know that the days of the months vary in merit according to what is attributed to them, just as the hours of the day and night vary in merit according to what is attributed to them. The night takes from the day in its hour, and the day takes from the night. The timing is based on the movement of the day, which encompasses both night and day. Likewise, the days of the months are determined by the traversing of the planets (*al-darari*) through the stations (*manazil*) of the Furthest Sphere (الفلك الأقصى), not the fixed stars which are conventionally called stations. The Moon has known days for traversing the sphere, and the Scribe (Mercury) has other days, and Venus likewise, and the Sun likewise, and the Red One (Mars) likewise, and Jupiter likewise, and the Fighter (Saturn) likewise. The servant should observe all of this in his deeds, for his lifespan is not sufficient to fulfill all of that, as the longest of these months is no more than about thirty years, no more.

### The Months of the Fixed Stars in the Sphere of the Zodiac

As for the months of the fixed stars in their traversing of the Sphere of the Zodiac (فلك البروج), there is no need for them because lifespans fall short of that. However, they have a ruling concerning the people of Hell (*Jahannam*), just as the movements of the planets (*al-darari*) have a ruling over those who are in the lowest abyss (*al-dark al-asfal*) of the Fire, who are specifically the hypocrites (*al-munafiqun*). The Esotericists (*al-Batiniyya*) do not have a station in the lowest abyss; rather, their station is in the upper part of Hell. The disbelievers (*al-kuffar*) have a station in every part of Hell. As for the People of the Gardens (*Ahl al-Jinan*), the Sphere of the Zodiac (فلك البروج) revolves around them, and it does not traverse anything, so its movement does not end by observation, because observation cannot grasp it, and its parts are uniform. For this reason, happiness (السعادة) is endless, and through it appears eternal permanence (الخلود الدائم) in everlasting bliss (النعيم المقيم) unto infinity. The Fire, however, does not have the same ruling as the People of Bliss, for what revolves around them is the sphere of the stations (*manazil*) and the planets (*al-darari*). These spheres traverse a sphere of finite area. For this reason, it is hoped that the torment (العذاب) will not be perpetual for them, even though the Fire is a dwelling of pain, and the torment is a ruling added to its being a dwelling. We know that its guardians are in perpetual bliss; they are not tormented within it, despite the fact that <<وَمَا هُمْ مِنْهَا بِمُخْرَجِينَ>> (they will not be removed from it), because they were created for it, and it is permanent, and the dweller within it is permanent because he was created for it.

### Allah is Pure Goodness in which there is no Evil, and Existence which no Non-Existence Opposes

Therefore, realize what we concluded this fasting discussion with: the precedence of Mercy (الرحمة) and its overcoming the Attribute of Wrath (صفة الغضب). Allah is too majestic and exalted not to have a theophany (تجلي) in every station. He the Exalted is Pure Goodness (الخير المحض) in which there is no evil, and Existence (الوجود) which no non-existence (*‘adam*) opposes. Existence is absolute Mercy (رحمة مطلقة) in the cosmos (الكون). Torment (العذاب) is something that occurs due to incidental matters that arise and happen. It is an accident (*‘arad*) due to an incident (*‘arid*). Accidents are not characterized by permanence; if they were, they would not be accidents. And what is incidental may not occur at all. For this reason, the assertion of the perpetuity of torment is weakened. For Mercy encompassed Adam in his entirety, and he was potentially the bearer of every structure. Thus, Mercy encompassed everyone, since there is no restriction. Adam would not have deserved to be called "one shown mercy" if there were those within him who would not accept Mercy. The Real (الحق) says: <<فَتَابَ عَلَيْهِ وَهَدَىٰ>> (So He accepted his repentance and guided [him]). That is, He returned to him with Mercy and made clear to him that He had returned to him with it, so it encompassed him. Praise be to Allah. And Allah is as His servant expects Him to be.

(Chapter on Standing in Prayer during Ramadan (*Qiyam Ramadan*))

### The Divine Name Ruling in the Month of Ramadan

No Divine Name (اسم إلهي) rules in the month of Ramadan except the Divine Name Ramadan and *Fatir al-Samawat wa al-Ard* (Originator of the Heavens and the Earth) over every servant, whether he is obligated to fast Ramadan or is only obligated to fast a number of other days. This applies to every act of worship in which the servant stands. Among the righteous deeds within it is standing in prayer at night for intimate conversation (مناجاة) with Ramadan, the Blessed and Exalted, sometimes through Unveiling (الكشف) if he is fasting continuously (*muwasil*), and sometimes from behind the veil of the Name *al-Fatir*. For the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) veil one another, and although both the veiler and the veiled possess the sovereignty of the time, some are more entitled to the veiling than others. This is prevalent in all states of creation (الخلق).

### Standing in Ramadan is an Expression of Prayer during its Night

Abu Ahmad Ibn Adi al-Jurjani mentioned, from the *hadith* of Amr ibn Abi Amr, on the authority of Al-Muttalib, on the authority of Aisha, that she said: "When Ramadan began, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) tightened his waist wrapper (شد مئزره) and did not return to his bed until Ramadan had passed."

Muslim also transmitted from her that she said: "When the last ten days of Ramadan began, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) would revive the night, wake his family, strive hard, and tighten his waist wrapper."

Standing in the night (*qiyam al-layl*) is an expression of prayer during it. This is what is known of *qiyam al-layl* in conventional Divine Law (العرف الشرعي). People in their intimate conversation with the Real (مناجاة الحق) during this time are of two types: some converse with Him through the Name *al-Mumsik* (The Withholder), which is also from the veil of the Name Ramadan; and some converse with Him through the Name *al-Fatir*, which is also from His veil. People differ according to their states.

### Contending with the All-Merciful and Contending with the Cosmos

> Were it not for the All-Merciful (الرحمن) contending with my deeds,
> My brethren would not contend with Him over creation (التكوين).
> He says "Be!" (*Kun*), and the occurrence of the cosmos is not ours,
> And He has no second in the existence of the cosmos.
> He says, "Fast!" And when we fast, He says to us,
> "This fasting is Ours, so where are My Fixed Entities (أعياني)?"
> If you say to Me, "Why do I address you with what is Mine?"
> Then My witnesses over the imposition of duty (التكليف) are My ears.
> You made me hear, then after hearing, You strip me?
> The fast is Mine, and for you, in the Law, there are two portions.
> If You strip me of it, then your affair
> In fasting is not truly My affair (شأني).

### The Name *al-Fatir* has a Stronger Ruling in the Night of Ramadan

Based on this, the Name *al-Fatir* (The Originator/Breaker) has a stronger ruling over us during the night of Ramadan than *al-Mumsik* (The Withholder). Thus, whoever is in a state of withholding (إمساكه) where his Lord feeds him and gives him drink during his sleep, while outwardly he is neither eating nor drinking, he is breaking the fast (*muftir*), even though he is fasting. I have tasted this. From this, I understood that his saying (PBUH): <<لَسْتُ كَهَيْئَتِكُمْ إِنِّي أَبِيتُ يُطْعِمُنِي رَبِّي وَيَسْقِينِي>> (I am not like you; I spend the night being fed and given drink by my Lord), was a denial that the group he addressed resembled him, for they did not possess this state. If he had meant the entire community, I would not have tasted it, yet I have found it through direct experience (*dhawq*), praise be to Allah. If one is not among those whom his Lord feeds and gives drink during continuous fasting (*wisal*), he is a parasite upon those who possess this attribute, like one who wears two garments of falsehood. Therefore, continuous fasting is disliked for him if he does not possess this attribute as a state (حال) that he witnesses through direct experience in his soul and whose effect appears upon him in his wakefulness. Allah loves truthfulness in its proper place, just as He loves falsehood in its proper place. This is not a place where falsehood is loved, for Allah dislikes it in this context. [End of the Sixtieth Section]

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

### Chapter on the Intimate Conversation with the Real in the Specific Time with the Specific Divine State

When Allah converses intimately with the servant (مناجى الله العبد) in this specific time with the specific Divine State (الحال الإلهي الخاص), the servant must be present with Him with complete presence (الحضور التام), turning away from everything else with his totality. He converses intimately with Him in every movement and rest, physically, insofar as He is the Inner (الباطن), and spiritually (معنى), insofar as He is the Outer (الظاهر), since the physical sense is outward and the spiritual meaning is inward. The spiritual meaning (المعنى) only stands before the Outer (الظاهر), for if it were to stand before the Inner (الباطن)—and the spiritual meaning is the inner aspect of the letter (الحرف) which is the sensible and the sense—it would be the standing of a thing before itself. A thing does not stand before itself, because it stands to gain benefit, and a thing does not benefit itself from itself.

### The Descent of the Real for Teaching and Defining, which is the Knowledge of Experience

Do you not see the descent of the Real (الحق) to teach and define for us, though He is the Knower of everything that was and will be? Despite this, He informed us of a reality that we do not reject, teaching us the true state of affairs: that the ruling belongs to the states (الأحوال). So, He lowered Himself to the rank of the beneficiary and made the benefit derived from His address, saying: <<وَلَنَبْلُوَنَّكُمْ حَتَّى نَعْلَمَ الْمُجَاهِدِينَ مِنكُمْ وَالصَّابِرِينَ>> (And We will surely test you until We make evident those who strive among you and the patient ones). This is despite the fact that He knows what will come from them. However, the state (الحال) prevents the establishment of His argument (الحجة) against us, the Exalted. He said: <<فَلِلَّهِ الْحُجَّةُ الْبَالِغَةُ>> (So for Allah is the conclusive argument). Thus, by testing, no one is left with an argument against Allah. By this testing, He eliminated the possibility of them saying, if He had judged them based on His knowledge: "Had You tested us, You would have found us adhering to Your limits." This is called the Knowledge of Experience (*‘Ilm al-Khibr*), which is the Name *al-Khabir* (The All-Aware) in His saying: <<عَلِيمًا خَبِيرًا>> (All-Knowing, All-Aware). This is a Divine scent (رائحة إلهية) in the benefiting of a thing from another, not from itself. We are more deserving of this attribute.

### The Gift of the Outer Name and the Gift of the Inner Name

Therefore, we made the servant's outward aspect (ظاهر العبد) converse intimately with the Inner Name (الاسم الباطن), and the servant's inward aspect (باطن العبد) converse intimately with the Outer Name (الاسم الظاهر), standing before Him as one seeking benefit, so He grants him whatever He wills to grant. If you see that the beneficiary has gained, through his standing, the breaking of sensory-perceived norms (خرق العوائد), generally called the miracles of the Friends of Allah (*karamat al-awliya’*) and the signs of the Prophets and Messengers (PBUH), then that is the gift (أعطية) of the Outer Name (الاسم الظاهر). And if you see that he has gained sciences (*‘ulum*) and wisdoms (*hikam*) that confuse the intellects, or which they reject or accept based on what the faculty of thought (القوة المفكرة) perceives of them, then all of that is the gift of the Inner Name (الاسم الباطن). Pay attention to what I have alerted and advised you about, so that you may know with whom you are conversing intimately, and do not mix things up, lest things be mixed up for you. For Allah says: <<وَلَلَبَسْنَا عَلَيْهِم مَّا يَلْبِسُونَ>> (And We would certainly have confused for them what they are confusing). And He said: <<وَمَكَرُوا وَمَكَرَ اللَّهُ>> (And they planned, and Allah planned). Then He negated planning from them, saying: <<فَلِلَّهِ الْمَكْرُ جَمِيعًا>> (So for Allah is all planning), meaning the planning attributed to His servants and the planning attributed to Him, the Exalted.

### Ibn Arabi is Commanded to Give Advice

Allah, the Exalted, commanded me through the tongue of His Prophet (PBUH) to give sincere advice (*al-nasihah*) to Allah, His Messenger, the leaders of the Muslims, and their common folk—a general address. Then He addressed me specifically, without intermediary, more than once in Mecca and Damascus, saying to me, "Advise My servants," in a vision of good tidings that I was shown. Thus, the matter became more incumbent upon me than upon others. May Allah make this for me a Divine favor (*‘inayah*) and an honor, not a trial (*ibtila’*) or a test (*tamhis*).

### The Standing One and the Sleeping One

Whoever stands before Allah the Exalted with this gnosis (معرفة) is the Standing One (*al-Qa’im*), even if he is sleeping, for he only slept by Him. And whoever does not stand before Him with this gnosis is the Sleeping One (*al-Na’im*), even if he is standing. Be an observer (*raqib*) over Him in your heart, for He is the One who encompassed it, just as He is an observer over you. You only know the locations of His effects in you and in others through observation (*muraqabah*). Know that those who stand in prayer during the month of Ramadan are based on two intentions (*khatirayn*): those who stand for Ramadan, and those who stand for the Night of Decree (*Laylat al-Qadr*), which is better than a thousand months. People differ concerning it. The state (حال) of the one who stands for Ramadan does not change with increase or decrease, while the state of the one who stands for the Night of Decree changes according to his doctrine concerning it.

(Chapter on the Night of Decree (*Laylat al-Qadr*))

### The Difference of Opinion Concerning the Night of Decree

People have differed concerning the Night of Decree (ليلة القدر), meaning its time. Some say it rotates throughout the entire year, and this is my view, for I have seen it in Sha’ban, in the month of Rabi’, and in the month of Ramadan. Most often, I have seen it in Ramadan, and in the last ten days of it. I saw it once in the middle ten days of Ramadan, on a non-odd night and on an odd night among them. We are certain that it rotates throughout the year, on both odd (*witr*) and even (*shaf’*) nights of the month in which it is seen.

### People are of Two Types: Servants and Hired Workers

Whoever stands in prayer for the sake of the Night of Decree has stood for his own soul (نفسه), even if his standing is due to the Real’s encouragement to seek it. But whoever stands for the sake of the Name (الاسم) that established him—Ramadan or otherwise—his standing is for Allah, not for his soul, and this is more complete. All of it is Divine Law (شرع). People are of two types: servants (*‘abid*) and hired workers (*ujara’*). It was for the sake of hiring (*ijarah*) that the Divine Books were revealed, establishing a contract between the hired worker and the employer. If they were servants (*‘abid*), the Real would not have written a book for them against Himself, for the servant does not set a time limit for his master; rather, he works in his master’s domain and takes what he needs. Those (the hired workers) have their reward (*ajr*), and the servants have their Light (نور), which is their Master, for He is <<نُورُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (the Light of the heavens and the earth). The Exalted said: <<أُولَٰئِكَ هُمُ الصِّدِّيقُونَ وَالشُّهَدَاءُ عِندَ رَبِّهِمْ لَهُمْ أَجْرُهُمْ وَنُورُهُمْ>> (Those are the truthful ones and the martyrs with their Lord. For them is their reward and their light). He means the hired workers (الأجزاء) who have their reward (*ajr*), and those from whom the Real bought their souls and their light, who are the servants (*‘abid*) and maidservants. May Allah make us and you among those highest in station (مقام) and most beloved to Him. Indeed, He is the Protecting Friend, the Benefactor.

### The Night of Decree is Better than a Thousand Months

Know that if a person encounters the Night of Decree (ليلة القدر), it is better for him, in terms of the blessings Allah bestows upon him, than a thousand months, even if it occurred only once in a thousand months. How much more so when it occurs every twelve months, every year? This is a subtle meaning (معنى غريب) that has not reached your ears except in this text. It also contains another meaning: that it is <<خَيْرٌ مِّنْ أَلْفِ شَهْرٍ>> (better than a thousand months) without limitation. Even if the excess beyond a thousand months is unlimited, one does not know where it ends. Allah did not make it equal to a thousand months; rather, He made it better than that—that is, superior to it—without setting a time limit. Thus, if the servant attains it, it is as if he lived in sincere worship of his Lord for more than a thousand months without a time limit. This is like one who exceeds the natural lifespan and enters the unknown lifespan; although he must inevitably die, he does not know whether, after exceeding the natural lifespan, he will live for one breath or thousands of years. Such is the Night of Decree when it is not restricted, as we have stated.

### The Month, in its True Consideration, is the Singular Perfect Servant

Know that the month (*al-shahr*) here, in its true consideration (الاعتبار الحقيقي), is the Perfect Servant (العبد الكامل) when the Moon—which Allah made a light (*nur*) and gave a Name from His Names—travels, so that the Exalted is the intended object, not the physical body of the Moon. The Moon, in terms of its physical body, is a locus of manifestation (*mazhar*) of the Real (الحق) in His Name *al-Nur* (The Light). It travels through the stations (*manazil*) of His servant, which are restricted to twenty-eight. When it completes this, it is truly called a month, because it has fulfilled its journey and begun another. This is perpetually the case from the perspective of spiritual meaning (المعنى), for the Act of the Real (فعل الحق) in the created things (الكائنات) is endless, so it has permanence through Allah the Exalted’s preservation. Similarly, the servant travels through the stations of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), which are ninety-nine. The ninety-ninth of these is *al-Wasilah* (The Means), which belongs exclusively to Muhammad (PBUH). The ninety-eight are for us, like the twenty-eight stations of the Moon. Some people call this the Singular Human (الإنسان المفرد) and the twenty-five hundredths, because they are originally one hundred Names, but He concealed one for the sake of oddness (*witriyyah*), for Allah is Odd (*Witr*) and loves the odd. Thus, what He concealed is odd, and what He manifested is also odd. We mentioned the twenty-eight stations of the Moon to draw attention to the fact that they arise from the multiplication of four by seven. The constitution of the human being (نشأة الإنسان) arises from four humors (*akhlat*) multiplied by seven attributes (صفات): Life, Knowledge, Will, Power, Speech, Hearing, and Sight. The human being resulted from the multiplication of these totals by one another, and he had no manifestation except through Allah, from His Name *al-Nur* (The Light), because Light manifests things and is manifest by itself. Thus, its ruling over things is an essential ruling (*hukm dhati*). Likewise, the month only appeared through the Moon’s journey, insofar as it is a light in the stations. The Exalted said: <<وَالْقَمَرَ قَدَّرْنَاهُ مَنَازِلَ>> (And the moon—We have determined for it phases). When its journey in them ends, that is the truly realized month (الشهر المحقق). Anything else called a month is according to convention, so there is no contradiction.

### The Two Nights and the Two Faces of the Realized Month

For Allah the Exalted, in every station of the servant that the Name *al-Nur* descends upon, there is a specific ruling, which we have mentioned in this book in the description of the inward-bound traveler (*al-salik al-dakhil*) and the outward-bound traveler (*al-salik al-kharij*). The separator between the two journeys is the night of fullness (ليلة الإبدار), which is the middle night of the twenty-eight—the fourteenth night of the realized month—and the night of concealment (*laylat al-sirar*) from it. The Light (النور) in it is always complete, for it has two faces, and the Theophany (التجلي) is necessarily attached to it and never separates from it. It is either in one face or in both faces, with increase and decrease in each face. It possesses perfection (الكمال) necessarily from its Essence (ذاته), and it possesses increase and decrease due to its having two faces. Whenever it increases in one face, it decreases in the other, yet it remains itself, by a wisdom decreed by the All-Mighty, the All-Knowing.

> In the two pans of our balance is a lesson for you,
> And you are the tongue within it, if you but understand.
> If one of them outweighs the other, its sister becomes light,
> And you, because of what is in them, incline and descend.

### The Night in which Every Wise Matter is Distinguished and Descends

The Exalted attributed the Night of Decree (القدر) to the night rather than the day because the night resembles the Unseen (الغيب), and decree (*taqdir*) is only unseen, for it is in the soul (نفس) of the human being. The day grants manifestation (الظهور). If it were in the day, the ruling would appear in an unsuitable and inappropriate place. For the act in the outward aspect only appears in the form of what is in the soul. Thus, it emerges from the Unseen (غيب) to the Witnessed (شهادة) relative to Allah, and from non-existence (*‘adam*) to existence (*wujud*) relative to creation (الخلق). It is a night in which <<كُلُّ أَمْرٍ حَكِيمٍ>> (every wise matter) is distinguished. The matter descends to it as a single entity (*‘aynan wahidah*), then it is distinguished within it according to the details it grants. This is like speech: you say it is one, by virtue of its being speech, then it is distinguished in the speaker according to the states of the one speaking, into narration, inquiry, confirmation, threat, command, prohibition, and other categories of speech, despite its unity. Thus, it is the night of the decrees (مقادير) of things, and the decrees seek none other than us. For this reason, we were commanded to seek the Night of Decree, which is his saying (PBUH): <<الْتَمِسُوهَا>> (Seek it), so that we may receive it. Just as one receives an arrival when he returns from his journey. When the traveler returns from his journey, if he possesses anything, he must have a gift for his family who receive him. When they receive him and gather with him, he hands over to them what he had prepared for them. Those are the decrees (*maqadir*) concerning them, and they should rejoice in that. Among them, the gift may be the meeting with his Lord (لقاء ربه); among them, the gift may be Divine success (*tawfiq*) and adherence (الاعتصام). Each receives according to what the Decreer willed to grant and bestow upon him, with no restriction upon Him in that.

### The Night of Decree is Rotating and Moving in All Months

Its sign is the effacement of lights (الأنوار) by its light. It was made rotating and moving (دائرة منتقلة) throughout the months and the days of the week, so that every month takes its share of it, and likewise every day of the week. Just as Ramadan was made to rotate through the solar months so that every solar month takes the merit of Ramadan, thus the merit of Ramadan encompasses all seasons of the year. If our obligatory fast were based on solar months, this universality would not be achieved. The Hajj is likewise, and the Zakat is likewise, for its year (*hawl*) is not fixed; rather, its beginning is from the time the obligated person acquires the wealth. There is no day in the year that is not the beginning of a year for a wealth owner. Thus, the year does not pass without all its days being a locus for Zakat, which is purification and blessing. All people are in the blessing of the Zakat of every day, encompassing everyone who paid Zakat in it and everyone who did not.

### The Sign of the Night of Decree is the Effacement of All Lights by its Light

The light of the sun is effaced from the body of the sun on the morning following the Night of Decree as a sign that the night is the time of its arrival and the day is the time of the manifestation of its rulings. For this reason, it is received at night, in veneration of it. Whoever misses perceiving it at night should observe the sun. If he sees the sign, he should supplicate with what he would have supplicated with during the night had he known it. The effacement of the sun's light by its light is like the light of the stars when the sun appears: no light remains visible to the eye. By this, the doctrine of those who consider the dawn (*fajr*) to be the redness of the twilight is strengthened, based on His saying: <<هِيَ حَتَّىٰ مَطْلَعِ الْفَجْرِ>> (It is until the emergence of dawn)—that is, until the emergence of dawn. That decree (*qadr*) is what distinguishes the boundary of the night from the day. The rising dawn is not that dawn in the Night of Decree derived from the sun's light. Rather, it is the light of the Night of Decree that appears in the body of the sun. Just as the light of the moon is only the light of the sun appearing in the body of the moon—if the moon's light were from its own essence, it would have rays, as the sun does, but since it is borrowed from the sun, it has no rays. Likewise, the sun has rays from its own essential light. When the Night of Decree effaces the sun's rays, the sun remains like the moon: it has illumination (*daw’*) in existing things without rays, even though the illumination is present. That illumination is the light of the Night of Decree until it rises the height of a spear or less. At that point, its light returns to it.

### And you see the Sun on the Morning of the Night of Decree as if it were a Basin, having no Rays

Thus, you see the sun rising on its morning—the morning of the Night of Decree—as if it were a basin (*tas*), having no rays, despite the presence of illumination, like the rising of the moon which has no rays. I only mentioned this to you so that you may know by which light you are illuminated on the morning of the Night of Decree, and thus know that the ruling over all lights belongs to the One Who is <<نُورُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (the Light of the heavens and the earth). He caused lights to descend, including what requires matter, which is the lamp (*misbah*). When the Real (الحق) caused His Light to descend in the similitude of a lamp—which is a light dependent on matter to supply it, namely oil—then the lights higher than it are closer to the similitude and higher in transcendence (*tanzih*). The Real only informed us of this and brought the *kaf* of similitude in His saying: <<كَمِشْكَاةٍ>> (like a niche) until the end of the verse, as a sign that He is the Light of every light; indeed, He is every light. He legislated for us the seeking of this attribute. Thus, the Prophet (PBUH) used to say: <<وَاجْعَلْنِي نُورًا>> (And make me light). And so he (PBUH) was.

(Chapter on Seeking It for Fear of Missing It)

### The Pre-dawn Meal is Success, and Success is Subsistence

Al-Tirmidhi transmitted on the authority of Abu Dharr that he said: "We fasted with the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), and he did not lead us in prayer until seven days of the month remained. Then he led us in prayer until a third of the night had passed. Then he did not lead us on the sixth night. He led us on the fifth night until half the night had passed. We said to him, 'O Messenger of Allah, if only you would lead us in voluntary prayer for the rest of this night of ours.' He said, 'Indeed, whoever stands with the Imam until he departs, the standing of a whole night is recorded for him.' Then he did not pray with us until three days of the month remained. He prayed with us on the third night, called his family and his wives, and led us in prayer until we feared we would miss *al-falah*." It was asked, "What is *al-falah*?" He said, "The pre-dawn meal (*al-sahur*)."

He said, "This is a *hasan sahih* (good and sound) *hadith*." Look at how remarkable the saying of this Companion is, where he named the pre-dawn meal (*al-sahur*) *falah* (success/felicity), and *falah* is subsistence (*baqa’*). He alerts us that the human being is only fasting accidentally (*bi’l-‘arad*), for fasting has no subsistence for him, since fasting is for Allah. Do you not see that its ruling ceases for the fasters with the passing of the world? In the Hereafter, he eats and drinks by virtue of what he sent forth during the days of fasting, which are the empty days (الأيام الخالية)—meaning the past days. The Exalted said: <<كُلُوا وَاشْرَبُوا هَنِيئًا بِمَا أَسْلَفْتُمْ فِي الْأَيَّامِ الْخَالِيَةِ>> (Eat and drink in satisfaction for what you put forth in the days past)—the days of fasting in the world. The Hereafter is the abode of subsistence (*dar baqa’*), and <<أُكُلُهَا دَائِمٌ وَظِلُّهَا>> (its food is perpetual and its shade). The pre-dawn meal is a meal of nourishment. Thus, he alerted us that the human being, in his subsistence, is an eater, not a faster. He is essentially nourished (*mutaghadhdhi bi’l-dhat*) and accidentally fasting (*sa’im bi’l-‘arad*). Nourishment is subsistent, so he called it *falah*, meaning subsistence.

### The Self-Subsistence of the Lord and the Self-Subsistence of the Servant

This comes from *al-sahar* (the time just before dawn), and *al-sahar* has two faces, as we mentioned: one face toward the night and one face toward the day, which is the time between the two dawns. Likewise, the human being has subsistence (*al-baqa’*), which is *al-falah* (success) and *al-sahur* (the pre-dawn meal) in the station (مقام) where he is. He has one face toward the Necessarily Existent by Himself (الواجب الوجود لنفسه) and one face toward non-existence (*‘adam*). He never separates from this, regardless of his state of existence or non-existence. For this reason, he is called contingent (*mumkin*) and is included among contingent things. This attribute remains with him. Even if he manifests a Divine description (*na’t ilahi*) at a certain time, he has no subsistence in it. Rather, his subsistence is in what we have stated. For this reason, the Companion, when characterized by *al-Qayyum* (The Self-Subsisting) in his night, said, "We feared we would miss *al-falah*," which is the passing of the time of night without having known our souls (نفوسنا), since in knowing them is the knowledge of our Lord. But they did not miss *al-falah*, praise be to Allah. Rather, Allah made them witness their souls through nourishment, so that they might witness that Self-Subsistence (*al-Qayyumiyyah*) belongs to Him essentially (ذاتية), while the servant's self-subsistence is only through the supply of what he is nourished by. For this reason, he (PBUH) said: <<حَسْبُ ابْنِ آدَمَ لُقَيْمَاتٌ يُقِمْنَ صُلْبَهُ>> (Sufficient for the son of Adam are a few morsels that keep his back straight). Thus, He attributed Self-Subsistence (*al-Qayyumiyyah*) to the nourishment, even though the human is the one standing by it. It is as if he were saying: "Even though we were adorned with seeking this Night from the Name *al-Witr* (The Odd), that seeking did not dispense us from the portions of our souls (حظوظ نفوسنا) by which our subsistence is maintained, which is nourishment. Our seeking of it is only for the good we attain from it in the Abode of Subsistence (دار البقاء). We only sought it through worship for a portion of the soul (حظ نفسي) by which we subsist in the Hereafter." The pre-dawn meal (*al-sahur*) is the Lord of the Time (*Rabb al-Waqt*) in the immediate state, and it is the cause of the subsistence of worldly life for righteous deeds. Thus, we feared missing its ruling, since that ruling was the very object of our seeking through the quest, even though the abode differs.

### The Night of Power in the Odd Nights, and it may be in the Even Nights

Then he (peace and blessings be upon him) placed it in the odd nights, not the even ones, because the night is singular (وتر) in relation to the day, which is dual (شفع). The day is composed of night and day. However, if a specific text were to be revealed concerning that year, it might occur in the even nights, except that year when the tradition (الخبر) mentioned seeking it in the odd nights of the last ten days.

And for another reason as well: when the seeking occurs during the odd nights of the month, the oddness (الوتر) acts as a guardian for this servant regarding the blessings and goodness granted by this night. Being in an odd time (وتر من الزمان) reminds him of the Singularity of the Real (وترية الحق). Thus, he attributes that goodness to Allah, not to the night, even though the night is the cause (سببا) of its attainment. The very witnessing (شهود) of the Singularity protects him from attributing goodness to other than Allah, even while acknowledging the established cause.

If it were in an even night, and that night were the cause, this servant would lack that which reminds him of his state (تذكير حال) at the time of seeking it or at the time of witnessing it (شهوده) when he finds it. He would then be receiving goodness from a hand other than its rightful owner, resulting in ignorance (جهل) and veiling (حجاب) in the reception of that goodness. The goodness he attained therein would not outweigh the deprivation and ignorance resulting from his veiling from the Giver of Goodness. For this reason, too, it was placed in the odd nights. Understand this.

### The Night of Power in the Middle Ten Days and the Last Ten Days

It was placed in the last ten days because it is a light (نور), and light is witnessing (شهادة) and manifestation (ظهور). Thus, it is equivalent to the daytime, as the day is named for the expansion of light within it. The day comes after the night because it is stripped away from it. The last ten days come after the middle and first ten days. Therefore, its manifestation and seeking occur in the most appropriate, later period. I have never seen anyone who saw it in the first ten days, nor has it been transmitted to us. It only occurs in the middle and last ten days.

Muslim reported from Abu Sa'id, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) performed *i'tikaf* (spiritual retreat) during the middle ten days of Ramadan, seeking the Night of Power (ليلة القدر).

Similarly, regarding the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي), it has never been reported in any prophetic tradition, sound or weak, that Allah discloses Himself (يتجلى) during the first third of the night. It has been reported that He discloses Himself during the middle and last thirds of the night. The Night of Power (ليلة القدر) is merely the ruling (حكم) of a Divine Theophany. Thus, it occurs in the middle and last thirds of the month, and not in the first third. For the first is necessarily you. Priority (الأولية) belongs to you in your knowledge (معرفتك) of your Lord, and you and He do not coincide, just as the proof (الدليل) and the proven (المدلول) do not coincide.

Whoever knows himself knows his Lord. Therefore, He places you first, for you are the proof (الدليل). Priority belongs to you in theoretical knowledge (المعرفة النظرية) and knowledge through Unveiling (الكشفية), for gnosis through Unveiling (معرفة الكشف) only occurs after spiritual discipline (*riyada*) and struggle (*mujahada*). Thus, your precedence is necessary, both theoretically and through Unveiling. Just as His Knowledge (علمه) of you derives only from His Knowledge of Himself. If He were not characterized by being Knower of Himself, He would not know you. Ponder deeply where Allah’s Knowledge of you originates, for this is an extremely subtle matter (مسألة دقيقة جدا) which we have mentioned in our book entitled *‘Uqlat al-Mustawfiz* (The Snare of the Hurrying Seeker) and in this book.

(Section on Seeking It in Congregation by Standing in Prayer during the Month of Ramadan)

Abu Dawud reported from Muslim ibn Khalid, from al-’Ala’, from his father, from Abu Hurayra, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) went out during Ramadan and saw people praying in a corner of the mosque. He asked, "Who are these?" It was said, "These are people who do not have the Qur’an memorized, and Ubayy ibn Ka’b is leading them in prayer, and they are praying with his prayer." The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "They have done well, and what an excellent thing they have done."

### Congregation is More Appropriate on the Night of Power than Other Nights, because it is a Night of Gathering

The state of gathering (الجمعية) is more appropriate on this night due to its suitability, for its measure (قدرها) is greater than a thousand months, both its nights and its days. Thus, it holds the station of this gathering. And Allah sent down the Qur’an therein as a *Qur’an* (a reading/gathering), meaning, gathered together. He sent it down using the plural of majesty and gathering (إِنَّا - We), thereby gathering all the Names (الأسماء) in its descent therein, by His saying: <<إِنَّا أَنْزَلْناهُ في لَيْلَةِ الْقَدْرِ>> (Indeed, We sent it down on the Night of Power). And therein <<تَنَزَّلُ الْمَلائِكَةُ>> (the angels descend)—not just one descends—<<وَالرُّوحُ>> (and the Spirit), who stands among them in the position of Ubayy leading the congregation in prayer, <<مِنْ كُلِّ أَمْرٍ>> (with every command). And "every" (كل) necessitates all the affairs that the Real (الحق) wishes to execute in His Creation (خلقه). And <<حَتَّى مَطْلَعِ الْفَجْرِ>> (until the rising of the dawn) is the ultimate limit, for it implies the particle *ila* (إلى), which denotes a limit. A limit cannot exist without a beginning. Thus, it is a gathering. This night is a night of gathering (ليلة جمع). Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "They have done well, and what an excellent thing they have done," envying them for what we have mentioned.

### The Impetus for Seeking the Night of Power

The impetus for seeking it involves matters that necessitate it, which are the motives for seeking it: the greatness of its measure (قدرها), the greatness of the One who sent it down, and the lowliness of the one who seeks it, as perceived by himself through his seeking. For by seeking this immensely great goodness, he witnesses in himself a profound corresponding need (افتقار عظيم). This is because whenever the servant desires to realize his servitude (*‘ubudiyya*), he diminishes his own worth until he attaches himself to non-existence (*al-‘adam*), which is his origin. Nothing is lower than non-existence, and thus nothing is lower than the soul of the created being (نفس المخلوق).

It is also named the Night of Power (ليلة القدر) because the People of Presence (أهل الحضور) know their own measures (أقدارهم) therein—meaning, their lowliness—even though the goodness they attain is a partnership with all seekers in contingency (*al-imkan*) and need (*al-iftiqar*). The poorest of existing things is that which is in need of one who is also in need. Thus, nothing is poorer than the human being, for no one has greater Gnosis (أعرف بالله) of Allah than he, due to his comprehensiveness (جمعيته), his intellect, and his knowledge of himself.

(Section on the Forgiveness Granted to One Who Stands in Prayer on It, Equating Him with the Messenger of Allah)

Allah the Exalted said, addressing Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him): <<لِيَغْفِرَ لَكَ الله ما تَقَدَّمَ من ذَنْبِكَ وما تَأَخَّرَ>> (That Allah may forgive you your sin that which has preceded and that which will follow). Muslim and Al-Nasa’i reported from the hadith of Abu Hurayra that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever stands in prayer on the Night of Power (ليلة القدر)—and in Muslim's version, 'and coincides with it'—out of faith and seeking reward, will be forgiven his sin that which has preceded and that which will follow." This means his sin is concealed from him so that he is not ashamed, even if he is among those to whom it was said, "Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you," as reported in the *Sahih* collection.

### Whoever Stands in Prayer on the Night of Power and Coincides with It, the Address of Prohibition is Concealed from Him

Thus, the address of prohibition (خطاب التحريم) is concealed from him, and it is made lawful for him according to the Law (*shar‘an*). He only acts within what is permissible, for <<إِنَّ اللهَ لا يَأْمُرُ بِالْفَحْشاءِ>> (Indeed, Allah does not command immorality). Were it not for the greatness of its measure (قدرها), Allah would not have attached it to the Attribute of Knowledge (صفة العلم), which is the noblest of Attributes. For this reason, the Exalted commanded His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to seek increase in it.

The meaning of my statement that Allah attached it is based on what is reported in the *Sahih*: that when a servant commits a sin, and knows that he has a Lord who forgives sin and holds accountable for sin, Allah says to him on the third occasion, "Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you." There is no cause necessitating the permissibility of what was forbidden to him except Knowledge (العلم). Thus, the merit of the Night of Power (فضل ليلة القدر) is attached to the Level of Knowledge (مرتبة العلم) in what we have mentioned. And he (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Whoever is deprived of its goodness is indeed deprived," as reported by Al-Nasa’i. And what goodness is greater than the lifting of restriction (رفع التحجير)? That is an immediate paradise.

(Section on I'tikaf)

### I'tikaf Linguistically, Legally, and Esoterically

*I'tikaf* (الاعتكاف) is linguistically defined as staying in a specific place. Legally (*shar‘an*), it is staying engaged in a specific act, in a specific state, with the intention of drawing near (*qurba*) to Allah, Glorious is His Majesty. It is recommended legally and obligatory by vow (*nadhir*). Esoterically (*fi al-i'tibar*), it is abiding with Allah (الإقامة مع الله) in a manner befitting Allah, preferring the Divine Presence (الجناب الله). If one abides *by* Allah (أقام بالله), it is more complete than abiding *by* oneself.

### The Act Specific to I'tikaf

As for the act specific to it, some say it is prayer, remembrance of Allah (*dhikr*), and recitation of the Qur’an, and no other acts of piety or drawing near (*qurb*). Others say it includes all acts of piety related to the Hereafter. What I hold is that the one performing *i'tikaf* may perform all acts of piety that do not necessitate leaving the place where he is abiding. If he leaves, he is not performing *i'tikaf*. In my view, the condition of stipulation (الاشتراط) is not established therein. It is established from ‘A’isha that the *Sunna* for the one performing *i'tikaf* is not to attend a funeral or visit the sick.

### Abiding with Allah by Allah, and Abiding by Yourself for Him

Know that if the abiding with Allah (الإقامة مع الله) is *by* Allah (بالله), then the person has the right to engage in all acts of piety, both those specific to the place of his retreat and those external acts that would normally cause him to leave his place, for Allah says: <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). But if the abiding is *by* yourself for Allah (بنفسك لله), then you have designated a place for it, and you must adhere to it until He discloses Himself (يتجلى لك) to you in something other than what you obligated yourself to. Understand this.

(Section on the Place Where I'tikaf is Performed)

Some say that *i'tikaf* is only permissible in the three mosques to which men travel. Others say *i'tikaf* is general in every mosque. Others say there is no *i'tikaf* except in a mosque where the Friday prayer (*Jumu‘a*) is established. Some say a woman performs *i'tikaf* in the mosque of her house. Others say *i'tikaf* is permissible wherever one wishes, except that if one performs *i'tikaf* outside a mosque, it is permissible for him to have intimacy with women, but if he performs *i'tikaf* in a mosque, intimacy with women is not permissible for him. I agree with this, but I add that if he intends to perform *i'tikaf* during days when the Friday prayer is established, he must only perform *i'tikaf* in a place where he can establish the Friday prayer while abiding there, whether that is inside the mosque or in a place near the mosque where it is permissible for him to establish the Friday prayer.

### Mosques are the Houses of Allah, Attributed to Him

Know that mosques are the Houses of Allah, attributed to Him. Whoever commits himself to abiding in them should not turn his face toward anyone other than the Lord of the House, for that is poor etiquette (*su’ adab*). The only benefit of their specific attribution to Allah is that they should not be mixed with anything related to the desires of the natural self (*huzuz al-tab‘*). Whoever abides with Allah in a house other than the one He attributed to Himself (i.e., a mosque) is permitted to have intimacy with his family, except during the state of fasting in his *i'tikaf*, if he is fasting.

### Intimacy with a Woman is the Intellect's Return from the State of Intellect to the Witnessing of the Soul

Intimacy with a woman (مباشرة المرأة) is the intellect’s return (رجوع العقل) from the state of intellect concerning Allah to the witnessing of the soul (مشاهدة النفس), whether he makes her a proof (دليلا) or not. If he makes her a proof, the proof (الدليل) and the proven (المدلول) do not coincide, so abiding with Allah (الإقامة مع الله) and engaging with the soul (ملابسة النفس) are not sound. The highest form of returning to and engaging with the soul is when a proof is involved in that engagement. But if no proof is involved, then only the witnessing of nature (شهود الطبع) remains. Therefore, the one performing *i'tikaf* should not have intimacy with women, whether he is in a mosque or outside a mosque.

### The Pervasion of the Real in All Existing Things

However, whoever’s witnessing (مشهده) is the pervasion of the Real (سريان الحق) in all existing things, and that He is the Manifest (الظاهر) in the loci of manifestation (مظاهر) of the Fixed Entities (الأعيان), and that Existence (الوجود) in the Entities came about through His Power and their preparedness (استعداداتها), such a person sees that [intimacy] is a form of marriage (*nikah*) and permits the one performing *i'tikaf* to have intimacy with his wife if he is not in a mosque. For in this station of witnessing (المشهد), it is not sound for the mosque to have a distinct existing entity (*‘ayn mawjuda*), since one whose state is this sees nothing in the Entities (الأعيان) but Allah. Thus, there is no mosque—meaning, no place of humility or bowing down. Understand this.

(Section on Making Up Missed I'tikaf)

Muslim reported from Ubayy ibn Ka’b that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to perform *i'tikaf* during the last ten days of Ramadan. One year he traveled and did not perform *i'tikaf*. The following year, he performed *i'tikaf* for twenty nights.

### Abiding Permanently with Allah is the Path of the People of Allah

Permanent abiding with Allah (الإقامة مع الله على الدوام) is the path of the People of Allah (أهل الله). This state merits universal praise (الثناء العام). Therefore, its possessor says, "Praise be to Allah in every state" (*Al-hamdu lillahi ‘ala kulli hal*). This is the remembrance (*dhikr*) of adversity, and it is the most general and complete remembrance. If the servant praises Him during adversity, how will he be during prosperity? Prosperity is one of the servant’s states and is included under the generality of the phrase "every state," which encompasses both extremes and what lies between them. The praise of prosperity is restricted. For the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) used to say during prosperity, "Praise be to Allah, the Bestower of Favors, the Gracious One" (الحمد لله المنعم المفضل), thereby restricting it. This praise is also more general than the first, even though restriction appears in it, but not everyone perceives this. For among Allah’s favors and bestowals upon His servant is that He grants him success to say, during adversity, "Praise be to Allah in every state." This is a manifestation of His Name, the Bestower of Favors, the Gracious One, upon him through this utterance.

### Seeing Allah with Everything and After Everything

If it happens that Allah transfers the one who possesses the attribute of abiding with Him in every state to one who sees Allah after everything, this state removes him from permanent abiding with Allah. He is then in the position of a traveler, which contradicts *i'tikaf*. He must therefore make up the missed *i'tikaf* (*qada’*) when he returns to his original state. The form of making it up is abiding with Allah (الإقامة مع الله) as established by legal proof (الدليل الشرعي). These are "other days," namely the middle ten days, which lie between the last and the first twenty. Similarly, these are the descriptions (*nu‘ut*) brought by the Law (*Shari‘a*) concerning the attributes of similitude (*tashbih*) between the sensible and the intellect, which is the Presence of Imagination (حضرة الخيال). In this Presence (حضرة), he makes up the *i'tikaf*. And in the last ten days connected to it, he performs *i'tikaf* according to his custom, with the attributes of incomparability (*tanzih*), rationally and legally, derived from <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing whatever like unto Him).

(Section on Determining the Time When the One Who Desires I'tikaf Enters the Place Where He Abides)

Muslim reported in his *Sahih* from ‘A’isha (may Allah be pleased with her) that when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) intended to perform *i'tikaf*, he would pray the Dawn Prayer (*Fajr*) and then enter his place of retreat (*mu‘takaf*).

### The General Absolute I'tikaf and the Specific Restricted I'tikaf

Know that the one performing *i'tikaf* (المعتكف), who abides with Allah permanently with the intention of drawing near (*qurba*), can only achieve this through a specific mode: that he witnesses Him in everything. This is the General Absolute *I'tikaf* (الاعتكاف العام المطلق). There is another, restricted *i'tikaf* (اعتكاف مقيد) in which the servant performs retreat with a specific Divine Name (اسم ما إلهي). That Name discloses itself to him through its authority and invites him to abide with it.

### The Divine Command is Cyclical, so it is Endless in Things

The consideration of the place of *i'tikaf* in esoteric meanings is the station (*makana*). There is no Divine Name (اسم إلهي) except that it lies between two other Divine Names, for the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي) is cyclical (دوري). For this reason, Allah’s command is endless (لا يتناهى) in things. The circle has neither a beginning nor an end, except by way of assumption. For this reason, the World (العالم) emerged circular, in the form of the Command as it is in itself, even in its shapes. The first shape before the universal body is the circular shape, which is the celestial sphere (*falak*). Since the things that come into existence from Allah occur at the movements of these spheres, according to what the Almighty, the All-Knowing, has decreed, wisdom dictated that they should take His form in shape or something close to it. There is no animal, tree, leaf, stone, or body that does not have an inclination toward circularity; it is indispensable, though it is subtle in some things and clearly manifest in others. Direct your attention to everything Allah the Exalted created—mountains, trees, and bodies—and you will see in it a bending toward circularity. For this reason, the spherical shape (الشكل الكري) is the best of shapes.

### Entering I'tikaf at the Time of the Appearance of the Sign of the Greatest Theophany

Since the General Greatest Theophany (التجلي الأعظم العام) resembles the rising of the sun, and the General *I'tikaf* (الاعتكاف العام) occurs with the solar Theophany, the one performing *i'tikaf* is told, through the interpreter of a specific Divine Name, "Enter your retreat at the time of the appearance of the sign of the Greatest Theophany, which is the rising of the dawn (*Fajr*) and after the Dawn Prayer, so that the Opening (*Fath*) may be near to you." This Divine Name with which you abide, or intend to abide, should not restrict you from the Greatest Theophany (التجلي الأعظم), which is equivalent to the rising of the sun. Thus, in your *i'tikaf*, you combine restriction (التقييد) and absolute freedom (الإطلاق). If the one performing *i'tikaf* were to enter at the beginning of the night, the temporal distance would be far for him, and the duration long, and he might forget the state he is meant to be in, for the human being is naturally disposed to forgetfulness. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Adam forgot, so his progeny forgot. Adam denied, so his progeny denied." This *hadith* is good news from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) for all people, for Adam was shown mercy, and thus his progeny were shown mercy wherever they were. Allah the Exalted granted them a specific mercy in whatever abode He placed them, for the matter is relative (إضافي), and the origins rule over the branches.

### Human Souls are Generated from Elemental Bodies

This indicates to you that these human souls (النفوس الإنسانية) are a result of these elemental bodies (الأجسام العنصرية) and are generated from them, for they only appeared after the leveling of these bodies and the balancing of their temperaments (*akhlat*). They are to the souls breathed into them from the Spirit attributed to the Exalted (الروح المضاف إليه تعالى) like the places upon which the sun casts its rays, whose effects vary according to the differences in the receptive capacities (*qawabil*). Where is the light of the sun in dense bodies compared to its light in polished bodies? For this reason, souls differ due to the differences in temperaments (*amzija*). You see one soul quick to accept virtues and sciences, and another soul the opposite, with intermediate ones between them. This is the reality, if you understand. The Exalted said: <<فَإِذا سَوَّيْتُهُ>> (When I have proportioned him)—meaning the human body—<<وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِنْ رُوحِي>> (and breathed into him of My Spirit). For this reason, we said that forgetfulness (*nisyan*) in the human being is a natural matter necessitated by the temperament, just as remembrance (*tadhakkur*) is also a natural matter in this specific temperament. Likewise, all the faculties attributed to the human being—do you not see that the action of these faculties is diminished in some individuals and increased in others?

### The Time the One Performing I'tikaf Enters His Place of Retreat

The Lawgiver (الشارع) drew attention to this by having the one performing *i'tikaf* enter his place of retreat after the Dawn Prayer and before sunrise.

(Section on What the Abiding of the One Performing I'tikaf with Allah Is)

### One Only Abides with Allah by the Heart

Know that abiding with Allah (الإقامة مع الله) is a spiritual matter (*amr ma‘nawi*), not a sensory matter (*amr hissi*). One only abides with Allah by the heart (القلب), just as one only turns toward Allah in prayer by the heart. Just as you turn your face toward what is called the *Qibla*, which is the Ka‘ba, so too does one abide sensually with acts of piety. Among the acts of piety may be observing the soul (ملاحظة النفس) in order to render to it its prescribed right, for your soul has a right over you. One may also prefer his own soul over others by conveying goodness to it, which is what Allah has legislated for us. We have no path to Allah except that which He has legislated. For this reason, a person obligates his soul to some of its interests so that the goodness returns to it, such as the one performing *i'tikaf* leaving for human necessity, or attending to his wives and family to manage some of his affairs during his abiding and retreat.

### The Ruling is Based on the Predominant Part

Muslim reported from ‘A’isha that she said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) performed *i'tikaf*, he would bring his head near me, and I would comb his hair. He would not enter the house except for human necessity. Al-Nasa’i reported from her that she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) would come to me while he was performing *i'tikaf* in the mosque, lean on the door of my chamber, and I would wash his head while I was in my chamber and the rest of him was in the mosque. In this is proof for those who hold that the ruling is based on the predominant part (الحكم للأغلب). The fact that his head was outside the mosque did not invalidate his *i'tikaf*, because the greater part of him was in the mosque, so the ruling of the majority was observed regarding the physical body.

(Section on the State of the One Performing I'tikaf During His Day)

Abu Ahmad reported from the hadith of Abdullah ibn Budayl ibn Warqa’ al-Makki, from Amr ibn Dinar, from Ibn Umar, from Umar, that he vowed to perform *i'tikaf* in the Sacred Mosque. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to him, "Perform *i'tikaf* and fast." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded whoever desired to abide with Allah (الإقامة مع الله) to abide with Him possessing an Attribute that belongs to Allah, which is fasting (الصوم), so that he may be *with* Allah, *by* Allah, *for* Allah. Thus, nothing is seen of him except Allah. This is the state of the People of Allah (أهل الله). It was asked of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), "Who are the Friends of Allah (*Awliya’ Allah*)?" He replied, "Those who, when they are seen, Allah is remembered." That is, due to their realization of the Realization of Allah (*tahaqququhum bi-Llah*), they are veiled by Him from themselves and from the eyes of creation. When people see them, they see nothing but Allah. Their sight reminds people of Allah, like the reminding signs (*ayat*). This is the station (*maqam*) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) requested in his supplication: "And make me a light (نورا)." Allah the Exalted answered his supplication and informed us that He sent him to mankind <<بَشِيراً وَنَذِيراً وَداعِياً إِلَى اللهِ بِإِذْنِهِ وَسِراجاً مُنِيراً>> (as a bearer of good tidings, a warner, an inviter to Allah by His permission, and an illuminating lamp). Thus, He made him a light (نورا) as he requested, for his saying to his Lord, "And make me a light," means: "So that I may be, by my Essence (بذاتي), the very Entity (*‘ayn*) of the Divine Name, The Light (النور)." And whoever has the Real (الحق) as his hearing, sight, tongue, hand, and foot, and does not speak out of caprice, then he is not himself. Nothing remains for the one who sees him to see but Allah, whether that observer knows it or not. This is how the People of Gnosis of Allah (أهل العلم بالله) witness them.

### The Caliphs Appear in the World in the Form of the One Who Appointed Them

Among the believers, the Caliphs (*Khulafa’*) appear in the world and among the common people with the attributes of the One who appointed them. Bilqis said concerning her throne, <<كَأَنَّهُ هُوَ>> (It seems like it). It was none other than it, but the distance, the rule of custom, and her ignorance of the measure (*qadr*) of Solomon (peace be upon him) with his Lord veiled her. This veiled her from saying, "It is it," so she said, "It seems like it." And what distance is further than <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing whatever like unto Him) from one who is like other things? The Perfect Human (الكامل) (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "I am only a human being like you," by the command of Allah. He was told, "Say," so he said: <<قُلْ إِنَّما أَنَا بَشَرٌ مِثْلُكُمْ>> (Say: I am only a human being like you). By this, we know that it was by the command of Allah, because he conveyed the command to us just as he conveyed the commanded thing. This statement was a cure for the sickness that afflicted those among his community who worshipped Jesus (peace be upon him) and said: <<إِنَّ اللهَ هُوَ الْمَسِيحُ ابْنُ مَرْيَمَ>> (Indeed, Allah is the Messiah, son of Mary). They missed much knowledge when they said "son of Mary" without realizing it. For this reason, Allah the Exalted said, establishing the proof against those whose attribute is this: "Say: Name them." They only name them with the names by which they know them, so that what they intend may be understood from them. When they name them, it becomes clear in the name itself that it is not the one the Messenger sent to them asked them to worship.

### Who is the Entity of the Universes and the Entities

We only said "It is it" because of what sound Unveiling (الكشف الصحيح) grants in particular, and clear faith (الايمان الصريح) grants in general, as reported in the Divine Prophetic tradition (الخبر النبوي الإلهي): that when Allah loves His servant, He becomes his hearing and his sight. And [the tradition] mentioned his faculties and limbs. The human being is nothing other than these mentioned matters, whose very identity (هويته) the Real (الحق) made to be their Entity (*‘ayn*). If you are a believer, you will know by whom you exist. If you possess sound Witnessing (شهود صحيح), you will know whom you witness. More than this prophetic clarification concerning Allah is not within human capacity, until the believer attains the state of direct vision (*hal ‘iyan*). He will then know who is the very Entity (*‘ayn*) of these Universes (الأكوان) and Entities (الأعيان).

(Section on the Visit of the One Performing I'tikaf in His Retreat, Who Abides with Allah by Virtue of a Specific Name, Which Other Divine Names Seek in the Entities of the Universes to Manifest Their Authority Therein, Contending with the Name with Which He Abides)

Al-Bukhari reported from Safiyya, the wife of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), that she came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to visit him in his *i'tikaf* in the mosque during the last ten days of Ramadan. She spoke with him for an hour, then stood up to leave. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) stood up with her to accompany her until she reached the door of Umm Salama. This was a Divine Name (اسم إلهي) that moved Safiyya to visit him, so that through her mediation, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) might receive from the abiding with the Divine Name that brought her. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) then abided with this Name during the time of his conversation with her. Then, when he accompanied her, it removed him from his place of sitting. This is a type of journey—indeed, it is a journey of honoring the woman by command, in veneration of her sanctity and intention. For travel is movement, and he only moved from his place by the ruling (حكم) of that Name upon him. When the one performing *i'tikaf* moves for human necessity, such as ablution or what is indispensable, all of that is by the ruling of the Name with which he abides during his retreat. There is no movement a human makes, whether in *i'tikaf* or otherwise, except that it results from the descent of a Divine Name (اسم إلهي) upon him. This is an established principle with us concerning the Divine Realities (الحقائق الإلهية), and the Names of Allah are countless in their multiplicity. Accompanying a visitor is not the usual concern of the one performing *i'tikaf*. He only moved for that purpose due to the ruling of the Divine Name that moved the visitor toward him. The physical eye (*al-‘ayn*) only knows that she is a visitor fulfilling her purpose of looking or speaking. But the Gnostic (*al-‘Arif*) witnesses the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية): "I have not seen a thing except that I saw Allah before it." The Divine Name that moved Safiyya was from behind the veil of Safiyya, and it was with this Name that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) observed proper conduct (*adab*). For it, he stood and accompanied her. The demand of that Name was to manifest its authority in him, and it was manifested. We have explained this in the discussion of the interplay of the Divine Names (مجاراة الأسماء الإلهية) at the beginning of this book and in *‘Anqa’ Mughrib* (The Fabulous Gryphon).

(Section on the I'tikaf of a Woman with Non-Menstrual Bleeding in the Mosque)

### Wisdom Grants Placing a Thing in Its Proper Place

The soul is denied due to a legally prescribed ailment that is not menstruation (*hayd*). For this reason, the woman with non-menstrual bleeding (*mustahada*) prays, while the menstruating woman does not. It is reported from ‘A’isha, as mentioned by Al-Bukhari, that a woman among the Prophet’s wives who had non-menstrual bleeding performed *i'tikaf* with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). [The rest of] the *hadith*. Whoever places things in their proper places has given them what they deserve from him, and he is the wise one of his time. For Wisdom (الحكمة) grants the placing of every thing in its proper place. And Allah is <<عَلِيمٌ حَكِيمٌ>> (All-Knowing, All-Wise).

### There is Nothing Absolute in the World of Contingency

There is absolutely nothing absolute (مطلق) because contingency (*al-imkan*) does not necessitate it, nor do the Realities (الحقائق) grant it, for absolute freedom (الإطلاق) is itself a restriction (تقييد). There is no matter except that it has a place that accepts it and a place that rejects it and does not accept it; this is necessary. Consider natural foods for the natural body: there is nothing consumed as food that does not contain both harm and benefit. The scholar of nature, insofar as it governs the body—who is called a physician (*tabib*)—knows this. The natural philosopher (*tabi‘i*) knows it generally, but the physician knows the details. Thus, there is no language of absolute praise (حمد مطلق) in the world, nor a language of absolute blame (ذم مطلق). The origin of this is the contrasting Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية المتقابلة), for Allah named Himself to us through them, by virtue of His being the Speaker. Just as He declared incomparability (*tanzih*) and similitude (*tashbih*), and declared Unity (*tawhid*) and association (*shirk*), His servants spoke with both attributes. Then He said: <<سُبْحانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصْفُونَ * وَسَلامٌ عَلَى الْمُرْسَلِينَ * وَالْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ رَبِّ الْعالَمِينَ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe. And peace be upon the Messengers. And praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds). This is the end of the sixty-first section.

جو توحید (توحید) کو شرک کے ساتھ ثابت کرتا ہے۔

ہدایت کا ستارہ اس میں تیرتا رہا
افلاک میں فرشتوں کے درمیان۔

کون (Creation) سے صوم (صوم) رکھ اور افطار نہ کر،

اور اس صوم کی نیت کر جہاں سے وہ ہے،

صوم میں ایک ایسا معنی ہے اگر تو اس پر غور کرے،
تو کوئی مخلوق تیرے ٹھکانے پر نہ ٹھہرے۔
صوم کی کوئی مثال نہیں، اس کے شارع نے مجھ سے یہی کہا،
پس اس پر غور کر۔
کیونکہ یہ ترک ہے، تو وہ کہاں ہے جو
تو نے عمل کیا یا تیرا دعویٰ کہاں ہے؟
امر اپنی اصل کی طرف لوٹ گیا ہے،
اسی کے ذریعے میرے رب نے تیری سرپرستی کی۔
اور صوم، اگر تو اس کے حکم میں غور کرے،
اور اس کا اصل معنی تیرے معنی میں ہے۔
پھر اس کی طرف سے ایک خبر دینے والا آیا
جس نے تیرے مشروع صوم کی خبر دی۔
پس صوم الحق (ذات حق) کے لیے ہے، پس تو جاہل نہ بن،
اور تو ہی اس کا مجلیٰ (مظہر) ہے، پس خبردار!
صوم الحق (ذات حق) کے لیے ہے اور تو ہی وہ ہے
جو بھوک سے مرتا ہے، یہ جان لے۔
رحمن نے تجھے اس کے لیے مونث بنایا

پاک ہے وہ جس نے تجھے اپنے لیے اہل بنا کر سنوارا،

پس تو زمین کی مانند ہے، اس کے لیے بستر،
اور اس کی آنکھ جو رونے والی سے موصوف ہے۔
اور اللہ کی صنعت اپنی عین کو دیکھتی ہے
تم دونوں کے درمیان، تو تیرا مقامِ ظہور کہاں ہے؟

اور قلمِ ارفع نے اپنی لوح پر

خبردار! تو اس پر راضی نہ ہو جس پر تو راضی ہوتا ہے،
اس کی خاطر جو تجھے راضی کرتا ہے، خبردار!
ہر اس چیز میں اپنی اصل پر قائم رہ جو
وہ چاہتا ہے، بھول نہ جانا ورنہ وہ تجھے بھول جائے گا۔
یہ وہ علم ہے جو مجھے ملا ہے
ایک ایسے کہنے والے سے جو جھوٹا نہیں۔
اسے ایک علامہ کے حکم سے نازل کیا
زاہدوں اور عابدوں کے درمیان۔

اور مجھے ایسی صورت سے خاص کیا جس کا
کمال تیرے ٹھکانے کے بغیر نہ تھا۔

### (صوم امساک اور رفعت ہے)

جان لے، اللہ تیری تائید کرے، کہ صوم (صوم) امساک (Restraint) اور رفعت (Elevation) ہے۔ کہا جاتا ہے: "صام النهار" (دن نے صوم رکھا) جب وہ بلند ہوا، امرؤ القیس نے کہا:

> إذا صام النهار وهجرا
> *جب دن بلند ہوا اور گرم ہوا۔*

یعنی بلند ہوا۔ اور جب صوم (صوم) تمام عبادات سے درجے میں بلند ہوا تو اسے صوم (صوم) کہا گیا۔ اور الحق (ذات حق) سبحانہ نے اس سے مماثلت (مثلية) کی نفی کر کے اسے بلند کیا جیسا کہ ہم ذکر کریں گے، اور اسے اپنے بندوں سے سلب کر لیا باوجود اس کے کہ وہ اس کی عبادت کرتے ہیں، اور اسے اپنی ذات سبحانہ کی طرف منسوب کیا، اور اس شخص کا بدلہ جو اس صفت سے متصف ہو، اپنی عنایت سے اپنے ہاتھ میں رکھا، اور مماثلت (مثلية) کی نفی میں اسے اپنی ذات کے ساتھ ملحق کر دیا۔

### (صوم حقیقت میں ترک ہے نہ کہ عمل)

اور یہ حقیقت میں ترک ہے نہ کہ عمل، اور مماثلت (مثلية) کی نفی ایک سلبی صفت ہے، پس اس کے اور اللہ کے درمیان مناسبت قوی ہو گئی۔ الحق (ذات حق) تعالیٰ نے اپنی ذات کے حق میں فرمایا: لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ (اس کی مانند کوئی چیز نہیں ہے)۔ پس اس نے اس بات کی نفی کی کہ اس کی کوئی مثال ہو۔ پس وہ سبحانہ عقلی اور شرعی دلیل سے بے مثال ہے۔ نسائی نے ابو امامہ سے روایت کی، انہوں نے کہا: میں رسول اللہ صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم کی خدمت میں حاضر ہوا اور عرض کیا: مجھے کسی ایسے عمل کا حکم دیجیے جسے میں آپ سے لے لوں۔ آپ نے فرمایا:

> عَلَيْكَ بِالصَّوْمِ فَإِنَّهُ لَا مِثْلَ لَهُ
> *تم صوم کو لازم کر لو، کیونکہ اس کی کوئی مثال نہیں ہے۔*

پس آپ نے اس بات کی نفی کی کہ وہ ان عبادات میں سے کسی کے مماثل ہو جو اس نے اپنے بندوں کے لیے مشروع کیں۔

### (صوم حقیقت میں نہ عبادت ہے نہ عمل)

اور جس نے یہ جان لیا کہ یہ ایک سلبی وصف ہے، کیونکہ یہ مفطرات (روزہ توڑنے والی چیزوں) کا ترک ہے، تو اسے یقیناً معلوم ہو گیا کہ اس کی کوئی مثال نہیں، کیونکہ اس کی کوئی ایسی عین (Reality) نہیں ہے جو اس وجود سے متصف ہو جو معقول ہے۔ اور اسی لیے اللہ تعالیٰ نے فرمایا: "الصوم لي" (صوم میرے لیے ہے)۔

پس یہ حقیقت میں نہ عبادت ہے اور نہ عمل، اور جب اس پر عمل کا نام مطلقاً بولا جاتا ہے تو یہ مجازاً ہوتا ہے، جیسے ہمارے نزدیک الحق (ذات حق) پر لفظ "الموجود" (موجود) کا اطلاق مجازاً ہوتا ہے، کیونکہ جس کا وجود عین ذات ہو، اس کی طرف وجود کی نسبت ہماری طرف وجود کی نسبت سے مشابہ نہیں ہو سکتی، کیونکہ لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ (اس کی مانند کوئی چیز نہیں ہے)۔

(ایک نبوی الٰہی حدیث کا بیان)

مسلم نے صحیح میں ابو ہریرہ رضی اللہ عنہ سے روایت کی، انہوں نے کہا کہ رسول اللہ صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم نے فرمایا کہ اللہ عزوجل نے فرمایا:

> كُلُّ عَمَلِ ابْنِ آدَمَ لَهُ إِلَّا الصِّيَامَ فَإِنَّهُ لِي وَأَنَا أَجْزِي بِهِ وَالصِّيَامُ جُنَّةٌ فَإِذَا كَانَ يَوْمُ صَوْمِ أَحَدِكُمْ فَلَا يَرْفُثْ يَوْمَئِذٍ وَلَا يَسْخَبْ فَإِنْ سَابَّهُ أَحَدٌ أَوْ قَاتَلَهُ فَلْيَقُلْ إِنِّي امْرُؤٌ صَائِمٌ إِنِّي صَائِمٌ وَالَّذِي نَفْسُ مُحَمَّدٍ بِيَدِهِ لَخُلُوفُ فَمِ الصَّائِمِ أَطْيَبُ عِنْدَ اللَّهِ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ مِنْ رِيحِ الْمِسْكِ وَلِلصَّائِمِ فَرْحَتَانِ يَفْرَحُهُمَا إِذَا أَفْطَرَ فَرِحَ بِفِطْرِهِ وَإِذَا لَقِيَ رَبَّهُ عَزَّ وَجَلَّ فَرِحَ بِصَوْمِهِ
> *ابن آدم کا ہر عمل اس کے لیے ہے سوائے صیام (صوم) کے، کیونکہ وہ میرے لیے ہے اور میں ہی اس کا بدلہ دوں گا۔ اور صیام ڈھال ہے۔ پس جب تم میں سے کسی کے صوم کا دن ہو تو وہ نہ فحش بات کرے اور نہ شور مچائے۔ اور اگر کوئی اسے گالی دے یا اس سے لڑے تو اسے چاہیے کہ کہے: میں روزہ دار ہوں، میں روزہ دار ہوں۔ اور اس ذات کی قسم جس کے ہاتھ میں محمد کی جان ہے، روزہ دار کے منہ کی بو قیامت کے دن اللہ کے نزدیک مشک کی خوشبو سے زیادہ پاکیزہ ہو گی۔ اور روزہ دار کے لیے دو خوشیاں ہیں جن سے وہ خوش ہوتا ہے: جب وہ افطار کرتا ہے تو اپنے افطار سے خوش ہوتا ہے، اور جب وہ اپنے رب عزوجل سے ملاقات کرتا ہے تو اپنے صوم سے خوش ہوتا ہے۔*

### (روزہ دار کی خوشی مماثلت کی نفی کے درجے سے ملحق ہونا ہے)

اور جان لے کہ جب صوم (صوم) سے مماثلت (مثلية) کی نفی کی گئی، جیسا کہ نسائی کی سابقہ حدیث میں ثابت ہوا، اور الحق (ذات حق) لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ (اس کی مانند کوئی چیز نہیں ہے)، تو روزہ دار اپنے رب عزوجل سے اس وصف کے ساتھ ملاقات کرتا ہے جو لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ ہے، پس وہ اسے اس کے ذریعے دیکھتا ہے، تو وہ دیکھنے والا اور دیکھا جانے والا بن جاتا ہے۔ اسی لیے آپ صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم نے فرمایا: "فرح بصومه" (اپنے صوم سے خوش ہوا) اور یہ نہیں فرمایا کہ "فرح بلقاء ربه" (اپنے رب کی ملاقات سے خوش ہوا)، کیونکہ خوشی خود سے خوش نہیں ہوتی بلکہ اس کے ذریعے خوش ہوتی ہے۔ اور جس کی بصارت الحق (ذات حق) ہو اس کے دیکھنے اور مشاہدہ (الشہود) کے وقت، تو اس نے اپنے آپ کو اس کے دیکھنے کے ذریعے ہی دیکھا، پس روزہ دار کی خوشی مماثلت (مماثلت) کی نفی کے درجے سے ملحق ہونا ہے۔ اور دنیا میں اس کا افطار سے خوش ہونا اس لحاظ سے ہے کہ حیوانی نفس کا حق پہنچایا جاتا ہے جو اپنی ذات کے لیے غذا طلب کرتا ہے۔ پس جب عارف نے اپنے حیوانی نباتی نفس کی اس کی طرف محتاجی دیکھی اور اس نے اپنا جود (سخاوت) دیکھا جو اس نے اس کے حق کی ادائیگی کے لیے اسے غذا پہنچا کر کیا جسے اللہ نے اس پر واجب کیا تھا، تو وہ اس مقام پر حق کی صفت کے ساتھ کھڑا ہوا، پس اس نے اللہ کے ہاتھ سے عطا کیا، جیسا کہ وہ ملاقات کے وقت الحق (ذات حق) کو اللہ کی آنکھ سے دیکھتا ہے۔ اسی لیے وہ اپنے افطار سے خوش ہوا جیسا کہ وہ اپنے رب کی ملاقات کے وقت اپنے صوم سے خوش ہوا۔

(اس خبر میں شامل امور کا بیان)
